SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1851 words

HEADLINE: Surplus Dreams;
A Debate Over Dividing Tax Dollars Yet to Be Collected

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
The heated battle over how to use projected Federal budget surpluses has exposed deep rifts between the two parties, both in political and economic terms.
It has divided Democrats and Republicans over such basic issues as whether there really is a Federal budget surplus. It has forced the two parties to articulate their cases for and against tax cuts and Government spending as ways of improving the country's long-term prospects. It has set the stage for a potential debate over an issue of real substance in next year's election for control of the White House and Congress. Finally, it has raised the prospect of actually reducing the national debt, a problem Washington has not had the luxury of addressing for decades. 
 Round One in the battle ended last week, when Republicans pushed their $792 billion tax cut plan through Congress in the face of President Clinton's veto threat. Round Two will start after Labor Day, when official Washington returns from its summer vacation and the two parties decide whether to seek compromise or to leave the issue for the campaign trail.
The starting point for any discussion is getting a handle on how much money is available.
The Congressional Budget Office projects that the total Federal budget surplus over the next 10 years will be $2.9 trillion. Of that, $1.9 trillion is generated by payroll tax revenues that are earmarked for Social Security. The two parties have more or less agreed to take that $1.9 trillion off the table, allowing it to be used only to reduce the national debt or to help finance an overhaul of the retirement system.
Most of the fight is over the remaining portion of nearly $1 trillion, which represents the surplus generated by general tax revenues.
Republicans say the figure is so big that the country can afford a $792 billion tax cut and still find plenty of money for needs like adding a prescription drug benefit to Medicare and increasing spending on the military.
Democrats point out that the surplus projections are based on a series of questionable premises: that the economy will avoid a protracted downturn; that unexplained surges in revenue will continue and that the forecasting ability of budget analysts will prove far more accurate than it has in the past.
Further, the projections assume what many say is an unrealistically low level of Government spending. The Congressional Budget Office surplus estimate is based on Congress's remaining within strict spending limits requiring cuts through 2002, and then increasing spending at no more than the rate of inflation.
Yet based on the appropriations bills moving through the House and Senate under the control of the Republican majority, Congress is on a path to shatter the spending caps next year, and indeed to use up all of next year's projected non-Social Security surplus of $14 billion.
If that pattern of rising spending were to continue, the non-Social Security portion of the surplus would all but disappear before it became available for tax cuts. "These surplus numbers give pie in the sky a good name," said Thomas S. Kahn, the Democratic staff director of the House Budget Committee.
Mr. Kahn helped produce a recent report for House Democrats that looked at what would happen if spending were to increase in line with historical trends and political realities. If spending were to increase just enough to keep up with inflation from now through 2009, the report concluded, it would use $595 billion of the $996 billion surplus.
The Democrats then looked at emergency spending, money that Congress appropriates each year to deal with unanticipated needs ranging from hurricanes to aid for farmers. From 1991 through 1998, emergency spending averaged $9 billion a year, not including the costs of the Persian Gulf war. The committee then assumed that emergency spending would remain at that average level, and subtracted an additional $90 billion from the surplus, leaving just $311 billion.
But there's more. The surplus estimate also assumed that all of the excess revenue would go to reducing the national debt, bringing down the Government's interest costs. To the degree that the surplus goes to spending -- or tax cuts -- those interest savings would not be realized. The committee calculated that the increased interest costs from maintaining inflation-adjusted levels of spending and accounting for emergency spending would be $179 billion.
After accounting for an additional $30 billion needed to pay for Social Security's operations over the next decade, the Democratic analysis concluded that the surplus over the next 10 years under its assumptions would be only $100 billion.
So far, however, that Democratic argument has not swayed Republicans. And even the White House is still assuming that it has nearly $1 trillion to divide up, allocating a third of the non-Social Security surplus to additional spending.
So for the most part the debate has not been over the availability of the surplus but over the relative merits of cutting taxes, increasing spending and reducing the national debt.
The Republican position is that tax cuts are the best way to insure continued prosperity -- and that they have the added benefit of blocking Democrats from spending the money, a course that Republicans said would be wasteful and economically inefficient. Reducing income tax rates, Republicans say, would motivate taxpayers to work harder, since they would keep more of their pay. Reducing capital gains taxes and expanding the individual retirement account program would encourage more savings and investment, helping the economy to retain its technological edge and become more productive. Scaling back taxes on business would encourage the creation of new jobs.
"My preference is that the surpluses be returned as tax cuts so the Government share of the economy will shrink and the private share of the economy will expand," said Lawrence Kudlow, a former Reagan Administration economist who is now with American Skandia, an investment firm. "The private sector is governed by market discipline and the profit motive. Those two factors will generate more efficiency and more productivity, and hence more economic growth."
Democrats say they are not against tax cuts, and have offered to go as high as $300 billion over 10 years. That suggests that they are not overly worried about their worst-case outlook of a mere $100 billion surplus. But they say any tax reductions should go to people who need them most, lower- and middle-income families, and that they should be used for specific purposes like making college more affordable or encouraging retirement savings.
The economy is doing just fine already, Democrats say. They warn that the additional stimulus of a tax cut could even lead the economy to overheat, forcing the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
The main Democratic argument against tax cuts, though, is that there are better things to do with whatever surpluses do materialize.
One is reducing the national debt. The two parties are not far apart on the benefits of paying down the debt incurred in the decades in which the Federal Government was running huge annual deficits. Democrats, Republicans and most economists agree that reducing the debt would leave interest rates lower, stimulating more economic growth, and would make it easier to address long-term problems like the solvency of Social Security by easing the financial burden on future generations.
"The best thing we can do for the economy is to increase savings, and the best way the Government has of increasing savings is paying down the debt," said Robert Bixby, the policy director of the Concord Coalition, a fiscal monitoring group. "Reducing the debt will increase capital investment and productivity, which helps keep economic growth going."
The main source of debt reduction is the anticipated $1.9 trillion surplus over the next decade from excess Social Security payroll taxes. That money is ultimately intended to help pay retirement benefits for today's workers, but the only way the Government can "save" it is to reduce the amount of Federal debt held by the public, now about $3.6 trillion.
Republicans are generally committed to using the $1.9 trillion for debt reduction, although they have left open the option of using some of it to help transform Social Security into a system of private investment accounts. Although he initially proposed spending some of the Social Security surplus over the next decade, Mr. Clinton is now more firmly committed to using the entire amount for debt reduction.
Republicans are talking about finding additional money for debt reduction by holding down spending increases after 2002. Mr. Clinton wants to take $374 billion over 10 years from the non-Social Security surplus for additional debt reduction, although his plan would in essence just leave the Government owing the money to the Medicare system rather than to the public.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, is one of the most influential advocates of debt reduction as the best use of the surplus. Despite his long record of advocating lower taxes -- he continues to press his case for elimination of the capital gains tax -- he bluntly warned Republicans last month that the time is not right for a tax cut.
Mr. Greenspan said a tax cut would be better suited for a time when the economy was in a downturn. And he asserted that the benefits of consistent debt reduction, in the form of lower-cost capital and greater investment in productivity-enhancing technology and machinery, would be the best way of keeping the long economic expansion going.
Mr. Greenspan offered one caveat that Republicans seized on -- that if the only choice was between tax cuts and additional spending, then his clear preference would be tax cuts.
Indeed, despite the bipartisan commitments to improving the Government's financial condition, some conservatives are uncomfortable with too much emphasis on debt reduction, saying it should not become a fixation that outweighs tax cuts as a priority for Republicans.
Many liberals also bemoan the emphasis on the debt and what they see as a lack of focus on spending for critical areas like education, basic technology, medical research and transportation. They say that the continual assault on Government spending by Republicans has led voters to believe that all Federal expenditures are wasteful and to lose sight of the fact that there is a substantial return on many types of public investment, from the development of the Internet to new drugs and better-trained workers.
"In 1992, Bill Clinton ran on the notion of public investment, the idea that there were the twin deficits -- the budget deficit and a deficit in investment in education, health care and research," said Robert B. Reich, who was Labor Secretary in Mr. Clinton's first term.
"That language seems to have vanished from American politics," Mr. Reich said. "It's ironic because the nation is in a far better position to afford those kinds of investments today than in 1992."

HEADLINE: U.S. Drops Charges of Crude Oil Dumping

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 9

 BODY:
The Department of Commerce in Washington dismissed accusations of unfair trade practices against Mexico and three other oil-exporting countries today, heading off a potential economic and political crisis for Mexico and the United States, its biggest trading partner.
The charges had come from 12 independent oil producers in Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas, asserting that Mexico, Venezuela and Saudi Arabia, as well as Iraq -- which the United Nations has recently permitted to increase oil exports -- had been selling crude oil in the United States at prices below production costs, a violation of anti-dumping laws. 
 All four countries denied the dumping charge, but Mexico, which ships 75 percent of its oil exports to the United States, was the most outspoken. Shortly after the complaint was filed in late June, Mexico retaliated by suspending plans to eliminate a tariff on natural gas imported from the United States.
The independent oil companies, which had banded together as a group calling themselves Save Domestic Oil, had asked the Clinton Administration to impose duties on Mexico and the other countries that would have forced them out of the United States market. Save Domestic Oil said it planned an appeal.
Luis Tellez, Mexico's Secretary of Energy, said in an interview that he was "very happy" with the Commerce Department's decision. "It was a very wise and just decision," he said. "We are not dumping oil on any international market."
Mr. Tellez said he expected that Mexico would put an end to its tariff on imports of natural gas from the United States in "a matter of days."
George Baker, an energy consultant in Houston, said the Commerce decision averted "a deterioration in U.S.-Mexico relations and some major economic shocks in both countries."
"Gasoline prices would have probably gone up in the U.S.," he said. "A big chunk of Mexican Government revenue comes from petroleum sales to the U.S. They would have had to scramble to find other customers and would have had to cut back production as well."
In Washington, Commerce Department officials said they had decided not to pursue the dumping charges after surveying more than 800 American oil producers, large and small, and finding that more than half the companies felt that no dumping was taking place. By law, at least half the industry must support a claim of dumping before the Commerce Department can start a formal investigation.
The independent producers had told officials that small oil companies in the United States had lost $15 billion in expected revenues between late 1997 and June, when the complaint was filed. Oil prices dropped to as low as $10 a barrel in late 1998, but a barrel has gone back up to $15, the low end of the range where it mostly traded since 1986.
The independent producers attribute the slump to pricing by Mexico and the other three countries. The countries provided about half of the eight million barrels of oil that were imported in 1998 into the states other than Alaska, Hawaii, California and four other Western states. Those seven use little oil from abroad.
Opponents of the dumping charges, including the American Petroleum Institute, a Washington trade group that represents most major American oil companies as well as some independents, said the drop in oil prices had come not from dumping but from market pressures.
"It was a worldwide phenomenon brought about by some fairly significant surprises," said Edward Porter, a senior economist at the American Petroleum Institute, citing the economic turmoil in Asia and Russia as well as unusually warm weather in the United States, as well as the United Nations decision permitting increased exports by Iraq.
Charles O. Verrill, Jr., the lead lawyer for Save Domestic Oil, said the major American oil companies opposed the complaint because they are the main customers of Mexico and the other countries and want the lowest possible prices.
"They have steadily reduced their exploration and production in the United States," Mr. Verrill said. "They have sold much of that production to the independents and increased their refining capacity, making them dependent on imported oil."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

State Securities Regulators Urge Day-Trading Changes
Many day-trading firms use deceptive marketing practices to lure customers into a stock trading strategy that will probably cause them to lose money, and then they help to keep them trading by arranging what could be illegal loans, according to the North American Securities Administrators Association, a group of state regulators.
In a report, the regulators urged the firms to do a better job of screening potential customers and to disclose more fully the risks. The group also asked national regulators to step up their enforcement of trading rules and to ban some of the day-trading industry's most common lending practices. Page A1. 

Advanced Micro Introduces Chip
Advanced Micro Devices introduced the Athlon microprocessor, which has higher performance than the fastest chips made by Intel, and said that I.B.M. and Compaq had already committed to using the chip in some computers. Shipments of the Athlon to computer makers began last month, the company said, adding that it expected PC's that use the chip to be available later this month. Advanced Micro shares closed at $19.25, up $1.875. C3.
 
Trustee for A. R. Baron in Talks
The trustee for the liquidation of A. R. Baron, a brokerage firm that defrauded investors of $75 million before it failed in 1996, is in negotiations with Bear Stearns Securities to resolve claims relating to the smaller firm's failure. A resolution may require Bear Stearns to pay more than the $38.5 million it agreed to in a settlement with the S.E.C. last week. C6.
 
U.S. Dismisses Oil Trade Allegations
The Commerce Department dismissed accusations of unfair trade practices against Mexico and three other oil-exporting countries, heading off a potential economic and political crisis for Mexico and the United States. C2.
 
Retailers Settle Sweatshop Suit
Nordstrom, J. Crew and other retailers settled accusations against them in a Federal suit that poses one of the biggest challenges ever against American sweatshops. A10.
 
China Bans Import of French Wine
In a move that baffles French officials and businessmen, Chinese customs authorities have suspended the import of all wine from France. The authorities have also ordered retailers in many cities to take French wine off the shelves, citing reports that vineyards in a few provinces of southern France were ignoring a ban on a byproduct of bovine blood because of concern over the possibility of a connection with "mad cow" disease. French officials say none of the vineyards have ever exported wine anywhere, much less to China. C4.
 
Financial Scandal in Indonesia
The head of the agency entrusted with bailing out Indonesia's financial system offered to step down as accusations of corruption threatened to discredit his organization. C4.
 
MCI Worldcom Cuts Some Rates
MCI Worldcom said that it had cut its evening, overnight and weekend calling rates to as little as 5 cents a minute, a move that is likely to add to price pressure in the industry. C3.
 
Death of Labor Leader Alters Talks
The unexpected death of a labor leader over the weekend makes it likely that Ford will be the lead company in negotiations for an industrywide labor contract. C2.
 
Postage to Be Sold on Internet
The United States Postal Service announced the availability of postage, called PC Postage, over the Internet. A15.
 
Wiatt Joins William Morris Agency
Three days after resigning as co-chairman of International Creative Management, a top talent agency, James A. Wiatt was named president of the rival William Morris agency. C2.

HEADLINE: Gore Pursues Black Voters in a Texas Foray

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore continued his efforts to woo black voters today as he again ventured into Texas, seeking to position himself for what he hopes will be an eventual Presidential race against the Republican front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush.
Though he never mentioned the Texas Governor by name, Mr. Gore repeatedly contrasted himself with Mr. Bush by raising issues like gun control, hate-crimes legislation, school vouchers and affirmative action. Mr. Gore also criticized the $792 billion tax-cut legislation recently passed by the Republican-controlled Congress, and endorsed by Mr. Bush, as "some of the worst handiwork of the Republican right." 
 He said the legislation would undermine Social Security and Medicare. "It takes courage and conscience to cross those conservatives who have no compassion," Mr. Gore told members of the National Urban League, who are holding their annual convention in Houston this week.
The scripted line, which Mr. Gore repeated several times in his speech, was a deliberate rebuke to the "compassionate conservatism" line that has become the early slogan of Mr. Bush's campaign. On Sunday night, when he addressed the group in a short welcoming speech, Mr. Bush promoted educational reforms in Texas and talked about the need to help people who have not benefited from the recent era of prosperity. In front of a group traditionally sympathetic to Democrats, Mr. Bush mentioned "compassionate" far more often than he did "conservatism."
But Mr. Gore, who is seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination, made certain to raise issues of particular concern to his predominantly African-American audience. He called on the House to pass a pending Federal hate-crimes bill and criticized the Texas Legislature for failing to pass a similar bill named after a black man who was tied to a truck and dragged to his death. Mr. Gore said he met with the family of the man, James Byrd Jr., earlier in the day. Though Mr. Bush never took a position on the politically sensitive bill, Democrats blamed his legislative allies for killing it.
With the process for conducting the 2000 census about to begin, Mr. Gore criticized elected officials in both parties who opposed changing the counting method. Minorities, in particular, have said that the census vastly underestimates the numbers of black and Hispanic Americans, and Mr. Gore agreed, saying that Texas had missed out on $1 billion in Federal benefits because of an undercount of its minority population.
Mr. Gore also called for background checks of people who buy weapons at gun shows. Mr. Bush has also publicly supported such checks, but gun-control advocates in Texas blamed his allies in the State Legislature for killing a bill this year that would have required them. Mr. Bush did sign into law a measure that prohibits Texas cities from filing liability lawsuits against gun makers. Several cities in other states are suing gun makers, seeking reimbursement for health care and public safety costs for gun violence.
 Mr. Gore, who recently spoke in Houston at the convention of the Hispanic advocacy organization the National Council of La Raza, also ticked off a laundry list of unfavorable statistics about Texas to an audience of people mostly from other states.
"For example, here in Texas, can we be satisfied when African-Americans are twice as likely to drop out of school, when on a national basis the black and white high school graduation rates are just about equal?" he asked. "Here in Texas, can we be satisfied when this state has one of the most regressive tax systems in the nation? Can we possibly be satisfied when Texas has the second-highest percentage of uninsured children in America?"
The criticism is in direct contrast to Mr. Bush's standard stump speech in which he paints Texas not only as an economic dynamo but also as a state where conservative policies have improved reading scores, particularly for minority children, and where diversity is embraced.

Teachers' Union Lobbies for Gore
ALBANY, Aug. 9 (AP) -- New York's largest teachers' union called today for its parent union, the American Federation of Teachers, to endorse Vice President Gore's bid for the White House.
Alan Lubin, executive vice president of the 420,000-member New York State United Teachers union, said such backing would allow the New York affiliate to throw its considerable muscle behind Mr. Gore's campaign and to help union members compete for delegate slots at the Democratic National Convention.

HEADLINE: Culture Resists Top-Down Policy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re Alice Goldfarb Marquis's criticisms of the new effort by the Pew Charitable Trusts to create an "infrastructure" for American culture (Op-Ed, Aug. 9): Increasingly, rather than support what is already going on, the big foundations make high-handed internal decisions about what is important and then select or create nonprofit institutions to carry out their wishes. 
 Even in these flush times, life remains tough for many nonprofit groups whose activities respond to the needs of citizens at large, not those of foundation staff and board members. Our country's myriad community-based arts organizations, many operating on shoestrings, contribute far more to American culture than the Pew-financed Rand Corporation ever will.
 
ROGER D. STONE
Washington, Aug. 9, 1999
 
The writer is president of the Sustainable Development Institute.

HEADLINE: Trenton Will Offer 2 Free Meals a Day to All Children in Elementary Schools

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
The Trenton School District will offer free lunch and breakfast to all children -- regardless of their family's income -- in its elementary schools this fall, under a Federal program meant for districts with a large number of needy students.
"It will help us give children at least two nutritious meals a day," said Dedra Wood, the director of food services for the Trenton district. "We know that a hungry child cannot learn." And it may not cost very much more to feed all the district's students, she said. 
 Trenton is joining a number of other districts, in New Jersey and elsewhere in the country, that are taking advantage of the program, which cuts the paperwork involved in getting families to sign up for free and reduced meals. The plan was first reported yesterday in The Times of Trenton.
Last year, about 85 percent of Trenton's 8,000 elementary school children got meals free or at a reduced cost, Mrs. Wood said.
But, she said that more children are eligible for the meals, and that including all the children would remove a stigma that some parents fear marks their children as needy. It will also make it easier for the parents whose children participated in the program because they will no longer have to fill out annual questionnaires determining their eligibility.
While feeding more children is the primary goal of the program, Mrs. Wood said the district will also economize, a primary concern when food costs are rising for hard-pressed districts.
Mrs. Wood said the district collected $70,000 in meal payments from the paying students last year, but officials believe they can make up most of that lost revenue through savings even when they offer free meals for all elementary students.
For example, she said, the district will save $42,000 that it pays to an armored car service to go to each of the 18 elementary schools to pick up lunch proceeds. It will also save $15,000 in the cost of printing meal tickets for all students.
She said the district was working to make its food services more cost efficient in other ways. Four years ago, she said, the district laid off 40 food service workers, and now instead of making its own food for elementary students, it buys prepackaged meals from an Illinois company that produces them in New York City.
The district is also trying to earn revenue by providing meals to outside agencies like the city's six charter schools and to smaller suburban districts.
"Most school districts now are trying to run their food services as a business," Mrs. Wood said. "It's very important for a district, especially the large urban ones, be as innovative as possible."
Kathy F. Kuser, the director for the Bureau of Child Nutrition Programs for the State Department of Agriculture, which administers the free meal program for the Government, said that the program to help districts with large numbers of poor children has been around for 15 years.
Other New Jersey cities whose school systems already take part in the program, or have applied for it, include Jersey City, Newark, Elizabeth, Camden, Atlantic City and Hoboken. Ms. Kuser said that 364,279 of New Jersey's 1.2 million schoolchildren qualified for free meals or meals at reduced costs.

HEADLINE: 22 Are Charged With Insurance Fraud in Stolen-Car Sting

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
After a 17-month undercover investigation into insurance fraud that included setting up a fake automobile resale shop, the New York City police arrested 22 people yesterday, including two government employees, on charges of selling their cars and then falsely reporting them stolen, officials said.
The Bronx District Attorney's office set up the shop in the Soundview section in March 1998. 
 The 22 were charged with grand larceny, attempted grand larceny and insurance fraud, and the police had the names of 22 more suspects. In addition, police officials said, four men accused of being middlemen in the transactions were arrested last week.
Insurers paid more than $750,000 in false claims, said Robert T. Johnson, the Bronx District Attorney. Officials expect the investigation to lead to even more suspects.
"This action should put all citizens on notice that fraud will not be condoned as a solution to their financial difficulties," Mr. Johnson said during a news conference at a Yankee Stadium parking lot, where the police displayed dozens of vehicles seized in the sting, including two cabs for tractor-trailer rigs, trucks, sports cars and four-door sedans.
Altogether, the authorities were able to recover 47 automobiles -- 40 that had been turned in to the fake company through middlemen and then reported stolen and 7 that had actually been stolen. The District Attorney's office paid no more than $2,500 for any of the vehicles, including the two tractor-trailer cabs, from Connecticut and Vermont.
Law enforcement officials said the vast majority of the suspects had no prior criminal records, and Mr. Johnson said most of them were "otherwise honest people."
William F. Zelenka, an assistant district attorney and deputy chief of the Arson, Auto and Economic Fraud Bureau, said the two government employees who were arrested were a court officer in State Supreme Court in the Bronx, Cheryl Pendola, and an engineer in the State Department of Transportation, Rasheed Balogun.
The defendants now face a maximum sentence of seven years in prison if they are convicted on the most serious charges.
Typically in such cases, the people trying to unload their cars contact middlemen, who the police say are often tied to organized crime. Those middlemen then sell the cars -- knowing they will be reported stolen -- to a shop that cuts them up for parts, or to a dealer who ships them overseas, said Howard Safir, the Police Commissioner.
Officials said they began the investigation because of the high rate of auto insurance fraud based on false theft reports in the New York metropolitan area, especially in the Bronx.
"We obtained vehicles from Connecticut, Massachusetts and Florida, and they all come down here to Bronx County," Mr. Zelenka said.
Ten percent of auto thefts reported in the country are false, but in the metropolitan area the rate is 20 percent, Mr. Zelenka said.
Thomas J. Sullivan, the regional security manager in the Woodbury, N.Y., field office of GEICO, the insurance company, said such fraud forced companies to increase premiums for all consumers.

HEADLINE: For That Bowl of Cherries, a Hard Life

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY 

DATELINE: WENATCHEE, Wash.

 BODY:
At the height of cherry-picking season, 12 men were making a patch of woods on Stemilt Hill into a home. Plastic grocery bags hung from nails in the Ponderosa pine bark: the pantry. A shard of mirror was wedged into the trunk of another pine: the bathroom. The kitchen was a Sunbeam propane grill, the bushes served as toilets, and six cheap tents formed the bedroom.
"The meat we have to buy every day, because it spoils," said Nereo Sanchez, who like the others came from Pachuca, Mexico. 
 Last year they stayed in an orchard, but this year the owner stopped the practice. They said they had looked for campgrounds, but found no room. They stayed here on public land, until forest rangers moved them along.
"We feel bad," said another worker, Juan Sanchez. "When we go pick, we don't know if our tents will still be here" at the end of the day.
Of the state's 16,000 cherry pickers, said an adviser to Gov. Gary Locke, 10,000 have not had adequate housing in the brief but profitable couple of weeks in which the fruit ripens. And in a recent crackdown, the Federal Department of Labor displaced 2,000 more, said the adviser, Rich Nafziger, after it threatened to close camps run by fruit growers that did not meet Federal health and safety standards.
Faced with fines, many growers simply stopped letting workers camp in the orchards.
Five years ago the state health department created a temporary licensing program for camps in the orchards while the growers worked on meeting more stringent standards for them. Workers were allowed to stay in tents they bought themselves, which often leaked and did not provide protection from insects and heat. Growers had to provide water and toilets but not refrigerators. Workers used ice-filled coolers to store their food.
"In hot weather the food ends up floating in water in the ice chest," said Richard Terrill, northwest regional administrator for the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. "You have a lot of people in close quarters, with the danger of communicable diseases. Some of the camps didn't have an adequate number of toilets and showers."
The licensing provisions were intended to allow growers time to supply better, more plentiful shelter for workers, but they served only to justify the status quo instead of encouraging growers to meet Federal standards, Mr. Terrill said. Those standards include making living quarters at least seven feet high, with adequate ventilation and permanent floors to keep out vermin and moisture. The camps also have to have water and refrigeration.
With growers showing little progress in meeting the tougher Federal standards, the Government stepped in.
"This year when we made our objections known, there were probably a few farmers who decided they wouldn't even provide what they had provided before, and that probably meant -- I'll be honest with you -- that several hundred more workers didn't have a place to camp," Mr. Terrill said. "Hopefully the outcome will be good, so next year and in the years after, there will be more housing and better housing."
Growers are not legally required to provide housing, said Dan Kelly, assistant manager of the Washington Growers Clearing House Association, a group of 2,800 tree fruit growers. Most growers say they cannot afford to build permanent housing for pickers in a two-week harvest.
Nick Fox, owner of C & S Orchard in Wenatchee, had a camp three years ago, but closed it. He employs 150 to 600 workers, depending on the size of his harvest.
"If it was economically feasible, I'd love to have the camp," Mr. Fox said. But he said meeting licensing standards would cost up to $500,000.
"Talk to any banker," he said "and a banker will laugh you out of the bank." He said workers were better off in a grower's camp than on the roadside. "It's safer, better, healthier, for everyone concerned."
But Guadalupe Gamboa, the state director for the United Farm Workers of America, is optimistic that the crackdown will result in improved conditions. He said establishing state standards that were lower than Federal requirements was "a huge subsidy to the industry."
If growers want to rely on migrant workers, he said, "they've got to find a place for migrants to stay."
Advocates for farm workers point out that growers are willing to make other large investments in a quick crop, like orchard warming machines that cost $26,000 just to transport, while showers for workers are more likely to be called a luxury.
"The whole issue about short seasons kind of bothers me," Mr. Terrill said. "If you're a grower and you grow a short-season crop, you still invest in chemicals, tractors, and other equipment."
Cherry picking requires special timing and skills; the fruit must be picked just as soon as it is ripe, and workers must be careful not to separate the stems from the fruit or damage the branches where next year's buds will form.
Working from 4 A.M. until noon, when heat can damage the fruit, pickers can make $4 for filling a 40-pound box, or up to $80 a day. Many travel for weeks at a time following the ripening from California to Oregon, then from Washington to Montana. The cherry harvest runs from mid-June through July in most of Washington. It begins a month earlier in California and ends up in Montana in August. Workers say living conditions in other states are better.
A few solutions are being tried in Washington. About 300 people found shelter this season through the state's Rent-a-Tent program, which leased 26 six-person tents for $200 per tent a month to 8 growers, with the hope that if enough growers participated statewide, the tents could move with the workers along the trail of ripening cherries. And in Mattawa, a town on the Columbia River, the state has developed the Esperanza migrant center, a village of 25 temporary shelters created out of shipping containers. Each sleeps up to six and has windows, air-conditioning and a bathroom with shower.
But such accommodations reach only a few workers. Many make do in the woods outside town.
Maria Padilla, 36, of Yakima, Wash., was camping with seven other people, including three of her six children. Their dinner was frying on a propane stove. They drank untreated water from a nearby creek and had no access to indoor plumbing.
"We would like a house or a cabin so we could wash dishes and shower," she said. "It is not very good," her husband, Lupe, 39, agreed. "But what can we do?"
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jaime Padilla and his five siblings camp in the woods with their parents, migrant cherry workers in Wenatchee, Wash. State and Federal officials are trying to enforce better living conditions for the pickers. (Loren Callahan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HUGE TAX PAYMENT ORDERED FOR U.P.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
A judge has ruled that United Parcel Service took inflated tax deductions in 1984 and must pay taxes, penalties and interest that the company said might total nearly $300 million for that year.
But its ultimate liability could be much larger -- perhaps growing into one of the biggest corporate tax cases ever -- because the Tax Court decision, issued Monday, covers only the first year of a business practice that has continued ever since. 
 The 114-page decision, and its withering dissection of testimony by U.P.S. executives, was a rare victory for the Internal Revenue Service in its efforts to prevent companies from taking tax deductions when they move money to subsidiaries overseas for the sole purpose of avoiding taxes.
Yesterday, United Parcel Service would not estimate its potential liability. But previously, the company had disclosed that it could owe $259 million in taxes alone for its returns covering the years 1985 through 1990, which have been challenged by the I.R.S.
Since 1990, U.P.S. has continued to claim these deductions on the same theory that the Tax Court denied, said Kenneth B. Sternad, the chief spokesman for the company. It expects the agency to contest its tax payments for the subsequent years. Based on the company's past estimates of tax liability, its total in taxes, interest and penalties could easily surpass a billion dollars.
U.P.S. may appeal Monday's decision, Mr. Sternad said. The case would move to the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Atlanta, where U.P.S. is based.
The decision will not affect plans, announced by the company last month, to sell shares to the public for the first time, Mr. Sternad said.
At issue in the civil case were deductions that U.P.S. took for the costs of insuring each parcel worth more than $100 against damage or loss.
The I.R.S. claimed that U.P.S. charged customers three times the competitive market price for the insurance in a scheme to funnel money to an insurance company it created in 1984 in Bermuda, thereby inflating its tax deductions. U.P.S. charged customers 25 cents per $100 for "extra value coverage" in 1984. It then paid the money over to National Union Fire Insurance of Pittsburgh and took a deduction for the expense.
But the transaction was a sham, Judge Robert P. Ruwe wrote in his ruling. National Union was merely acting as a front, he said, because after taking a small fee, it sent the money on to Overseas Partners Ltd., a Bermuda insurance company owned and controlled by U.P.S.
United Parcel argued that its insurance fees were reasonable, but the judge held that the rates were as much as three times what U.P.S. would have paid for the insurance in the open market.
Overseas Partners counted at least 63 cents of each dollar it received as profit, Judge Ruwe wrote -- in some years as much as 78 cents on the dollar.
The finding that the customers paid three times the market price for insurance is sure to draw attention from major shippers who may see an opportunity to seek refunds.
In funneling business to the Bermuda insurer, the judge ruled, U.P.S. was motivated only to reduce its income taxes in the United States, and not by any legitimate business purpose. It is legal to organize business activities in ways that reduce taxes -- but it is illegal to engage in transactions whose sole purpose is to avoid taxes, Judge Ruwe noted.
He quoted at length the testimony of Neil A. Doherty, an expert witness hired by the company. At trial, an I.R.S. lawyer asked Mr. Doherty if the fee of 25 cents per $100 would have made sense for U.P.S. if the money were not being paid to an insurer it controlled.
"It would be a rather strange business decision to basically give off that profit to an outsider," testified Mr. Doherty, a professor of insurance and risk management at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.
The insurance charges allowed U.P.S. to take nearly $65 million in improper deductions, the judge held, while inflating the profits of Overseas Partners, which is not required to pay United States income taxes.
The judge upheld the I.R.S.'s finding that U.P.S. owed $64.9 million in taxes, $14.5 million in penalties for negligence and underpayment of taxes and interest that would bring the total to about $300 million.
Before 1984, the judge wrote, U.P.S. collected fees to cover damage or loss to packages worth more than $100 and treated that money as part of its regular revenue stream, paying taxes on its profits.
The company argued that it had created the Bermuda insurance company not to avoid taxes, but to avoid running afoul of state insurance regulators, some of whom had questioned car rental companies about charges they added to customer bills to cover potential damage to vehicles.
Kenneth Johnson, at the time the company's chief insurance official, acknowledged in his testimony in the case that no state insurance official had challenged U.P.S. and that he had never asked any state or Federal official if the company was acting improperly in charging the fees.
The judge also noted that U.P.S. had letters from each state authorizing its earlier practice of adding charges for high-value packages.
As a major company, Judge Ruwe wrote, he would have expected U.P.S. to investigate any such risks and to produce documents showing its legal and economic analysis of the issue. But during the period it was considering setting up the Bermuda insurer, he added, U.P.S. "produced no documentation, such as corporate minutes" indicating that it "had motives other than tax reduction."
Mr. Sternad, the company spokesman, said U.P.S. believed the judge was wrong and that its insurance charges were reasonable. He said the company was not considering making refunds to customers.
The I.R.S. has fought an uphill battle against a range of corporate practices intended to reduce income taxes in the United States by taking profits in countries with small or no corporate income tax, like Bermuda, Luxembourg and the Cayman Islands.
There are many legitimate reasons for companies to move funds overseas, tax experts note, so the I.R.S. must prove that the sole motive for the transaction was tax avoidance.
In insurance arrangements like that set up by U.P.S., it has been nearly impossible for the I.R.S. "to draw a bright line around which payments to captive insurance companies are proper and which are not," said Andrew D. Pike, a former Treasury Department official who teaches tax law at American University in Washington.
The I.R.S. has lost cases involving captive insurance companies owned by Gulf Oil; Sears, Roebuck; U-Haul; Humana and others, according to Lee A. Sheppard, a New York lawyer who writes for Tax Notes magazine.
Just last month the I.R.S. lost a $180 million case against National Westminster Bank P.L.C, a big British bank, over how it allocated interest expenses between its American and overseas operations.

HEADLINE: Raise Water Taxes to Combat Drought

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "It's Time We Got Smart About Drought" (Op-Ed, Aug. 5): 
 The best solution to droughts is to give water users the proper economic incentive. This can be done by increasing water taxes by, say, $200 a year and by using the increased revenue to reduce property or other taxes by a similar amount.
We would not pay a dime more in net tax revenue. But we would all use less water because wasting water would be expensive. As a result, reservoir levels would be significantly higher in times of rain failure.
This has the additional advantage of preserving liberty: during droughts it would be less necessary to punish citizens for specific water uses.
 
THOMAS O'BRIEN
Charlottesville, Va., Aug. 9, 1999
 
The writer is director for research, Horizon Institute for Policy Solutions.

HEADLINE: WINE TALK;
Why That Bottle Costs $50 in a Restaurant

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
REMEMBER the so-so cabernet you shelled out $50 for in that restaurant last week? And how you felt you'd been taken? Well, if it makes you feel any better, the winemaker didn't do too well on the deal, either. He or she probably made about $2.
In the wine trade, that's actually not bad money. Take Ravenswood, a well-known winery in Sonoma, Calif. Ravenswood has been making superior wines, mostly zinfandels, for almost 20 years. Last year the winery, which is publicly traded, posted a net profit of about $1.5 million on sales of $17 million. With some 131,000 cases of wine sold, that translates into a profit of about 95 cents a bottle. 
 The Robert Mondavi Winery, also a public company, netted $29 million, selling just under 6.8 million cases, or some 81.2 million bottles of wine. Net profit per bottle: 36 cents. Beringer Wine Estates did a little better, making $29.5 million on about 6 million cases, or 41 cents a bottle.
No need to send any of these people CARE packages. Volume clearly makes up for any shortcomings in the per-bottle profits. Even so, it should be evident that no one, at least no one at the publicly owned wineries, is making a killing in the wine business. Privately owned wineries do not release their profit figures.
So where did your $50 go? (Closer to $60 with tax and tip.) Mostly to the restaurant. The winery would have sold it to a wholesaler -- called a distributor in the liquor business -- for about $12.50. The distributor then would have marked it up about a third, selling it to a retailer or to a restaurant for about $16.50, plus freight and state taxes. The retailer then would sell it for about $25, and the restaurant for double that, charging you around $50.
This is called the three-tiered system. Antiquated and costly, it's part of the liquor laws of almost every state. And there can be a fourth tier as well. Many larger wine producers hire marketing companies to augment the efforts of the distributors. Typically, a marketer will take a five-figure fee for selling a predetermined number of cases.
It cost the maker of our $50 bottle about $10.50 to produce it. Wine making costs are not difficult to understand. First, there are the grapes. Some wineries use only grapes they have grown themselves. Big wineries like Mondavi and Beringer own vineyards and also buy grapes from other growers. Many smaller wineries, like Ravenswood, buy all their grapes, currently paying $2,000 and more a ton for the best cabernet sauvignon. Estate-grown or purchased, grapes can account for up to 25 percent of production costs.
The bottle, cork, label and the capsule around the bottle's neck would ordinarily account for little more than $1, except at the E.& J. Gallo Winery, which makes its own bottles and prints its own labels. Accounting for the rest of the wine production costs: barrels, which can cost $600 each, storage costs while the wine is aging, taxes, marketing and promotion.
Of course, prices, markups and fees are flexible. If a highly regarded small-production wine, say a Bruno Giacosa barbera from Italy or a Silver Oak cabernet from California, is much in demand and only one distributor carries it in a state or a city, he may increase his markup from a third to 40 percent or more. Retailers and restaurants will pass this increase on to their customers.
Once, restaurants simply added 50 percent to the retail price of a bottle of wine. More commonly now, they double or triple the retail price. It's no longer surprising to find wines that sell for $10 in New York wine shops on restaurant lists for $25 to $35. Most restaurateurs defend high wine prices as a way to hold down the cost of food and general overhead. But there are restaurants -- Harry's Hanover Square, Sparks Steakhouse and Union Square Cafe, to cite three in New York -- that consistently offer wine prices lower than their competitors'.
Some price increases are unavoidable. Like many serious restaurateurs, John Foy at the Sonoma Grill in East Rutherford, N.J., holds his best Bordeaux and California cabernets for three or four years before selling them. Since he uses bank loans to buy the wine, he adjusts his prices periodically to cover his interest payments.
"I won't be selling my 1994's for another two years, my 1995's for three," he said. "I've got to finance my inventory."
Even with periodic adjustments, Mr. Foy said, he hews as closely to the 50-percent-over-retail principle as he can.
"When I see some of the prices in New York restaurants, I feel like saying, 'If you want to hold me up, why don't you just take a gun and ask for my wallet?' " he said. "It would be less hypocritical."
Mr. Foy's concerns are not necessarily those of all restaurantgoers, especially in these good economic times. According to the most recent restaurant poll conducted by Wine & Spirits, a consumer magazine, the average price paid in United States restaurants last year for cabernet sauvignon was $56 a bottle; for pinot noir, about $47, and for chardonnay and merlot, about $40.
Noting that the average price of the most popular wines in 1998 was $43.59, a 24 percent jump in three years, Wine & Spirits' editors said: "It's beyond inflation and beyond most people's ability to comprehend."
So be grateful you got that bottle for $50. At the rate we're going, next year it may be $75.

Tastings
Classic Chianti
 
Cetamura Chianti, Badia a Coltibuono 1997, Tuscany, Italy. About $10.
 
SO many good wines are coming out of Italy these days that it's hard to keep up with them. Unfortunately, many have only two of the three basic requirements for relatively little-known wines: quality and a reasonable price. The third leg of the stool is availability. Fortunately, Cetamura, from Badia a Coltibuono, a prominent Chianti producer, is quite widely distributed. Less impressive than Coltibuono's better Chiantis, Cetamura is nevertheless a delightfully rounded everyday red wine with an array of rich flavors, good concentration and lots of fruit. It's a classic Chianti, composed of sangiovese and canaiolo, the essential Chianti grapes. An easygoing, uncomplicated red for late summer and fall.

HEADLINE: NATURAL ORIGINS: Chesapeake Bay;
The Glorious Summer Of the Soft-Shell Crab

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: Urbanna, VA.

 BODY:
THE sun was a blood-orange disk pinned to the horizon as Thomas Lee Walton eased his 24-foot Carolina Skiffcq into the creek and headed toward the Rappahannock River. An osprey was perched in a dead tree on the far shore. It was 6:05 A.M. We were going crabbing.
 Our quarry was the Atlantic blue crab -- Callinectes sapidus to marine biologists, which means "savory beautiful swimmer" in Latin. But not the run-of-the-mill fellows you boil up with plenty of Old Bay seasoning, then crack with a hammer before pulling out the sweet, delicate white meat. Mr. Walton fishes for "busters" or "peelers," which are crabs that have already begun to shed their shells, or are about to, before growing new ones. 
 "Watching them shed," Mr. Walton said with a tender reverence suprising in a rugged outdoorsman, "it's like they're reborn."
 If you catch them at the right moment and pull them from the water, the process of growth stops and you have a soft-shell crab, one of summer's most prized treats, not only here on the rim of the Chesapeake Bay, but also, increasingly, in cities across the United States.
 They seem to be on every menu in New York this summer, prepared in more or less the same way: you eat the whole thing, claws, legs and all, sauteed or grilled, maybe seasoned with a squeeze of lemon juice. Before you try one, it sounds decidedly dubious, like tripe or seaweed. But a single taste makes a convert.
 Years ago, I served a soft-shell, grilled in my garden, to Paul Bocuse, who formed a wildly inflated view of my cooking skills as a result. Soft-shells can be deep fried, too, which makes them crunchier, and good ol' boys like to stick them between two slices of white bread to make sandwiches. Me, I prefer my soft-shells sauteed, because I think the crust masks the flavor.
 All crabs molt, up to 20 times during their lives; they must do so to grow. But the soft-shell form of the Dungeness crab on the Pacific Coast or king crab in Alaska is seldom eaten, if ever, and Europeans use soft-shell crabs mostly for bait. In this as in so many things gastronomic, the Venetians are an exception. They consider Mediterranean shore crabs that have shed their carapaces, which they call moleche, a great delicacy.
 Even here, where soft-shells have been savored for more than a century, putting them on gourmands' tables is a dicey proposition, requiring luck, hard physical labor and painstaking attention to detail, in roughly equal proportions. Nobody has found a way yet to farm crabs. Mr. Walton and his fellow watermen, as they call themselves, must catch peelers in wire-mesh traps, take them ashore, transfer them into shallow sea water tanks and check each one carefully every six hours around the clock, waiting for them to shed their shells.
The crabs, elusive and pugnacious, don't make it easy.
In William W. Warner's fine book about crabs, "Beautiful Swimmers" (Little, Brown, 1994), he quotes a splendid triple-negative aphorism he heard from a waterman on Maryland's Eastern Shore: "Ain't nobody knows nothing about crabs." Mr. Walton agrees, steeped though he is in crustacean legend and lore. "Catching crabs is mostly instinct," he said.
"Every time you think you've got them figured they change on you," he added, standing at the tiller of his boat, bronzed from a summer's work. "We try to outthink them, but they don't think. They just react to changes in the water, little changes in chemistry that we don't understand."
He put in a fresh wad of Red Man chewing tobacco and squinted into the sun, looking for the buoys that marked one of his lines of traps.
MR. WALTON'S family has lived and worked on the water for generations -- how many, he could not say. They moved to Urbanna from remote Tangier Island, out in the bay, after a terrible hurricane in 1933. They have been here ever since. He, his brothers, his uncle, his aunt and his son, Lee, are all crabbers, all true Tidewater folks who pronounce "about" not at all like the rest of us, but about halfway between uh-BOAT and uh-BOOT.
Jimmy Sneed is what the Walton family and their neighbors call a come-here -- someone from somewhere else. But after almost a decade he has won their confidence, and they have taught him most of what they know about soft-shells, which is one reason his restaurant in Richmond, the Frog and the Redneck, may serve the most delectable soft-shells anywhere.
Bearded, ribald, shod day and night in one of his 14 pairs of Lucche se boots, Mr. Sneed is (and is not) the redneck in his restaurant's name. It comes from a moment of comic conflict more than a decade ago, when he was working for the French chef Jean-Louis Palladin, then the proprietor of Jean-Louis in Washington and now installed at Palladin in Manhattan.
As Mr. Sneed tells the story, Mr. Palladin was shouting at him, not for the first time, and Mr. Sneed snapped. "Shut up, you stupid frog," Mr. Sneed shouted back. Mr. Palladin whirled, glared, slammed his knife on the counter and demanded, "What did you call me?" When Mr. Sneed repeated the epithet, Mr. Palladin yelled, "Then you must be a . . . a redneck!"
He isn't, of course, though he sometimes relishes the role; the son of a Veterans' Administration administrator, he grew up in a dozen towns and cities, including Charleston, S.C., and Peekskill, N.Y. Of course, Mr. Sneed and Mr. Palladin became close friends. And of course, when Mr. Sneed decided to move to Richmond after five years of running a restaurant in Urbanna, he could not resist naming his new place in honor of his mentor.
Crab has become Mr. Sneed's metier. Every night of the year, he serves a rich red pepper cream soup garnished with crab, as well as ethereal crab cakes, made of prime backfin lump crab meat, bound together with little more than a dab of mayonnaise and the chef's prayers. He serves them even when crab is so scarce, as it is right now, that he has to charge $32.50 for them to make a profit. When soft-shells are in season hereabouts, from May until mid-October, he serves them as well.
Mr. Sneed buys mostly from Thomas Lee Walton, who saves the softest of soft-shells for him. These are the ones that have been culled from the tanks within a half-hour of molting. (The tanks are called floats by the watermen because in the early days of the industry they were slatted boxes floating in the creeks.)
The new crab shells begin to form at once, and because the watermen can't hover over the tanks, they get only a fraction of the soft-shells at the optimum moment. These are called "velvets" in the colorful terminology of the crabbers. Plump and bursting with salty-sweet flavor, they are also very fragile, so Mr. Sneed, his wife or his daughter drives to Urbanna every other day, a two-and-a-half-hour round trip, to fetch them at the source.
"Soft-shells are very important to us," Mr. Sneed told me in a rare outburst of understatement. "And you have to try for the premium raw materials, no matter how much trouble it is. Product is king."
A self-described culinary minimalist, Mr. Sneed cooks the crabs in the simplest way imaginable. He pulls them from the refrigerator, dusts them with Wondra flour, which is milled extra fine so that it doesn't clump, and slides them, shell side down, into a heavy cast-iron frying pan filled to a depth of a quarter of an inch with a 50-50 mix of canola oil and drawn butter. After 60 seconds, he turns them and cooks them 30 seconds on the other side.
"Careful," Mr. Sneed warned. "When soft-shells are really fresh, they're full of salty water, so they tend to pop and burn you."
And don't serve them with tartar sauce, not unless you want to make the nonredneck see red.
IT took the watermen many years to make the discovery that put the soft-shell trade on a sound commercial footing. Finding a buster in a pot or along the shore is a relatively rare occurrence. They needed some means of forecasting when other crabs were about to molt, so they could take it ashore and wait for it to do its thing. Finally, some unstoried hero noticed that on the next-to-last section of the articulated swimming leg, the most translucent part of the crab, a white line that later turns pink, and finally an intense dark red can be detected when a crab is about to shed its shell.
It can be detected, that is, by an experienced waterman like Mr. Walton. I could just barely make out the line at its cherry reddest, when the crab was an hour, maybe minutes, from molting, but the rest of the time I couldn't break the code, no matter how closely I looked.
The crabs with white lines, known for some reason as "greens," shed in two weeks, those with pink lines, sometimes called "ripe," will molt within a week, and the red liners, termed "rank," will need a day.
In fact, the telltale lines are the edges of new shells, or exoskeletons, forming inside old ones in anticipation of molting.
I marveled at Mr. Walton's skills. When we arrived at the traps, or pots, that he had set out along the northern shore of the Rappahannock estuary, he chugged up to the first, set the tiller so it kept the boat tracing a circle around the pot and put on an oilcloth apron and two pairs of gloves. Then, with practiced grace, he snagged the buoy with a boathook and pulled up the line attached to it, hand over hand, heaving the pot into the boat until it broke water.
The pot is a cube-shape contraption with three conical entrances, which crabs can swim into but not out of. In the first one were a half-dozen crabs, as well as a croaker and an alewife, as menhaden are called hereabouts. Mr. Walton undid the latch and dumped the catch onto a sorting table, then quickly pitched the fish and the hard-shells back into the water, closed the latch and lowered the pot.
Only five or six times all morning did he expend more than a passing glance in "reading" which crabs were peelers and which not. Most of the time, he instantly tossed the greens into one bushel basket at his feet, the ripes and ranks into another and the few busters into a blue plastic basin filled with river water so that they could continue to molt there. When he was unsure, he held the crab in question up to the sun, its claws a beautiful powder blue, studied it and pitched it in the appropriate direction.
On picking the right crabs on such slim evidence rests his livelihood. He makes few mistakes.
But if the crabs aren't there, no crabber can catch them. Mr. Walton pulled about 70 good peelers and busters from his first line of 50 traps, but from the second and third, he got only about 10, and then he quit for the day. August is never the best month for soft-shells. That comes each May, when he usually takes five or six bushels of crabs off his boat at day's end -- about 1,000 to 2,000 crabs. The May catch is almost as big as those of all the other months put together.
At $1.50 each, the morning's work grossed about $120. But out of that Mr. Walton has to pay for gas and the upkeep of his boat, his pickup truck, his pots (which cost $12 each) and his two dozen shedding tanks, which look like shallow plastic bathtubs. No formula for instant riches.
Is the overall crab catch in the bay and its tributaries shrinking, as the harvests of striped bass and oysters did in recent years, with disastrous economic consequences? Many watermen, and Mr. Sneed, think it is, and they blame winter crabbing with dredges, which pull hibernating crabs from the mud, along with laws permitting crabbers in Virginia to keep female crabs carrying a spongelike mass of eggs.
Not so, said Mike Osterling, the top crab expert at the Virginia Institute of Marine Science at Gloucester Point, near Hampton.
"I've seen no records indicating a long-term decline in soft-shells," he said. "Soft-shell fishing has its good days and bad, like anything else. But more people are going into the soft-shell business every day, all the way from here to Texas, and that's no sign of a fishery in decline."
Tradition says that the Chesapeake produces the best soft-shells, and I'm a great respecter of food traditions. But the season lasts a little longer farther South because of the warmer water, and I've eaten some pretty good soft-shells taken by fisherman in Louisiana and North Carolina, mostly small operators like the watermen on the bay.
As for Mr. Walton, he sells all the velvets he has to Mr. Sneed, and those with a slightly firmer shell, called "shippers," he ships. Every so often, a refrigerated truck stops here, picks up trays of crabs covered with wet paper or eel-grass and heads north toward the big fish market at Jessup, Md., near Baltimore.
Sorted by size -- whales are the biggest, spiders the smallest, with jumbos, primes, hotels and mediums in between -- they go to a wholesaler named Louis Foehrkolb, whom Mr. Walton has never met. He keeps track of the shipments and sends Mr. Walton a check at month's end.
I asked whether he ever worries about being shortchanged.
"Nah," said Mr. Walton, whose smile is as roguish as ever at 52. "I figure if he stops sending me money, I'll stop sending him crabs."
 
TEMPURA OF SOFT-SHELL CRABS
Adapted from the Frog and the Redneck, Richmond
Time: 20 minutes
 
8 cleaned soft-shell crabs
1 cup flour
 1/4 teaspoon baking soda
2 ice cubes
Peanut oil for deep frying
Sea salt to taste.
 1. Lay crabs backside down on a cutting board, and cut in half lengthwise, so that each half has a claw.
2. Stir about 1 1/4 cups water into the flour to make a smooth, thick batter. Add baking soda and ice cubes.
3. Pour enough oil into a deep pot to fill it halfway, and heat to 375 degrees. (To test, carefully sprinkle a drop or two of water into the pot. If the oil rumbles, it's not hot enough. If it crackles, it is.)
4. Dip crab pieces, four at a time, into batter, and immediately drop into hot oil. Stir after several seconds to separate the pieces, then cook until golden brown, 30 to 45 seconds. Drain on paper towels. Repeat with remaining crab pieces. Salt to taste, and serve immediately.
Yield: 4 servings.
 
ROASTED RIPE TOMATO SALSA
Adapted from Lucky Star in Virginia Beach, Va.
Time: 1 hour, 20 minutes
 
10 plum tomatoes, halved lengthwise and cored
5 tablespoons olive oil
1 teaspoon herbes de Provence
Kosher salt and freshly ground pepper
3 ripe tomatoes, cored and diced large
3 shallots, peeled and julienned
1 yellow bell pepper, stemmed, seeded and diced medium
3 scallions, trimmed and sliced
1 teaspoon red wine vinegar.
 1. Heat the oven to 400 degrees. Place a large cast-iron skillet inside it and heat 15 to 20 minutes.
2. Place the plum tomatoes cut side up on a rack over a baking tray. Drizzle them with 1 tablespoon olive oil, then season with the herbes de Provence, and salt and pepper to taste.
3. In a large stainless steel bowl, toss the diced tomatoes with 2 tablespoons olive oil, 1 teaspoon kosher salt and 1/2 teaspoon pepper. Spoon into the heated skillet. Place the sliced plum tomatoes in the oven as well. Roast 45 minutes, or until plum tomatoes appear to be drying and diced tomatoes have released their juices. Remove from the oven, and let cool.
4. Place a skillet over medium high heat, add remaining 2 tablespoons olive oil, shallots, yellow pepper and scallions, and saute 2 to 3 minutes, or until softened. Transfer to a large bowl.
5. Cut cooled plum tomatoes into quarters and add to bowl along with diced tomates. Toss to combine. Season with vinegar, salt and pepper.
Yield: About 6 cups
 
SAUTEED SOFTSHELL CRABS
Adapted from the Frog and the Redneck, Richmond
Time: 20 minutes
 
1 cup flour
Salt and pepper to taste
8 cleaned soft-shell crabs
 3/4 cup clarified butter
 1/2 cup canola oil
3 tablespoons lemon juice
1 tablespoon chopped parsley.
 1. Heat a large cast-iron skillet over medium heat. Place flour on a plate, and season with salt and pepper. Dredge soft-shell crabs in flour, shaking off excess. When the skillet is hot, add half the butter and canola oil to a depth of about 1/4 inch. Add four crabs, backside down, being careful to avoid spattering. When they brown lightly, turn, and finish cooking on the other side, until cooked through, 3 to 5 minutes total, depending on the size of the crabs. Drain on paper towels, and repeat with remaining crabs, adding more butter or oil to pan if needed.
2. In a small bowl, stir together remaining clarified butter and lemon juice. Drizzle over crabs, sprinkle with parsley, and serve immediately.
Yield: 4 servings.

HEADLINE: Milosevic Meets His Backers As Opponents Seek to Unite

BYLINE: By CARLOTTA GALL 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Aug. 10

 BODY:
President Slobodan Milosevic attended a rare strategy meeting of his Socialist Party this afternoon, apparently in response to the growing opposition movement against him.
Mr. Milosevic has found himself under increasing pressure as opposition parties have begun to show a new will to unite to remove him from power. The Serbian Orthodox church has added its weight, bringing key opposition leaders together on Monday and backing their plans for democratic change in Serbia. 
 The Holy Synod, the highest body of the church, convened today to discuss its role in political developments. Pushed by outspoken members of the church in Kosovo, who have denounced President Milosevic's disastrous policies in the province, the church is poised to take a prominent role in the move for change. The synod is expected to issue a statement on Wednesday on the results of its meeting.
State news media have been quick to criticize the opposition's attempts to win the backing of the church. The state news agency, Tanjug, and the main Government newspaper, Politika, denounced the political meeting, saying the opposition leaders "are practically inducing the church to violate the Constitution," which they said bars the Church from engaging in politics.
The Socialist Party today repeated its standard criticism of opposition leaders, calling them "NATO's lackeys" who are trying to bring down the Government and thus achieve what NATO failed with its bombing campaign, Radio Television Serbia reported.
Yet the party apparently plans business as usual; it appointed two members to its executive council but otherwise announced no changes in its tactics or its program.
Opposition groups announced after Monday's meeting that they would join forces for a rally planned on Aug. 19 in Belgrade, and they pressed Patriarch Pavle, the head of the Serbian Orthodox Church, to take part.
The Holy Synod is considering whether the patriarch should attend the rally and also another request, to mediate between the Government and the opposition to find a political settlement, the Beta news agency said, quoting opposition members.
The rally next week is being organized by two independent economists, Mladjan Dinkic and Predrag Markovic, the founder of the Stability Pact for Serbia.
Patriarch Pavle led the meeting on Monday of the opposition forces, including the Democratic Party leader Zoran Djindjic and Vuk Draskovic, head of the Serbian Renewal Movement. It will be the first time in two years that the men will share a platform; their bitter personal rivalry was blamed for the collapse of the democratic movement in 1997.
The two politicians are united in calling for a transition Government, but remain divided on how to bring it about and on the form of Government. The authors of the Stability Pact for Serbia and others, in a plan that has Washington's backing, insist that President Milosevic must go first, before any transition Government can take over.
Mr. Djindjic is hoping the rally will build a momentum of its own, describing it as "a kind of a referendum where people will have a chance to say whether they are for changes." He warned that no compromise was possible with Mr. Milosevic. "After the 19th, Milosevic will have to realize that he is out of time," he told reporters. "It is the day when the countdown begins."
But Mr. Draskovic questions how Mr. Milosevic's removal will come about. He is arguing for a transitional Government that includes power-sharing with Mr. Milosevic.
"I told Patriarch Pavle I oppose a government which would be formed on the streets," he told reporters. "We will not support such a government because it would deepen the agony and the divisions among the Serbian people."
The Patriarch also met separately on Monday with the former Yugoslav Army Chief of Staff, Momcilo Perisic, who has founded his own party, the Movement for Democratic Serbia. Mr. Perisic, who was dismissed from his post eight months ago, has called for democratic change and for Mr. Milosevic to step down.
The general has been criticized for not joining one of the many existing democratic parties, but he could prove a potent figure in the swelling ranks of the opposition movement.
Opposition rallies have continued daily around the country although the crowds are sometimes small. The Aug. 19 rally will be watched as a measure of public discontent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Signs of strain between agencies and their customers persist for a second year.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
RELATIONS between agencies and advertisers are showing signs of strain for a second consecutive year, according to an annual survey.
The results of the survey, which asked executives at agencies and client companies to assess the nature of their dealings with each other, indicate that efforts to narrow the gap between them have fallen short, as they did last year. The two years of deterioration follow surveys in 1996 and 1997 that had indicated improvement in relationships. 
 "As an industry, we're not doing great," said Nancy L. Salz, president of Nancy L. Salz Consulting in New York, who offered a preview of the findings of the 1999 Salz Survey of Advertiser-Agency Relations. "Our numbers are absolutely confirming what the A.A.F. found."
Ms. Salz's reference was to a much-publicized survey released in June by the American Advertising Federation. That study showed surprising skepticism among top corporate executives about the effectiveness of advertising in helping their companies grow as well as a reluctance to declare themselves more than merely satisfied with advertising on behalf of their businesses.
Advertisers who responded to the Salz Consulting survey also judged advertising to be less important to their sales growth than before.
For instance, when asked how much sales could improve if their agencies were always able to do the best possible work, the mean figure the respondents gave was 21.4 percent. That was the lowest since a mean of 21.1 percent in the recession year of 1991 and a sharp decline from 31.4 percent as recently as 1996.
And when asked to rate the quality of work from their agencies on a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 highest, the mean rating from advertisers for 1999 was 7.0. That was the lowest since the same rating in 1992 and 1993 and a significant decrease from 7.5 as recently as 1996.
"This is all about accountability," Ms. Salz said. "Advertising as a tool has got to be accountable."
"It isn't 'Show me the money,' " she added. "It's 'Show me the results.' "
As it turns out, this year's answers to the survey, which has been conducted for the last 14 years, point to a results-oriented way to dissipate tensions between Madison Avenue and clients: the practice known as performance-based compensation. That's when clients switch from traditional methods of paying their agencies, like a 15 percent commission or a flat fee, to basing payments on predetermined, measurable goals like increases in sales of products. Among the well-known marketers using or experimenting with performance-based compensation is the Procter & Gamble Company.
"Performance-based compensation has an effect for the good," Ms. Salz said, reviewing survey tables showing that advertisers using it reported smoother relationships with their agencies than those that did not: more teamwork, more respect, more focus on the work.
Performance-based compensation is no cure-all, Ms. Salz acknowledged; otherwise "you'd see more people using it" than the 39 percent of advertisers who reported they did. Agency executives who responded said that 22.9 percent of their clients were compensating them based on performance.
Still, Ms. Salz said, performance-based compensation "offers a foundation for better advertising," primarily because it encourages agencies and clients to collaborate more, by "focusing on common goals."
"It's putting agencies in the same boat as clients," she added. "They are rowing or not rowing together."
For agencies, the survey indicated a potential bump in the road to more performance-based compensation: clients using it said they were likely to go beyond their agency rosters in assigning tasks in realms like strategy and marketing. Of course, the struggle to keep clients from seeking advice elsewhere has been one of the most pressing recent concerns among agency leaders.
The three reasons most often cited by advertisers for delegating tasks were expertise, wanting a new perspective and cost.
"With more on the line under performance-based compensation," Ms. Salz said, "advertisers are paying a lot more attention to how they're spending their money."
The survey was conducted in March and May for Salz Consulting by Thurm Marketing and Consulting Inc. in Princeton, N.J. Salz Consulting sponsors training seminars in agency relations and advertising development for marketers like Clorox, GTE and Hewlett-Packard.

HEADLINE: 13 Needless Deaths

 BODY:
The deaths of 13 farm workers in a vehicle crash in Five Points, Calif., underscores the need for better enforcement of the laws that protect farm laborers. The circumstances of Monday's accident are shocking but not uncommon -- an unlicensed driver ferrying 15 people home just before dawn in an overloaded van. It defies common sense that vans used for the express purpose of transporting such laborers are not required to have seat belts. Farm workers often have no alternative means of transportation to and from the fields.
These accidents are yet another mark of a callous system that exploits the migrant laborer, allowing growers to shirk accountability by using farm labor contractors as middlemen to hire and manage the workers. Although California has relatively tough laws protecting farm laborers, there are loopholes that place them at risk. The law requires that drivers of these vans be specially licensed, but in practice many are not. California already assigns officers to patrol the highway in the early morning hours to stop vehicles that violate occupancy and licensing laws. But these and other efforts to prevent violations need to be increased. 
 Steps must also be taken to force growers to take more responsibility for the general safety of their workers. Their political muscle has allowed them to abuse the system for too long.
