HEADLINE: The Other Surplus Option

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich, former Secretary of Labor, is a professor of social and economic policy at Brandeis University and national editor of The American Prospect.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
The way a debate is framed and choices are posed is often more important than which option is chosen. That's because the framing of the debate sends a powerful message to the public about what's at stake. It sets the boundaries of discourse. For politicians to stray beyond requires too much explaining and runs the risk of appearing irrelevant or radical.
The debate over what to do with the Federal budget surplus offers a case in point. Congressional Republicans want to use almost all of it for a tax cut. President Clinton argues that it should be used to pay off present and future obligations. "Save Social Security. Save Medicare. . . . And get America out of debt for the first time since 1835," he said last week in response to the Republican proposal. 
 Both alternatives -- cutting taxes and paying off obligations -- are attractive, if done equitably. Once the posturing is over, any final compromise is likely to feature some of each. But a third option -- to apply some of the surplus to public investments in our future -- is left out almost entirely.
By public investments I mean things that will make the nation more productive in the future but that individuals or businesses have little incentive to do on their own. Such public investments complement private investments. Without them, the private sector cannot sustain high returns over the long term.
Politicians once talked about public investment. This was a central theme of the President's 1992 campaign. Bill Clinton came to Washington stressing the urgency of dealing with "twin deficits" -- the budget deficit and America's failure to invest adequately in our people. We are far better able to afford public investment today than in 1992, when the deficit loomed large. Yet we're investing less, as a percentage of gross domestic product.
Basic research and development, for example, is the foundation for applied research by the private sector. The Internet emerged from basic research financed by the Government, and similar efforts cry out to be made in fields like physics and environmental remediation. Yet basic research hasn't kept up. In 1992, Federal investment in R & D was 0.43 percent of the gross domestic product. This year, it's 0.39 percent.
Likewise, an educated work force is essential if we are to reap the benefits of new technologies. Companies have been investing considerable sums in computers and digital gadgets, but chief executives complain that they can't find enough skilled people to use them.
Yet the problem goes much deeper than a chronic shortage of software engineers. One out of six Americans is functionally illiterate. Our classrooms are overcrowded and understaffed, some literally falling apart. In 1992, Federal investment in education and training made up 0.61 percent of G.D.P. This year -- as record numbers of students swell schools and colleges -- it's 0.58 percent.
The health of our nation's children, important for its own sake, is also important to our future prosperity. Yet 1 of every 4 children under 6 years of age is growing up in poverty. And although progress has been made in getting these children access to doctors, too many lack good nutrition and adequate care. In 1992, food and nutrition assistance (including school lunches and infant health) made up 0.53 percent of G.D.P. Now it's 0.40 percent.
The return from public investments in R & D, education, children's health and other essentials like highways and mass transit is often decades away. But our failure to invest adequately will also show up decades from now.
Because the Federal budget fails to distinguish between investing for tomorrow and spending on today (the normal distinction made by families and businesses in their own budgets), the concept of public investment has been debased by both sides. Either every favored budget item -- from farm programs to prescription drug benefits for the elderly -- is called an "investment," or everything the Government does is assumed to be spending that crowds out private investment.
But many other nations have figured out how to draw the distinction. There's a common-sense test. If it's likely to make us more productive in the future, it's an investment. If not, it's spending.
Granted, there are hard cases. Spending on national parks and environmental protection might be seen as investments, to the extent they make the future more livable. Yet spending on health care for the middle aged (like me), although desirable on other grounds, is probably not. But hard cases should not distract us from making the principled distinction.
Private investment is critical, of course. The best argument for cutting taxes and paying off financial obligations is that both free up money for the private sector, some of which will be invested. But the other portion will be consumed. And it is this distinction -- between investment and consumption -- that should be the focus, rather than the distinction between private and public.
Our future prosperity depends on the amount and wisdom of our private and public investments and on the restraint we show in our private and public consumption. Therein lies our real choice. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: William Slayton, 82, Official Who Aided Urban Renewal

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
William L. Slayton, who moved against racial discrimination as Commissioner of Urban Renewal in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, died on Saturday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 82 and lived in Washington.
Mr. Slayton, a Kansas-born Democrat, worked for the Housing and Home Finance Agency and as an urban renewal expert for the Ford Foundation before President John F. Kennedy chose him in 1961 to be Commissioner of the Urban Renewal Administration. It was part of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, which was succeeded by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Mr. Slayton held the post until 1966. 
 Early in 1962 he issued a policy letter notifying 539 local public agencies involved in urban renewal that all contracts with private developers had to specifically include this clause:
"The redeveloper will comply with all state and local laws, in effect from time to time, prohibiting discrimination or segregation by reason of race, religion, color, or national origin in the sale, lease, or occupancy of the property."
By then, 17 states and numerous cities had enacted measures against discrimination in housing. But until then, local public agencies had been required only to notify developers of the existence of such laws and to warn them that violators would be prohibited from further participation in urban renewal.
Charles Abrams, president of the National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing, pointed out that the new policy did not prevent discrimination by redevelopers in the South, where no anti-discrimination laws existed, as long as no restrictive covenants were employed. Mr. Slayton subsequently announced further steps to combat racial discrimination.
In mid-1962 the Urban Renewal Administration announced stiffer rules to insure that families displaced by urban-renewal projects were not left without decent housing. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People had asserted that, in eight communities outside New York City, blacks had been displaced by urban-renewal projects and had not been relocated satisfactorily.
Mr. Slayton was something of a champion of the big cities. He said in a 1964 speech that they might continue to lose people and manufacturing to the suburbs, but they could still survive as major cultural and entertainment areas, financial centers and special marketing outlets.
In 1964 the Urban Renewal Administration announced that more than 100,000 acres in 177 communities had been set aside for recreational and scenic uses under the Federal-state-local open-space land program. Mr. Slayton said then that almost half of the grants being issued had gone to metropolitan areas with populations of more than one million.
In the same year, The New York Times architecture critic Ada Louise Huxtable wrote that recent urban-renewal and other government-aided construction included "some handsome buildings and some well-planned projects, and the Urban Renewal Administration, under its design-conscious head, William L. Slayton, can point to some obvious, if occasionally partial, successes."
As Commissioner, Mr. Slayton was popular and widely regarded as an able official. But he resigned in 1966, after being passed over for two assistant secretary posts in the Department of Housing and Urban Development, after it succeeded the Housing and Home Finance Agency.
He went on to become president of Urban America Inc., a nonprofit organization in Washington concerned with the crisis in the cities. The other posts he held in his later years included Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Foreign Buildings.
A native of Topeka, Kan., he received degrees in municipal government and in public administration from the University of Chicago.
His survivors include his wife of 58 years, the former Mary Pritchard; two daughters, Betsy Slayton Campbell of Salt Lake City and Barbara Jean Slayton Shelton of East Quogue, N.Y.; a brother, Clarence H. Slayton Jr. of Mount Airy, Va., and four grandchildren. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
3 Big Makers Of Aluminum Seek a Merger

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Alcan Aluminium of Canada, Pechiney of France and the Alusuisse Lonza Group of Switzerland confirmed today that they are in merger talks that could create the biggest company in the aluminum industry, a business plagued for nearly a decade by oversupply and depressed prices.
The potential combination may be a signal of other big cross-border deals and could lead to stable or higher prices for aluminum, a basic industrial metal. 
 Although executives of the companies said they were still in discussions and an agreement was not certain, their talks were a vivid illustration of how corporate consolidation is achieving global scale.
The three-way combination under consideration would create an aluminum and packaging giant with more than $26 billion in annual revenue, easily eclipsing the $15.5 billion in revenue of the current No. 1, Alcoa of the United States.
The three companies make aluminum used in products ranging from aircraft bodies to cooking foil, as well as packaging for drugs and food. In addition, the Swiss company, informally known as Algroup, has a profitable specialty chemicals division, which would probably be sold if the merger talks succeed.
The aluminum business has been badly depressed since the early 90's, when the collapse of the Soviet Union, one of the biggest producers of aluminum, led to undisciplined selling by Russian exporters in a quest for foreign currency. Aluminum supplies surged and prices fell. The supply glut was aggravated in the last two years by the severe economic problems in Asia, Russia and Latin America.
In addition, mergers in the automotive and aircraft industries have created huge global customers with the buying power to keep prices low.
Thus, world aluminum prices have fallen about 30 percent since the late 80's and touched a five-year low in March, hurting the earnings of big producers and raising pressure on them to find partners.
In brief identical statements, Alcan Aluminium, Pechiney and Algroup would say only that they were in discussions regarding a "potential business combination." News of their discussions was reported today in The Wall Street Journal.
"There are talks, there have been talks, but there's no deal yet," said Marcel Barthe, a spokesman for Alcan Aluminium, at the company's headquarters in Montreal. The talks were conducted against a background of mergers in other metals industries, all of which have been hurt to varying degrees by low prices. In June, British Steel agreed to acquire the Dutch steelmaker Royal Hoogovens for $2.3 billion, and last year two huge German steelmakers joined to form Thyssen Krupp A.G.
But deals have unraveled, too. Indeed, Algroup last year announced an $8.7 billion merger with Viag, the German utility and aluminum maker, but the deal collapsed. Earlier, two big Swiss chemical producers, Ciba Specialty Chemicals A.G. and Clariant A.G., canceled a stock swap.
In some cases, the deals that succeeded reflect new-found attention to shareholder value at European corporations, many of which number among their major shareholders large American and British pension funds eager for returns. But many deals simply reflect the volatility of commodity prices and the need to gain scale and reduce costs to inject some stability into the business.
"They see the potential to unlock value, so that everyone comes away a winner," said Peter Davey, an analyst with Societe Generale Securities. Through the companies' mixture of primary aluminum production, packaging and other activities varied, he said, there was sufficient overlapping to justify consolidation.
Rene Weber, an analyst at Bank Vontobel in Zurich, agreed. "Pechiney and Alusuisse have food, pharmaceutical and cosmetic packaging operations that overlap, and both Alusuisse and Alcan have aluminum plants in eastern Switzerland," he said.
In the United States, officials for both Alcoa and the Aluminum Association, a trade group, declined to comment on such a merger's impact.
But many investors seemed to think that a deal represented good news, with the creation of a huge global manufacturer that would not necessarily have to cut prices to thrive.
"This is a very big positive for the entire aluminum industry," said Daniel A. Roling, an analyst with Merrill Lynch Global Securities.
In Paris, shares of Pechiney rose intraday to a 52-week high of 54.20 euros before falling back to close at 51.05 euros, or $54.63, down 1.3 percent. Algroup's shares rose 3.8 percent in Zurich to 1,810 Swiss francs, or $1,210. And in Toronto, Alcan Aluminium turned in the best performance of the would-be partners, gaining 6.2 percent to $50.50 (Canadian), or $33.68 (United States). Alcoa gained 81.25 cents, closing at $66.4375 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Though a deal could face formidable obstacles, including possible monopoly challenges by European Union regulators, who said today that they had been informed of the talks last week, it is expected to set off a scramble for partners among smaller aluminum producers, like Norsk Hydro of Norway and the VAW Aluminum subsidiary of Viag.
Under the terms of the deal that the companies are looking at, Pechiney and Algroup stockholders are expected to receive shares of Alcan in exchange for their shares. The planned combination would have its headquarters in Montreal and would be led by Alcan's president and chief executive, Jacques Bougie. Jean-Pierre Rodier, Pechiney's chairman, is expected to be named chief operating officer.
All three companies have similar activities, producing primary aluminum from basic raw materials and turning it into such products as rolled aluminum and ingots from which aluminum products are made.
But Alcan Aluminium, which hired Morgan Stanley Dean Witter as adviser in the discussions, is by far the most profitable of the three, yielding pretax profit equivalent to 10.5 percent of revenue, compared with 9.6 percent at Algroup and 6.6 percent at Pechiney.
Pechiney has been using Credit Suisse First Boston while Algroup has been using Goldman, Sachs as adviser.

HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA;
A 'Brave Thing,' Writing Verse, Especially at Poetry Camp

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: IDYLLWILD, Calif.

 BODY:
The poet, famously quiet in the face of the noise of life, is used to finding sustenance, even inspiration, in silence, but as I discovered on my first day of poetry camp, there is poetic silence, and then there is the other kind.
We were just getting acquainted, my poet classmates and I, on a brilliant morning in this mountain resort a mile above the desert near Los Angeles, gingerly offering supportive comments as each participant read aloud the first in-class assignment, a sort of free-association piece about our early memories of speech. 
 I was happy not to go first, and delighted when an elementary school teacher who read a poem unrelated to the theme still drew smiling responses. But all the hesitation I'd brought to this experiment in personal reinvention returned when an older woman, a children's book author, read a touching, well-shaped poem about helping her grandmother with a crossword puzzle as a child. It was thoughtful and, worst of all, confident.
When my turn arrived, I steeled myself and was reminded why middle-aged journalists so rarely attempt this sort of psychic bungee jumping. For years I have written newspaper articles read by a million people a day, but I had never felt so, well, naked, holding a legal pad and preparing to read a few lines of verse about, of all things, myself.
I declaimed what I imagined to be a rhapsodic if rambling poem, composed in 10 minutes or so, comparing my earliest search for words with recollections of my daughter's first utterances. Not exactly the T. S. Eliot and Ezra Pound I had studied in graduate school, I thought, but not an unworthy notion. Then I looked up and met the stares, and silence, of my 11 classmates.
"Anyone want to comment?" the teacher, Cecilia Woloch, a nimble, gentle poet, eventually asked. She has taught everywhere, from a prison to elementary schools. After a painful pause, she filled the vacuum with a few words, noting how novel were my descriptions of smearing peanut butter across my face as a toddler and of using the knob of a toy cabinet as a telephone receiver. More silence.
It was both humbling and, once the shock wore off, invigorating.
"I thought this was really, really hard," one of my classmates, an author of adventure books for children, said a couple of days later after reading an unflinchingly personal poem in which she artfully wrote about her mother as a glacier.
Ms. Woloch replied, "It's supposed to be."
We were, in fact, part of a quietly expanding trend in the country, ordinary people seizing the notion that they have something important to say through prose or poetry and paying good money to shape their voices. My colleagues included a middle-aged physician who had never done serious writing, a handwriting analyst, a Silicon Valley computer engineer, a real estate broker, a water utility worker and a music editor.
(The Idyllwild program cost $295 for three days of workshops, lectures and readings and an additional $175 for a private room in the dormitories and meals in the cafeteria, relatively cheap by workshop standards.)
The program avoided any deep exploration of traditional meter or poetic forms, although one section used haiku and tanka in its exercises, but neither did it merely encourage undisciplined and emotive doodlings. There were both in-class and overnight writing exercises, based on specific sets of random words or ideas. Our poems grew increasingly personal and careful in their use of language as the week progressed, and we analyzed the writing closely for both content and style.
David Fenza, the executive director of a trade organization called Associated Writing Programs, said that the number of degree-granting programs in creative writing had grown from 13 three decades ago to slightly more than 300 today. And he said the number of qualified summer writing workshops has leaped from a minuscule few to almost 100 registered with his group.
Another source, "The Guide to Writers' Conferences," by Shaw Guides, lists 359 conferences, seminars and workshops of various kinds, many for established writers who must submit manuscripts to get in, but plenty for rank amateurs. They range from the old and well-known Bread Loaf Writers' Conference in Vermont, operated by Middlebury College, to the Squaw Valley Community of Writers in Nevada City, Calif.
The conferences are often in resort communities, like Key West, Fla.; Provincetown, Mass.; Sun Valley, Idaho, and Taos, N.M., which can make them seem little more than slightly cerebral vacations. But the deeply emotional character of the writing and the pithy quality of the poems written by the Idyllwild group suggested that more was at work.
One woman wrote of teaching Emily Dickinson the domestic art of folding a baby's laundry, only to have the famous poet discover that gently tucking together socks was not unlike composing one of her poems.
"I've been doing various kinds of workshops for years, and there are always wonderful surprises," said Ms. Woloch, who would offer, "I think you caught a fish" when a student read a winner to the class.
John Brandi, a poet from New Mexico who taught another section of the workshop, said: "People get down to this. They write poetry. It's a brave thing."
The depth of interest was evident at Idyllwild, a pretty town of cabins and small inns 110 miles southeast of Los Angeles in the San Jacinto Mountains, the home of a music and arts boarding school during the year. There has been a summer arts program here for 50 years, and about 1,200 people now take courses or workshops.
This year the nonprofit organization that runs the site, the Idyllwild Arts Foundation, offered a poetry workshop for the first time. It had been inspired by signs of growing national interest in such courses and a sense that, as John Maguire, the senior consultant to the program and the retired president of Claremont Graduate University, put it, "Poetry offers a spiritual core for a society that seems to lack one."
Not only were the three-day workshops filled almost instantly when the brochures were first sent out months ago, but the foundation also added a second section in each session and expanded the number of slots to about a dozen per class, from an anticipated 10. The foundation is planning a further expansion next year because of the demand, Mr. Maguire said, and it has already lined up two writers as visiting poets: Billy Collins, author of several books of poetry, and Mary Karr, who wrote "The Liars' Club."
"Part of what drives the summer programs is what drives the whole economy, aging boomers," Mr. Fenza said. "The kids are out of the house, people are divorced, people are reinventing themselves. For some it's a spiritual crisis. For some it's the start of a real commitment to a different way of life."
There were two poets in residence, Naomi Shihab Nye, who has published two books of verse and a number of children's books and has appeared on several PBS and National Public Radio shows, and Thomas Lux, who teaches at Sarah Lawrence College and has published his poems widely and won several awards and fellowships. They said they were receiving an increasing number of invitations to appear at workshops; Mr. Lux said he was attending four this summer.
"I have a theory on why adults are writing more poetry," he said. "They're usually very accomplished people who've wanted to get back to the 60's or whatever, and now they have a chance to do that. They have the time and they have the money, and the interest hasn't gone away."
My own poems did improve considerably from the peanut butter-smeared face of the first day, even if they did not ascend the emotional summits. Perhaps most satisfying was an exercise in which I had to use both Muhammad Ali and cooking in a poem. I turned it into a lesson, in which the whimsical and inventive boxer taught me how to cook for my children, persuading me in the process that although I had believed I cooked quite well and that my children were well fed, they were, in fact, hungry -- a verse, of course, about my metaphorical efforts to refresh my use of language. Well, it was a start.
Ken Karman, the music editor who was my classmate, had turned the trip into a family experience. His wife took a painting class, and his teen-age son was studying electric bass. He said he felt he had almost no facility with words and was awkward in the first exercises without anything very clear to say.
But on our final morning he suddenly blurted out that right then and there he had written a poem and was eager to read it. It was a jazzlike verse about his father, as a philandering hipster in a two-seat sports car, and the impression he had made on the child.
"I think you caught a fish," Ms. Woloch said.

HEADLINE: With Concerts and Web Site, U.N. Agency Attacks Poverty

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Bidding to fight poverty with music and megabits, the United Nations Development Program and Cisco Systems Inc., the No. 1 maker of data communications gear, have enlisted a dozen popular entertainers to kick off an Internet-based initiative to help the world's poor.
The new project, called Netaid, appears to represent the most extensive partnership the United Nations has ever formed with private enterprise in trying to relieve poverty in the developing world. The development program is casting about for ways to advance its anti-poverty mission even as countries including Denmark and Germany have slashed their contributions to the agency. 
 Cisco, which makes makes much of the complex communications equipment that forms the synapses of cyberspace, has agreed to underwrite the Netaid project with assistance from KPMG, the consulting firm, and Akamai Technologies, an Internet communications company. Cisco and KPMG have each agreed to spend up to $20 million on the project, according to people close to the companies.
"It's not unprecedented in that we on many fronts are starting to engage with the private sector," said Mark Malloch Brown, who took over as administrator of the U.N.D.P. last month after serving as a vice president of the World Bank. "However, there has been nothing attempted on this scale and of this ambition before. For us, this is a quantum step up from the previous level of collaboration with the private sector."
Netaid's public debut is scheduled for Oct. 9, when the group will stage overlapping concerts at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N. J., Wembley Stadium in London and the Palais des Nations in Geneva featuring musicians including Jimmy Page, Pete Townshend and Jewel. The MTV and VH1 cable television channels have agreed to televise the concerts in the United States; the British Broadcasting Corporation will televise them in Britain.
But Cisco and Mr. Malloch Brown say that Netaid is not just another charity telethon. The heart of Netaid is not the concerts, they say, but a Web site (www.netaid.org) being created to allow people around the world to participate in antipoverty efforts long after the music is over.
The Web site will be intended to allow, say, a church group in Iowa to make contact with a needy church in Indonesia. The U.N.D.P. plans to work with nongovernmental organizations to develop the site.
"The money raised is not the measure of success of this project," Mr. Malloch Brown said in an interview yesterday. "This is organized very differently from the earlier things like We Are the World or Live Aid, which were intended to meet the immediate knee-jerk fund-raising potential of the event. For me, the money will come, but it will come out of building a very large group of people in the millions who will keep coming back to the issues through the Web site."
He added, "People who write their Congressman or organize a local chapter of Oxfam will be making at least as significant and perhaps more significant contribution than someone who writes a $15 check."
The others scheduled to appear at the Netaid concerts are Bush, the Corrs, Counting Crows, Celine Dion, the Eurythmics with Annie Lennox, Wyclef Jean with Bono, Michael Kamen and Orchestra, George Michael and Robbie Williams. It is not clear which artists will appear at which concerts. Netaid plans to add a few more artists to the lineup.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Blockbuster Closes at Its Offering Price

BYLINE: By Bridge News 

 BODY:
Shares of Blockbuster Inc. closed unchanged yesterday from the offering price after the video rental chain's $465 million initial public stock offering, reflecting investors' view of the company as a well-known name offering few surprises.
Blockbuster priced 31 million shares at $15 each, below the expected range of $16 to $18 on Tuesday. 
 The Dallas-based Blockbuster has about 6,500 stores in 27 countries. Blockbuster's stores captured a 27 percent market share in the United States in 1998, according to an industry estimate from Paul Kagan Associates.
It plans to open approximately 1,500 new company-operated United States stores by 2001, with 200 new franchise stores. International expansion plans call for 170 new company-operated stores and 125 franchises over the next three years.
The market for initial offerings has been less than receptive in recent weeks as the flow of deals has begun to smother buyer interest and the stock market in general is weighed down with interest rate fears.
Blockbuster was carved out of the media and entertainment group Viacom Inc., which bought it in 1994. Blockbuster has been in operation since 1985.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Many LatinStocks Leave Home, Trading on Wall Street

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 11

 BODY:
For the first time since he started trading stocks 16 years ago, Helio Ozaki, the chief trader at a small securities firm here, is shifting his focus to Manhattan. His firm is planning to move much of its trading of Brazilian shares to the New York Stock Exchange because declining volume and high transaction costs have sapped much of the activity on the local stock market.
"This is one of the most melancholic times of my career," said Mr. Ozaki, 40, in an interview at his trading desk on Avenida Paulista, a skyscraper strip that is the Wall Street of Sao Paulo, Brazil's financial capital. "Foreigners have lost their interest in the Brazilian market, and we Brazilians are being forced to trade our own stocks in the United States." 
 Since Brazil's Government imposed a tax on financial transactions in June, volume on the Sao Paulo Stock Exchange, Latin America's largest market, has dropped by a third. With many banks and brokerage firms opting to trade in international centers like New York and London, the Sao Paulo market has become a victim of a trend that has spread through Latin America in the 1990's.
While markets like the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq are thriving, and even considering issuing shares to the public, their counterparts in Latin America are struggling to survive. The institutions in the region once synonymous with capitalism could fall prey to the volatile capital flows that once fueled their success.
"This is what happens when the migration of capital turns so free," said Ivan Sant'Anna, 58, who left a career as a trader in the Brazilian and United States markets to become an author of novels of financial intrigue.
One of the most telling indicators of the problems faced by Latin markets is a region-wide plunge in trading volume. After swelling when foreign interest in Latin equities reached a peak in mid-1997, volume has fallen in markets from Bogota to Buenos Aires.
From July 1997 to July 1999, the average daily trading volume on the Sao Paulo exchange fell by 75 percent, in Mexico City by 48 percent, in Lima by 69 percent, in Buenos Aires by 37 percent and in Bogota by 74 percent, according to Economatica, an economic research firm here.
Some smaller exchanges, like the Maracaibo stock market in Venezuela, have shut down. Others, like the 156-year-old Rio de Janeiro exchange have made radical changes to stay alive. Last month, the Rio exchange switched from the old-fashioned auction system with screaming floor traders to an electronic trading system similar to the Nasdaq.
This is not the first time Latin America's stock exchanges have suffered a decline in business. Over the years, they have been subject to swings between euphoria and despair.
"Similar phenomena occurred in 1914 with massive capital flight out of Brazil to Europe to help fund the First World War," said Gail Triner, an economic historian at Rutgers University.
Yet there are signs that this latest bout with fickle money flows may test Latin markets in new ways.
Transnational corporate takeovers have rocked some exchanges. When Repsol of Spain acquired YPF S.A. of Argentina earlier this year, it chose to delist the big oil company from the Buenos Aires market. In one swoop, the exchange lost one of its largest companies and about 15 percent of its market capitalization.
Another factor is the proliferation of American depository receipts, or A.D.R.'s. These securities represent shares of foreign stocks that can be traded in the United States. Foreign companies can also raise money in United States markets by issuing new A.D.R.'s. And there are similar securities called global depository receipts that can be listed on stock exchanges in other financial centers, like London.
Latin America's largest companies have increasingly used these securities in the last few years, starting in 1990 with the region's first A.D.R., from Compania de Telecomunicaciones de Chile. There are now 95 Latin A.D.R.'s listed on the New York Stock Exchange and a handful more on Nasdaq, according to Guzman & Company, a Miami-based securities firm.
"The growth of A.D.R.'s happened after companies sensed they could widen their investor base," said Leo Guzman, the firm's president.
Many of these securities were listed in the mid-1990's, when much of Latin America, aside from Mexico, was buoyed by strong flows of foreign investment into local stock markets. With business going well, resistance to this trend, and others that strained local exchanges, was not that strong. That has changed.
"It is worrisome that the authorities are standing by while the capital markets of this country are being squeezed," said Alfredo Rizkallah, the president of the Sao Paulo Stock Exchange, which is known as the Bovespa.
Nowhere are the problems of Latin America's stock markets more apparent now than in Brazil. Last week, the Bovespa's 300 floor traders halted dealings for half an hour to protest the shift in business to the New York Stock Exchange, where costs are cheaper largely because of the financial-transaction tax here. The traders received support from their brokerage houses and the administration of the stock exchange.
The tax on almost all financial transactions is part of the Government's effort to contain the budget deficit, a piece of discipline that is a critical component of an aid agreement with the International Monetary Fund that has helped stabilize Brazil since the currency crisis in January.
Over one year, the Government hopes to collect about $9 billion from the tax, which has proved easier to collect than income tax or many corporate taxes, since the banking system is closely regulated by the central bank.
The tax shows another weakness that has contributed to troubles at Brazilian stock exchanges: the deficit. Since Brazil has had difficulty reining in public spending, many investors have cut their holdings of Brazilian securities because they feel this stifles economic growth. The deficit also contributes to a low domestic savings rate, which translates into less capital to invest in stocks.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
The Traffic Congestion Strangling New York

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

 BODY:
People on California's central coast have decided that gridlock and congestion just do not mesh well with their life style.
Last week the Santa Cruz County Regional Transportation Commission approved a plan to put five miles of high-occupancy/toll (HOT) lanes on Highway 1. While those in carpools, buses and vans would ride in the designated lanes free of charge, solo motorists would pay a variable toll that would be higher during rush hours and lower in the off-peak. Like similar lanes in San Diego and Houston, the HOT lanes would free space in general-purpose lanes. Toll revenue would help finance the lanes. 
 In the New York metropolitan area, the vast majority of folks seem content to spend large chunks of their waking hours inhaling fumes in bumper-to-bumper traffic and using their vehicles as some kind of mobile study outfitted with books on tape, cell phones and CD's. Local radio and television stations nowadays cover rush hour in the region as if gridlock were a natural phenomenon beyond human control, right up there with Nor'easters. Some people even see clogged streets as an indicator of prosperity -- great for the economy and the area's future.
This mindset does not augur well for that future. Travel times in the region are 40 percent longer than they would be if traffic flowed freely, according to the Texas Transportation Institute, which reviewed 1996 data from 70 metropolitan regions. Fuel wasted annually in traffic jams amounts to 51 gallons per capita and 63 gallons per driver. Congestion's cost -- adding the price of delay and wasted gas -- makes the New York region second in the nation in dollars squandered, wasting $9.8 billion in 1996, just behind Los Angeles.
This is not, of course, a new problem. A mid-1980's congestion study clocked the average commute to Manhattan from eight communities, all of them a mere 15 miles away. Under free-flow conditions, reaching Manhattan took anywhere from 20 minutes (Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn) or 21 minutes (Yonkers) to no more than 34 minutes (Little Neck, Queens). Rush-hour trips from these points took anywhere from a maximum of 47 minutes (Yonkers) to 49 minutes (Sheepshead Bay) or 1 hour 10 minutes (Little Neck). Things have only gotten worse since then.
More and better rapid transit -- a new trans-Hudson commuter tube from the west, a new subway on Manhattan's East Side and improved rail service from the other directions -- would surely help. Cutting aid for new roads and sewers and other incentives that promote sprawl and auto use is another good idea. But these ideas, which take years to institute, have yet to make the jump from press release to firm policy.
Political leaders ought to declare rush-hour road space a scarce, underpriced commodity, similar to the services utilities offer. Power and telecommunications companies use peak and off-peak prices to vary the cost of their products and modulate demand. Similarly, there should be variable tolls on some stretches of road and major bridges and tunnels, higher at rush hour and lower when fewer cars are on the roads. At the very least, the region should experiment with variable tolls on all or most of the bridges and tunnels leading to Manhattan -- including the toll-free bridges on the East River, which charged a fee until Mayor William Gaynor removed the tolls early in the century.
Regrettably, neither the Governors of New York and New Jersey nor the Mayor of New York City seem eager to let market forces rule rush hour, even though all three are Republicans and, presumably, believers in the market's wisdom. The only congestion-pricing experiment in the region is a modest one for trucks on the Tappan Zee Bridge.
The New York region has spent the last decade ducking opportunities to use variable pricing, despite Federal mandates to produce cleaner air and the area's thirst for more jobs. Those needs, plus the quality-of-life gains that smoother traffic would bring, should persuade local politicians to give market forces a try.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Big Companies Back a New Web Site Aimed at Blacks

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
A group of big media and technology companies has agreed to back BET Holdings, which operates several black-oriented cable television stations, in establishing an elaborate Internet service aimed at black Americans.
BET has raised $35 million for the project from the Microsoft Corporation, USA Networks, the News Corporation and AT&T's Liberty Media unit, which is a minority owner of BET. The service, which is known as BET.Com, is scheduled to be introduced on Nov. 1 and will replace the company's existing joint venture with Microsoft, MSBET. 
 While the earlier site mainly focused on links to programming on BET's Black Entertainment Television network, the new site will have a broader range of offerings including news, E-mail, shopping and -- most important -- chat rooms and other features to help build a community within the World Wide Web site.
So far, blacks have been less active on the Internet than has the overall population. Forrester Research estimates that 23 percent of the 12 million black households are on line, compared with 34 percent of white households. But on-line use by blacks is increasing faster, Forrester notes.
"Until now, African-Americans have found the Internet hard to use, expensive and at the end of the day they said 'There's nothing here for me,' " said Robert L. Johnson, the chairman and majority owner of BET. "We're going to change that."
Mr. Johnson said the audience was poised to increase now that the price of computers and Internet access had fallen sharply and in some cases could be had free.
The company hopes to make money by selling advertising and by selling merchandise, including urban apparel, black-oriented music and collectible items.
The BET venture will compete with several existing sites aimed at blacks, all of which are backed by major media companies. The largest is Blackvoices.com, an offering of the Tribune Company, which says it serves 500,000 users a month who look at a total of 14 million pages. Net Noir (www.Netnoir.com), which is 20 percent owned by America Online, is a close second. Blackfamilies.com is another and is operated by Cox Communications.
E. David Ellington, the chairman of Net Noir, said tht he was not worried about the BET venture, despite the company's well-known name and the promotional power of its television network.
"This is a new medium and it needs new brands," he said. "Name a big media company that has done well on the Web."
Mr. Ellington said that Net Noir was raising $10 million to $15 million from venture capital funds and that it was about to add new features to its site.
Barry Cooper, the president of Blackvoices.com, said that the Tribune Company was considering selling a portion of the Internet service to raise money to compete with BET.
"If it takes $35 million to stay at the top, we'll raise $35 million," he said.
Mr. Cooper said Blackvoices.com had found limited success trying to sell advertising and merchandise on line.
"African-Americans are new to the Internet, and to expect them to give their credit cards on line is a bit of a stretch," he said. The company has found a profitable niche selling job listings from large companies that are seeking to attract a diverse work force. Serving this need works well with the largest group of blacks Internet users: office workers who surf at their jobs.
Mr. Johnson, however, said that BET expected that its consumers would ultimately shop on line and that the service could help enable a new group of black entrepreneurs to find ways to sell their products on line.
"There is tremendous wealth being created in the Internet economy that African-Americans should be a part of," he said. "The Internet can give us the opportunity to control our own destiny by cutting out the middle man."

HEADLINE: Solomon Dutka, 75, Founder Of Marketing Research Firm

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
Solomon Dutka, who started a marketing research firm in a one-room office in New York City in 1953 that grew into one of the largest companies in the industry, died on Saturday at his home in Riverdale, the Bronx.
Mr. Dutka, who was 75, was the chairman of Audits and Surveys Worldwide, with operations in more than 90 countries. His death was caused by complications from a stroke, the company said. 
 Mr. Dutka was born in the Bronx on Nov. 5, 1923, the son of a tailor. He graduated from City College with degrees in mathematical statistics and physics before joining the United States Army during World War II. While in the armed forces, Mr. Dutka worked as a nuclear physicist on the Manhattan Project, which earned him a citation from the Secretary of War for his efforts.
He began his career in marketing research with a teaching position at Columbia University. He became the chief statistician at Dun & Bradstreet and Elmo Roper Associates before leaving to start a business first called Audits and Surveys Inc.
The company eventually grew into one of the most respected firms of its type, representing clients like the Coca-Cola Company and the Xerox Corporation.
Audits and Surveys became a publicly traded company in 1994 and was acquired by the London-based United News Media earlier this year. Mr. Dutka continued to serve as the chairman after the acquisition.
He wrote books and articles on research methodologies and their practical applications. In a 1996 commencement address to the graduate school of Baruch College, he warned the new graduates of the dangers of conventional thinking.
Mr. Dutka served as an American statistical associate delegate to the United Nations subcommittee on statistical sampling and was a member of the United States Census Advisory Committee. He was a fellow of the American Statistical Association and of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
He was also a past president of the Market Research Council, a trade group, which presented him with its 1984 Hall of Fame Award for his contributions to the practice of market research.
Mr. Dutka also served on the boards of Daytop Village, a narcotics treatment center; the Neurosciences Institute, and numerous other social, scientific, academic and cultural organizations.
He is survived by his wife, Joyce; two sons, James of Santa Monica, Calif., and Michael of Doylestown, Pa., and three stepsons, David Fried of Montpelier, Vt.; Barry Fried of Makawao, Hawaii, and Stephen Fried of New York.

HEADLINE: Clinton to Seek Using Farm Products in Lieu of Fossil Fuel

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
President Clinton will announce a long-term effort on Thursday to help replace coal, oil, natural gas and uranium with farm products, crop wastes and trees to make things as diverse as electricity, pharmaceuticals and car fuel and forks.
In an executive order, the President will set a goal of working with various industries to triple the amount of energy generated from such products by 2010. The order, White House officials said, will also instruct the Secretaries of Agriculture and Energy and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to write plans to coordinate research, create markets and take other steps to nurture "renewable technologies." 
 The Administration also plans to develop proposals for research grants and tax credits to promote such technologies.
Administration officials predict that developing more uses for agricultural products will result in $15 billion to $20 billion in additional farm income by 2010 and less use of imported oil.
"Essentially all of society in the last 100 years has been built on petroleum as the energy and raw material," said a participant in the effort, Dr. Robert R. Dorsch, director of biotechnology development at Du Pont.
"We need to go from black gold to green gold," Mr. Dorsch said.
Du Pont is working on an improved polyester based on natural sugars instead of petroleum, and is hoping that with Federal research money and coordination, the price of such sugars will fall.
Other companies that have been working with the Government over the last nine months contend that motor fuels, solvents and electricity can be made from natural materials, known as biomass, on a cost-effective basis, with a reduction in pollution. The discussions have included major companies in agriculture, chemicals, oil, natural gas and forestry, as well as genetic engineering and other high-tech companies.
"We're looking at taking things we currently just throw away, making them profitable, fighting global warming and cleaning the environment at the same time," said Roger Ballentine, the deputy assistant to the President for environmental initiatives.
Vice President Al Gore, who has emphasized Federal promotion of new technology as well as environmentalism and support for farmers, said today in a telephone interview that the initiative would "help insure that the agricultural economy is part of the new economy."
The Vice President said that the effort did not yet involve allocating money but that some money would be redirected from other programs, mostly in the Energy and Agriculture Departments. More Federal attention could encourage use of natural materials, he said, and would be "a very significant step forward."
Past efforts to use natural materials have been stymied in part by falling prices for oil and natural gas. But proponents of the idea say the drive to reduce pollution and technological advances in biology and materials science will help them.
Biomass now accounts for about 3 percent of national energy use, including processes as simple as home heating with wood.
Some agricultural processing companies expect big markets if they can make new products that have environmental benefits, at equal cost. Cargill Inc., for example, has a venture with Dow Chemical to produce polylactic acid, a polymer that can be used instead of petroleum-based products like polystyrene in insulated cups, and polyethylene in soft drink bottles. The acid can also be used for garbage bags or for clothing fibers. Unlike plastics, it breaks down completely in a compost heap.
"It could be made from any kind of organic biomass," said Robert R. Parmelee, president of bioscience division of Cargill.
Polylactic acid is now made from sugar from corn kernels and other high-value products, but with a few technical advances it could be made from parts of the plant with lower value or none at all, like corn stalks, Mr. Parmelee said.
"Over time, if you really want to make this big, then raw material costs are going to have to come down," he said.
The Government is already involved in many biomass projects, but the participants see greater potential. For example, the Energy Department contributed $1.3 million to pay for equipment at the Northern Indiana Power Company's Bailly Generating Station in Burns Harbor to mix wood chips with the coal. The result was less nitrogen oxide, which contributes to smog, less sulfur dioxide, which makes acid rain, and less carbon dioxide, which is believed to cause climate change. But the company would like to try a different system of using wood, cooking it into a gas that can be burned at very high efficiencies in a turbine, said Arthur E. Smith, Jr., the environmental officer at Nisource, which is Northern Indiana's corporate parent.

HEADLINE: Drought Forces Farmers Into Unprofitable Livestock Sales

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: MONTEREY, Va., Aug. 11

 BODY:
The endless bawling of calves being separated from their mothers sounded doubly pitiful today here at the auction block. For the cattle ranchers were hurting, too, as they unloaded their livestock at an emergency sale in order to cut their mounting losses from the deepening drought.
"Out of water, out of grass," said Swanson Dowling, one of the local ranchers who came by all day to the Monterey Livestock Sales auction yard to commiserate with one another and reluctantly shed large parts of their herds, which are proving increasingly expensive to maintain given the searing heat and the lack of rainfall. 
 The emergency sales this month and last in some of the hardest-hit areas of Virginia and West Virginia are providing a graphic measure of the economic impact of the drought gripping the nation's Eastern farm belt.
"I estimate we'll lose 10 percent of the state's 21,000 farms," said Gus R. Douglass, the Commissioner of Agriculture in West Virginia, where the entire state -- like all of Connecticut and parts of New York, Virginia and four other Eastern states -- has been declared a Federal farm disaster area.
"We're having a most unusual mass marketing of livestock all through the drought region," Mr. Douglass said, adding that "35 percent of our water wells have failed" in West Virginia. He noted that the state had been forced to start laying pipe to tap into emergency flood control dams in the areas suffering the most and to haul water in by National Guard tankers.
The severity of the conditions varies widely across the drought-hit Middle Atlantic States. In Pennsylvania, the nation's fourth-largest dairy state, milk production is down at least 20 percent because of the drought, according to state agricultural monitors. Estimates of losses in basic crops like corn, soybeans, feed hay and garden vegetables vary from 30 percent to 100 percent across the state, said Bob Bunty, spokesman for the Pennsylvania Agriculture Department.
In Maryland, where farmers are searching for ever more costly feed beyond their seared fields, the state is instituting a cover crop program in an effort to retain moisture and prevent soil erosion. Under the program, emergency plantings of barley, rye and winter wheat will be undertaken with 87 percent state financing -- provided that enough ground moisture arrives by autumn planting time.
"Our main concern now is that the pasture land in central Maryland is all burned out and our farmers are already dipping into winter supplies," said Harold Kanarek of the State Agriculture Department. "We had droughts in '97 and '98, and this might be the one that pushes farmers over the edge," Mr. Kanarek said of the fears of failure among hundreds of the state's 12,000 farms.
There is nothing new under the sun about the risks and vagaries of the agricultural industry. East of here, there are wineries anticipating a bumper crop of grapes that are sweetening beautifully now in the relentless blaze of the summer.
But here in the rich Shenandoah region, vital pastures glare fallow in endless swaths of yellow worthy of van Gogh, long burnt out by the 14-month-old drought. Feed intended for winter use is already running short, and water is being hauled. No end of the drought is predicted, and ranchers warn that problems can compound: free-flowing water is healthiest for stock, while ponds and other still waters that are now the emergency resort increase the risk of disease.
"I sold a $100 ton of hay for $150 here two weeks ago," said Kenny Hoffman, a buyer from Columbia City, Ind., who brought the hay in when he came to bid at the emergency cattle auctions. "That farmer turned around and sold it for $200. That's how bad things are here."
And Mr. Dowling, a rancher for 25 years, said: "There's never been a time like this. Old-timers are saying not since the dust-bowl days of the 30's."
Normally calves far fatter and more profitable would come to auction in the autumn. But ranchers are being forced either to run up more debt by buying feed and hauling in water or to cull their herds earlier and far more deeply than usual.
The immediate result is a price perhaps $100 less than a calf would typically fetch, or about $3,200 less for Mr. Dowling's yearlings. The owner of a larger ranch just over the state line in West Virginia suffered a $40,000 loss in similarly having to cut corners.
Beyond the calf sales, the longer-range threat is that ranchers like Mr. Dowling are also being forced to sell their mature cows and bulls -- as much as two-thirds of his basic 40-head herd, he said. They thus reduce their reproductive inventory and their ability to rebound well from the drought. Indeed, Mr. Douglass, the West Virginia Agriculture Commissioner, said this forced culling meant that genetic lines of the ranchers' foundation herds would be damaged well after the return of the rains.
"The only thing surviving out there is the chicken industry," Mr. Douglass said. "But their wells are starting to go dry, and that could create a domino effect."
For example, West Virginia may be forced to consider curtailing water to a principal chicken processing factory in Moorefield, a town on the Potomac River, in order to guarantee good water to communities downstream. This could affect 1,700 slaughterhouse workers, which, in turn, could crimp the livelihood of hundreds of poultry broiler growers.
In Maryland, the region's chief poultry state, officials say the large agribusiness producers are weathering the drought so far with no threat to production. These companies have multiple deep wells, but officials are nonetheless tracking them, given rainfall in the last year 14 inches below normal for the region.
Back here in Monterey, "we've never moved anywhere near this amount of livestock in July and August," said Sherry Sullenberger, manager of the Monterey Livestock Sales auction yard, which has put on three emergency sales, with others scattered all about the Virginias. "But our hay crop is probably less than half of what it should be. Some farmers have even come in and gotten rid of all their sheep. Some are going to have to go out of business."
Out in the yard, truck after truck arrived with cattle to be auctioned to buyers mainly from the West, where ranchers hit hard by drought two years ago are buying to rebuild their herds.
"It's grim around here," said one bidder, a middleman who uses video and cell phones in handling sales. "These ranchers are so discouraged. Their calves are averaging 100 to 200 pounds lighter than usual, and they know they can only dip into herd assets for so long for a problem that's been running nonstop for 14 months."
Nearby, some of the ranchers in leather chaps stared morosely as they prodded and shouted the cattle into the auction pens in a hot, dusty scene marked above all by the bawling of calves.

HEADLINE: Anxiety in Amex's Smaller Pond;
Can N.A.S.D. Save It? What if It Goes Public? Stay Tuned

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
If the New York Stock Exchange successfully converts itself to a public corporation later this year, as it plans, the owners of its 1,366 seats will get shares of the new company that might ultimately be worth as much as several million dollars a seat.
If the American Stock Exchange, after the Big Board the nation's second-largest auction market for stocks, follows suit, its 864 members will be legally entitled to -- well, nothing. 
 The members sold their stake in the Amex last year when they approved its acquisition by the National Association of Securities Dealers, which also owns the Nasdaq stock market. In return, they mostly got promises, including the critical assurance that the N.A.S.D. would make $110 million in overdue technology improvements that the exchange could not afford on its own.
The seat owners "weren't thinking in terms of an I.P.O.," said John T. Sullivan of Charlotte, N.C., who leases out the Amex seat that he owns. "We were thinking in terms of survival. We needed that infusion of capital. We needed that technology." An initial public offering "was a pie-in-the-sky notion at the time; our view was, first things first," he added.
To appreciate the galloping uncertainty at the nation's stock exchanges these days -- uncertainty that is driven by new competitors, new technology and escalating investor demands -- one need look no further than the desperate past and unpredictable future of the American Stock Exchange.
Just a year ago, the Amex seemed to face such daunting odds that its members agreed to give up their ownership stake to gain access to the money necessary to stay competitive. Today, other markets around the world, including Nasdaq and the Big Board, are betting they can raise money by selling ownership stakes to public investors.
Frank G. Zarb, the chief executive of the N.A.S.D., says that within the next two years even the long-struggling Amex -- the perennial also-ran in the stock market sweepstakes -- could get a new lease on life and fresh capital by being spun off as a publicly traded company.
But that optimistic vision assumes that the N.A.S.D. can first conquer the problems that caused the exchange to rush into its arms in the first place: outdated trading technology, a dearth of new equity listings and an uncertain market niche. If the association fails -- as some Amex members fear it will if core weaknesses in the market's equity trading are not addressed quickly -- there may be little for former seat owners to squabble over.
By one measure, at least, the Amex is thriving. Seat prices have increased by nearly 60 percent in the 17 months since the N.A.S.D. deal was announced, more than twice the percentage gain in the price of Big Board seats during that time.
But the number of listings has drifted relentlessly down, from 822 in January 1995 to 772 last January to just 761 more recently. That is barely a quarter of the number of Big Board listings and less than a fifth the number of listings on Nasdaq. And the annual Amex trading volume, roughly 7.3 billion shares, is utterly dwarfed by the multibillion-share volume at its two bigger rivals.
The American Stock Exchange was born in the mid-19th century as the New York Curb Market, a loose affiliation of brokers who gathered outdoors in lower Manhattan to trade stocks that were not listed on the New York Stock Exchange.
Like the N.Y.S.E., the Amex is an auction market, where traders gather on a central trading floor to bargain openly for shares of each listed stock. From the first, it was the home of stocks that did not meet the stiffer financial standards for listing on the Big Board. That remained its primary identity until the debut, in 1971, of Nasdaq, a decentralized "dealer market" in which market makers, linked by phones and computer screens, buy from sellers at one price and sell to buyers at a higher price, profiting on the markup.
The Amex tried to diversify. In 1975, it introduced trading in stock options, and by the early 1980's options trading had become a thriving business. But by then its traditional stock market business was being increasingly eclipsed by Nasdaq, especially among the technology companies that have become so important to the modern economy.
Again, the Amex tried to supplement its lagging equity business with creativity. In the early 1990's, it established a strong presence in equity derivatives. Today, it conducts robust trading in more than four dozen equity-linked products, from unit investment trusts meant to track various Standard & Poor's indexes to a new "tracking stock" that mimics the Nasdaq 100 index.
But despite its successes -- it is the nation's second-ranking options market, after the Chicago Board Options Exchange -- the Amex remains heavily dependent on its equity trading business to pay its bills. And by late 1997, that business was a chronic invalid, too weak to generate the amounts of money the Amex would need to upgrade electronic trading systems that were, by that point, as much as a decade old.
By early March 1998, leaders of the Amex were negotiating the details of the N.A.S.D. deal, which had a structure only Rube Goldberg could love. The N.A.S.D. set up a subsidiary holding company, which controls a new limited liability company, Amex L.L.C., which acquired the assets of the old American Stock Exchange from its members.
The exchange members were granted certain rights, including trading privileges, of course, and a voice in any major changes in the trading structure on which their livelihoods depend. Members also got a right of first refusal if Amex L.L.C. is ever put up for sale, provided they can match the best competing offer.
Most important, the members were promised that N.A.S.D. would invest up to $110 million in the exchange.
That promise is being kept in ways that will soon become obvious to everyone, said Salvatore F. Sodano, the N.A.S.D. chief financial officer, who is acting president of the Amex. "It is probably a two-year project for everything we want to get implemented," Mr. Sodano said. "But we have made some pretty significant strides in moving the institution along in a short period of time."
Roughly $30 million worth of technology upgrades are already in the works, Mr. Sodano said. These include a faster and vastly more versatile electronic system to display and track pending stock orders at specific prices and a new order-routing system for equities and options that will sharply increase the capacity on the options floor, Mr. Sodano said.
Beyond technology, the Amex plans to set up a service desk to deal with its trading firms' problems, and it will soon hire a senior-level sales executive to oversee efforts to attract more listed companies and retain those already listed.
Moreover, in an aggressive bid for orders from brokers who serve individual investors, it is permitting any retail order of fewer than 2,100 shares to trade on the floor at no charge. Investors are demanding low-cost trading, Mr. Sodano said, "and it is tough to beat 'free.' "
So far this year, he said, 40 to 45 companies have listed on the exchange, compared with about 50 new listings in all of 1998. "And we have a pipeline of more than a hundred companies waiting to list," he said. "If all goes well -- and they are all real good companies -- we will have 150 new listings by the end of the year."
That would help offset the steady loss in listings as companies merge or move to other exchanges. But people working with the exchange, which has suffered through some major scandals in its life, say management is still wrestling to bring the regulatory machinery up to speed, a problem that must be resolved before there is any substantial surge in new listings.
That will further disappoint people who had expected the N.A.S.D. to usher in a more effective pursuit of new Amex listings, without which its trading floor cannot prosper. The continued growth in Nasdaq's listings adds to the apparent bitterness that some traders express.
Among those skeptical of the efforts being made to improve the core stock-trading operation is Andrew Schwarz, a specialist on the Amex and a former member of its board of governors.
"Our equity business was broken and needed to be fixed," he. "Unfortunately, that has not been fixed yet, and the floor was, and continues to be, unhappy about that situation."
He favors establishing segments of the Amex market to match the existing segments in the Nasdaq market, the National Market System and the Small-Cap Market, with each Amex marketplace ready to list any company that wants to move from the corresponding Nasdaq lineup. The Amex could set up a market where even unlisted "Bulletin Board" stocks could benefit from auction trading, he suggested, so long as any companies that proved dubious were promptly kicked out.
"If you go back to the basics of what Frank Zarb promised -- that companies on the Nasdaq would be given a choice between the dealer market and the auction market -- that hasn't happened," Mr. Schwarz said. "We still get hung up on miles of red tape and listing standards."
He argues that the Amex can survive and prosper only if it returns to its roots and once again becomes the auction market for companies too small for the Big Board. Only then, he added, does it make sense to speculate about what a publicly traded Amex might be worth, and to whom.
"How does one predict the future when the environment is changing as fast as it is?" Mr. Schwarz asked as he questioned who would dare buy shares in a stock exchange. "If you look at the last 50 years, there has been more change in the last 2 years than in the previous 48."
While members are hoping for a turnaround that could make the Amex more valuable, such a success might also intensify the bickering over any profits from a spinoff.
The N.A.S.D. acquisition of the Amex was "a bloodless coup," said William B. Astrop of Atlanta, the owner of two Big Board seats and one seat on the Amex. Estimating that an Amex seat might be worth as much as $1 million in a public offering, Mr. Astrop predicted that "there are going to be some unhappy seat owners when it dawns on them that they are left out totally, that there is no payday, no windfall."
Some members acquainted with terms of the acquisition wonder whether the right of first refusal if the N.A.S.D. sells the Amex could become a lever for disgruntled members to pry a share of the proceeds out of the new owner of the exchange.
Mr. Astrop, who gives Mr. Zarb extremely high marks for the progress that has been made, nevertheless says that seat owners might "get their dander up" if the Amex was sold in a way that "was viewed as being high-handed." He mused, "If we made a big enough fuss, Mr. Zarb might toss us a bone just to keep us quiet."
For his part, Mr. Zarb said that it was "legally debatable" whether the old Amex members could claim any of the proceeds from an Amex sale or stock offering. "But practically, an unfriendly transaction would be very, very unlikely," Mr. Zarb insisted. "Who would want to own an institution that doesn't have a wholesome, happy set of practitioners?"

HEADLINE: Fed Report Seems to Take Edge Off Worries on Rates

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
The economy is expanding with little sign of inflation, the Federal Reserve said today in its latest regional report card, taking the edge off investor expectations that the central bank would raise interest rates again soon.
The survey, which is produced eight times a year and is based on reports from the Fed's 12 district banks, cited expanding manufacturing, strength in retail sales and construction, and rising loan demand as evidence that the economy was not slowing much. That leaves the current expansion on track to set a record for longevity early next year. 
 At the same time, the Fed said most regions of the country reported more jobs than workers to fill them. "Despite the labor shortages, none of the districts report evidence of any broad-based acceleration in wages," the report said. "There is no evidence of any broad-based pickup in consumer price inflation."
Tight labor markets were reported in most districts, the Fed said. "There are severe shortages of skilled construction workers in most districts," the report said.
Still, with little wage pressure, "consumer prices remain relatively stable despite some apparent intensification in input price pressures," the report said. Prices for construction materials, transportation and energy have been rising, it said.
"Retail sales, which had been robust in the second quarter, decelerated somewhat in July, in some cases due to low inventories of clearance merchandise," the report said. "Manufacturing activity continues to expand in most parts of the country, though a few districts indicate some softening."
The report, known as the beige book, will help form the basis for discussion on interest rate policy at the Aug. 24 meeting of the Fed's policy-setting Open Market Committee. Still, the anecdotal details of the report will not do a great deal to enlighten committee members, who will have already seen detailed statistics on employment and prices for July as well as internal Fed analyses of economic conditions.
"People have been saying a Fed tightening is a slam-dunk on Aug. 24, but it's not," said Diane Swonk, chief economist at the Bank One Corporation in Chicago.
The latest beige book underscores other reports that the economy is not slowing as much as the Fed had expected earlier this year.
The July employment report showed that the economy added 310,000 workers, after an increase of 273,000 in June, while hourly wages rose at the fastest pace in half a year. Unemployment stayed just a tenth of a point above the three-decade low of 4.2 percent earlier in the year.
That is just the mixture that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, warned about last month in his twice-yearly message to Congress.
"If new data suggest it is likely that the pace of cost and price increases will be picking up, the Federal Reserve will have to act promptly and forcefully" to raise interest rates, he told the House Banking Committee on July 22.
Inflation, however, has remained in check. The Consumer Price Index was unchanged in May and June after jumping seven-tenths of a percent in April. The core rate of the index, which excludes food and energy costs, rose just one-tenth of a percent the previous two months.
And that is a conundrum for the Fed. "At this particular moment, the underlying core cost structure of the economy is behaving, in my judgment, quite benignly," Mr. Greenspan said. "There is no immediate evidence that I can see that what we are dealing with is an incipient acceleration of core inflation."
