HEADLINE: Alcoa Seeks To Acquire A Competitor

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
In the second consolidation shock to hit the aluminum industry in two days, Alcoa Inc., the largest producer, said yesterday that it wanted to buy the Reynolds Metals Company, a troubled competitor that is nonetheless the third-largest player.
The announcement came a day after three huge Alcoa rivals -- Alcan Aluminium of Canada, Pechiney of France and the Alusuisse Lonza Group of Switzerland -- announced they intended to merge, creating a $21.6 billion behemoth called Alcan that would displace Alcoa, which had $15.5 billion in sales last year. All three foreign companies had been rumored to be talking to Reynolds themselves. 
 Reynolds said its board would discuss the offer on Sunday. But if Alcoa's proposal is accepted, the merged company's combined 1998 sales of $21.3 billion would put it back within breathing distance of the top spot. In fact, since the new Alcan would derive $17.4 billion of its sales from aluminum, Alcoa would remain the biggest company in the business.
While this merger flurry is big news on Wall Street, where both Reynolds and Alcoa shares rose yesterday, it is unlikely to have much impact on the consumers who buy Reynolds Wrap and other aluminum foils, or the automotive companies designing ever-more aluminum into their cars.
Even if the mergers result in fewer aluminum producers, aluminum itself is a basic commodity that is in in ample supply throughout the world.
"Neither of these mergers, assuming they go through, will have any impact on aluminum prices, or even on aluminum supply," said Leanne Baker, the metals analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. Even the heaviest users of aluminum seem unworried. "Aluminum is a market-driven commodity, so you've got to presume that the market will drive the price to wherever it is going to go," said Ronald H. Iori, a spokesman for the Ford Motor Company.
The deal may yet run into antitrust opposition. In December 1997 the Justice Department sued to prevent Alcoa from purchasing some of Reynolds' assets in Alabama, saying the purchase would result in higher prices. A day later, the companies abandoned the deal. "Since we looked at the previous proposal, it is likely we'll be looking at this one as well," said Gina Talamona, a spokeswoman for the Justice Department.
Still, analysts expect this proposal will survive regulatory scrutiny. In fact, some analysts suggested that the advent of two such big deals may help each one go through.
They reason is that the Justice Department is likely to look more favorably on a strengthened Alcoa, now that it has the prospect of a far bigger Alcan operating across the border in Montreal, while the European Union will want a bigger presence in the aluminum industry to fight the specter of a joined Alcoa and Reynolds.
Moreover, Alcoa and Reynolds are not mirror images. Reynolds, for example, is big in aluminum packaging, which Alcoa has shunned. Alcoa is a huge supplier of aluminum sheeting for cans; Reynolds divested that business a few years ago.
While aluminum producers cannot affect prices or supply by joining forces, they can reduce costs and thus increase the profit from every pound of aluminum they sell. That is something many need to do.
Aluminum prices have been badly depressed for a decade. First, the collapse of the Soviet economy led to heavy selling of aluminum by Russia, a huge aluminum producer, in a panicky quest for hard currency. At the same time, auto makers, aerospace companies and other huge consumers of aluminum were merging into global giants with more influence over what they would pay for aluminum, keeping prices low. The General Motors Corporation, for example, announced a multibillion-dollar 10-year contract with Alcan in November that provides a steady supply of the metal at a relatively stable price.
The result is that aluminum, which routinely sold for more than $1 a pound in the 1980's and often spiked far higher, costs 70 cents a pound or less now.
"Prices have been on such a steady downtrend that many companies were not even earning their cost of capital," said Warren Spitz, a portfolio manager at Prudential Investments, whose funds are heavily invested in both Alcoa and Reynolds shares. "This consolidation is hitting an industry that has had substandard profitability for at least a decade."
The news has not been all bad in the industry, of course. As economies in Asia and Latin America continue to recover, aluminum demand and prices are expected to increase, "although even getting to 75 cents would be worth a hallelujah," said James N. Kelleher, an analyst with Argus Research.
Aluminum producers have also succeeded in increasing industrial use of the metal in place of steel. Auto makers now use aluminum in transmissions, wheels, doors and roof racks. The popularity of four-wheel drives has been a boon for the aluminum makers, since the vehicles require two transmissions instead of one.
G.M. will use 1.7 billion pounds of aluminum in its cars and trucks this year; five years ago, that volume was 1.1 billion pounds. Last year G.M. cars and trucks contained an average of 275 pounds of aluminum; this year they contain 290 pounds.
"The use of aluminum has increased much faster than anyone had expected," said Daniel J. Bealko, G.M.'s global commodity manager for lightweight metals.
Still, the persistently low prices, combined with the huge number of plants producing aluminum have kept prices and profits low. Manufacturers have coped partly by shuttering older plants.
Alcoa, by far the lowest-cost producer, has been one of the few to remain solidly profitable. It also was one of the first to pursue mergers, buying Atlanta-based Alumax and three European aluminum companies in the last year. The company earned $2.42 a share last year. Charles L. Hill, director of research at the First Call Corporation, which tracks analysts stock recommendations, says that analysts predict it will earn $2.67 this year.
Reynolds, by contrast, has foundered. Last year it earned $3.47 a share; this year, analysts predict it will do $2.15 at best. In this year's first quarter, a bad one for the entire industry, Reynolds lost 15 cents a share.
Reynolds has spent the last three years trying to reorganize. It has cut costs by closing old plants and selling a number of operations deemed to be underperformers.
In 1977, revenue at Reynolds totaled $6.88 billion; this year, the figure is unlikely to hit $5 billion. But, that revenue will be heavily from packaging, construction, wheels and primary aluminum ingots, the businesses that have historically been Reynolds' best.
"If I were Jerry Sheehan, I'd be terribly frustrated right now," said Mr. Kelleher, the Argus analyst, referring to the Reynolds chairman, Jeremiah J. Sheehan. "He's got to feel, we've restructured this company, whipped it into shape, done the heavy lifting, and now Alcoa comes up with this."
Alcoa's offer was presented to Mr. Sheehan in a letter that Alcoa made public yesterday. The letter suggested an offer of half stock and half cash that amounted to about $5.8 billion, or $65 a share. Reynolds had rejected a merger overture from Alcoa in March, saying the price -- a combination stock-and-cash deal that had Alcoa paying about $60 a share for Reynolds stock -- was too low.
The price in the offer announced yesterday pushed Reynolds shares up $9.375, or 16.8 percent, to $65.25. Alcoa shares rose $2.9375, or 4.4 percent, to $69.375.
Still, turning down the March offer has cost Reynolds investors. The shares of both companies have increased in value, and if Reynolds had accepted stock from Alcoa, that deal would be valued today at about $94 a share.
Reynolds investors, in fact, have been pushing Reynolds to find a buyer for some time. Richard L. Grubman, an investor at Highfields Capital Management in Boston, which owns approximately 6.5 percent of Reynolds, wrote Mr. Sheehan a scathing letter in June, accusing him of "trying to buy time to execute a transaction best for you before being forced to pursue one that is best for us."
This time, Mr. Sheehan may have no choice but to accept the offer. Unlike Alcoa, which ranks high on many analysts' lists of recommended stocks, Reynolds rarely makes it on the Wall Street recommended buy lists.
"Analysts just do not like this stock," said Mr. Hill of First Call. Reynolds executives reportedly spent much of the spring speaking to all three of the companies involved in the Alcan merger, in hopes of finding a more generous buyer. None of them offered a sweeter deal, and now that they are caught up in their own merger, Alcoa is the only logical suitor left.
Alcoa is being advised by Credit Suisse First Boston. Merrill Lynch is working with Reynolds.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Markets Rebound Sharply, With the Nasdaq Gaining 3%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
After some early hesitation, stocks bounded higher yesterday as computer-related shares lifted the Nasdaq market by slightly more than 3 percent, its biggest gain in eight weeks.
Besides bargain hunting and a handful of surprisingly strong earnings reports, notably that of Cisco Systems, the main catalyst seemed to be a growing belief that interest rates might be approaching a peak. That notion seemed to spread in the afternoon when a Federal Reserve survey found "no evidence of any broad-based pickup" in consumer prices or in wages. 
 Rate jitters have bedeviled stock markets in recent weeks, with most analysts expecting the Federal Reserve to raise short-term rates by another quarter-point at its Aug. 24 meeting.
But after that, said Ned Riley Jr., chief investment officer at BankBoston, the pressure on stocks may subside. "Equity investors seem a bit more optimistic that rates will retreat after the Federal Open Market Committee" meeting, he said, noting that high-technology and financial stocks, which are among the most highly sensitive to rates, were pace setters yesterday.
Alfred Kugel, senior strategist at Stein Roe & Farnham, largely agreed. "If we have any more increases, it won't be a lot," he said. "The beige book put the icing on it," he added, referring to the Fed's eight-time-a-year survey that it uses to help make monetary policy.
Defying a recent series of broadly lower market days, more than three stocks advanced yesterday for each two that declined on the New York Stock Exchange, the best breadth since mid-July. Volume was a moderate 792.4 million shares, compared with 831.6 million on Tuesday.
Broadly based market gauges performed strongly. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 20.50 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,301.93, compared with the narrower Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 132.65 points, or 1.24 percent, to 10,787.80. The Nasdaq gained 74.87, or 3.01 percent, to 2,564.98.
Twenty of the 30 stocks in the Dow, the market benchmark, advanced.
J. P. Morgan, which was up 4 3/4, to 126 11/16, and I.B.M., up 4, to 123 5/16, accounted for one-third of the Dow's rise. Alcoa also posted a big gain, adding 2 15/16, to 69 3/8, after making a $5.6 billion bid for Reynolds Metals, which soared 9 3/8, to 65 1/4.
Drug stocks, which have been weighed down amid continuing fears of Federal legislation that would curb prices, were left behind in the rally. Merck was the biggest loser among Dow stocks, down 1 5/16 to 60 5/16. Eli Lilly slumped 1 9/16, to 61 1/2, while American Home Products, which is mired in litigation over its discontinued fen-phen diet-drug combination, fell 2 1/8, to 41.
Although the climate for initial public offerings has recently soured, Red Hat Inc., which sells a version of a computer operating system that seeks to compete with Microsoft Windows, made a spectacular debut. The company, based in Durham, N.C., offered six million shares at 14, and they finished at 52 1/16 on a volume of 17.9 million shares, meaning that each share changed hands an average of three times. It was the biggest gain for an initial offering since July 1.
But Blockbuster Inc.'s 31 million shares, spun off by Viacom, ended the first day of trading at the offering price of 15, apparently requiring support from the underwriters, Salomon Smith Barney.
The session's high-technology winners, most of them computer companies as opposed to Internet issues, included a surge by Intel of 4 1/4, to 76. Cisco gained 4 3/16, to 62 15/16. EMC soared 5 1/4, to 58 7/8. Gateway also rose 5 1/4, to 83 1/4. Motorola added 4 1/4 to 92 3/4, and Microsoft was up 1 1/4, to 84 3/16. Apple Computer rose 4 5/16 to a 52-week closing high of 59 11/16. America Online jumped 7 3/8, to 92 3/8.
"The deflated Internet sector is very healthy for the market," said Timothy J. Morris, a senior official at Bessemer Trust.
Among financial stocks, besides J. P. Morgan, Merrill Lynch rose 3 5/16 to 67; Goldman Sachs gained 4 1/2, to 61 1/2; Chase Manhattan rose 2 5/8, to 76 15/16, and American Express rose 2 1/2, to 127.
Advancing issues beat declining ones on the Big Board by 1,881 to 1,147. Still, new 52-week lows exceeded new highs by 230 to 44.
Overseas, stocks were modestly higher in Europe, nearly unchanged in Japan and up a hefty 3.1 percent in Brazil and 2.4 percent in Mexico.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Bonds Are Higher, Too
 By Bloomberg News
 Bond prices rose for the first time in four days yesterday after a Treasury sale of 10-year notes drew more demand than expected, and the Federal Reserve said there was relatively little evidence of inflation.
The $12 billion in notes sold at a yield of 6.085 percent, the highest for a 10-year auction since August 1997 and a level that drew buyers into the market. "We're going to take a look at possible purchases here," said Ted Neild, a portfolio manager at the Nuveen Advisory Corporation in Chicago, which oversees $40 billion of fixed-income securities. "We think interest rates may be peaking."
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 14/32, to a price of 87 4/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.21 percent from 6.25 percent on Tuesday.
Treasuries also gained as the Federal Reserve's regional economic-outlook report helped cool concerns about higher inflation, which erodes the value of a bond's interest payments.
Demand for the notes surprised many in the market. Investors bid for 2.07 times the amount of securities available, the most in a year.
But corporate bond sales in the days and weeks ahead may hurt prices, as they offer investors a higher-yielding option to Treasuries, Mr. Neild added.
DaimlerChrysler A.G., Europe's largest industrial company, is leading borrowers with a planned $3 billion issue.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

P.& G. to Pay $2.3 Billion For Pet Food Maker Iams
Procter & Gamble is expanding its mix of top-selling brands by acquiring Iams, the maker of premium pet food, for $2.3 billion.
The deal, P.& G.'s largest acquisition in dollar terms, moves the consumer products maker into a market-leading position in the high end of the $25 billion pet food market. And it is a first step in the company's strategy to speed growth by diversifying beyond its traditional categories. Shares of P.& G. rose 50 cents, to $93.25. Page C2. 

Telefonica-IDT Venture Expected
Telefonica of Spain has agreed to form a joint venture with IDT to market telephone and Internet service to Spanish-speaking people in the United States and Latin America, according to executives close to the deal, which is expected to be announced today. C6.
 
American Airlines and Union to Talk
American Airlines and its pilots union have agreed to meet with a private mediator next week in a final attempt to end a bitter dispute over American's integration of Reno Air. C6.
 
Technology Leads Markets Higher
Stocks bounded higher as computer-related shares lifted the Nasdaq composite index 74.87 points, or 3 percent, to 2,564.98, its biggest gain in eight weeks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 132.65 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,787.80, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 20.50 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,301.93. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.21 percent. C9.
 
Fed Report Shows Little Inflation
The economy is expanding with little sign of inflation, the Federal Reserve said in its latest regional report card, taking the edge off investor expectations that the central bank will raise interest rates again soon. C3.
 
Shares Triple for Vendor of Linux
An initial public offering by Red Hat, the leading distributor of the free Linux operating system, which has been promoted as an alternative to Microsoft's Windows, saw the shares more than triple in price by the close of trading on Nasdaq. Red Hat's co-founders, Robert Young, left, and Marc Ewing, each retain 14 percent of the company. C3.
 
Internet Service Focuses on Blacks
Big media and technology companies have agreed to back BET Holdings, which operates several black-oriented cable television stations, in establishing an elaborate Internet service aimed at African-Americans. C5.
 
Panic of ICN Charged With Fraud
Milan Panic, the former Prime Minister of Yugoslavia, has been charged with fraudulently misleading investors in ICN Pharmaceuticals, the company he runs, by failing to notify them promptly that the company's application to market a drug had been rejected. C6.
 
Iridium Defaults on $1.5 Billion
Iridium, the struggling operator of a $5 billion global satellite telecommunications network, said that it had defaulted on loans totaling more than $1.5 billion, pushing the company another step closer to insolvency. C20.
 
U.N. and Cisco Join to Help Poor
The United Nations and Cisco Systems, the maker of data communications gear, have enlisted a dozen popular entertainers to kick off an Internet-based initiative, called Netaid, to help the world's poor. A8.

HEADLINE: The Birds of Manhattan Are the Prey of a Killer

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
A young girl was chatting with friends in the northeast section of Central Park yesterday when a pigeon fell at her feet, dead.
The girl, Victoria Sweet, 11, said that she and her friend "were just scared and sad to watch Mother Nature just fall from the tree." 
 Between Tuesday morning and yesterday afternoon, 30 pigeons, 10 sparrows, one grackle and two ducks were found dead in the park, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said at a news conference near the Harlem Meer. And yes, he said, poisoning was suspected, as stricken birds continued to fall to the ground.
"The poisoning of innocent animals is an outrage," Mr. Stern said, quickly acknowledging that the precise cause of death would not be known until state conservation authorities in Albany completed autopsies in about two weeks.
But the Commissioner said he strongly suspected that the Central Park birds were being killed by the same culprit who has been targeting city birds since 1997.
In August of that year, the first evidence of poisoning emerged when a sick red-tailed hawk was found on Fifth Avenue and 74th Street. The hawk, which was found to have ingested a very powerful pesticide called carbofuran, recovered. But the hawk's mother was killed by the same poison two months later. Since pigeons are the principal food of hawks, Parks Department investigators reasoned that the hawks must have eaten pigeons that had been fed poisoned seed.
The poisonings continued in July 1998, when there were numerous reports of dead pigeons from the Upper East Side and West Side to Times Square. Forty dead sparrows were found in a parking lot on 97th Street and Columbus Avenue.
In the fall of 1998, several groups of 10 to 20 dead pigeons were found on the Upper East Side. Autopsies revealed carbofuran in the bodies.
Mr. Stern said that the culprit faced criminal prosecution, though he did not yet know what specific city or state law would be applicable. Killing the ducks, sparrows and grackle would be a violation of the Federal Migratory Bird Act, he said.
Mr. Stern said he would ask the Manhattan Distict Attorney for a jail sentence for the perpetrator. "As long as he's on the loose, the pigeons and ducks and birds of this park are in danger," he said.
A reward of $1,000 has been offered by the City Parks Foundation, a private philanthropic group, for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the bird killer.
Parks Department workers discovered the first dead birds on Tuesday morning. Seeds and bread crumbs at the scene were collected for examination. Police emergency tape blocks off the areas where the crumbs and seeds were found, and law enforcement officers are on duty to steer children and dog walkers away, said Bob Lawson, a department spokesman.
The Commissioner acknowledged that his agency often complained about pigeons and that he had many times advised the public not to feed them. But, he emphasized, the Parks Department does not kill them. Ed Skyler, a spokesman for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, said that no city agency killed pigeons or any other birds.
Building owners can legally control the pigeon population by employing a trained and licensed exterminator who uses the pesticide Avitrol. Both houses of the State Legislature passed a bill allowing localities to ban the use of Avitrol, but the bill was vetoed by Gov. George E. Pataki. Yesterday at the Harlem Meer, which attracts birds year round, women pushed baby strollers and camp groups marched in single file as birds struggled and died. Eric Erickson, an unemployed man who visits this part of the park every day, said, "I've never seen anything like this. It's a sick act."
Doubtless the most informed person on pigeons in the area was Sean Fine, a producer and cameraman who is filming a documentary about pigeons in New York City for the television series "National Geographic Explorer." As he photographed the death scene, he said that there were approximately as many pigeons in the city as people and that they had originally been brought from Europe as a source of fresh food.
Mr. Fine had a theory on why the killings were happening. He pointed to an article about the earlier killings in the current issue of New York magazine, and suggested that it had motivated the killer.
"I think some person is just laughing in people's faces," he said.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Opportunity Presents Itself: Kill the Penny

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
AS New Yorkers struggle through the great penny shortage of 1999, there are profound mysteries to contemplate:
How many bonuses must banks and stores offer to get New Yorkers to bring in the pennies stashed in their sock drawers? 
 How many pairs of socks would those pennies buy?
How can there be a shortage of something that nobody wants?
Those mysteries are too profound to be addressed in this space. But there is room to deal with a more mundane question: how can we seize this historic opportunity to get rid of the penny?
Prompt action is required, because the United States Mint is working around the clock to inflict more pennies on America. To resupply banks that have run out, it is churning out more than a billion pennies a month, most of them justly destined for oblivion.
"The majority of pennies don't circulate," said Philip N. Diehl, director of the mint. "They make a one-way trip from us to penny jars, sock drawers, piggy banks and the spaces between couch cushions. Two-thirds of the pennies produced in the last 30 years have dropped out of circulation."
Those billions of castoff pennies prove that Americans are too smart to spend their valuable time handling worthless pieces of copper-plated zinc. This lesson still escapes the Federal Government, even though a few penny abolitionists are at work in Washington.
The most vocal is James C. Benfield, the executive director of the Coin Coalition. His group, which is supported by the vending-machine industry, wants to eliminate the penny to make room in cash registers and pockets for one-dollar coins. He advocates rounding off to the nearest nickel on all cash transactions.
"Pennies are useless, but they make up 42 percent of the coins you get in change," Mr. Benfield said. "Forty thousand tons of zinc a year are wasted to make new pennies. We can easily get rid of this nuisance by rounding off. It's already being done on American military bases overseas."
Attempts to eliminate the penny, though, have been stymied in Congress by politicians from Illinois, who object to taking Lincoln's face out of coin circulation, and by the penny industrial complex: the companies that mine zinc and turn it into the blanks used to make the coins.
These companies support a group called Americans for Common Cents, which puts out material like "Ten Reasons to Keep the Penny." No. 9 is, "The penny has been an integral part of the American experience." No. 5 is even more weighty. Noting that consumers would feel "ripped off" by having to pay $7.80 for a $7.78 purchase, Americans for Commons Cents warns: "Abolishing the penny could erode consumer confidence in the economy."
IT'S easy to see how those arguments, accompanied by an occasional campaign contribution, could stop politicians from doing anything. But why hasn't the private sector responded? A few merchants have taken steps -- Saul Zabar has priced everything in his new cafe on Broadway to spare clerks from handling pennies -- but most are passing up a chance to save themselves time and money.
A typical drug store could save more than $2,000 a year by eliminating pennies, according to a study done by the Walgreen Company. Managers wouldn't have to buy rolls of pennies; clerks wouldn't have to unwrap the rolls and count up the coins at the end of the shift. The average transaction would be 2.5 seconds shorter.
"Rounding off is something we might consider if the penny shortage persists," said Ed King, Walgreen's director of trade and corporate relations. "But we're not sure how customers would react."
That uncertainty, along with the work involved in retraining clerks and reprogramming cash registers, has stopped most retailers from making the switch. What if clerks had to spend a minute explaining the system to each customer? What if some misers refused to accept the rounding up of a 98-cent purchase?
But if enough retailers started doing it, most customers would adjust. And as a public relations measure, perhaps a store could post a sign offering to provide the rounded-off pennies to anyone who demanded them. That way penny-pinchers would be mollified, and everyone else would have lighter pockets -- plus, of course, extra space in the sock drawer.

HEADLINE: Returning Gleam To Marble Church;
Crumbling Piece of City History Is Getting Its Stones Restored

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
If any church in New York City ought to have its stonework in good repair, it is the one called Marble.
Looking like a Romanesque pile of sugar cubes, it was consecrated in 1854 as the Fifth Avenue Church. But the glistening stones imprinted themselves on the civic consciousness, and the building material at last gave its name to the congregation, which was formally designated the Marble Collegiate Church in 1906. 
 Now, the congregation is repaying the favor. It has undertaken a $1 million repair, restoration and cleaning of the stones, all of them discolored and some disturbingly eroded by time, the seasons, polluted air and acid rain.
"To our knowledge, this has not been touched in 145 years," said Dr. Arthur Caliandro, the senior minister. "We really needed to do it, to brighten the building up and bring it back to its lustrous original self."
While it does not rival the grandeur of St. Patrick's Cathedral farther up the avenue, the Marble Church at 29th Street has been in the public eye for a long time. Centuries, in fact. As part of the Collegiate Reformed Protestant Dutch Church, it traces its origins to 1628. And it was the pulpit for 52 years of Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, author of "The Power of Positive Thinking."
What is now an intense job of architectural surgery -- a web of scaffolding envelops the landmark as workers go over the stone surface with diamond-edged grinders, chisels and knives -- began innocently enough two years ago as a simple cleaning project of the marble, which was quarried in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.
"The building has never had a bath," said Dwight D. Rangeler, the church master. "Our first image was, 'Wouldn't it be nice to bring up a garden hose and spray it on the building?' "
Before they could start cleaning, however, church leaders were advised to examine the facade.
They brought in Diane S. Kaese, senior architect at Wiss, Janney, Elstner Associates, a nationwide engineering and architectural firm based in Northbrook, Ill., that specializes in solving problems for existing buildings.
That was when the congregation learned that sugar has an ominous meaning in the stone trade -- not white and sparkling but granular and crumbling. An inspection disclosed that the marble was "sugaring" in many spots under a black gypsum crust caused by decades of exposure. In some places, the mortar had turned to powder, if it remained at all. Blocks could be rocked back and forth by hand. Through stones in the bell tower, one could see blue sky.
Church leaders decided to seize the opportunity provided by a strong economy to undertake a more ambitious restoration of their building. "We want to make sure it can last for another few generations," Mr. Rangeler said. "By that time, some new preservative techniques may have come to the fore."
"It's got to be done," he said. "Or else."
Or else more of the conditions he saw the other day on a not-too-happy tour of the facade given by Ms. Kaese; Timothy D. Henry and Timothy J. Farrell of Henry Restoration, the contracting company from Nesconset, N.Y., and John K. Copelin of the William A. Hall Partnership, the architect for the church.
They began along the rooftop balustrade. Ms. Kaese paused. "It looks like someone poured hot water on a sugar cube and it melted," she said, pointing to an 18-inch-high, 4-cusp opening called a quatrefoil.
Indeed, it did. The contours of the once-crisp carving had softened into a doughy lump and the surface was the color of a calico cat: white marble, black gypsum crust and orange granules.
"I shouldn't have worn bifocals today," Mr. Rangeler said as he peered over Ms. Kaese's shoulder at the deterioration. "I should have come up blind. I don't want to see this."
At the base of a spire at the southeast corner of the church, Ms. Kaese was able to stick her finger all the way into a masonry joint because there was so much space between stones and so little mortar.
"Theoretically, that should not be," she said.
They shimmied their way along the planks and through the narrow network of pipe supports. "Here, Dwight, I want to show you this," Ms. Kaese said, pointing to the arabesque base of a pier on the south facade from which a knoblike ornament known as a boss had simply broken off.
"Ay, ay, ay, ay, ay," was Mr. Rangeler's appreciative response.
Mr. Farrell, the field superintendent for Henry Restoration, kept watch on his crew. One worker was using a chisel to extract old mortar from a buttress. "Don't bury that shank all the way in or you'll pop the stone, O.K.?" Mr. Farrell cautioned.
At another buttress, Mr. Farrell used a low-tech device called the flat of his hand to determine the condition of the stone. Instead of a sharp report, the block sent back a hollow reverberation. "It doesn't sound good," he said.
Discouraging as this litany might seem, Ms. Kaese does not despair. Over all, she said, the metal anchors behind the stone blocks are in good shape and there has been minimal breakage of stone. But there is more surface and joint deterioration than she expected to find.
Some stones will have to be recarved. Others must be replaced entirely. Most of them will be cleaned with a light misting of water that will eventually dissolve the gypsum crust. For those that are badly stained, a clay-based poultice can be applied -- not unlike a facial mudpack, Ms. Kaese said.
Church leaders are tamping down expectations in the congregation that the building will emerge dazzling from its cocoon. "It's going to be cleaner than this," Mr. Copelin said, "but it's not going to be the Taj Mahal."
After the restoration work is finished, in about four months, the grounds around the building will be landscaped and the building will be illuminated at night.
"Churches -- not only Marble -- serve as lighthouses to passers-by," Dr. Caliandro said. "For many, there's a feeling of comfort, hope and security when they see churches. Also for the neighborhood. The Flatiron district is moving north and we will be helpful to the whole value of the neighborhood by being outstanding."

HEADLINE: Alexander, After 6-Year Run, Is Short on Time and Money

SERIES: THE CONTENDERS -- Running Toward 2000

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Lamar Alexander is trying hard to stay positive while he runs out of money. "We're just beginning," Mr. Alexander insists, six and a half years into his Presidential run, on another day spent driving across the state to share a sack lunch or a bowl of ice cream with a tiny handful of mostly longtime supporters.
But his bitter belief that the Republican Party's whole nominating process is being short-circuited by big money and big media has become a consuming preoccupation. And in these last days before Saturday's straw poll in Ames, where even supporters say he needs a surprising show of strength for his campaign to survive, his appearances have turned into extended warnings that not only his candidacy but a whole way of political life is in danger. 
 "This could be the last Iowa caucus," he says at nearly every stop. "Now you can just come into the airport, buy a few bales of hay, pretend you know Iowa and have the media proclaim you the winner. You don't need to bother with picking a President because it's not your business anymore."
In one sense the straw poll is an unfair measurement, because its votes are literally bought and paid for. But as Mr. Alexander acknowledges, it is an indication of early organizational strength and can energize or end a candidacy.
All of the other Republican campaigns have shown a certain amount of exasperation at their party's rush to bankroll Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. Former Vice President Dan Quayle's wife, Marilyn, recently lashed out by calling Mr. Bush a "party frat-boy type."
But no one has been running harder or longer than Mr. Alexander, a two-term Tennessee governor and Bush Administration Education Secretary, who has not held any other full-time job since he left Washington in January 1993. And he is leading the field in complaining that Mr. Bush and his money are subverting the system.
Away from the podium, Mr. Alexander's resentment is even more pronounced. Surfing wave upon wave of Iowa cornfields in a borrowed van, he derided the front-runner in a way that was remarkable not for its viciousness but for its volume.
Mr. Alexander is a serious man, known for improving Tennessee's schools and economy, as well as for the plaid shirt he has finally ditched. In 1996, he had an encouraging third-place finish in both the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary. That same year, President Clinton told friends that Mr. Alexander was the Republican he most feared running against.
He has been to Iowa so often he would surely win the upcoming straw poll if it were awarded after a pop quiz on the state. But he is almost broke -- with just $91,000 on hand compared with Mr. Bush's $30 million in the bank -- and has already laid off staff members. Everywhere, he fields only one real question from reporters: When is the wake?
Jim Beckner, a Nashville lawyer who has raised money for Mr. Alexander in past years, said he had stopped trying, explaining: "Most of his supporters were saying, 'Last time I gave out of enthusiasm, but this time, show me some reality.' "
After Mr. Alexander left the Governor's mansion in 1987, he took his family to Australia for six months, to reflect and reconnect. In his memoir of that trip, "Six Months Off," he describes the chemical reaction that occurs when voters fall for a candidate -- in this case, him, as he walked across Tennessee while running for governor:
"The thousand-mile walk, day after day, became my metronome, a practiced discipline that infused me with the music of the lives of the people I sought to serve. I knew I was in my groove -- or was it their groove? I began to radiate the glow of a winning candidate. For the first time ever, I possessed that incandescence that voters see in a candidate with a sense of purpose."
But some of that rosy glow is conferred by cash, and with both Mr. Bush and Steve Forbes outspending him 10-to-1 on the straw poll alone, even friends are saying this does not seem to be Mr. Alexander's turn to be incandescent: "Why does a lousy restaurant sometimes have a line down the block and people knocking to get in?" Mr. Beckner said. "Who knows? Politics is like that, too. He's very intelligent, wonderful background, but for whatever reason he just has not caught on."
In hopes of pulling off a surprise on Saturday, Mr. Alexander, traveling with his national chairman, former Gov. Terry Branstad of Iowa, is trying to hit 64 of the state's 99 counties, fairly begging folks to strike a blow for the little guy through the straw poll. He is offering them free T-shirts, dinner and a mini-concert by the singer Crystal Gayle, not to mention transportation in an air-conditioned bus, in all, "a $25 value."
But Iowans show no sign that they share his frustration. When he told members of the Pachyderm political club in Marshalltown to remember that "there is no Ronald Reagan in this race, and no George Bush, either," nobody laughed. Afterwards, a couple of people said they thought he seemed a little negative, and two others thought he might make a fine Vice President.
"I like all of the Republican candidates, but I think Bush can win," said Bill Egleston, who runs a mail order business here. "Anyway, the money goes to benefit the Iowa Republican Party, so Iowans should be happy about it."
Mr. Alexander, though, spends considerable energy unhappily working and reworking his own feelings about the Texas Governor. Over bacon and eggs at a coffee shop in New Hampton, Mr. Alexander said, "He's relying on celebrity and money while I'm relying on hard work and issues."
Clenching his fist, his voice tightening, Mr. Alexander went on: "Governor Bush has been here three times, all in the last month. It's all built on image and on sand. All the people he's talking to are screened."
On a long drive to lunch in Vinton, he mocked Mr. Bush's attempts to speak Spanish. "Bush says, 'Todos los ninos must be educated,' Mr. Alexander said, trying a Texas twang. "I can do that."
Passing near Waterloo, Iowa, he remarked: "In the real Waterloo, there's a statue of Napoleon that says, 'Whenever I see a throne, I have an urge to sit on it.' I've known a lot of people like that."
And that evening, before tucking into a comfort-food extravaganza of turkey, dressing and a chocolate shake, Mr. Alexander observed: "We've had an overdose of charisma. You don't beat Al Gore trying to sound like Bill Clinton."
When Mr. Alexander is not on the subject of Mr. Bush, his ideas come through much more clearly. At dinner with a few aides and reporters, amid a discussion about how much television is suitable for children, he recalled struggling with the question of at what age he should let his children read of the evil of the Holocaust in Elie Wiesel's "Night."
Then he said: "It all boils down to something that may be more profound than what we can deal with in a Presidential race. How do people know the difference between right and wrong and why it's getting harder, with the culture getting coarser and institutions weaker? That's the issue with Clinton and that's the issue with all these shootings."
"This whole debate has gotten off track," he went on, "because our party gets off on family values and issues including abortion and gay rights and other things that quickly get us off track, instead of talking about how we can arm parents to teach their children."
His central message is that he wants to improve schools and make life easier for parents in a number of ways, including tax breaks. For the rest of the evening, he seemed energized.
But the next morning, back in the van, someone had seen a copy of a political obituary for Mr. Alexander in The New Republic, and after a few lines were quoted to him he got quiet. Then, for probably the 10th time in 24 hours, a reporter from Mr. Alexander's home state of Tennessee repeated the same question: "So, would you say this is make or break for you?"
In response, with his voice rising a little, he said, "The real question isn't the money people but the media. Typically, you wait for a race to start before declaring a winner. The press has traditionally given at least three tickets out of the Iowa caucus. Now at least they ought to give three out of the straw poll."
Later in the day, as his van pulled into the parking lot of his Des Moines headquarters, he tried once more. "I would just like to say that the whole purpose of what we do between now and the end of the year is to come in in the top three," he said. "That's what the competition was all about."

HEADLINE: SHOOTINGS IN LOS ANGELES: THE SUSPECT;
Acquaintances Describe Loner Bent by a Rage

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Aug. 11

 BODY:
It did not take long for people who had seen the police mug shot of Buford O'Neal Furrow Jr. when it flashed on a television screen to remember other, more disturbing images of the man.
There was the picture, taken four years ago by a Spokane newspaper, of Mr. Furrow in a neo-Nazi uniform, standing guard outside the north Idaho compound of the Aryan Nations. He had developed a militant hatred of Jews, blacks and homosexuals who are routinely compared to "spawn of the devil" at the headquarters of a small group of racists, acquaintances recalled. 
 There was the confrontation in the forest, when Mr. Furrow, with pistol strapped to his hip, asked a logging crew in northeast Washington State if there were any blacks among them, according to people who worked for the timber outfit.
And, perhaps most revealing, Mr. Furrow himself told the authorities who questioned him after he was arrested in an assault case last year that he was a racist who fantasized about committing a mass killing. In his wallet was a card identifying him as member of the Aryan Nations, and in his car was a 9-millimeter handgun and rounds of ammunition.
"Sometimes I feel like I could just lose it and kill people," he told the police in the Seattle area, court records show.
He was a loner with an obsession for guns who thought constantly about murder and suicide, acquaintances say. But there was another dimension: a hatred for people different from himself that led him from the Aryan Nations compound to a small Washington town, where, several friends said, he became the second husband of the widow of one of the United States' best-known domestic terrorists.
In Metaline Falls, Wash., a broken mining and timber town of fewer than 300 people, Mr. Furrow took up residence for nearly two years in the mid-1990's with Debbie Mathews, the widow of Robert J. Mathews. Still revered by white supremacists around the country, Mr. Mathews founded a neo-Nazi group called the Order, which carried out a campaign of assassinations, bombings and robberies. He died in a shootout with Federal authorities in 1994.
Mr. Furrow met Mrs. Mathews at the Aryan Nations compound. Several friends said the two later married, although civil documents have no record of any ceremony.
"They were living together, and I never was sure if they were married or not," said Roger Lynn, manager of a tractor repair business in Colville, Wash., that formerly employed Mr. Furrow as a mechanic.
After the Order was broken apart by arrests, internal dissent and killings, some of the more violent racists of the Pacific Northwest vowed to strike at their targets in small groups, or alone, earning membership in something known as the Phineas Priesthood by committing a violent act against Jews, blacks, homosexuals or abortion providers.
The police would not say today whether Mr. Furrow was a member of the loose-knit fraternity of racists who called themselves priests. But in his van yesterday, police officials in Los Angeles found a book written by Richard Kelly Hoskins, who also wrote a manifesto on the Phineas Priesthood and many other books about race and banking.
In a brief interview today from his home in Lynchburg, Va., Mr. Hoskins said the book found in Mr. Furrow's van, "War Cycles/Peace Cycles," was about "the history of usury," including what he called "the traditional Jewish presence in banking."
He added, "I don't know what a book of economics has to do with shooting children at a day care center," and then he hung up.
On his Web page, Mr. Hoskins describes the book as "the definitive work on usury" and writes that it explains "the necessity for assassination of national leaders."
In describing his book on the Phineas Priesthood, Mr. Hoskins wrote: "As the kamikaze is to the Japanese, as the Shiite is to Islam, as the Zionist is to the Jew, so the Phineas Priest is to Christiandom."
After taking a taxi cab across the desert from Los Angeles to Las Vegas, Nev., then turning himself in to the Federal Bureau of Investigation on Tuesday, Mr. Furrow told the authorities that the shootings were done as "a wake-up call to America to kill Jews," The Associated Press reported. But Federal authorities and the Los Angeles police would not confirm any statements about the motive for the shootings at the Jewish community center in the Granada Hills section of Los Angeles.
Some of the people who know Mr. Furrow say he demonized Jews particularly, in accordance with the religion of Christian Identity, which holds that Jews are subhuman and are the offspring of the devil.
Groups that research and track hate groups say there are about 35,000 Christian Identity followers in the United States.
"There are a lot more active followers of Christian Identity than there are members of the Ku Klux Klan," said Morris Dees, legal director of the Southern Poverty Law Center, which has filed many lawsuits against racist groups.
T. J. Leyden, a former skinhead who is a consultant for the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles, said Mr. Furrow "was very hard-core Christian Identity."
Mr. Furrow was once teaching a course in hand-to-hand combat at the Aryan Nations compound outside Hayden Lake, Idaho, said Mr. Leyden. Mr. Leyden, a former marine, said he told Mr. Furrow that his combat technique was wrong. A strong argument ensued, in which Mr. Furrow talked of his hatred for nonwhites, Mr. Leyden said.
Mr. Furrow also showed flashes of the temper while living in Metaline Falls, some acquaintances said. And it was the temper that led to Mr. Furrow's only known brush with the police.
"He had a violent temper," said Meda VanDyke, who described herself as a 20-year friend of Mrs. Mathews in Metaline Falls. The couple broke up, she said, because "he wanted to control everything and tell her what to do."
Outside her house in the woods today -- posted with three 'No Trespassing' signs -- Mrs. Mathews declined to talk to reporters.
Around Metaline Falls, which is tucked in the heavy forests of Pend Oreille County near the Idaho border, Mr. Furrow was ubiquitous in camouflage outfits in the mid 1990's. Rick Rieber, the town marshal, said he stopped Mr. Furrow once for speeding, his only known infraction.
He presented himself as an engineer or a mechanic in various jobs and on official documents. From Metaline Falls he commuted 100 miles round trip every day to a job at LaDuke & Fogle Equipment in Colville.
"He showed up to work every day, did his job, and never got involved with any trouble that I knew of," said Roger Lynn, the company manager. "After he left, I heard he was a neo-Nazi and a racist. But we never heard any of that while he was here."
He worked for the company for about a year, in the mid 1990's, and then was laid off, Mr. Lynn said.
After leaving Mrs. Mathews, Mr. Furrow moved back to Western Washington. Last year, Mr. Furrow tried to stab a woman at a psychiatric center outside Seattle. In court documents, he described his rage and fantasies of committing a mass killing. He had come to the center, Fairfax Hospital in Kirkland last year, seeking admission. But he appeared to be drunk, and when hospital officials tried to take his car keys, he threatened to stab one of them, according to court records in Seattle.
Mr. Furrow served 165 days in jail for attempted assault. He was released this May.
Dan Donahoe, a spokesman for the King County Prosecutor's office, said Mr. Furrow served a slightly above average sentence for his crime. As a first-time offender, he could not be expected to spend more time in jail, Mr. Donahoe said.
He also said Mr. Furrow's racist background was not ground for further charges or prosecutorial investigation.
Growing up in a rural community outside Olympia, Wash., Mr. Furrow was known as somewhat overweight boy. "He was raised in a good Christian, patriotic family," said Bill Wells, an uncle to Mr. Furrow, who lives in West Columbia, S.C. "We don't support any white supremacist groups. We are not a bunch of bigots or racists."
Mr. Furrow may have tried to present himself at the Aryan Nations compound as a warrior schooled in the arts of combat, but as a real soldier in the United States Army, he was a bust. Military records from the Pentagon showed that Mr. Furrow lasted only two months in the Army in 1980. He had an unstable knee and received an honorable discharge, records show.
In recent years, Mr. Furrow listed addresses in Lynnwood, Wash., at his parents' home outside Olympia, and -- most recently -- in Rosamond, Calif. Outside the Furrow family house in Old Nisqually, near Olympia, neighbors today recalled a mostly benign man prone to occasional grandiose acts.
"He stopped traffic outside my driveway once to help my my wife get the mail," said Tim Tyrolt, who lives next to the Furrows. "They are regular, quiet neighbors."

HEADLINE: Look Who's Paying Estate Tax

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Teddy Roosevelt Betrayed" (Op-Ed, Aug. 9), by Susan Dunn:
I doubt that Theodore Roosevelt, who persuaded Congress to establish the inheritance tax, intended for the tax to have a punitive effect on the middle class, but that's what has happened. 
 The estate tax has become a revenue-raising device, not a way of leveling the playing field. Real estate inflation and the booming stock market have increased significantly the number of middle-class people exposed to the tax. Surely Roosevelt never intended to include in the plutocratic class middle-class people who have two adult children and four grandchildren, and want to assist with the housing and education needs of their offspring. That is not a way for our Government to reward initiative and a lifetime of hard work.
By all means let the true plutocrats be subject to Teddy Roosevelt's wishes, but leave the middle class out of it.
 
HUGH TREANOR
Palo Alto, Calif., Aug. 9, 1999

HEADLINE: The Car You Covet: Was It Totaled?

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
ANN HASSELBACH paid $27,000 for a low-mileage, three-year-old Toyota Supra from A. J. Foyt Honda in Kingwood, Tex., in 1997. When the car developed steering problems, the nursing student took it to a mechanic, who gave her more bad news. It needed a new transmission and its electrical systems required an overhaul because it had been flooded. The seat belts were not even bolted down, she said.
When she confronted the dealer's used-car manager, she said, he denied knowing the car's history and declared the vehicle safe. "Talk about anger," Ms. Hasselbach said. "Even a slight fender bender and I could have been dead." 
 Neither the general manager at A. J. Foyt Honda, nor the dealer's lawyers, returned phone calls seeking a response.
Ms. Hasselbach's lawyer obtained a title history indicating that the car had passed among three auto brokers in a year before reaching the dealer. Only after filing suit against the dealer and brokers for fraud did Ms. Hasselbach, 25, learn she had paid top dollar for a cosmetically disguised wreck.
It turned out that a doctor from Beaumont, Tex., had surrendered the once-flooded car to the Progressive Insurance Company after receiving a $31,000 payoff.
"Nobody did this intentionally," said Mark R. Lapidus, Progressive's lawyer in Houston. "I think what happened is, a mistake was made and the paperwork didn't get sent." A trial is set for next year.
Concealing damage when reselling autos prompts so many complaints that legislation to set a national car-title standard has been proposed in Congress several times, only to collapse under pressure from competing interest groups. Insurers, law enforcers, the collision industry and consumer advocates agree that the issue should be resolved, but they disagree over how.
From 20 to 40 percent of the 2.3 million vehicles that are declared "totaled" by insurers each year are rebuilt and put back on the highway, some legally, some not, say experts who have studied the problem. A significant portion of the vehicles that insurers consider too damaged to repair are freshened up and reregistered without their titles being branded as salvage -- the category for cars that cannot be economically fixed. Telltale signs, like spot frame welds and parts from different model years, can be hard to detect.
Last year in Indiana, the State Farm Mutual Insurance Company, the nation's largest auto insurer, agreed to pay nearly $4 million in restitution to settle a case involving extensively damaged cars it had bought and resold without obtaining salvage titles.
"What we hear from other states is that the practice is not unique to Indiana," said Jeffrey A. Modisett, the state Attorney General. He said a similar investigation was under way in Iowa; plaintiff's lawyers in Texas and New Jersey are at work on class-action suits over similar allegations.
Unscrupulous rebuilders and car thieves have plenty of opportunity to reregister vehicles with clean titles or new identification numbers, since there is no national data base for salvaged and stolen vehicles.
And state laws governing vehicle titles are inconsistent. In Iowa, for example, a car must be given a salvage title if repairs exceed 50 percent of a vehicle's value. In Texas, the threshold is 75 percent. States with relatively lax rules, like Oregon and Pennsylvania, become havens for laundered vehicle titles, cleaned through reregistration.
A bill proposing a national standard for titling salvage vehicles was approved in June by the Senate Commerce Committee. It is supported by insurers and auto rebuilders, but opposed by consumer groups and several state attorneys general. Critics hope that the bill, written by Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, will be amended before it is considered by the full Senate.
Attorneys general including Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, Joseph Curran Jr. of Maryland and Bill Lockyer of California oppose the proposed Federal standard, saying it is weaker than many existing state laws that it would pre-empt. The proposal defines a salvage vehicle as one needing repairs worth 75 percent of its value, but exempts vehicles over six years old and those valued at less than $7,500.
Consumer groups support a competing bill by Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California. Rather than focus on salvage vehicles it would require pre-sale damage disclosures on registrations, a condition set in a few states including North Dakota, Iowa and Minnesota. Her bill, which would set criminal penalties, was not considered by the Senate committee.
Insurers oppose rules requiring owners to tell potential buyers about accident damage that falls short of salvage status. Insurers do not want policyholders' vehicles to be stigmatized over what amounts to cosmetic damage, said Dave A. Hurst, a State Farm spokesman in Bloomington, Ind.
Shoddy repairs stem partly from the strong used-car market. Insurers end up declaring repairable cars "totaled" and paying policyholders the full value, then recouping much of that expense by selling the cars at auction, said Jack J. Rozint, marketing vice president of CCC Information Services Inc., an auto claims processor in Chicago.
"The rebuilder has a strong incentive to complete the repair as cheaply as possible, as every penny saved goes in his pocket," Mr. Rozint said. "The title still should be branded as salvage."
 
Clues on the Web for Title Sleuths
 
PROSPECTIVE used-car buyers need not accept on faith assurances about a car's history from salespeople or private parties. For $20, consumers can obtain a title history from Carfax or VHR, rival information providers that have long catered to insurers and auto dealers.
Carfax began in 1985 as a service to dealers who wanted to avoid buying problem cars at auction. A third of its business now comes from consumers, who can check histories on line at www.carfaxonline.com or by calling (888) 422-7329.
VHR, owned by CCC Information Services of Chicago, developed its data base from its business of auto-insurance claims processing. It includes records on 18 million vehicles declared "totaled" by insurers, said Jack J. Rozint, a company spokesman. Its Web site is www.vehiclehistory.com.
Both companies' historical knowledge can be useful to buyers of used cars. Even so, gaps exist in both data bases, because a few states have refused to make public their registration and title records.
Histories are indexed based on vehicle identification numbers and labels like "lemon buyback," "salvage" and "gross polluter." These red flags are sometimes excised when cars are moved between states that use different definitions of what is a lemon or a flooded vehicle. "Title washing happens all the time," said Scott Fredericks, a spokesman for Carfax, which was recently acquired by the Polk Company. With a title history, consumers can learn the previous registrations and transactions involving a vehicle, whether it was repossessed or used as a taxi, and whether its odometer was rolled back. ANDREA ADELSON
 
http://www.nytimes.com

Chart: "How A Damaged Vehicle's Title is 'Washed' "
 
A truck owned by an Iowa farmer, Joe, is rear-ended. Joe submits a claim to his insurance company.
 
The insurer declares the truck totaled because repairs would exceed 50% of it's value, the salvage threshold under Iowa law.
 
Joe receives a check and surrenders the truck and its title to the insurer.
 
The truck goes into an insurance salvage pool and is bought by an auto broker, shipped to Texas, repaired and made ready to be sold at auction.
 
Because Texas does not consider the vehicle to be salvage unless repairs exceed 75% of its value, the broker legally obtains a "clean title."
 
At auction, the truck is resold to a used-car dealer in Dallas.
 
The truck is put on a lot and bought by a college student. The title says that the most recent owner was a Texas auto broker.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Big Increase in Retail Sales Pushes Treasury Yields Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Yields of Treasury securities moved sharply higher yesterday as stronger-than-expected retail sales kept alive investor concerns that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates later this month.
Also weighing on the market was a $10 billion Government bond sale, which generally reduces demand for existing issues anyway. Yesterday's sale was the third and final part of the Treasury's $37 billion quarterly refunding this week. 
 The bond auction did not go as well as some in the market had hoped. The issue's high yield came in at 6.144 percent, which was slightly more than expected. But even as the number of bids produced an acceptable bid-to-cover ratio of 2.22 to 1, retail demand was weak.
By late in the day, the price of the current 30-year bond dropped 13/32, to 86 12/32, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.27 percent from 6.21 percent on Wednesday. The newly auctioned long bond saw its yield rise to 6.17 percent from an average 6.113 percent.
"Market participants are now firmly convinced that another Fed move to a less accommodative policy stance will take place at the Aug. 24 F.O.M.C. meeting," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management. The Fed's Open Market Committee last raised rates on June 30, when it increased the overnight lending rate between banks, known as the Federal funds rate, a quarter-point, to 5 percent.
"At this juncture, the best planning assumption looks for a quarter-point rise in the target Federal funds rate, to a level of 5.25 percent," Mr. Fine said. Furthermore, he added, an additional quarter-point increase seems likely at the Fed's meeting on Oct. 5 in light of rising prices and wages amid a buoyant economy with low unemployment.
Retail sales in July rose a greater-than-expected seven-tenths of a percent, although a downward revision to the June data took some sting out of the number. The latest weekly jobless claims were also interesting, Mr. Fine said, as the four-week moving average registered a cyclical low of 288,250, a sign of an extraordinarily tight labor market.
On that note, the market is awaiting the release today of Producer Price Index data for July. While the core rate is expected to be subdued, rising energy prices are projected to raise the overall index by three-tenths or four-tenths of a percent.
Other data to be released today include business inventory figures for June and the University of Michigan's midmonth consumer sentiment survey, the first look at consumer attitudes in August.
Theodore Ake, Treasury note trading manager for First Union Capital Markets in Charlotte, N.C., said, "The Street bid on the long bond today and they now own it, while for the most part the retail side continues to wait for upcoming inflation data before they decide."
"What direction short-term interest rates will take will be dictated by those numbers," Mr. Ake said. "However, the real question is how many more Fed tightenings will it take? The market is betting on not too many more in the pipeline."
Over the next couple of weeks, the yield on the 30-year bond should hover around 6.25 percent, Mr. Ake said.

HEADLINE: Gap and Kmart Both Post Rises In Their Second-Quarter Profits

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Gap Inc. and the Kmart Corporation said yesterday that second-quarter profit rose as shoppers scooped up low-price spring and summer fashions.
Low inflation, rising wages and unemployment near 30-year lows have encouraged consumers to spend, producing the longest stretch of gains in retail sales in at least a decade. Among retailers, discount chains have benefited the most, broadening their appeal by redecorating stores and updating fashions while keeping prices low. 
 "More consumers seem to be interested, however good the economy is, in saving money and making their dollar go further," said Kurt Barnard, an industry consultant.
Net income at Gap, which owns the lower-priced Old Navy chain as well as its namesake outlets and Banana Republic stores, rose 43 percent, to $195.8 million, or 22 cents a diluted share, compared with $136.9 million, or 15 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter ended July 31 jumped 29 percent, to $2.45 billion.
Analysts had expected Gap, based in San Francisco, to earn 21 cents a share, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings.
Kmart's profit from continuing operations rose 44 percent, to $134 million, or 26 cents a diluted share, compared with $93 million, or 19 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 7.9 percent, to $8.76 billion.
The company, based in Troy, Mich., was expected to earn 25 cents a share, according to First Call.
In the quarter, Kmart took a charge of $230 million, or 41 cents a share, for costs related to the bankruptcy filing of the Hechinger Company, which subleased some former Builders Square properties from Kmart. Kmart sold the Builders Square chain in 1997 but guaranteed some of the leases.
The charge resulted in a net loss of $96 million, or 15 cents a share.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Stocks Slide After Fears Of Rate Rises Kill a Rally

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks were held to a minuscule gain yesterday and broader indicators retreated. A surge in interest rates after a disappointing Treasury bond auction deflated a bid to extend Wednesday's broad stock-market rally.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 1.59 points, to 10,789.39. The Dow rose as much as 113 points earlier in yesterday's session, following through on Wednesday's gain of 132.65 points. 
 The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.77 points, to 1,298.16; the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index slid 15.49 points, to 2,549.49.
Stocks were higher across the board for much of the session as bargain hunters sought out shares that have been pounded down from the record heights reached in mid-July. But worries about higher interest rates, which have held the market down for the last three weeks, prevailed again yesterday.
Stocks fell after the Treasury's afternoon auction of $10 billion in 30-year bonds. Traders said demand for the bonds fell short of expectations, driving the price down and the yield up. Yields on 30-year bonds hit 6.27 percent in the open market, a level not seen since October 1997.
"As long as the bond market is behaving like a bear market, it will be tough for stocks to take off," said Eugene G. Mintz, financial markets analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company.
The rise in bond yields this summer has hurt stocks in two ways. Rising interest rates raise the cost of business borrowing, cutting into profitability. And, with rates at more than 6 percent, bonds present an attractive alternative to investing in volatile stocks.
The latest evidence that the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates further came from a stronger-than-expected report on retail sales. The Commerce Department said yesterday that retail sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in July, bolstered by a big gain in automotive sales. Strong consumer spending could suggest to the Fed that the booming economy is overheating.
But without automobiles and seasonal goods like air-conditioners, the retail sales increase was quite modest, Robert Smith, chief executive of Smith Affiliated Capital in New York, noted. "It was really kind of a bland number," he said. "But there's a lot of anxiety right now about every new domestic economic indicator."
Most analysts say the Fed will be more interested in the Producer Price Index, due for release this morning. That index is a measure of inflation pressures at the wholesale level, or before reaching consumers.
While economists focused on the stream of economic data, companies across a wide range of sectors served up market-moving news.
United Technologies posted the sharpest gain of all Dow components after saying it would cut 1,500 jobs to try to reduce costs at its Pratt & Whitney jet-engine unit. United Technologies shares rose 3 3/16, to 66 3/8.
Caterpillar also helped buoy the Dow after Goldman, Sachs added the company to its list of recommended stocks. An analyst there said that Caterpillar should benefit from the improving global economy. Shares of Caterpillar climbed 1 3/4, to 61.
America Online, the leading provider of on-line services, extended its recent gains. Shares of America Online rose 7 3/8 on Wednesday after company executives held an upbeat conference call with analysts and investors. Yesterday, they rose another 3/8, to 92 3/4.
But stocks of most major computer manufacturers slipped after an analyst at Merrill Lynch said that a trend toward low-priced computers could eventually cut into profits. Hewlett-Packard was the Dow's biggest declining component, falling 6 5/16 a share, to 103 1/16.

HEADLINE: 2 Reports Bolster Outlook on Rates

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Retail sales accelerated in July and the number of workers seeking jobless benefits fell to near a decade low, Government reports showed today, suggesting that more growth is likely for the economy.
Sales rose seven-tenths of a percent, to $248.7 billion, paced by increased demand for cars, pickup trucks and building supplies, Commerce Department data showed. That more than reversed a decline of two-tenths of a percent in June. 
 In addition, the four-week average of the number of workers filing state unemployment claims declined to 288,250 last week, the Labor Department said. The figure is down from 295,000 a week earlier and the lowest level since the week of Feb. 4, 1989.
Both reports left intact concerns that Federal Reserve policy makers will raise interest rates later this month -- to slow the economy and to prevent tight labor markets from leading to outsize wage gains that ignite inflation.

HEADLINE: Pathum Thani Journal;
Most Serene of Sects Creates Uproar in Buddhism

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: PATHUM THANI, Thailand, Aug. 10

 BODY:
The sheer psychic power of 30,000 people meditating together can make miracles happen, say the monks here at the headquarters of Thailand's biggest, richest and -- to the established priesthood -- most dangerous new Buddhist sect.
Last Oct. 5, for example. 
 In the harsh heat of the afternoon, worshipers say, the sun seemed to soften above them into a cool crystal ball. Then the vivid image of the sect's founder materialized within the ball, deep in meditation along with his followers.
"Tens of thousands of people saw it," said Chuleeporn Chungrangsee, a witness. "Some saw only a halo effect. Some saw the sun spinning in rainbow colors."
The spectacle was reported widely in Thai newspapers, along with pictures of the sect's newly constructed temple, a vast, low-slung building that sits in the dry fields, 30 miles north of Bangkok, looking like a slightly menacing flying saucer.
People suddenly became aware that a huge and unsettling religious movement had been growing in their midst and had put up by far the largest temple in the land.
The movement calls itself Dhammakaya (pronounced tah-mah-guy), and the circular shape of its main temple is meant to represent the universe, a fitting symbol: its leaders intend it to become the central landmark of world Buddhism, a sort of Vatican or Mecca for their faith, whether the established hierarchy likes it or not.
Unlike the Falun Gong in China, a new sect that has drawn a government crackdown, the Dhammakaya sect has existed unobtrusively in Thailand for several decades, swelling recently to claim more than 100,000 followers, who gather in temples around Thailand and 10 foreign countries, including the United States.
Religious scholars and commentators say this is a movement for its time -- a sign of the failure of the established priesthood in Thailand to minister to a changing, modernizing nation.
Dhammakaya, they say, offers solace to Thailand's newly affluent middle class -- with its newly acquired middle-class angst -- left reeling and rootless by two decades of heady economic growth followed two years ago by a sudden and dislocating crash.
"We forgot where we were going," said Manit Rattanasuwan, an advertising executive who worships here. "Our youngsters want to be like Westerners, with their music and clothes and outgoing style, not so serious about life. And the old traditions cannot deal with that."
Another worshiper, Penchara Asavasopon, managing director of an executive-search company, offered a familiar middle-class complaint. "These days we hardly find time for the children, for the family," she said. "We have all these problems with teen-agers, with drugs, so many things. So we are looking for some activities that the whole family can do together, like meditation."
And then there is making money. Over the last two decades, many here say, it has become a national pursuit, as much a part of today's Thai culture as its Buddhist traditions. That's fine with Dhammakaya.
"The audience is the globalizing middle class, and Dhammakaya is telling people they can have it both ways," said Suwanna Satha-Anand, a professor of philosophy at Chulalongkorn University. "It is trying to transform Buddhism to make it comfortable with both capitalism and consumer culture."
For example, she said: "One teaching is, you make money Monday to Friday, then on Saturday and Sunday you come to the temple and meditate and your mind will be more supple and clear so that on Monday you can make more money."
All of this has thrown Thai Buddhism into an uproar. The sect's leader, Phra Dhammachayo, 55, has been accused of fraud and embezzlement as well as heresy. Newspapers are filled with demands that he be tried or defrocked or both. The top body of Thai Buddhism has demanded the abbot's removal and has summoned him for questioning -- all of which he has ignored, only deepening the public's sense that the traditional religious structure has become weak and irrelevant.
The controversy strikes at the cultural heart of Thailand, where Buddhism is a state religion in all but name and most of the country's 60 million people follow the established religion. Thailand is one of the few countries to adhere to the older form of Buddhism, the Theravada school. There are 40,000 temples in Thailand and 300,000 full-time monks, whose numbers are augmented each year by tens of thousands of young men who enter the monkhood for a short stay.
But respect for the monkhood has been shaken in recent years by scandals involving corruption and criminality. Monks frequently attract followers and make money by telling fortunes and suggesting lucky lottery numbers.
"To put it in a nutshell, traditional Buddhism does not cater for modern Thai people, only for those who go to temples for superstitions or astrologers or fortune telling," said Sulak Sivaraksa, a Buddhist scholar and social critic. "Otherwise people only care about the temples for funeral services and car parking." Many temples make extra money by letting out their grounds for parking.
Or in other words, said Kavi Chongkitavarn, a columnist for The Nation, an English-language daily: "It is Jurassic Park."
Ms. Suwanna offered a telling detail. "Over 95 percent of all the textbooks the monks read today were either written, revised or supervised by one monk, and that monk lived almost one century ago," she said.
By contrast, Wat Dhammakaya, the main temple, is modern: clean, efficient, quiet, with a huge underground garage and ample bathroom facilities. Almost all its monks have college degrees, while most other monks have only minimal education.
Unlike most temples, this is a place to spend the day, eating and meditating. People dressed mostly in white -- a sign of purity -- sit cross-legged in a huge open-sided hangar, with the distant abbot cloned on hundreds of video monitors.
Insulated from the traffic, pollution and abandoned, half-built office buildings of Bangkok, the giant temple offers a vague, one-world utopianism that has as much in common with New Age optimism as with Buddhism. "World peace through inner peace," proclaims the temple's literature.
"Maybe the new religion is peacefulness," Mr. Manit said. "Maybe we can share that. Share the similarities, avoid the differences; that is what we always say."
He added: "We are at the forefront. Maybe that is why we are being attacked."
