HEADLINE: Earle Jorgensen, Reagan Adviser, Dies at 101

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Earle M. Jorgensen, who built one of the nation's largest steel distribution companies and helped persuade Ronald Reagan to go into politics, died Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles.
He was 101 and until weeks before his death went to work nearly every day at the business he founded, the Earle M. Jorgensen Company in Brea, Calif., which has annual sales of about $1 billion. 
 Mr. Jorgensen served on Mr. Reagan's "kitchen cabinet," an informal network of businessmen who advised Mr. Reagan and urged him to run for governor of California in 1966 and later for President. But Mr. Jorgensen declined to take any job in Washington, saying that he wanted to stick with his business.
William A. Wilson, a California businessman who served as Ambassador to the Vatican in the Reagan Administration, said Mr. Jorgensen's personal success story "had a lot to do with influencing" Mr. Reagan's economic policies in support of free enterprise. "Everyone had appreciated the fact that Earle had started with nothing and built himself a nice fortune," Mr. Wilson said.
In a statement issued today, Mr. Reagan and his wife, Nancy, said: "Earle Jorgensen was one of our oldest and dearest friends, and we will miss him terribly. However, he has left us with many wonderful memories."
Mr. Jorgensen was a former chairman of the Los Angeles chapter of the American Red Cross and was the largest individual contributor to the chapter over the years. He donated to many universities and was a trustee of the California Institute of Technology for 42 years, despite having never gone to college, or even finishing high school. He was also a founder of the Los Angeles Music Center and the Los Angeles Art Museum and involved in many other civic organizations.
Mr. Jorgensen was born in San Francisco on June 22, 1898, the son of Danish immigrants. His father, a sea captain, died when Mr. Jorgensen was in high school, forcing him to drop out and get a job, according to Mr. Wilson, a friend who has known him since 1936.
After serving in the Army Tank Corps in World War I, Mr. Jorgensen came to Los Angeles in 1920 and, the next year, began trudging over sand dunes to sell steel to oilmen working on the beach. The business eventually prospered as a supplier to California's growing aerospace and construction industries.
In 1989, Mr. Jorgensen's son John, who had become president of the steel company, died of cancer at the age of 64, forcing Mr. Jorgensen, at age 91, to resume a more active role in the business. Mr. Jorgensen sold the company to Kelso & Company, a New York leveraged buyout firm, in 1990 for $264 million, with his 32 percent stake worth $84 million. He remained chairman until 1994, when he became chairman emeritus.
His slogan, written on a sign on his office wall, was "Hustle! -- That's All." In his desk he kept stacks of a book called "The Go-Getter: A Story That Tells You How to Be One," about a scrappy kid who becomes a successful salesman. Mr. Jorgensen had stumbled upon the book, written by Peter B. Kyne in 1921, in a bookstore and liked it so much he bought the publishing rights and gave away signed copies to visitors.
The friendship with Mr. Reagan came after Mr. Jorgensen was introduced to the Hollywood scene, apparently through his wife of 47 years, Marion, who had previously been married to Milton Bren, a Hollywood producer. Mr. Jorgensen became the stepfather of his wife's two sons, Donald and Peter Bren. Donald Bren is now a billionaire real estate developer as owner of the Irvine Company, outside of Los Angeles.
In addition to his wife and stepsons, Mr. Jorgensen is survived by two children from his first marriage, Maren Long of Ojai, Calif., and Earle M. Jorgensen Jr. of Mariposa, Calif. His son John and a daughter from that marriage, which ended in divorce, predeceased him. He also had 17 grandchildren, 21 great-grandchildren and one great-great-grandchild.
Mr. Jorgensen did not take up sports until learning to ski at age 59, according to Mr. Wilson. He then moved to tennis and golf. Even in his 100th year, he was getting up at 5 A.M. three days a week to work with a personal trainer. But work was always paramount and it seems he credited it for his longevity.
"I've always worked," he told Forbes magazine last year. "I'm too busy to die."

LENGTH: 718 words

HEADLINE: Waiting to See Reynolds' Cards

BYLINE: ByCLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Talk to industry insiders about Paul H. O'Neill, Alcoa's chairman, and words like "maverick," "stickler," even "ruthless," crop up all the time. But rarely does "poker player" enter the vocabulary.
Still, that may just be the role Mr. O'Neill is playing, as he waits to see what the Reynolds Metals Company's board will do when it meets on Sunday to discuss Alcoa's $5.8 billion bid to buy their company. Most everyone paying attention to the deal expects the board to say that the price, which comes out to about $65 a share, is just too low, and that Alcoa will have to sweeten the pot or Reynolds will go elsewhere. 
 Many industry observers say, however, that Reynolds has nowhere else to go. Alcan, Pechiney S.A. and Alusuisse Lonza Group A.G., the three big aluminum companies that Reynolds has talked to in the past, are busy combining their own operations. Although Jacques Bougie, Alcan's chief executive and the man who will head the merged mega-company, said yesterday that "we will rule out no options," few expect him to seriously entertain a Reynolds bid.
Reynolds might be bluffing. And most expect Mr. O'Neill to call that bluff.
"For Alcoa to offer more money would be like bidding against itself, and why would it want to do that?" said a person close to the talks.
In his 12-year tenure as Alcoa's chief, Mr. O'Neill has certainly not made a name for wasting money. He is often credited with keeping costs so low and management systems so lean that Alcoa could reap more profit from the metal than any other company in the business.
"In personality, he's not all that distinguishable from the other suits, but in vision, this man is truly innovative," said James N. Kelleher, an analyst with Argus Research.
Mr. O'Neill has been full of surprises from the day he joined Alcoa in 1987. That was the year that the Alcoa board, concluding that aluminum was a dead-end business, decided that only an outsider could get the company into more lucrative fields. It plucked Mr. O'Neill, who had been an outside director of Alcoa for a year, from the presidency of International Paper to be Alcoa's new leader.
Mr. O'Neill proceeded to do the opposite of what the board had expected. He scuttled a budding diversification program, instead snapping up aluminum assets in the United States and elsewhere.
Alcoa had been treating its overseas operations as ancillary. Mr. O'Neill treated them as pivotal to Alcoa's becoming a global presence. He formed a joint venture with Kobe Steel of Japan. When Alcoa executives advised him to shut down Alcoa's ailing Brazilian operations, he instead coordinated with local management to turn them around -- and groomed a Brazilian executive, Alain J. P. Belda, to be his successor. (Mr. Belda was recently named chief executive, and will become chairman when Mr. O'Neill retires in December 2000.)
By the late 1980's, many American executives had grown leery of bloated staffs and endless meetings, but Mr. O'Neill was allergic to them. Armed with degrees in economics and public administration, he had spent 16 years working for the Government, culminating with a stint as deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget from 1974 through 1977.
When he joined Alcoa, he began slashing. Early on, he wiped out two layers of management jobs, shuttered underproductive plants and reorganized the company in about 25 businesses.
Nor did he confine the benchmarking activity to internal operations. He adopted many quality control techniques from Kobe. He studied the Toyota Corporation's "just-in-time" inventory control and adapted it to Alcoa.
Alcoa's plants are now the smoothest running, lowest cost in the industry. They also have one of the best safety records -- a fact that Mr. O'Neill recites like a mantra, quoting safety statistics at the beginning of every conference call with analysts.
Last year, Mr. O'Neill introduced what is probably the most visible symbol of the made-over Alcoa. He moved the company's 400 headquarters employees -- down from 2,000 when he first took over -- into a sparkling new six-story building in Pittsburgh. It has no elevators, no long corridors and no doors on offices. Escalators link the floors. And no one's office is bigger than 9 feet by 9 feet, not even Mr. O'Neill's.

HEADLINE: SOCCER: MetroStars Struggle to Get a Footing;
In City Where Success Counts, Team Is Losing Games and Fans Are Losing Patience

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Their MetroStars had lost 15 of 20 games and had scored no goals in 366 minutes. For their season tickets, the fans wanted spirit but what they saw were sad sacks in shorts. When asked to express his frustration during a bus ride to Wednesday night's MetroStars game at Giants Stadium, a fan named Brent Gamit spelled aloud, "C-H-A-R-L-I-E," the first name of the team's general manager, Charlie Stillitano.
And Gamit offered a mordant toast of beer bottles with a friend, Holly Duthie. 
 "To a shootout loss!" he said as the bus rolled along Route 3.
"I don't even remember what a goal would look like," Duthie said.
"You wish there was relegation, so the MetroStars could go down to the second division for a couple of years," said Blaise Dupuy, a recording engineer from Manhattan, referring to the policy of demotion that awaits failing teams in European and South American leagues.
These are difficult days for the MetroStars, the New York-New Jersey beachhead of the four-year-old Major League Soccer, a laboratory for soccer socialism with a single-entity structure that handles all player signings centrally.
Because the team has never posted a winning season, the MetroStars are discovering how difficult it is to barge into a market saturated with 10 other major league teams, and to look even moderately successful when 15,000 fans spread to watch an underachieving team in a massive 77,000-seat stadium.
But it is even harder to generate fan and sponsor support when the team undergoes a hefty turnover of players and coaches. And the hoped-for Holy Grail of a new soccer-only stadium is at least a couple of years away.
"When things haven't worked out, we've gone through a series of Band-Aids that haven't worked," said Stuart Subotnick, one of two investor-operators of the MetroStars and the M.L.S. chairman of the board. "You may not believe it, but we're trying to improve the MetroStars."
Although the MetroStars finally scored on Wednesday -- and even led, 1-0 -- they lost by 4-1 to powerful D.C. United and endured their 16th loss. The announced attendance of 6,876 for a sultry weeknight game rescheduled from Oct. 6 seemed to be three times larger than the actual crowd.
The MetroStars' average attendance of 17,608 is the league's fourth best -- although it ignores the season's 52,000 no-shows -- yet they have lost more money than any other team in a league that has lost $100 million since its inception.
The team's television ratings on the MSG Network have plunged 48 percent since 1996, worse than the 42 percent drop in the league's ESPN ratings. Most league games are carried by ESPN2, where ratings have perked up 23 percent this season.
"We're obviously concerned about not being successful in New York," said Don Garber, a National Football League executive who replaced Doug Logan as the M.L.S. commissioner last week. "It's a major priority to work on. Nothing could be more important than having a New York franchise winning more games and having a higher level of appeal."
The MetroStars have a 48-69 regular-season record and have faltered in two playoff appearances. They have used a league-high 78 players and are being led by their fifth coach, Bora Milutinovic.
Yet the team is resisting a clamor from critics and fans to dismiss Stillitano, the general manager. They say that he has turned over the roster too frequently to suit coaches' whims; that he wrongly hired as the team's first coach Eddie Firmani, who left after eight games amid tension with his players, and then had two more coaches bolt for better offers abroad; and that he unearthed too few foreign players of the caliber of Roberto Donadoni, who departed to return to his Italian league team, AC Milan.
Stillitano said fans now unfairly compare the MetroStars to the Columbus Crew in Ohio, "which they view as the epitome of a well-run organization, but in Years 1 through 3, they had one more win than we did." Actually, it was two.
This year, Columbus is 14-7 and second in the Eastern Conference, after three years of finishing 15-17.
The best marketing tool is often a winning team, which the MetroStars are not. The MetroStars' woes are exacerbated, in part, by a core audience that has fond memories of the New York Cosmos of the North American Soccer League, with its roster of international superstars like Pele and Giorgio Chinaglia.
The M.L.S. would love to have a wildly popular New York team like the Cosmos, but not by overspending, which doomed the N.A.S.L.
"This team is completely devoid of stars and celebrities in a market spoiled by the Cosmos," said Leandro Stillitano, a vice president of Integrated Sports International, a sports marketing firm. Stillitano is a brother of the MetroStars' general manager and a former team executive.
Still, one critic said, the MetroStars have not thrived in a league with lower expectations. "The problem is 90 percent management, but the absolutely extraordinary thing is the only one who doesn't see it is Subotnick," said Paul Gardner, a columnist for the weekly Soccer America. "No g.m. with this record for three and a half years should last this long."
Subotnick said: "I don't attribute bad luck and injuries to Charlie. I won't give in to a hatchet job of someone who doesn't have full player control."
Last year, however, Subotnick relieved Stillitano of his marketing duties, replacing him with Jim Leahy, the vice president for marketing, who has built a data base of fans, has tried to increase season tickets above 6,500 and has put games on Spanish-language radio and bought time on WFAN-AM for a weekly soccer show.
Indeed, no M.L.S. general manager can exert full roster control, as, say Steve Phillips of the Mets can. In the M.L.S. single-entity system, players are signed by the league, paid from a central fund and allocated to the 12 teams to ostensibly create parity.
General managers can scout players and recommend which ones they want, but if they are too costly, the league will not approve them. The league has never paid more than $2 million for a foreign player, thus restricting its participation in a free-for-all world market. Spain's Real Madrid recently paid Arsenal of England's Premier League a $35.7 million transfer fee for Nicolas Anelka.
"If Charlie was running the Knicks or Yankees, every one of his decisions would be his responsibility," Subotnick said. "But he can only suggest and recommend players he wants."
The single-entity system is designed to hold at bay the spiral of player costs caused by free agency and salary arbitration in other sports. There are no traditional owners, but investor-operators who hire coaches and general managers and control front-office operations like sales and marketing. The single-entity system is also employed by the Women's National Basketball Association, which is controlled and bankrolled by the N.B.A.
M.L.S. executives note that the average 1999 attendance of 14,994 is healthy for a four-year-old league (but down 14 percent from the inaugural 1996 season) and better than the W.N.B.A's season-to-date average of 9,768.
The comparison is imprecise. W.N.B.A. teams play in 15,000- to 20,000-seat arenas, while M.L.S. teams play largely in football stadiums. And eight of the W.N.B.A.'s 12 teams reap the cost benefits of playing in arenas owned by their parent N.B.A. clubs. Although there is considerable wealth among the M.L.S. investors, greater confidence is seen in the N.B.A.'s backing of its offspring.
The M.L.S.'s system of governance is being challenged in Federal court by players who charge that the single-entity system is a traditional league in disguise with investor-operators who illegally conspire to restrain salaries.
Even Subotnick is unhappy with the way some players are distributed. "We haven't built up teams from the bottom the way we should," he said. "It hasn't always worked right. It's not a perfect world."
Six months ago, the M.L.S. deputy commissioner Sunil Gulati, a respected soccer expert who was in charge of player allocation, was dismissed by Logan for renewing the contract of MetroStars midfielder Tab Ramos without informing Subotnick. The injured Ramos has played in only five games this season.
The MetroStars not only need better players, but stronger economics. Their rent is the league's highest (from $15,000 to $60,000 a game), said Subotnick, and they have been unable to get some M.L.S. sponsors to advertise at Giants Stadium because they are in conflict with some of the facility's sponsors.
Like most team executives hankering for a new stadium, Subotnick said the MetroStars were in dire need of a facility where they could control all revenues, not share them as they do with the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.
Subotnick said the team would choose later this year between sites at the Meadowlands and in Newark to build a $40 million, 27,500-seat stadium.
The model for a new soccer-specific stadium is the new one built by Lamar Hunt, the investor-operator of the Columbus Crew, who also owns the Kansas City Chiefs of the National Football League.
"It's hard to make seats scarce in an 80,000-seat stadium or sell season tickets if you can just get tickets by walking up," Subotnick said.
Subotnick said the league is examining whether to sell a 20 percent stake in the league to the public to raise money to help build more new stadiums. The plan, of course, would have to overcome skepticism about the future of a league in which no team has made a profit and two teams lack investor-operators.
"Everybody talks about survival," said Mark Abbott, the M.L.S.'s chief operating officer. "There are no survival issues here. Lamar Hunt didn't invest $28 million in a stadium if he thought we were going out of business."

HEADLINE: Venezuelan Leader Moves a Step Closer to Broad New Powers

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Venezuela's newly empowered Constitutional Assembly approved a decree today that gives the group far-reaching authority to abolish Government institutions and dismiss officials, and strengthens the authority of President Hugo Chavez.
Citing what it called the "exhaustion, collapse and loss of legitimacy" of the current political and administrative structure, the assembly gave itself the right to "decree measures pertaining to the competency, functioning and organization of the public powers of the state." No date was set for the relinquishment of the special powers, with the decree stating that the edict would remain in effect "until the cessation of the situation that justifies it." 
 Mr. Chavez, a 45-year-old former Army paratrooper who in 1992 led an unsuccessful coup attempt, took office in February vowing to carry out a peaceful social revolution in his country, which in recent years has become the principal source of imported oil for the United States. But his critics maintain that his real aim is to impose a left-wing military dictatorship on the South American nation and its 23 million people.
Sworn in last week, the assembly has six months to write a new Constitution to replace the country's current charter, which dates from 1961. Mr. Chavez, however, urged the representatives to speed up their work so that a plebiscite can be held before year's end, and submitted a draft constitution that would expand his term to six years and permit him to succeed himself in office.
In theory, the decree formalized today would allow the assembly to dissolve the Congress and the Supreme Court, as Mr. Chavez repeatedly threatened to do before the July 25 special election to pick 131 assembly delegates. Seeking to avoid such a confrontation, Congress went into recess until October and even offered to let the new body hold sessions in the capital building.
Assembly members have made it clear, however, that they intend to resolve hundreds of cases involving lower-court judges accused of taking or demanding bribes. They have also called for the dismissal of several popularly elected state governors and mayors, many of whom are opponents of Mr. Chavez, that they maintain are corrupt.
Acting in accordance with his own argument that all other government organs are subordinate to the new assembly, Mr. Chavez even volunteered to resign as President if the body so desired. But, to no one's surprise, his offer was rejected, and on Wednesday he took his oath of office again before the body, delivering a speech in which he spoke of a deepening economic crisis and denounced what he called "an international campaign against Venezuela."
Supporters of Mr. Chavez, including his wife, a brother and a half dozen members of his Cabinet, occupy 120 of the 131 seats in the all-powerful body. Three other seats are reserved for representatives of the country's Indian tribes, meaning that supporters of Venezuela's two traditional political parties and other members of the opposition account for only eight seats.
One of those critics, the lawyer Alan Brewer Carias, described the special powers measure as too broadly drawn, and "the equivalent of declaring a state of siege." Isaias Rodriguez, a vice president of the assembly, dismissed such concerns, describing the document as merely "a declaration of competence to deal with national problems."

HEADLINE: Suspect in Los Angeles Shootings Confesses to a Killing

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12

 BODY:
In chilling detail, Buford O. Furrow Jr., the man held in a shooting on Tuesday at a Jewish community center here, has confessed that he shot a Filipino-American letter carrier because he was a nonwhite "target of opportunity."
Mr. Furrow told investigators that he was driving down a quiet residential street in a Toyota he had carjacked when he spotted the letter carrier, 39-year-old Joseph Santos Ileto, in his uniform, stuffing letters in a mailbox next to a mail truck. 
 Mr. Furrow said he thought Mr. Ileto was Hispanic or Asian, and he told investigators that he stopped his car and asked Mr. Ileto if he would mail a letter. Mr. Ileto agreed. Mr. Furrow said he then pulled a Glock Model 26 pistol from his back pocket and shot Mr. Ileto twice. But that was not the end, he said.
"He stated that the mail carrier bent over and attempted to run away," said a criminal complaint filed on Wednesday but unsealed this morning. "He then shot the mail carrier a few times in the back until he saw the mail carrier fall to the ground face down."
Mr. Ileto was shot at close range nine times.
The complaint added that five of the nine shots that hit Mr. Ileto were considered fatal by the coroner. Both the Federal and state authorities filed murder charges today in that killing. Either could bring the death penalty.
At a news conference this morning the District Attorney, Gil Garcetti, said he separately filed a seven-count complaint against Mr. Furrow, 37, including the hate-motivated murder of Mr. Ileto, the attempted murder of the five people at the Jewish center and carjacking.
Mr. Furrow made an initial appearance before a Federal magistrate on the murder charge and on another felony count, illegal possession of a firearm. He was denied bail. But the relaxed, heavyset man in prison blues, handcuffs and shackles stood in stunning contrast to the cold-blooded, racist murderer described by the United States Attorney and the Los Angeles District Attorney.
Mr. Furrow, about 5 feet 8 inches tall, with close-cropped hair, a mustache and wire-rimmed, aviator-style glasses sliding down his nose, shuffled into the courtroom so quietly at 11 A.M. that few of the several dozen reporters present seemed to notice him initially.
He tersely answered a few procedural questions posed by the Federal magistrate, Carolyn Turchin, and spoke up only once in the seven-minute hearing, to correct her when she read his name, adding "Junior" after she said Buford O. Furrow.
In trying to fill in details of Mr. Furrow's rampage here on Tuesday, the authorities only added to the questions about how Mr. Furrow, a well-known member of white supremacist groups and a convicted felon, could amass the money he used to pay for his expedition to Los Angeles from his home in Washington State and the huge arsenal of weapons he brought with him.
He was believed to be unemployed with a history of losing jobs, but he used at least $4,000 to buy a van last Saturday. He then spent $800 on a taxi ride to Las Vegas, Nev. Law-enforcement officials would not comment on whether they have evidence that he received financial or other kinds of assistance.
The shootings began about 10:49 A.M. on Tuesday, when he entered the North Valley Jewish Community Center in the Granada Hills section of Los Angeles and squeezed off at least 70 shots with an Uzi submachine gun, hitting five people, including three children at a day camp.
All five are now recovering, although one 5-year-old boy was still listed in critical condition today. He then fled in his van, parked it then carjacked the Toyota, the police said.
"There is evidence that the murder was racially motivated," said Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the United States Attorney here.
Another puzzling element was added today when the taxi company that transported Mr. Furrow to Las Vegas after the shootings said that he had hailed the taxi near the heart of Hollywood, about 20 miles from where he had abandoned the Toyota after shooting Mr. Ileto. Somehow he covered that distance in spite of a police dragnet in the vicinity of the crimes.
Alexander Konopov of the Independent Taxi Company said a driver, Hovik Garibyan, had picked up Mr. Furrow near Sunset Boulevard. and Cherokee Street between 5 P.M. and 6 P.M. Mr. Furrow initially asked to be taken to the airport, then said he was afraid of flying and asked to be taken to Las Vegas, Mr. Konopov said.
A price of $800 was negotiated, Mr. Furrow paid with $100 and $50 bills, and then he slept most of the way.
In addition to raising serious concerns about a conspiracy, the shootings also intensified the debate over gun control. Mr. Furrow had such a large arsenal, including handguns, an assault rifle, hand grenades and thousands of rounds of ammunition, that the police had said earlier they felt lucky more people had not been hurt.
President Clinton commented on the shootings today, calling them "another compelling argument for the passage of hate crimes legislation and the common-sense gun legislation." Law-enforcement officials have not yet said how they believe Mr. Furrow obtained the weapons or the results of any tracing they have done of the origins of the guns.
The Federal complaint unsealed today listed two charges, the premeditated murder of a Federal employee in the performance of his duties, and the illegal possession of a firearm by a convicted felon. Mr. Furrow was convicted of attempted assault in Washington State last year. Mr. Mayorkas said Mr. Furrow could face other Federal charges. His next hearing on the Federal charges will be on Aug. 24.
Law-enforcement officials did their best to present a unified front, since there had been a behind-the scenes struggle between the United States Attorney's office and the District Attorney over who would charge and try Mr. Furrow first. Those issues remained unresolved today, but at the news conference Mr. Garcetti said they had formed a joint task force to continue the investigation and to determine when and where Mr. Furrow would ultimately be tried.
"We intend to continue working together to insure that justice is served," said Mr. Garcetti, who added that he expected Mr. Furrow to be arraigned on the state charges within a few days.

HEADLINE: Forbes Puts His Money and His Message on the Line in Iowa's Straw Poll

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: AMES, Iowa, Aug. 11

 BODY:
Aboard his high-tech bus, watching the corn fields whiz by, Steve Forbes is wheeling into town squares all over Iowa these days in search of respect as a Presidential contender.
Mr. Forbes -- publisher, politician and patrician -- is a blur of nonstop motion, rolling around the rural landscape at the rate of four to six cities a day, 180 events in four weeks. He is seeking enough support -- and spending whatever it takes -- to make a respectable showing in the Republican straw poll here on Saturday, a prize that confers headline status even though it is no real test of voter sentiment. 
 Accompanied by an entourage in two shiny big buses equipped with the latest satellite and digital gear, Mr. Forbes is banking on a decent enough showing to justify the $10 million he has spent on his message of conservative morals, politics and economics, themes his advisers say resonate best in rural America.
For all his money, in fact, Mr. Forbes is often seen here as being a regular guy, as he travels the byways from Grundy Center to Marengo, Pella to Monona.
"I back everything he said," said William Baretich, a retired high school principal who showed up at a Forbes event this week in Eagle Grove. "So far as I am concerned, his wealth is a plus. I have no idea how he got it, but he's got a good business sense and we need someone with his expertise to run the Government because it's probably the biggest corporation of them all."
Alone among the Presidential candidates to foot his own bill, Mr. Forbes, chief executive of the business magazine Forbes, whose net worth is estimated at $440 million to $500 million, said he would spend whatever it took to be competitive with Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. Mr. Forbes spent more than $35 million on his failed Presidential bid in 1996. Mr. Bush has raised more than $36 million, and both candidates have opted out of the campaign finance system and its limits on spending.
"Be assured," Mr. Forbes, 52, said, without being specific, in a back-of-the-bus interview, "I will spend enough to be very competitive."
In Iowa, what he is buying, besides lots of radio and television advertisements, is organization, which is what really counts in the nearly 25-year-old Iowa straw vote. His campaign entourage has been pulling up to American Legion and Elks halls in hundreds of quiet Iowa towns, the sound system on the buses blaring Mr. Forbes's presence like a political music man. While the scenes can be charmingly old-fashioned, the buses are anything but.
Inside, they look like something from a James Bond movie set. A squadron of clean-cut young men, all in identical khaki pants and blue polo shirts emblazoned with the Forbes logo, operate from a hidden high-tech world of laptops, digital laser printers and satellite phones, and make use of three cellular telephone line connections and two dedicated lines for modem use from any town square. Also in the entourage are a bevy of young women in khaki skirts and white polo shirts with the Forbes logo, who hand out Forbes materials, as well as a separate small crew of men in khaki pants and gray polos with a Forbes Iowa logo, who are local supporters.
All the gadgetry is intended to create grass-roots support, and what it means is this: Names and phone numbers written on cards handed out at the events are put into the campaign data bank before the bus reaches the next town; Anyone who wants a picture taken with the candidate gets a color laser copy of the photo before the campaign event is over, and any photos taken can be instantaneously put onto the Forbes campaign Web site, which has received 35 million hits, the Forbes staff said, and drawn 25,000 volunteers on line.
"We're using the Wal-Mart strategy," said K. B. Forbes, the campaign's Iowa press secretary, who is no relation to the candidate. "We are hitting the rural areas first. We're finding the activists who are attracted to Mr. Forbes. All the other candidates are focusing on the chiefs, the elites. We're focusing on the Indians, the grass-roots activists."
This weekend will be the first test of whether Mr. Forbes's messages really do resonate here. 
In his endless stream of gatherings, typically attracting 40 to 80 people, Mr. Forbes offers a stump speech that attacks abortion, Washington-as-usual politics and the recent interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve Chairman, Alan Greenspan, while extolling a flat 15 percent income tax, higher military spending and greater choice in school and health care selection.
He has loosened up his speaking style, and, while he still appears to be more the banker than the politician, his words are greeted with respectful interest and standing ovations in this politically conservative region. His reference to the "infernal revenue service" is a standard laugh-getter, with his designation of Washington officeholders as "critters looking for the honey pot" of money.
Cora Goodman liked what she heard when Mr. Forbes appeared in Gundy Center, her hometown, this week. "We need a leader to carry on the Reagan policies," Ms. Goodman said. "His idea for a flat tax is honest and simple, and he's not a Washington politician."
John Whalen of Eldora said, "We're in a world of hurt here, and we've got to get the Government out of things, whether it's farming or Medicare. He's right on those issues."
The Iowa straw poll has been criticized as a way for the local Republican Party to gather publicity and dollars -- everyone who votes in it must pay a $25 entry fee and voting must be done in person here in Ames. As a result, candidates like Mr. Forbes pick up the $25 fee for supporters and try to get as many people as they can to come to Ames on a hot summer weekend to vote in a poll that is not binding.
It is a contest where money matters, and Mr. Forbes is pouring on his resources: His aides say they have lined up 85 buses to transport potential voters -- for a total of about 4,000 people in a contest where 10,000 to 15,000 are expected to vote. To attract supporters, Mr. Forbes is offering them a barbecue party in Ames beneath two air-conditioned tents where the country music singer Ronnie Milsap and the inspirational singer Debby Boone will entertain.
Such spending, especially from so wealthy a man, is not troublesome to some here.
Catherine Broer of Iowa Falls, who said she typically voted Democratic, said Mr. Forbes's wealth "was one of the reasons why he intrigues me."
"He's willing to risk his personal fortune in this endeavor," Ms. Broer said.
Keith Schwebke, also of Iowa Falls, said: "His wealth does give him the ability to compete with the Bushes. Yet he still comes across as a common guy I could go up and talk to."
While Mr. Forbes may be dismissed by some as indulging in the political fantasies of a rich man, he sees himself as a man with a message. He contends that the Republican Party has failed when it offers candidates who are long on image but short on policy substance.
"There can be no victory without a message," he said. "Right now, my party is rallied around one candidate," he said, referring to Mr. Bush. "But those who want real change will come more and more to this campaign."
In contrast to his slow start in 1996, Mr. Forbes came out early and aggressively this time, and is sustained by the belief that the party establishment will no longer shrug off his candidacy if he does well in early party caucuses.
Mr. Forbes is spending his money on television, radio and newspaper advertisements and direct mail and phone banks in crucial early states like Iowa, New Hampshire, Arizona and California. As a measure of how the candidate is doing, his campaign likes to pull out a headline from The Fairfield Ledger which said: "Forbes, author of the flat tax, sings to the choir in Fairfield."

HEADLINE: To Save Money, Spend the Surplus on Health;
New Yorkers' Penalty

 BODY:

To the Editor:
John Tierney is right that New York State pays a disproportionate share of Federal income taxes (Big City column, Aug. 9). The tax structure is unfair to New Yorkers, whose taxable incomes are not adjusted for the high cost of living, and puts a huge fiscal drag on our economy. 
 In 1993 the Federal tax increase drained more money out of New York than all but two states, Connecticut and New Jersey. By absorbing funds needed for spending and investment in recession-stricken New York, our recovery was more difficult. Sadly, the increases were passed with the support of many of New York's representatives in Washington.
It's time for substantial tax relief for New York and its neighbors. Congress's tax cut would undo some of the 1993 damage.
 
STEPHEN KAGANN
New York, Aug. 10, 1999
 
The writer is chief economist to the Governor.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Tax Cut Poses More Risks for Giuliani Than for Mrs. Clinton

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Across the nation, Congressional Republicans fanned out this week to rally support for the $792 billion tax cut -- the cornerstone of their 2000 election effort -- that President Clinton has pledged to veto. Across New York, Hillary Rodham Clinton, advocating the Democratic line as she prepares for a probable run for Senate, denounced the same bill as a threat to Medicare, Social Security and the nation's financial health.
Those conflicting political views have now converged at the feet of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the New York Republican who, like Mrs. Clinton, is considering a race for the Senate next year. Suddenly, Mr. Giuliani is finding himself squeezed on one side by Mrs. Clinton and on the other by conservative Republicans who are pressing him to take a position on a piece of legislation that he would, presumably, like to avoid discussing for as long as possible. 
 Since Ronald Reagan came to Washington in 1981, reducing taxes and government spending have been the defining issues for Republican officeholders in this nation. That philosophy shaped the nearly $800 billion tax cut that Congress passed earlier this summer, the largest since Mr. Reagan was in office, and it is the program that Congressional leaders hope to run on next year.
But there is no evidence, pollsters and political consultants said yesterday, that New York voters of either party share quite the passion of Congressional Republicans on tax cuts, particularly during flush economic times. That is particularly true when cuts are presented as coming at the cost of spending on programs that are relatively popular, like Social Security and Medicare.
"Mayor Rudy Giuliani will have a difficult time mobilizing the New York electorate using tax cuts as his message," said Jonathan W. Siegel, director of the Harris Poll Election 2000 unit. "Barring a change in the political or economic environment, they are simply not that compelling an issue to most people."
Initially, Mr. Giuliani, while reiterating his own support for more Federal tax cuts, declined to say how he would have voted on the tax cut bill, saying he had not had an opportunity to study it. By yesterday, under attack by Judith Hope, the chairwoman of the state Democratic Party, and Representative Rick A. Lazio, the conservative Republican who had threatened to challenge Mr. Giuliani for the senatorial nomination, the Mayor offered a slightly more expansive view on the measure.
Mr. Giuliani said that he backed large tax cuts, but not as large as those that had been legislated by the Republicans.
Mr. Giuliani did not say whether he would actually have bucked his party's leadership had he been in Washington to vote against the bill; Mrs. Clinton has repeatedly said she would have voted against it.
On one hand, the debate on the Republican tax cut has presented New Yorkers with a sharp and early contrast between the two probable major party candidates for Senate. Over the last few weeks, Mrs. Clinton has been talking first about assuring the viability of two of the nation's largest spending programs, Medicare and Social Security. By contrast, Mr. Giuliani has talked mainly about cutting taxes, particularly the capital gains tax.
Beyond that, Mr. Giuliani's predicament suggests that Mrs. Clinton is not alone in confronting some fairly tricky ground in the year ahead, as each seeks to please the diverse political agendas of supporters. In Mrs. Clinton's case, the main complication is her husband's administration; for Mr. Giuliani, it is the Republican leadership in Congress, as well as conservative voters in New York.
There is no doubt that the Republican Party, intense in its devotion to defeating Mrs. Clinton, will give Mr. Giuliani some room to move as he seeks office in a state where Democratic voters hold the edge.
"Short of endorsing Al Gore, Rudy Giuliani can do anything he wants, and the Beltway G.O.P. will tolerate it," said Nelson Warfield, a Republican consultant. "Rudy Giuliani has cheated on the national party repeatedly, and on issues like the tax cut, he'll stray again. But the G.O.P. leadership is married to him."
But there is only so far that this Republican in particular can go in defying the Republican leadership in Congress, should he choose to do so. Mr. Giuliani is already viewed suspiciously in Republican circles, given his moderate position on such issues as abortion rights and gay rights, and his endorsement of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, in 1994.
Tax cuts are a particularly central issue for the party, as has become clear this year on Capitol Hill. And Washington politics notwithstanding, Mr. Giuliani has to take care not to take positions that discourage Republican voters from turning out. And he presumably needs to make sure that the Conservative Party, which has made no secret of its concerns about Mr. Giuliani's opinions, does not abandon him in the 2000 election.
That is what explains Mrs. Clinton's decision to attack the tax bill at her recent listening seminars; though she never mentions Mr. Giuliani's name, she is trying to force him to deal with the issue. Mrs. Clinton found herself in a curious lock step with Mr. Lazio when he criticized Mr. Giuliani for not taking a position on the issue.
Still, even in New York, the tax cut is not a cut-and-dried issue, and for all of Mr. Giuliani's difficulties, Mrs. Clinton may not have an easy time using it against him.
That is because income in the Northeast is so high, and New York residents are apt to get back a disproportionate amount of any Federal tax cuts. And because living costs in the region are so high, a tax cut that might be attacked by Democrats in other parts of the nation as benefiting the upper class will in fact be of interest to many upper-income New Yorkers who consider themselves middle class.
That was why Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, the chairman of the Democratic Senate Campaign Committee, voted for the initial Republican version of the tax cut bill.
"It's a caution I'm giving to Hillary," Mr. Torricelli said yesterday. "What may have looked like a significant income tax cut in Arkansas is decidedly middle class in New York and New Jersey."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Beekman Town House Going Condo

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
Work is winding down on a $10.5 million renovation to transform a 19th-century single-family town house that has long been vacant on Beekman Place into a seven-unit condominium building, a first for this tony two-block stretch of Manhattan, between 49th and 51st Streets on the East River.
The seven-story building, at 25-27 Beekman Place, will have seven one- and two-story apartments, including a penthouse. The apartments will all have terraces, river views and fireplaces -- as many as three -- and will range in size from 1,725 to 2,950 square feet. The prices will be from $2.6 million to $5.2 million. The ground-floor duplex units also have gardens. 
 The developer is Enrico Minoli, an investment banker from Italy, who stumbled upon the 40-foot-wide building, between 50th and 51st Streets while he was seeking a Manhattan pied-a-terre, said Elizabeth Sample, a director at Brown Harris Stevens, the brokerage firm. Ms. Sample and her associate, Brenda Powers, are the sales agents.
Combining the two ground-floor duplexes for his own use, Mr. Minoli was hoping that others would want to buy units in an intimate building.
"I wanted to incorporate the luxury and elegance of the European life style into functional yet sophisticated living in Manhattan," Mr. Minoli said. Contracts have been signed for three of the remaining five apartments, the sales agents said.
The Minoli project is not the only example of a large town house in a prime location undergoing conversion to condominiums. At 136 East 19th Street, between Third Avenue and Irving Place, a 47-foot-wide five-story town house is being turned into five apartments of 2,200 to 2,400 square feet that are for sale. Prices have not been set, according to the Sunshine Group, which is marketing the project.
At 3 East 80th Street, off Fifth Avenue, a 40-foot-wide six-story town house is becoming two apartments, one with 8,000 square feet for the developer. The other, with 6,000 square feet, is to be sold for $9.75 million.
And a development team from Greenwich, Conn. -- Stephen Weiss and Stuart Berelson, principals in the Newhardscabble Corporation -- is building a new high-end town house condominium -- a five-story building at 9 East 64th Street, between Madison and Fifth Avenues. The building, designed to blend with its neighbors, will have three condominium apartments, ranging in size from 3,300 to 6,800 square feet, and in price from $3.9 million to $7.5 million, according to Douglas Elliman, another brokerage that is marketing the building as well as the one at East 80th Street.
The activity, brokers say, is constrained because of the limited inventory of one- and two-family town houses in Manhattan, which the Real Estate Board of New York put at 2,854. Zoning restrictions are also a factor. Large town houses in prime locations are even more scarce and generally are being bought by people as private homes, said Sharon Baum, director of the exclusive property division at the Corcoran Group.
Nan MarElia, director of the town house division at Douglas Elliman, added, "The few buildings being turned into apartments represent special opportunities to create condos in a town house setting, but developers must buy them at the right price to make the economics work."
In the last year, prices for town houses have risen. According to the Real Estate Board, the median sales price for East Side town houses increased to $2.5 million in 1998 from $1.7 million in 1997 and for West Side town houses, it rose to $1.4 million from $1.3 million.
Beekman Place is named for the Beekman family, which in 1763 built its long-since-demolished riverfront mansion, Mount Pleasant, there. Today, few town houses become available and, with the United Nations nearby, many are used as foreign missions and consulates.
Still, two are for sale at $5.6 million and $21 million, brokers report. Ms. Sample of Brown Harris Stevens said town houses in good condition were selling for $8 million to $9 million. And at 1 Beekman Place, the 39-unit cooperative that John D. Rockefeller developed in the 1920's, a three-bedroom, 4,500-square-foot unit is on the market for between $7 million and $8 million, she said.
The units at 25-27 Beekman Place are selling for an average of $1,200 a square foot, which is competitive and slightly below the price for new condominium apartments on Fifth, Madison and Park Avenues, she said.
Mr. Minoli bought the Beekman Place town house in 1997 for $5 million. The building is known as the Merle-Smith House after Van Santvoord Merle-Smith, a diplomat and banker, who bought the two houses in 1927 and gave them a neo-classical facade. It also had a squash court.
It was sold in 1984 to a developer who proposed a 60-story building on the site. Local residents successfully battled the proposal in court and won a zoning change to restrict the height of new buildings to the neighborhood's low-rise scale, said Buddy Radisch, president of the Beekman Place Association, a neighborhood group. After that, the town house sat vacant.
In 1998, Mr. Minoli began renovating the building, including installing new mechanical systems, creating a lobby and adding terraces as well as a rooftop room for the penthouse. The building will be faced with white limestone-colored stucco and most of the one- to three-bedroom units will have entry foyers and nine-foot ceilings. The renovation architect is Constantine Wickenberg of Manhattan.
The project was delayed for six months through last March because of a change in construction companies. Occupancy is expected in October, Ms. Sample said.

HEADLINE: Resisting a Society's Rage to Spend;
Robert H. Frank Wants to Rein In Galloping Consumption With a Tax

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y.

 BODY:
On the bulletin board of Robert H. Frank's office at Cornell University here are two glossy photos.
One is of a Porsche 911 Turbo, price $105,000. The other is of a Patek Philippe Calibre '89 timepiece, price $2.7 million. 
 They are not there as objects of lust, but they are not there quite as objects of mere censorious academic disapproval either.
Instead, they symbolize the subject of Mr. Frank's work on the psychology and utility of spending and the relative virtues of public and private consumption. Indeed, Mr. Frank, whose newest book is "Luxury Fever" (Free Press, 1999), has become the popular economist of the moment and academia's most conspicuous critic of the dizzy spendathon of the 90's. He argues that people are caught in an arms race of consumption and that tax policies need to be changed to encourage public investment over private spending.
Mr. Frank's new-found celebrity -- he has become an opinion-page regular of various newspapers and an ascendant talking head on television -- has not come without criticism. Even some friendly economists fault his work for being long on supposition and short on data. And conservative economists say the government has no business encouraging or discouraging people from buying luxury goods they want.
But even some who see his prescriptions as political nonstarters concede that Mr. Frank has ventured into one of the most intriguing thickets in economics and modern life: why people spend money, what they spend it on, whether they spend it on the right things.
"What's smart for each individual may not make sense for the group," said Mr. Frank, who is 54. "It's very often smart for one, dumb for all. It's my core idea. I've been pushing it for 25 years, but when I wrote about it back in 1985, no one wanted to discuss it. I'm glad people are listening now."
Mr. Frank, who has an undergraduate degree in mathematics, a masters degree in statistics and a doctorate in economics has taken a textbook route from cloistered academic to op-ed page regular and talking head.
His early books, like "Choosing the Right Pond: Human Behavior and the Quest for Status" (Oxford University Press, 1985) focused on rivalry and cooperation in economic and social behavior and were written for a largely academic audience.
But in recent years Mr. Frank has emerged as a purveyor of deceptively simple ideas that have skillfully tied economic issues to broad social problems. In 1995, he and his co-author, Philip J. Cook, published "The Winner Take-All Society," which argued that the economy and public life is being warped by a society increasingly dominated by a few big winners and many losers. Instead of thousands of privately owned coffee shops, there are now thousands of Starbucks. Students, instead of happily going to their local college, are funneled into a national sweepstakes in which the lucky few get into Harvard. The outcome, they argue, is a high-stress society that directs too many resources in the wrong direction and generates wasteful spending patterns.
In "Luxury Fever: Why Money Fails to Satisfy in an Era of Excess," Mr. Frank updates many of the ideas of "Choosing the Right Pond," to the Land Rover-stock options-Chateau Latour era. In the earlier book he examined the ways, as he saw it, in which "people come into the world equipped with an inner voice urging them to rank as high as possible on whatever social hierarchy they belong to."
In the new one, he analyzes the boom in luxury spending, whether for a $5,000 Viking-Frontgate Professional Grill, a $17,500 Patek Philippe wristwatch, a $1,800-a-night suite at the Four Seasons Resort in Palm Beach, Fla., or a $48,000 Lexus LX450 sport-utility vehicle.
He argues, as he did in "Choosing the Right Pond," that spending choices have more to do with comparative values than absolute ones. A 3,000-square-foot house that would be a palace in Japan, for example, or even in 1970's America, no longer measures up if your neighbor's house has 4,000 square feet. If competitors are wearing $1,500 suits to job interviews, you need to do the same thing.
There are other critics of consumption, many of them allied with the notion of "voluntary simplicity," which argues for individuals to scale down their lives and demands.
Unlike them, Mr. Frank contends that hyper-consumption can make sense for individuals. If they want the best school district for their child, it might make sense to buy an overpriced house in an exclusive town. If others are driving enormous sport utilities vehicles, people might not be safe in an economical, environmentally friendly Honda Civic. Like a crowd of people at a concert, who all decide to stand because the row in front of them has done so, individual behavior -- standing at a concert, instead of comfortably sitting -- can sometimes make sense if it is dictated by group dynamics.
The problems arise when the needs of the individual are contrary to the needs of the group. The result of luxury fever, he argues, is that individuals work too many hours and undergo too much stress; that society neglects too many critical public needs, ranging from better roads to cleaner air and water, at the expense of often-frivolous private ones.
"The left basically got it wrong from the beginning," said Mr. Frank, who votes Democratic and is clearly closer to the left end of the spectrum than the right. "They said the market is bad because the firms are too powerful and they take advantage of us. They manipulate us through advertisements. They control the political process. It's totally wrong. If there's something really good out there, you'll buy it with or without advertising and if there's a crumby thing, the ads can make you try it once, but you won't come back. So corporations have an incentive to spend their advertising dollars on things you are going to like."
The right, he said, gets it wrong by putting all its faith in the wisdom of the market and the idea that individual demands give the best outcomes for all.
"Sometimes, they do," he said. "But often they don't. When whatever I want has negative consequences for someone else, then the invisible hand doesn't work."
To Mr. Frank, the solution does not lie in the good intentions of the "voluntary simplicity" movement or the imposition of luxury taxes on yachts or diamonds. Instead, he says, it lies in a progressive tax on consumption: not the conventional sales tax, under which all purchasers pay the same thing, but a tax on total spending, with rates increasing as spending increases. Consumption would be calculated, essentially, by subtracting savings from earnings.
The tax would act like boxing gloves or steroid bans, he said, to keep the competition at a more sensible level by deterring runaway spending on luxuries: the biggest houses and biggest boats and costliest cars would tend to get smaller and less costly and the restraints on spending would ripple down through society, just as the luxury arms race now ripples up.
"Listen, I love stuff," said Mr. Frank, who has a Saab and BMW in the garage of his 1911 Arts and Crafts-style house in Ithaca, N.Y. "I like cars. I like food and wine. I buy rugs and lamps. You can't change human nature. You can just change the rules of the game. You don't eliminate the race. You just make it cheaper."
Many mainstream economists applaud the idea of a consumption tax, and say the idea makes sense, however dim its political prospects may be.
"Even if you don't use the argument Frank does about consumption, it's an excellent way to encourage savings," said Kenneth Arrow, a retired Stanford University economist and Nobel laureate. And many liberal economists applaud Frank's ability to put broad issues about consumption and public investment on the table.
To many free-market conservatives, however, Mr. Frank's scholarship and newfound celebrity are equally suspect.
Sherwin Rosen, an economist at the University of Chicago, said Mr. Frank's views on why people spend are based on supposition, not on research. He said the Government has no business telling people what to spend money on, and the robust economy is eloquent rejoinder to Mr. Frank's critique. And he argues that data showing an alarmingly low savings rate fail to take into account the degree to which a rising stock market has allowed people to accumulate wealth in ways that savings figures do not measure.
"Why should some guy in Ithaca be telling me what I should be spending money on?" he said. "How does he know why people spend? He has no data, no proof. You can't have economic policy or government involvement in the economy based on pure speculation."
Some say an overall consumption tax is too crude an instrument, one that would still allow people to spend on the most socially harmful goods if they chose. Others say that a proposal, in effect, to take resources from the rich and give them to the Government is the kind of solution only a liberal academic could seriously propose at a time when politicians are battling over the size of tax cuts. And conservatives argue that private spending is more efficient than Government spending, so a dollar taken from consumption need not mean a dollar in services like better roads or Federal food inspection.
Mr. Frank concedes that his argument can sound too simple, particularly when he adds the seemingly contradictory kicker that if people followed the incentives to save and invest rather than spend, their extra earnings would allow them to spend even more than they did earlier.
Still, even the critics tend to give credit to Mr. Frank for being onto something truly vexing and insufficiently examined in American life at a time houses built in this country have doubled in size since 1970.
Jack Hirshleifer, a retired University of California at Los Angeles economist, reviewed "Luxury Fever" unfavorably in the publication Reason. But he concluded: "Still, I am inclined to defend Frank in one important respect: as a moralist and a Jeremiah. If our society is to remain at its barely civilized level, from time to time we do need to be reproved for the vulgarity of wasteful consumption, not to mention the in-your-face boorishness currently recommended by ideologies of self-assertiveness and self-esteem."
Mr. Frank sees his work as scholarship, not moralizing. But he is comfortable with the degree to which his work has taken economic issues and raised overarching social issues.
"It's always been natural for me to think of everything as an economic question," he said. "It's all choice. It's all scarcity. You want to do more of one thing, you have to do less of another. Money is just a unit of accounting to think about how much we care about different things. I think one of the problems with economics is that it has insisted on too narrow a model of human nature, too impoverished a view of social interaction. You can't explain everything as trying to squeeze our every ounce from the bottom line."

HEADLINE: After Years of Division, Cherokees Get New Leader

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: TAHLEQUAH, Okla., Aug. 12

 BODY:
As a member of the Cherokee Nation and a student of its history, Chad Smith need only look to his family tree to find a famed leader of his tribe. Redbird Smith, his great-grandfather, was a patriot who went to prison rather than accept the Federal policy that deprived the Cherokees of millions of acres.
A century later, Mr. Smith will take office on Saturday as the Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation, and, like his great-grandfather, who served in the Cherokee Senate, he is assuming leadership at a time of crisis. For the last four years, the Cherokees have engaged in political infighting so bitter that it almost undermined their constitution and ultimately led to intervention by the Federal Government. 
 Asked about the priorities of his administration, Mr. Smith, a 48-year-old lawyer from the Tulsa suburbs, replied simply, "Healing."
With an estimated 200,000 members, half of whom live here in northeastern Oklahoma, the Cherokees are the country's second-largest tribe, behind the Navajos. And they have enjoyed a degree of prosperity and autonomy that has made them a model to other tribes. Now Mr. Smith must restore confidence in the tribal government not only among Cherokees but also among Federal officials, who stepped in two years ago at the height of the tribe's crisis, after members brawled outside the tribal courthouse.
"It's extremely important that the tribe come back together, and I think it will," said Rennard Strickland, dean of the University of Oregon School of Law, who is half-Cherokee and has written five books about the tribe. "The Cherokees have a very long history of being able to heal these kinds of tribal divisions. It has been a long 100 years."
For many Cherokees, the last four years alone have seemed interminable. The election of Joe Byrd as Principal Chief in 1995 followed the disqualification of his runoff opponent by the tribe's highest court. That opponent, George Bearpaw, was ruled ineligible because he had once pleaded guilty to an assault charge, though the conviction was later expunged. Many Cherokees regarded Mr. Byrd's victory as tainted, and his predecessor, Chief Wilma Mankiller, refused to attend his inauguration.
In 1997, the tribal government, with headquarters here at Tahlequah, teetered on collapse. First Chief Byrd dismissed 15 members of the Cherokees' marshals service who had executed a search warrant of his office as part of an investigation into the possibility of financial wrongdoing. Then, at the urging of Chief Byrd, eight members of the tribal council -- the seven other members were absent -- ousted by impeachment the three justices on the court who had issued the warrant. And on June 20 of that year, an armed security force hired by Chief Byrd seized the tribal courthouse and locked out all the employees, a move tantamount to taking over the judicial branch.
"It seemed that every month we would have a new problem," Ms. Mankiller said the other day. "Just when we would think things wouldn't get any worse, they did."
The bottom came on Aug. 13, 1997, when the fired marshals, led by their director, Pat Ragsdale, tried to take back the courthouse at the behest of the three impeached justices. A fight broke out with Chief Byrd's security force, and town police officers and county deputies arrested Mr. Ragsdale. Federal officers eventually came to Tahlequah (pronounced TAH-luh-kwah), and Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt helped mediate the dispute. The justices were ultimately reinstated.
The 1999 election, with a field of nine, including Chief Byrd, became a referendum on his administration. Respected leaders like Ms. Mankiller and Julian Fite, a former United States Attorney, endorsed Mr. Ragsdale in the primary, but Mr. Smith, who had finished third in 1995, built a coalition with an appeal to Cherokee tradition, heritage and culture. He had worked as a tribal prosecutor, as well as a public defender in Tulsa, and had served in two tribal administrations. He had also taught Indian law and history at several colleges, including Dartmouth.
Still, Mr. Smith's candidacy was not without problems: It came out during the primary that he had fathered three children outside his marriage. But his wife, a former Miss Cherokee, issued a statement entitled "In Support of My Husband," and when Mr. Smith emerged as Chief Byrd's runoff opponent, the defeated candidates and their backers rallied behind him. He won by 1,600 votes, of about 13,000 cast, in the runoff balloting last month.
"The kind of coalition that came together to bring in new leadership and defeat this administration was really something that I haven't seen in a long, long time," Ms. Mankiller said.
The soft-spoken Mr. Smith says his "defining moment" came on June 20, 1997, the day Chief Byrd's officers seized the courthouse. County deputies had cordoned off the building, essentially enforcing the Chief's takeover, but Mr. Smith ducked under the police tape. As he began to walk toward the courthouse to protest, he was tackled and arrested. He says he considered the seizure of the courthouse a challenge to the legitimacy of the Cherokee Nation's government and constitution.
The challenges facing Mr. Smith and his new administration are formidable. The Cherokees, who have no reservation per se but exercise certain jurisdictional rights in 14 northeastern Oklahoma counties under agreements with the state and Federal governments, operate on an annual budget of $150 million, about $90 million of it from Washington. But the Government, having found a lack of accountability in the use of Federal money, has placed the tribe under a monthly draw for those grants, rather than yearly. Chief Byrd himself also faces misappropriation-of-funds charges brought by tribal prosecutors.
In an interview this week, Chief Byrd denied any wrongdoing and said he had never overstepped his constitutional bounds. He said that he would leave the tribe with a $12 million surplus in the current fiscal year and that under his leadership improvements had been made in the tribe's high school and its business, Cherokee Nation Industries, which builds computer boards.
"We're leaving the goose that lays the golden egg," said Chief Byrd, who remains popular among the people from whom he sprung, the tribe's many rural Oklahomans.
Mr. Smith and his allies are far less certain of the tribe's fiscal health. Ms. Mankiller, whose daughters are now working on Mr. Smith's transition team, said initial financial reviews had found a bookkeeping mess. She said only one independent audit of government finances had been conducted since 1995.
Mr. Smith said he planned to institute new rules and procedures to insure the tribe's fiscal integrity. He also hopes to promote economic development, improve services and promote the Cherokees' culture and heritage. At the inauguration, he said, he will plant a tree on the courthouse grounds.
"It symbolizes rebirth," he said. "We reach into our history, and we try to honor it and remember it."

HEADLINE: L. L. Bean Casts About For Ways To Grow;
New Clothing Lines; Updated Web Site; More Retail Stores

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

DATELINE: FREEPORT, Me., Aug. 9

 BODY:
First came the indoor trout pond. Then there was the barnlike addition devoted to children's clothes and accessories. Now comes what is perhaps the ultimate sign that L. L. Bean, the 87-year-old arbiter of what's what in rugged outerwear, is going after cosseted baby boomers in a big way: the company's Maine Hunting Shoe, its first product and essential icon, has been revamped to make it more comfortable.
The changes in the boot are subtle to the naked eye. What was a vulcanized, hand-formed rubber sole is now molded in a machine-driven method that the company says saves money and results in a lighter, warmer, better-fitting product. "It may look the same on the outside," declares the literature that accompanies the new boot, which is still arrestingly utilitarian-looking, "but there's an inside story." 
Other recent changes within the privately held company -- based, as it has always been, here in this tourist mecca of outlet stores and lobster shacks -- reflect an even bigger effort to recast the venerable L. L. Bean into a more up-to-date mold.
The company has added a new brand aimed at working women, expanded its home-furnishings department and "turned up the volume" on its children's line, as one executive put it. Even more startling, Bean plans to develop a bigger retail presence -- once unthinkable in a company that made its name in mail-order -- by opening three to five full-scale stores along the Eastern Seaboard. The first is scheduled to appear by next summer in a sprawling suburban mall at Tysons Corner, Va., outside Washington.
All this is meant to counter plateauing sales at L. L. Bean, which does not publish a financial statement but says it sold just over $1 billion worth of gloves, parkas, kayaks, coffee tables, boot-shaped chocolates, rifles, fly rods, lamps, duffle bags, snowboards, men's dress shirts, dog beds, khakis, blazers, skirts, pillow shams, knapsacks and bathing suits last year.
The company witnessed enormous growth until recently. In 1967, it had just under $5 million in sales. Lately, however, the commercial environment has grown more complicated, with shifting consumer tastes and the explosion of electronic commerce -- two areas where Bean has been slow to adapt.
Now the goal, says Leon A. Gorman, who has been Bean's president for the last 32 years, is to increase sales at a double-digit rate every year, to about $1.4 billion by 2002.
Mr. Gorman outlined the challenges facing the company in a memo last year. Among his points was that the company's traditional attitude toward profits -- that they would emerge naturally if customers were treated well and stakeholders well served -- had to go. "This attitude was naive, perhaps, on our part although it served us well for many years," Mr. Gorman told his staff. "In today's environment, however, we are going to have to focus much more intently on profitability."
Some see risks, however, in moving further into bricks-and-mortar retailing. "It's going to be intriguing to watch, because often you find the folks who are successful with catalogues are not successful with stores, and vice versa," said Kenneth M. Gassmann, a retail analyst with Davenport & Company in Richmond. "J. Peterman? We all know what happened there."
J. Peterman, whose catalogues were famously wordy and eccentric, declared bankruptcy earlier this year after a high-speed expansion into retail stores that did not do well.
But Bean executives, pointing to successful examples of outdoor-oriented companies like Patagonia, a unit of Lost Arrow, and REI that have expanded beyond mail-order into retailing, insist that they have examined the issues carefully and expect the concept of additional stores to work. While the company has a handful of factory outlets in four states, and through a partnership has a dozen or so boutiques in Japan, it says its new, large stores will bring in many new customers.
"There are 1.5 million Bean customers within five miles of Tysons Corners," said L. L. Bean's general manager for retail, William P. Shea, a portly, exuberant proponent of the retail concept, so much so that Mr. Gorman, his boss, refers to it as "Bill's baby." He added: "And that's before we arrive. Just wait till we arrive."
Mr. Shea plans to move as many as 100 Bean employees to work in the new store, "to transfer the culture," as he put it.
Mr. Gorman, a serene, athletic 63-year-old, is emblematic of the old-school L. L. Bean, which his grandfather started in 1912. Committed to as much domestic manufacturing as possible, especially if it is done in Maine, he was pivotal in the effort to revamp the Bean boot, whose rubber soles will be made by a small factory near Lewiston, Me. (Another small factory made the old soles.) He supports sturdy causes like the Nature Conservancy, the Boy Scouts and the Maine chapter of the N.A.A.C.P.
At the same time, he talks of brand loyalty like someone fresh out of an M.B.A. program, citing the self-assessment and subsequent reorganization the company went through last year as priming it well for the future.
"We have the initiatives in motion now that will provide substantial growth opportunities in the years ahead," Mr. Gorman says, looking slightly embarrassed about the management-speak that has invaded his vocabulary lately. Terms like "brand management" do not sound quite at home at a company that hacked its way out of the wilderness, selling hunting gear and, when its thoughts turned to domesticity, scratchy woolen blankets and chairs made from snowshoes. "I have to invent a new word," he said.
Yet for all its cautious leanings, Bean set itself up for a serious fall twice in the last two decades. First came its response to "The Official Preppy Handbook," a spoof of boarding-school style, or lack thereof, published in 1980 that named Bean footwear as part of the required wardrobe.
Mr. Gorman says now he wishes that distinction had passed the company by. "The women's apparel in particular got this frumpy appellation," he said, calling it "not really reflective of the product line." The company geared up to handle an influx of orders, which came and went, leaving Bean with excess capacity.
More devastating was the company's blighted love affair with the Japanese. In the late 1980's, the Japanese became heavy users of Bean products, part of it a fashion trend, part of it stemming from interest in the outdoors, and all of it helped along by the strong yen. Sales to Japan built steadily, reaching 20 percent of the company's overall business by 1995, Mr. Gorman said.
Shortly after that, the bottom dropped out of the Japanese economy, taking most of Bean's sales to Japan with it. At the same time, domestic sales were weak, and competition from longtime rivals like Lands' End, which posted $1.4 billion in sales last year, intensified.
Then there is the matter of the Internet. Bean had jumped on the concept early, and its Web site was open for business by 1996. But competitors roared by it, embracing improved technology that helped consumers find their sizes, for example, while the Bean site puttered along exactly the way it had started.
"At a very basic level, there are some things L. L. Bean really needs to get on, including offering more sizing information and more tools," said Evie Black Dykema, an analyst with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "Over all, their site is very thorough. It's basically their catalogue, on line. But to realize their full potential, they will need to expand their functionality beyond what can be found in their catalogue."
Other outdoor suppliers, like Lands' End and Recreational Equipment Inc., or REI, have moved well beyond Bean's efforts in cyberspace, she added. And other analysts are less charitable about the situation.
"They really fell behind the pack by not picking up on E-commerce soon enough and not being more aggressive with it," said Alan Mak, an analyst with Argus Research in New York. "They lacked the vision to see how powerful the Internet was as a retail medium. And trying to play catch-up on the Internet is extremely difficult."
Part of the problem seems to have been the revolving door at Bean's E-commerce division. Patricia Robles, the current executive in charge, is the third person to hold the post in the last two years. One recent departure was Tom Harden, an executive vice president who left to work for an Internet mail-order gift company, Send.com. But Ms. Robles insists that the company's revamped Web site, which is supposed to be available in October, will counter all of the criticism by being as efficient, user-friendly and up-to-date as possible.
"For a company that's known to be conservative and traditional, we really were out on the Web early," said Ms. Robles, whose 15-year career at Bean has included stints as a women's apparel product manager and a manager of inventory control. "The disadvantages are that you put in early infrastructure and it quickly becomes outdated. We did not move quickly to replace some of the infrastructure, but we're doing that now."
Electronic commerce recently achieved improved status within L. L. Bean, Ms. Robles said. "We are really putting significant resources into the Web," she said. The new site, she said, will include tips on where to go on outdoor excursions, as well as what someone might need and how to order it from Bean.
Another recent addition is a brand called Freeport Studio, which is supposed to appeal to working women by offering clothing that is low maintenance, relatively stylish and affordable. "We're trying to address the casualization of America," said Cindy Marshall, the marketing executive for the line. "We're certainly not corporate."
The brand came out with its own catalogue in January, and sales are strong, Bean executives say. The line came about in response to a letter from a longtime customer who bought other Bean products, but pointed out that while they were useful on weekends, "there are only 52 weekends a year, and I need something to wear the rest of the time."
She closed the letter by advising the company: "Get with it."

After decades of rapid gains that transformed L. L.Bean from a tiny $5 million company in 1967 to a $1 billion titan in the mid-1990's, sales have stalled recently. To restore growth, L. L. Bean is even tinkering with its iconic Maine Hunting Shoe, above, expanding into cyberspace and building its first full-scale retail stores outside Maine.
