HEADLINE: Producer Price Index Numbers Ease Investor Fears

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
The stock and bond markets surged yesterday after the Government released a reassuring report that showed a modest increase in prices at the wholesale level in July, easing investor concerns about inflation.
The Labor Department said the Producer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 percent in July as the first decline in food prices since April blunted the impact of a surge in energy prices. The July increase, which followed a decline of one-tenth of a percent in June, was below analysts' forecasts. When the volatile food and energy components were excluded, prices were unchanged. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average leaped 184.26 points, its biggest rise since mid-June, as interest rates fell as much as one-tenth of a percentage point.
While most analysts say they believe the Federal Reserve will still raise the target for a key overnight lending rate at its policy meeting on Aug. 24, the July producer price figures seemed to rule out any need for a rate increase of more than a quarter of a percentage point and diminish the likelihood that further increases would be needed to keep inflation at bay.
But other soundings could still change things, including the Government's report Tuesday on inflation at the consumer level.
"It was a quite good number," Stan Shipley, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch, said of yesterday's report. "Deflationary pressures persist in the economy."
The so-called core rate, which excludes food and energy, was unchanged last month, after a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in June. That figure was also a bit lower than the consensus of forecasters.
Moreover, analysts said they found no immediate cause for concern about inflation at earlier stages in the production pipeline even though price increases in some categories of goods were enough that they might become unsettling if they were to continue.
Prices of intermediate goods, like cloth, rose six-tenths of 1 percent, while those of crude goods, like coal, declined two-tenths of 1 percent.
The drought that has ravaged grain, vegetable and other crops in much of the Northeast and Southeast had little effect on food prices, which tumbled nine-tenths of 1 percent, offsetting the combined increases for May and June.
"It's difficult to find any food commodities that rose in price that could be attributed to drought," said Joe Kowal, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, noting that growing conditions in the Midwest have been excellent.
It is possible, other analysts said, that the drought actually helped restrain the rise in producer prices as farmers and ranchers sped livestock sales up because of a lack of affordable feed. Prices of cattle for slaughter, for example, fell 2.4 percent in July after rising 3.8 percent in June and price declines accelerated for hogs and chickens for slaughter.
Bruce Kasman, chief United States economist at J. P. Morgan, called the latest inflation reading "very benign" but added that a long period of steadily lower inflation was giving way to price "normalization" that would require vigilance at the Federal Reserve.
Other Labor Department reports in recent weeks have showed wage acceleration and continued drum-tight job markets, intensifying jitters about inflation in the securities markets.
"There's no problem here right now -- no reason to slam your feet on the brakes," Mr. Kasman said. But he added that some of yesterday's data did show "reasons to be a little concerned" if increases persisted into the autumn. But James E. Glassman at Chase Manhattan said that strong productivity growth by manufacturers was likely to prevent these increases from being passed along.
One sensitive area is durable items like copper and plywood used in the manufacturing process, an element of the intermediate-goods category. These materials, which also include brass mill shapes, building board and glass, jumped eight-tenths of 1 percent last month after rising seven-tenths of 1 percent in June.
Construction materials rose seven-tenths of 1 percent while chemicals and other nondurables consumed by factories rose four-tenths of a percent following an exceptional surge in June.
Energy prices were sharply higher at all stages of production -- 3.4 percent among finished goods, 2.9 percent among intermediates and 3.7 percent for raw material. More than half the jump in finished energy was a result of a 12.7 percent jump in gasoline after a decline of 1.9 percent in June.
The index for beef and veal slumped 3.4 percent after rising more than twice as much in June, while the price of fresh eggs jumped 7.1 percent, both moves possibly reflecting the effects of drought.

HEADLINE: A Worsening Crisis Over Taiwan

 BODY:
With tensions mounting dangerously across the Taiwan Strait, both sides need to step back and consider the risks they are courting -- Taipei by its reckless declarations and Beijing by its unacceptable military threats. Taiwan and the mainland have escalated the crisis by repeatedly flying warplanes in the direction of each other's territory. Chinese publications now regularly report on Beijing's preparedness to assault Taiwanese-held territory, and Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, holds to his provocative demand that China deal with his island as a separate sovereign state.
Any military clash between China and Taiwan would imperil Taiwan's prosperity and democracy, threaten China's economic development and gravely damage relations between Washington and Beijing. 
 The United States, like most countries, recognizes Beijing's as the only lawful government of China. Washington considers Taiwan geographically part of China, but not currently subject to mainland political rule. That widely accepted formula leaves the question of China's eventual reunification to be resolved peacefully, at a later date, by people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait. Meanwhile, America is committed to providing Taiwan with adequate means to defend itself against attack.
That sensible arrangement was deliberately challenged last month by President Lee with his new formula of two separate sovereign states. Beijing predictably and unjustifiably responded with threats of military force. Concern has centered on the possible blockade, shelling or occupation of several small islands controlled by Taiwan just off the Chinese mainland.
Four decades ago, Chinese shelling of the two offshore islands Quemoy (now called Kinmen) and Matsu brought American warships to the Taiwan Strait and Washington and Beijing close to military confrontation. Relations between the United States and China have come a long way since that unhappy era. Beijing should not risk reversing that progress with a new episode of aggression.
In the event of Chinese military action against Taiwan, President Clinton would have little choice but to chill relations with Beijing, freeze economic talks and consider whether American military intervention was warranted. The Administration must be sure that Beijing understands these likely consequences before China resorts to force. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Pullout From Panama and Venezuelan Reluctance Leave Gap in U.S. Air War on Drugs

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela

 BODY:
The withdrawal of the United States from military bases in Panama, combined with the refusal of Venezuela's new Government to let its airspace be used for American surveillance and pursuit flights, has created a huge gap in regional drug interdiction that trafficking cartels are exploiting, American officials say.
The weakness has emerged since May, when the United States returned Howard Air Base, from which 2,000 anti-drug flights a year had been operating, to Panama as required by the Panama Canal Treaties. 
 Three alternative sites have been found, but they either are not yet able to function at full capacity or their effectiveness has been sharply limited by political considerations.
"These are very clever people," Gen. Barry McCaffrey, director of the White House's Office of National Drug Control Policy, said of the drug cartels, "and they are watching us very closely. So if you have an enormous hole in the middle of the equation, it will have a fundamental change on the effectiveness of these solutions." He made the remark during a four-nation South American tour in late July.
In a telephone interview from Washington, one Pentagon official expressed hope that "by the end of the year, we should be up to 85 or 90 percent" of the flight capacity that existed before the end of operations in Panama.
The official would not estimate the number of drug shipments now getting through as a result of the problem but conceded that at the moment, interdiction efforts were "not doing so well in the source zone."
Still, said Bruce Bagley, a professor at the University of Miami who is an expert on the Latin American drug trade, the United States "is not without other assets that can be used," like satellite photography.
"Although it is a setback, it is not a disaster," Professor Bagley said of the Venezuelan policy. "Colombia is the principal focus of growing and processing cocaine now, and the lack of rights to overfly Venezuela does not inhibit efforts as significantly as many analysts in Washington have suggested."
Although interdiction "doesn't work very well" and is "barely a holding action," he said, "the alternative is "to do nothing, to give up."
Venezuela is not a grower of coca, the raw ingredient for cocaine, or of opium poppies, from which heroin is derived. But it shares a long, poorly patrolled border with Colombia, which produces 80 percent of the cocaine consumed in the United States, and more than 100 tons a year of that drug were estimated to have passed through Venezuela last year before flights were banned.
The United States hoped to negotiate an agreement with Panama that would allow the use of Howard Air Base into the next century. But after announcing in December 1997 that such an accord had been reached, President Ernesto Perez Balladares of Panama reneged.
In an effort to close the gap, the Netherlands agreed in April to grant the United States ground and air access to and use of selected airfields in the Dutch colonies of Aruba and Curacao, which lie just off the Venezuelan coast.
A similar agreement has been signed with Ecuador, which allows United States drug surveillance planes to fly from a military base in the coastal city of Manta.
The Manta flights are intended to monitor drug trafficking up the Pacific coast of South America to Mexico, which is the main drug route to the United States. But the runway there is not long enough for sophisticated electronic surveillance aircraft, nor can it take their weight. That makes flights from the two Dutch islands "extremely important," a Pentagon official said.
Without overflight permission from Venezuela, though, the flights from Aruba and Curacao are of limited use.
"We want this to be a truly multilateral effort," said Niek van Zutphen, the Dutch Ambassador in Caracas, referring to aerial surveillance and interdiction. "If you leave one weapon so explicitly unused, you give yourself a handicap and make things very easy for the other side."
President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela, a 45-year-old former army colonel who took office in February promising a social revolution, has stated explicitly that he will not countenance what he regards as a violation of his country's sovereignty.
"Venezuela is historically very zealous about everything occurring on these two islands," the country's Foreign Minister, Jose Vicente Rangel, said in an interview, "because we consider that it affects our national security."
He said that "we cannot accept that planes leave from these bases," and that he "absolutely ruled out" any possibility that Venezuela would change its position.
Mr. Rangel said the Chavez Government had cooperated with the United States in other areas of the war against drugs, including the installation of three radar centers near Colombia or on drug routes and has "captured more drugs in five months than were seized all of last year."
He also argued that Venezuela had the drug interdiction situation well under control and thus did not need outside interference.
"We have complied with our responsibilities without any need for bases in Curacao and Aruba or overflights that we do not consider to be suitable," he said.
But General McCaffrey said that since the closing of Howard, "there have been seven criminal penetrations of Venezuelan airspace that have had unsuccessful endgames because there is no endgame in Venezuela."
Some key members of the United States Congress are growing impatient with the Venezuelan stance. They warn that if Mr. Chavez's position does not change soon, the United States may retaliate by refusing to certify that Venezuela is collaborating fully in the drug war, a step that would deprive it of trade and other benefits.
"If Venezuela isn't cooperative, and the amount of trafficking increases as a result of that, then it would certainly affect the certification process," said Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, the New York Republican who is chairman of the House International Relations Committee.
"Right now we are hard pressed in our efforts, and until we are able to establish some alternative facilities, which is going to take quite a while, we will continue to have a major strategic gap," Mr. Gilman said.
But the Clinton Administration is eager to avoid such a confrontation. Venezuela has the largest oil reserves outside the Middle East and in recent years has become the United States' principal source of imported oil.
Despite the public rebuffs they have received, American officials remain hopeful that Mr. Chavez can be persuaded to change his mind. Even before General McCaffrey's visit, State Department and other delegations sought to lay out the American case to him, pointing out that drug traffickers were regularly violating the sovereignty he says he holds dear.
"President Chavez has been so focused on politics and the economic situation that he frankly hasn't spent a lot of time up to now on drug stuff," said an American official who monitors the issue. "Our goal is to help him and his administration get oriented as to how we see the drug threat regionally and how it affects Venezuela specifically, and use that as a basis to move forward on cooperation."

HEADLINE: Teamsters Push To End Decade Of Supervision

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Ten years after Federal officials gained a strict supervisory role over the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in an effort to rid it of mob control, the union's new leadership is pushing hard to get the Government out.
The teamster president, James P. Hoffa, who took office in March, has made ending Federal supervision his chief goal, insisting that the giant union can run its own affairs now that the Mafia's hold on it has been broken. 
 Mr. Hoffa says that the supervision, unprecedented in its scope and duration, is too meddlesome and expensive. For all the millions that the mob has bled from the union, many teamsters complain about the $82 million the union has had to pay for the decadelong Federal effort.
"The teamsters' union is as free of corruption as any great institution," Mr. Hoffa said.
And with Mr. Hoffa saying the teamsters will no longer reflexively endorse Democrats, as it did under his predecessor, Ron Carey, some union officials say he may ask Presidential candidates to support an end to supervision as the price of endorsement by the 1.4-million-member union.
Government officials acknowledge that the teamsters has been substantially cleaned up but are uneasy about withdrawing, saying pockets of corruption remain in the powerful union, which was long infamous for shakedowns, intimidation, payoffs and looted pension funds.
These officials say it would be unwise to cut short the supervision -- the most ambitious Government effort to clean up a single union -- which they say has largely succeeded by obtaining the expulsions or resignations of more than 250 teamster officials accused of corruption.
"The cleanup has done a tremendous amount of good, but it would be a mistake to say the union is corruption-free, mob-free," said Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney in Manhattan and the Federal official in charge of the supervision. "You don't want to say prematurely, 'It's fixed.' You don't want to backtrack."
The teamsters were forced to accept Federal oversight in 1989, to settle a racketeering lawsuit. The agreement set no time limit on the supervision and established the first rank-and-file elections for the teamsters presidency to give members the power to vote out corrupt leaders. While teamster officials kept the powers to negotiate contracts and handle most union matters, major anti-corruption work was given to Federally appointed monitors.
The oversight has included a Government-appointed investigations officer, with a staff of a dozen investigators; a three-person review board to adjudicate corruption cases, and a Government-appointed elections monitor.
The agreement has an understanding that the Federal Government would end its supervision when it was satisfied that the union was clean and would aggressively move against any hints of corruption.
Mr. Hoffa has vowed to keep organized crime out of the union, long considered the nation's most mob-dominated, saying the Mafia was responsible for the disappearance of his father, the teamster leader James R. Hoffa, in 1975. The elder Hoffa, who led the union from 1957 to 1971 and went to prison for jury tampering, disappeared after promising to end mob control as he campaigned to regain the union's presidency.
But many critics of the younger Hoffa assert that he has ties to a corrupt old guard, and they question his motives for wanting to end Federal oversight.
Interviews with prosecutors and teamster leaders indicate that Federal supervision has accomplished something that 40 previous years of investigations and prosecutions had failed to accomplish -- it has rid the teamsters of mob control.
For years, the Mafia handpicked the union's president and the heads of many locals, and strong-armed the union into lending mobsters hundreds of millions of dollars from its pension funds. Federal prosecutors said the Mafia even controlled the elder Hoffa for several years.
"The union has come an enormous way since the 1980's," said Michael Cherkasky, the Federal elections monitor. "The union is not controlled by the mob anymore. At local after local where there was pervasive corruption and complete control by organized crime, you see a sea change."
But law-enforcement officials say the cleanup is far from over. Some mob influence remains, and in a union with 600 locals, including truck drivers, warehouse workers, security guards and flight attendants, an unsettling number of officials continue to steal union money or commit other crimes, though on a far smaller scale than in decades past.
Federal officials point to stubborn problems like Local 714 in Chicago, which represents movie-truck drivers and trade show workers. A Federal oversight board ordered it into trusteeship in 1996 after finding the local's leaders guilty of nepotism and doing business with movie-truck companies owned by relatives.
The local's principal officer, William T. Hogan Jr., Chicago's most powerful teamster, was disgraced into leaving the union and dropping his campaign for secretary-treasurer on the Hoffa slate.
But many members complain that a corrupt old guard is back because last year Mr. Hogan's son, Robert, won the local's top post, and he appointed his father as Local 714's organizing director and his uncle as executive director.
At the same time, there have been shining examples of cleansed locals. For decades, Local 560 in New Jersey was a piggy bank for the mob and was considered the nation's single-most-corrupt union local. It was run by Anthony Provenzano, a captain in the Genovese family, who was sentenced to life in prison for murdering a popular union rival and who, prosecutors say, had another teamster murdered for rubbing him the wrong way at a meeting.
But after a trusteeship purged the local of more than a dozen mob associates, members attending the local's recent monthly meeting did not hesitate to criticize or joke with Local 560's popular new president, Pete Brown, whom Federal monitors have vetted as clean.
The Federal oversight has been unprecedented in its size and invasiveness.
Under agreements with the Government, other unions have had anti-corruption monitors, including the Laborers International Union of North America, which many labor-relations experts consider the most corrupt in the country today. But those unions, in effect, were allowed to handle their cleanups.
The $82 million the teamsters have had to pay for oversight has included $17 million for the three-person review board, the investigation officer and their staff, and $38 million for Federal monitors to conduct three nationwide teamster elections.
With the end of mob control, law-enforcement officials say, the teamsters has again become a union dedicated to winning its members better wages and working conditions.
The national economy has also benefited because mob extortion amounted to a criminal tax of several percent on the billions of dollars in freight that teamster truck drivers hauled around the country. Already, in New York City, the authorities estimate that ending mob domination of the union has saved the construction industry millions of dollars.
Control of the teamsters was so central to the prosperity of many crime families, that breaking their hold has hurt them badly, the authorities say.
To demonstrate that the union can clean its own house, Mr. Hoffa recently appointed a respected former Federal prosecutor from New Jersey, Edwin H. Stier -- the man who cleaned up Local 560 -- to head an in-house, anti-corruption effort.
Mr. Hoffa has also begun talks with the Clinton Administration and several members of Congress with the aim of persuading the Government to end its supervision.
"We have been under Government supervision for 10 years," Mr. Hoffa said. "It's time for a fresh review of this."
Ms. White, the Federal prosecutor, and other Government officials declined to say outright whether supervision should be ended, saying they were still weighing the matter. But several former Federal prosecutors were more emphatic about the need to continue supervision.
"After five decades of organized corruption in a union, corruption does not go away in one year or 10," said Randy Mastro, who as an assistant United States Attorney in Manhattan oversaw the racketeering lawsuit that forced the teamsters to accept supervision after 40 years of failed efforts by the Government to end the Mafia's choke hold.
The lawsuit, brought under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, sought to place the union under Federal supervision as part of a comprehensive strategy to kick corrupt officials out and keep them out. It named 26 Mafia leaders and all 18 of the union's board members as defendants, accusing the board of failing to fight corruption and the mob bosses of controlling four teamster presidents, including Jimmy Hoffa.
Fearing years of litigation and millions in legal fees, teamster leaders agreed to the most far-reaching Federal supervision of any national union.
In the decade since, the investigations officer, Charles M. Carberry, a former Federal prosecutor, has charged two dozen teamsters with being members of organized crime, including the heads of two large Chicago locals and the president of New York City's teamster council. He has also charged 60 teamsters with associating with mobsters and 150 more with financial wrongdoing.
Mr. Carberry said mob control is gone but that mob influence remains in some locals along with plenty of garden-variety graft. "You won't see a capo of the Gambino family as secretary-treasurer of a local anymore," he said. "But one may anticipate they will try to maintain whatever influence they still can, although more subtly than in the past."
Both sides in the debate over ending supervision can find ample evidence within the sprawling union to support their view.
Those who want supervision ended can point to successful cleanups like that at Local 282 on Long Island, which Carlo Gambino, once New York's boss of crime bosses, had turned into family property.
The local's 3,000 members deliver concrete to New York's construction industry, and the Gambino family recognized that if it controlled Local 282 and its deliveries, it could easily extort money from builders by threatening delays.
In 1982, Federal prosecutors gained an extortion conviction of the local's president, John Cody, who was so feared by builders that they provided him with chauffeurs and helped build his beach house. His successor, Bobby Sasso, also had the Gambinos' blessing, but he was pressured into resigning in 1992 after the review board charged him with extortion.
When yet another mob associate became president, the Federal cleanup went into high gear. Local 282 was put into trusteeship, Mr. Carberry brought charges that resulted in the removal of 22 local officials, and one of the local's trustees, Milton Mollen, stripped 50 local officials of their posts because of mob ties, theft or other wrongdoing. Today, all Local 282 officials must pass an F.B.I. screening.
Years ago local members were too intimidated to talk at union meetings, but nowadays Gary Labarbera, the trustee who runs the local's day-to-day affairs, welcomes rank-and-file input as a way to strengthen the union.
But those who favor continued supervision point to locals still troubled by mob ties. In 1991, Mr. Carberry brought charges against four officers of Local 377 in Youngstown, Ohio: two for extortion and two for engaging in a gun battle. But as recently as February, Mr. Carberry accused one of the local's shop stewards with finding a construction job for a mob enforcer newly released from prison, while the oversight board expelled one of the local's leaders for running a gambling operation for Pittsburgh's mob boss.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Good News on Inflation Sends Markets Up Sharply
Stocks soared following news that inflation was not a problem last month at the producer level. July's Producer Price Index rose by just two-tenths of a percent. The so-called core Producer Price Index, which excludes food and energy prices, was unchanged last month. The Dow Jones industrial average surged 184.26 points, or 1.71 percent, at 10,973.65. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumped 29.52 points, or 2.27 percent, to 1,327.68. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite rose 88.32 points, or 3.46 percent, to 2,637.81. 
 In the inflation-sensitive bond market, the benchmark 30-year bond jumped 1 4/32 , to 100 12/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.10 percent from 6.27 on Thursday. C3.
 
J. P. Morgan Is Sued by Sumitomo
J. P. Morgan was accused of lending at least $535 million to a copper trader in the mid-1990's, money that helped fuel a trading binge that inflicted $2.6 billion in losses on the Sumitomo Corporation. The information was disclosed in a lawsuit filed by the Japanese bank this week. C2.
 
Teamsters Seek End to Supervision
Ten years after Federal officials gained a strict supervisory role over the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in an effort to rid it of mob control, the union's new leadership is pushing hard to get the Government out. A1
 
Wire Transfers Raise Questions
Many of the estimated six million Mexicans who live and work in the United States send money to relatives in Mexico. But as the wire transfer business has boomed, more customers have complained about the costs. Class-action lawsuits have accused the dominant wire transfer companies of profiteering, while internal debates at the two companies over wire transfer rates are said to have led to the departure of high-ranking Hispanic executives in the United States and Mexico. C2.
 
Daewoo Unit Gets $3.2 Billion Bid
An investment group led by a little known California businessman has agreed to buy most of Daewoo Electronics, the consumer electronics unit of the troubled South Korean conglomerate. Daewoo's president, Yang Jae-yeol, left, said that Walid Alomar & Associates, based in Beverly Hills, will pay $3.2 billion for the Daewoo Electronics assets and operations in North and South America, Western Europe, Japan and South Korea. The price includes the assumption of some Daewoo debt. C2.
 
Malaysia Rejoins a Financial Fold
After 11 months as a financial pariah, Malaysia earned some redemption when Morgan Stanley Capital International said it would readmit the country to portfolios that many fund managers use as guides to determining where and how much of their clients' money to invest. In response, the country's benchmark stock index soared. The composite index in Kuala Lumpur, the capital, rose 6 percent. C2.
 
DeVilbiss Air Power Sold to Pentair
Pentair, a maker of professional tools, agreed to acquire DeVilbiss Air Power, the air power tools unit of Falcon Building Products of Chicago for $460 million in cash. Pentair said the acquisition would increase the annual sales of its professional tools and equipment business to $1.5 billion and raise its total sales to around $3 billion. C3.
 
Investment Banker Joins Softbank
Bill Burnham, the young investment banker who helped define the Internet brokerage industry by compiling its first rankings and statistics, is leaving Credit Suisse First Boston to become general partner of a new $1.2 billion venture capital fund of Softbank, Japan's largest distributor of packaged software and hardware. Mr. Burnham, 28, will be one of four general partners in the fund, which has already made a half-dozen investments, and will develop a research staff for Softbank. C4.

The new school year will bring a quiet revolution in the teaching of Israel's history to most pupils there. New, approved textbooks make plain that many Israeli beliefs are as much myth as fact. HEADLINE: ART REVIEWS;
A Career Cut Short and a Continuing Tradition

BYLINE: By Helen A. Harrison

 BODY:

'Light'
 William Floyd Memorial Library, First Street, Greenport. Through Aug. 25. 477-0660.
In 1952, when the German photographer Ingeborg Tallarek arrived in New York, she was immediately struck by the captivating quality of American light. She decided to make her home here and eventually moved to East Marion, where she still lives. Sadly, her career was derailed after all her cameras and darkroom equipment were stolen in the mid-1970's. Nevertheless, many of the images she created establish her as a notable member of the small sisterhood of early freelance photographers that includes Margaret Bourke-White, Berenice Abbott and Dorothea Lange. 
 But unlike those women, whose achievements have been honored in solo exhibitions, Ms. Tallarek has never before had a one-woman show. Although some of her pictures have been widely reproduced, there is no publication devoted to her work. This is the first opportunity to see a sizable group of her prints, including portraits, photojournalism and North Fork landscapes, and it should not be missed.
Ms. Tallarek's assignments led her to a diverse range of subjects, from political heavyweights, artists and movie stars to anonymous firefighters and children living in poverty. One of her best-known images shows two unidentified Hasidim in Central Park. Although their backs are to the camera, one can imagine their fascinated expressions as they study a skywriter's tick-tack-toe game. The volunteers battling a blaze on a Provincetown rooftop are also unnamed, but their heroism is dramatized by the smoke and sparks surrounding them.
Images that capture Marilyn Monroe's candid sensuality, Marlene Dietrich's detached hauteur (juxtaposed with her daughter's shy reserve) and Eleanor Roosevelt's audience with members of the Women's Press Corps stand out as prime examples of the photographer's ability to reveal intimate dimensions of celebrated subjects. Her shot of a fainting Miss America at the 1952 beauty pageant exposes the private tension behind the public performance.
 
'Footfalls '99'
Greenport. Through Sept. 26.
Fourteen artists have created site-specific sculptures for this year's group of outdoor installations in and around the village. Many respond to the area's maritime heritage, while some relate to issues of communal space and civic responsibility.
The facade of the library, where Ingeborg Tallerek's photographs are on view inside, serves as a forum for Poppy Johnson's Keatsian equation, "Beauty Is Truth." Bold banners proclaim the equivalence, rendered in pointillistic painted letters that strike a note of subjectivity to counter the statement's authority. An even more authoritative document, the United States Constitution, provides the text for Gary Rieveschl's "We the People," a sculpture of privet hedges that vitalizes words to symbolize the living nature of participatory democracy.
The port and its history inspired Andre Kreft to memorialize the slaves who came to the area by sea and whose gravestones are often blank. His grid of 20 boulders, extending from the beach into the water, is revealed as the tide recedes, poignantly indicating the slaves' marginal status and reminding viewers of their tragic journey from distant shores.
Mel Pekarsky's "Ghosts" is a different kind of memorial, one that pictures a solitary bush in a barren twilight landscape. Its sparseness stands in sharp contrast to the bustle and clutter of the nearby ferry dock and restaurant, highlighting human intrusiveness on nature's fragility.
"Tourist Trap," a wood construction by Bennett Blackburn, is a more lighthearted commentary on human intrusion. Resembling an oversize lobster trap, the enclosure has lawn chairs for the comfort of those it snares. Louise O'Regan Clark's imposing compasslike structure alludes to navigation as the guiding principle of maritime life. Like the skeleton of an old-fashioned three-dimensional trade sign, Ed Smith's "Lure" pays nostalgic tribute to the artist's memories of fishing in childhood, when the catch was plentiful and life seemed less complicated.
 
'The Search For the Pictorial'
Oysterponds Historical Society, Village Lane, Orient. Through Sept. 26. 323-2480.
Subtitled "The Life and Art of William Steeple Davis," the exhibition traces the career of a self-taught painter, printmaker and photographer whose memorial trust supports residencies at the Davis home and studio on King Street. Last year's resident scholar, Kimberly Rhodes, catalogued his work and organized the show, which is to travel to the Museums at Stony Brook next year.
Born in Orient in 1884, Davis spent most of his life in his native village. His family encouraged his artistic aspirations, but he never received formal training. His 1909 self-portrait shows a serious, rather shy young man studying his own reflection. Its color scheme and composition indicate familiarity with Whistler's work, which he apparently knew from reproductions. His primary inspiration, however, was the surrounding landscape and seascape, and he regularly sent paintings of those subjects to exhibitions in New York City and elsewhere. He also worked as a commercial illustrator, making paintings for reproduction on calendars, book and magazine covers, and post cards.
Although Davis received modest financial reward and recognition for his paintings, they are not his most notable achievement. His oil technique is uneven, and his larger canvases are often contrived and sentimental. His sketches and pastels, on the other hand, are fresh and lively, and he had a particular talent for printmaking. Subjects that he overworked in oil are treated with sensitive economy in etchings like "Racing Along," a study of competing yachts, and block prints like "In Tumult," showing surf pounding against a massive rock.
But Davis' most significant work was in photography. He began photographing seriously as a teen-ager, wrote prolifically on the subject and invented a developing machine that he patented and marketed. The show includes a fine selection of his prints, illustrating an esthetic rich in tonal nuance and allied with the Pictorial ist movement championed by Alfred Stieglitz and his contemporaries. Whatever his shortcomings as a painter, Davis deserves recognition for this all-but-forgotten body of work, as well as for the William Steeple Davis Trust, a legacy that allows succeeding generations of artists to live and work in his former home and find creative stimulation in the surroundings he loved.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Tax Liens Can Enrich Investors

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
ANYONE who has seriously contemplated making money in real estate has probably encountered the arcane but potentially profitable practice of investing in tax liens at public sales -- the legal process through which municipalities obtain payment of delinquent property taxes.
Real estate experts say it is possible to make a secure investment with a high rate of return in property tax liens, even for unsophisticated investors. And savvier, more careful and more knowledgeable investors can even obtain title to real estate for a small fraction of its market value by buying property at a tax foreclosure sale, the experts say. 
 "Tax liens can be a great investment," said Saul M. Simon, a certified financial planner for Allmerica Investments in Edison, N.J., "as long as you know what you're doing."
Mr. Simon said that investors must normally seek out these sales independently. Tax lien investments are generally not marketed like securities by brokerage houses. The investors must be aware that states have different procedures for handling properties on which the owner has failed to pay property taxes. In New Jersey, for example, municipalities are allowed to "sell" their tax liens -- or their right to foreclose on a property when the owner has failed to pay taxes -- at public auction. Mr. Simon said he has realized a 16 percent rate of return on tax lien certificates he has purchased in these sales.
So what is a municipal tax lien certificate?
"It's a memorialization of a town's lien for unpaid taxes on a property," said Hugh McGuire, a Jersey City real estate lawyer. When a property owner in New Jersey fails to pay local property taxes, he said, the municipality acquires an automatic lien against the property. That lien gives the municipality the right to force the sale of the property to raise the money necessary to pay the overdue taxes.
Usually, however, instead of foreclosing, most municipalities take advantage of a provision in state law that allows the tax collector to sell the municipality's lien in exchange for the payment of overdue taxes, Mr. McGuire said. To make it worthwhile for investors to buy those liens, the law also allows the buyer to collect interest on the amount he paid when he redeems the lien.
Mr. McGuire said that the interest rate that applies to a particular lien is determined at the time the lien is sold by the municipality. The maximum interest rate permitted by New Jersey law -- and the rate offered at the time of sale -- is 18 percent. Accordingly, when a tax collector holds a tax lien sale, investors will "bid" for liens on particular properties, Mr. McGuire said. Since the municipality is interested in obtaining payment of all of the unpaid taxes, however, all bidders must bid the entire amount of unpaid taxes. The successful bidder is the one who is willing to accept the lowest interest rate.
So, for example, if only one bidder is present, he will obtain the highest interest rate permitted by state law -- 18 percent. If a rival bidder is present, however, he may "bid down" to 17 percent, meaning that he is willing to pay the overdue taxes in exchange for a 17 percent rate of return.
"Most people purchase tax lien certificates with the hope that at some point in time, someone will come forward" and reimburse the investor for his outlay, paying any interest charges that have accrued, Mr. McGuire said. That is what happens in most cases, he added.
For example, if the original owner tries to sell the property, the buyer will require that all back taxes and tax liens -- as well as interest due any lienholders -- be paid in full. And when it appears that the lien might not be satisfied, either because the owner cannot be located or cannot or will not sell the property, the law gives the lienholder the right to foreclose after holding the lien for at least two years, Mr. McGuire explained.
"If your ultimate intention is to foreclose," Mr. McGuire said, "it is usually wise to continue paying taxes for the two-year period to prevent someone else from picking up a subsequent year's lien." Generally speaking, he said, it makes sense for investors to pay taxes that accrue during the waiting period because when they redeem a lien, they are allowed to collect interest on any additional taxes paid at the same rate established at the tax sale.
In Connecticut, similar procedures are used, but in New York State, the procedures for handling tax-delinquent property depend upon where it is located.
Eric Davis, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said New York City sells tax liens similar to the liens sold in New Jersey. However, he said, in recent years the city has adopted procedures for the sale of such liens that have resulted in the liens being sold "in bulk" to large institutional investors.
In other areas of the state, Mr. Davis said, individuals can invest in tax-delinquent properties, but the procedure is somewhat riskier than the city's.
Outside New York City, a county tax collector is allowed to hold a tax sale for any property that has accrued three years' back taxes, Mr. Davis said. Before holding such a sale the tax collector must notify the property owner of the time and date of the sale and the amount of taxes that are due. If the taxes have not been paid by the date of the sale, the tax collector has the right to sell the property to the highest bidder. But buying property from a tax collector is not the same as buying it from the owner.
"What you get from the county is what is known as a quitclaim deed," Mr. Davis said. Such a deed transfers to the successful bidder all of the county's rights to the property.
And while the county's tax lien takes precedence over all other liens except Federal claims, a quitclaim deed from the county tax collector may not always be the safest investment.
"If the county didn't provide proper notice of the tax sale, the sale could be subject to challenge," Mr. Davis said. For example, he said, if the county notifies the property owner at the address on the deed, but the property owner had properly notified the county of a change of address, the sale could be defective.
Moreover, Mr. Davis said, properties sold at tax sale can be occupied by tenants, squatters or even the property owner himself -- a complication that could require lengthy legal proceedings to rectify.
Accordingly, Mr. Davis said, investors considering purchasing New York State property at a tax sale should inspect it before the sale. It is also wise to conduct a title search to determine the chain of title and to find out whether the person the tax collector has identified as the owner is the current owner of record, he said.
"This is not something you would want to just jump into," said Mr. Davis, who has purchased about 120 acres of upstate property at tax sales. "The risks can be significant. But that's not to say you can't get lucky."

HEADLINE: Parrish Plans Growth Without the Pains

BYLINE: By PHYLLIS BRAFF

 BODY:
COMBINING a need to modernize with an opportunity to expand, the Parrish Art Museum is embarking on a revitalization plan that is likely to bring a needed infusion of energy and sparkle to Southampton's commercial area.
On Aug. 7, the museum's 25 trustees unanimously voted to accept the recommendations of its architectural planning committee for restoration and improvement made possible by the acquisition of the Rogers Memorial Library building next door at Job's Lane and Main Street. Now, the staff will prepare a master plan for governmental and community review this fall. Work is expected to begin in September 2001, with completion in early 2003. 
 Long aware of the need to bring its 1897 facility up to current museum standards, the Parrish was waiting for the library building to become available for purchase. (A new library is under construction one block west, on Windmill Lane.)
"The decision to delay any modernization and wait for the adjacent structure, which also dates from the late 19th century, opened up a whole new way of thinking about the village and about the museum," said Trudy Kramer, the Parrish's executive director. "We now had a chance to gain needed space while also preserving two historic buildings. We could provide a hub with a cultural facility that is true to Southampton's period character. Long Island villages are changing quickly."
The museum project is very appealing to local businesses. "We see the Parrish's success as helping the local economy to be more of a year-round success," said Wayne Swiatocha, a past president of the Southampton Chamber of Commerce.
The space revisions will accommodate larger exhibitions and larger paintings; additional galleries, allowing popular works to go on permanent view; climate-controlled storage for the collection; an orientation area; a reading room; a lecture hall; offices; classrooms, and visitor amenities like a tearoom and an expanded museum shop.
An architect with considerable experience in museum projects, Chad Floyd of Centerbrook Architects and Planners in Essex, Conn., is preparing the design. Mr. Floyd's previous commissions have included the Hood Museum at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H., and the Norton Museum in West Palm Beach, Fla.
"I'm interested in making the character of the existing museum really sing," Mr. Floyd said.
He said he was developing plans that would retain the integrity of the original museum building but permit the installation of updated technical systems. He plans to change only post-19th-century treatments he regards as inappropriate. "Everything we do will have a friendly relationship to the historic building in terms of textures and colors," he added.
No changes are planned for the exterior of the red-brick Queen Anne-style library building, although classrooms, a lecture hall and offices are to be created inside.
Ms. Kramer expressed confidence that the overall new concept and the way the redesigned space is programmed would give the Parrish the potential to be a noteworthy destination. "Our ability to tell the story of art on eastern Long Island will be an attraction, and one that will be enhanced by visitor orientation materials," she said.
Alicia Longwell, the museum's curator, added: "With the collection on permanent view, people will arrange visits knowing that the paintings they dearly want to see are available."
Late last month, the museum announced the establishment of the Otto Endowment Fund for the Study of the Art of Eastern Long Island. Werner and Maren Otto, part-time residents of Southampton, have given $750,000 to support research, study and interpretation of the art and artists of the region.
The museum owns works by many well-known 19th- and 20th-century artists associated with the area: Thomas Moran, Childe Hassam, Willem de Kooning, Jackson Pollock, Larry Rivers, Alfonso Ossorio, Malcolm Morley, Lynda Benglis, James Brooks, Esteban Vicente, John Ferren, Ibram Lassaw, Jane Freilicher, Chuck Close, Roy Lichtenstein, Dorothea Rockburne and Jane Wilson.
But the collection also has a broad range. When the Parrish organizes the new space to tell the story of American art in general, it will be able to draw from its 19th-century portraits, genre and landscape paintings, including pieces by William Sidney Mount, Albert Pinkham Ryder, John Twachtman, Thomas Doughty, James McNeill Whistler and Martin Johnson Heade. Galleries for 20th-century art are likely to use pieces by Charles Burchfield, Robert Henri, John Marin, Reginald Marsh, Eli Nadelman, Agnes Martin, Phillip Guston and Alex Katz.
Other Parrish resources that generate widespread interest and demand for gallery space include the extensive holdings of works by William Merritt Chase (1849-1916) and Fairfield Porter (1907-1975). These large collections of major paintings are supplemented by related archival and reference materials that make the museum the primary study center for both artists.
On the exterior, Douglas Reed, a landscape architect based in Cambridge, Mass., is doing the research and planning on how the surrounding three-acre park setting and its re design will serve the community. "I asked for a close collaboration with the landscape architects from the initial phases because the role of the park is such a positive force in this museum scheme," Mr. Floyd said.
Mr. Reed sees special meaning in the way the project merges the functions of campus and park with historic sites and the roles of public and private institutions. "It's a wonderful opportunity for an important civic place," he said.
"The museum's interest in reaching out to the public in new ways is driving the site development design. The idea is to create a cohesive character along Job's Lane with walks and terraces that allow the entire length to function as an entrance, bringing the public into the buildings and surrounding areas.
"We want to make the arboretum and park accessible from Job's Lane and to go further by creating a center for pedestrian circulation, increasing the hub character and tying-in, too, with Southampton's master plan for an independent system of pedestrian walks." That system is currently under review by the village planning board. "The Parrish is regarded as a major centerpiece for the village," said Charles Coulter, a planning board member.
The arboretum was laid out in 1897 by another Boston-area landscape architect, Warren H. Manning, using many rare specimen trees, and it was regarded by Samuel Longstreth Parrish as an important part of his gift to Southampton. Saving the original arboretum, which the planners are now calling the historical arboretum, is a significant aspect of the project.
A summer resident during his boyhood and in the years he practiced law in New York City, Parrish moved here permanently after retiring and became active in village endeavors. An admirer of classical Italian art, Parrish also commissioned copies of 18 marble busts of the Roman Caesars for his museum. Long a familiar part of the garden, the busts are to be retained in the renovation.
In addition to developing a fuller agenda of lectures, workshops and classes in the expanded space, the museum plans to treat the original arboretum as a teaching resource.
The museum staff considers Parrish's spirit of edification and enlightenment to be the foundation of a strong education mandate. "We've never had the physical space to carry out our teaching role as completely as we wished, but we are now in a position to fulfill our mission," Ms. Kramer said. "In all its endeavors, the museum should give visitors a memory to carry away, and we want to do that."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
The New Goal at Retail Power Centers: Eye Appeal

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
IN response to New Jersey's strong retail market, big-box retailers continue to expand in the state and developers put up shopping centers to house them. But now a small but growing number of towns are requiring -- and at least one county is aggressively advocating -- that the centers have a more appealing design, signaling a departure from the gray cracker box strips of the past.
An example is the combined Nassau Park and Nassau Park Pavilion on Route 1 and Quakerbridge Road in West Windsor, which at 1.1 million square feet is the largest "power center" in the state. Following a design ordinance by the township, the center, nearing completion on its final phase, has distinctive exterior architectural touches and extensive landscaping and walkways. When completed in March, it will also have amenities from a promenade and plazas to fountains and an ice skating rink. 
 The project is a power center as defined by the International Council of Shopping Centers in Manhattan: an open-air retail strip with 250,000 square feet of space or more and three or more large specialty or big-box stores. It will have six big-box retailers, including a 135,000-square-foot Wal-Mart; a 127,000-square-foot Target, and a 115,000-square-foot Wegman's supermarket, as well as 17 other stores with 9,000 to 59,000 square feet each.
More than half the stores are completed and occupied and the rest, already leased, will open by year's end, said J. Charles Hendon Jr, president of Hendon Properties of Atlanta, the developer. "We followed the township's demands and in retrospect the project is better for it," he said.
The trend extends to smaller strip centers, including one proposed on King George Road in Bernards Township in Somerset County. The township hired an architect to design the center and, as part of rezoning the 20-acre site from residential use, adopted an ordinance requiring the developer to build the project following its design.
"If we didn't do this we knew we would get the quickest and easiest retail strip," said Peter Messina, the township engineer and planner. The project will have six colonial- and Victorian-style buildings, totaling 95,000 square feet, that will frame a central green and feature a clock tower and antique street lamps.
"There will be more cost up front, but the project will draw higher-end tenants who typically do not go into strip centers," said Scott Loventhal, a vice president at Garden Commercial Properties, of Short Hills, the developer. Construction will start next year.
Last fall, Somerset County responded to the spate of projects, particularly power centers, under way or planned in the county by developing guidelines that municipalities can follow and a model ordinance they can adopt to incorporate design elements into projects of 40,000 square feet or more. They include at least four power centers, totaling almost three million square feet.
Robert Bzik, the county's planning director, said the guidelines called for, among other things, projects designed with materials, colors and roof lines compatible with those in the adjacent neighborhoods. They also require increased landscaping and community spaces, like seating areas.
"The aim is to increase the quality and appearance of projects so they reflect their surroundings," he said, adding that the Bernards center embodied that concept. Though the guidelines have not yet been used fully in the large projects, Mr. Bzik said a few have utilized certain aspects, like adding architectural variety and upgraded materials.
Power centers and shopping strips are the dominant form of retail being built today, data from the shopping center council show, although the rate of growth of power centers nationally has slowed. There were 54 power centers built last year, down from 81 in 1997, according to the National Research Bureau, a publisher of shopping center trends based in Chicago.
Ted Kraus, who heads TKO Real Estate Advisory Group in Mercerville, said big-box retailers continue to drive the market in New Jersey, which with a vacancy rate of less than 3 percent is strong. The look of a center can help distinguish it from the competition, but it will not make an unsuccessful center a success, Mr. Kraus said.
"The rub is the cost," said Bill Farber, chief executive of Levin Management in North Plainfield, which develops, owns and manages shopping centers. Smart developers will not fight a better design, he said, but "mandating it is the extreme and happens only in towns where the economics are strong enough to make the project viable."
That is the case for the West Windsor center, which sits on 162 acres once zoned for offices. It is the first project in New Jersey for Hendon Properties, which bought the initial 62-acre component in 1994 from Wal-Mart, which was working with a developer who did not proceed.
The company, using bond financing from Wall Street, began that component with a rezoning in place and secured leases from three tenants -- Wal-Mart, Sam's Wholesale Club and Home Depot -- totaling 380,000 square feet. By 1996, it began adding 220,000 more square feet in eight stores, Mr. Hendon said. In 1997, Hendon brought in Developers Diversified Realty of Cleveland, a real estate investment trust, as an equity partner. It then bought 100 adjacent acres, which after two years of legal wrangling was rezoned to build Nassau Park Pavilion, expanding the complex by 450,000 square feet to its current size.
MR. HENDON said that Target, Wegman's and an 86,000-square-foot Kohl's store would anchor Nassau Park Pavilion, which is rising on 40 acres. The remaining 60 acres will be open.
The project is the only power center in West Windsor and there are no other large sites zoned or expected to be rezoned for retail, said Sam Surtees, its director of community development. So "we wanted it to be aesthetically pleasing and have amenities" to invite in the public, he said.
The township's ordinance, which was even more entensive for the project's third phase, specifies the colors and textures of the material to be used. All the buildings have a colored masonry base and their facades are accented with horizontal bands, with those of the larger stores also featuring canopies and synthetic stucco finishes. Designed by Pieper O'Brien Herr Architects of Atlanta the centers also feature metal trusses and brick and steel towers.
The focal point of the amenities, now under way, will be the pedestrian plaza, winter-garden and ice skating rink complex. The plaza, set next to the Wintergarden -- a glass enclosed structure that may house a restaurant -- will access the rink, which will double as an amphitheater during the summer. There will also be a gazebo, which will serve as a sitting area, overlooking a pond, green areas and the historic Delaware & Raritan Canal beyond. The Hillier Group of Princeton is the project's planner and landscape architect.
Mr. Hendon said that the required design and amenities added $14.5 million to the project's cost, to $120 million. "We had to compensate for that cost in the rents," he said, noting that they were raised by $2 to $5, to $16 to $30 a square foot. But, he said, tenants were willing to pay and be flexible in their typical store designs because of the center's location and the area's demographics.
The site is close to the Quakerbridge and Mercer Malls in nearby Lawrence Township, creating what Mr. Hendon described as a "retail node" in that part of central New Jersey. And, he added, 397,555 people with an average annual household income of $67,360 live within 10 miles of the site.
"We would never do the project this way if all those factors were not in place," Mr. Hendon said. In the five-year development process, he added, "we were lucky the retail market remained strong and no other sites outside of West Windsor opened up."
"Having a more attractive center," he said, "is good for the community and good for us because it brings in more people."

HEADLINE: No Small Potatoes;
Agriculture Is Booming in Suffolk, as Farmers Move Beyond Spuds Into High-Tech Methods and Upscale Crops

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
WITH hundreds of acres of farmland growing a final crop of houses each year, agriculture on Long Island's East End remains under assault by land development that continues to consume some of the finest soil in North America.
But as open spaces and traditional farms in the Island's last truly rural region come ever more under siege, a surprising economic evolution has taken place. 
 Far from being on the ropes, a new and vastly different agricultural industry centered in the East End towns of Riverhead, Southold, Southampton and East Hampton is prospering, and Suffolk County is maintaining and even strengthening its hold on first place in New York in the market value of its agricultural products.
Traditional farmers who grow potatoes and other field crops continue to struggle, but operators of greenhouses, nurseries, vineyards and, to a more limited degree, sod farms have taken up the slack.
According to United States Department of Agriculture figures based on a 1997 agricultural census, the market value of Suffolk products from greenhouses and nurseries, combined with sod and such specialty items as Christmas trees and mushrooms, accounted for $125,975,000 of the $167,858,000 Suffolk agricultural total, which in turn was a 25 percent increase over the total in 1992, the year of the previous survey.
The increases came over the same years when the roaring regional economy raised development pressures to new heights and peppered farm areas with new housing. But the 1997 agricultural census, which profiles agriculture in every county in the nation, showed that the amount of land in Suffolk being farmed actually increased by 1.4 percent during that period between 1992 and 1997, or from 35,353 to 35,858 acres.
The figures do not reveal how much of these lands farmers are renting from developer-owners, a years-old pattern particularly common among traditional farmers.
And to be sure, in a county where farmers grew potatoes on more than 50,000 acres four decades ago, the remaining farm acreage in use is not great. The No. 2 agricultural county in New York, Wyoming County, has nearly 200,000 farm acres and the Suffolk total was among the lowest in the state. And only about 6 percent of Suffolk's total acreage is used for farming.
But it is this ability to do more with fewer acres that characterizes the new era of agriculture in Suffolk County, where capital-intensive greenhouse operations cover 214 acres and produce many times the profit a potato farm on the same acreage would earn even in the most favorable market.
"The agricultural economy has reinvented itself," said Stephen M. Jones, the county Planning Director. "It is no longer potato-based, it is based on high-value crops."
While Suffolk still remains first in the state for potato production, and while its high-quality vinifera grapes account for just 6 percent of the grapes grown in the state, it is the high-value crops that have made the difference, Mr. Jones and others said.
In addition to grapes, the list of high-value crops includes a wide range of plants, flowers, ornamentals and young trees as well half the sod grown in the state.
Some traditional farmers have found niches such as varieties of lettuce or other field crops that are custom-grown for special markets. Others grow fruits, corn and other produce for their own or neighbors' farm stands, bypassing wholesale markets to sell directly to customers.
"It is remarkable how resilient this industry has been," said Joseph M. Gergela, the Long Island Farm Bureau's executive director. "It continues to evolve, and now you have people looking to buy farmland because it is disappearing. There's still a chance for us to hold on here."
Suffolk farmers are praised by the state. "They are masters of agriculture," said Pete Gregg, a spokesman for the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets. "It's just a fabulous area for agriculture.
"There is a lot of direct marketing of agricultural products and a tremendous amount of agritourism, and that definitely helps revenues. The vineyards are doing great, and of course the greenhouses and nurseries are just booming. I would say Suffolk is pulling further ahead."
One measure of the county's intense, high-value agriculture is a market value for products in 1997 of $4,681 an acre, a figure no other county in the state approached. The state average was $390.73 an acre.
While the $167,858,000 market value of all Suffolk products sold is small compared with values in counties in prime farming regions elsewhere in the country, the per-acre value is still impressive. In Fresno County, Calif., the No. 1 agricultural county in the country's No. 1 agricultural state, market value for products was nearly $2.8 billion in 1997. But the value per acre was $1,474, or less than a third of Suffolk's.
The numbers mask the strains felt by traditional farmers, whose fields of crops, far more than rows of young trees or greenhouse complexes, fit the public notion of what farms should be.
Severely tried by economic hardships and tempted by rising land prices that make selling to developers inviting, farmers' ranks have dwindled to about 400 full-time farms and about 600 farms in total averaging 60 acres, according to the 1997 agriculture census, which was released in February by the United States Department of Agriculture.
But the tenacious traditional farmers who remain, including some whose families have farmed the North Fork for more than 300 years, have relied on a variety of strategies and crops plus dogged hard work.
Their operations have also taken a toll. A monitoring program to detect pesticides in groundwater, performed by the Suffolk County Department of Health Services for the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, contained alarming results. The report, released in June, showed far more pervasive contamination of groundwater in farm areas, particularly on the North Fork, than officials had anticipated. Some of the contaminants were traced to pesticides that were banned 10 or more years ago.
The findings highlighted the chemical-intensive nature of Suffolk agriculture, particularly among traditional farmers, and raised questions about the health impacts on residents of farm areas whose wells for drinking water contained contaminants in excess of safety standards.
While East End farmers have relied heavily on pesticides, fungicides and herbicides, they have had natural advantages, including highly productive soil and the easy availability of groundwater for irrigation.
In the current drought, a disaster for farmers in many areas, farmers and greenhouse and nursery operators have fared well.
"One thing about irrigation, it's expensive and labor-intensive, but we can always put the water where we want it, when we want, and only as much as we want," said Philip A. Schmitt, who specializes in growing lettuce and cabbage on a 150-acre farm on Sound Avenue in Riverhead.
"It's not that I'm loving it quite this dry," Mr. Schmitt, a former president of the Long Island Farm Bureau, said before the dry weather was interrupted by drenching rain last week. "It's just that I'd rather have it dry than too much rain."
The drought is also having limited impact on greenhouses and nurseries. Vineyard operators, whose high-quality grapes do best in hot, dry conditions, said the weather was raising hopes of a vintage year.
A troubling downside, industry spokesmen said, is a scarcity of farm labor as higher wages paid by restaurants and landscapers lure away freelance workers, many of whom are illegal immigrants.
The abysmal labor camps that once housed migrant laborers, most frequently black men, are now history, and few farm operators make arrangements with the New York State Department of Labor to legally hire and house foreign laborers for specified times. The labor department said only 2 of 235 applications filed statewide for such hiring this year came from Suffolk.
Most operators get by with help from family members, retired farmers or local residents still willing to work long farm hours for minimum wage or little more. Almost universally, the operators work Herculean hours themselves.
"The biggest problem right now is labor," said William J. Sanok, an educator at the Cornell Cooperative Extension in Riverhead. "Any time you have unemployment so low, you don't have a lot of people coming to the farms."
But the agriculture industry has had a degree of public support that may be unequaled anywhere else. Since the advent of a county farmland preservation program in the 1970's, Suffolk has purchased development rights to hundreds of farm acres to assure that the land can be used only for agriculture.
Most of the purchases have been in the North Fork towns of Riverhead and Southold, where Suffolk agriculture is most intensive. Residents in the South Fork towns of Southampton and East Hampton, where land prices are higher, have augmented the county program with local development-rights purchases.
Kevin McDonald, vice president of the Group for the South Fork, a private environmental and planning group in Bridgehampton, said 2,400 acres in Southampton and 800 acres in East Hampton had been preserved under combined programs. He said 3,600 acres in Riverhead and 2,300 acres in Southold had been preserved on the North Fork.
County Executive Robert J. Gaffney, like his predecessors, has pledged support for East End farm preservation. In November, Suffolk voters approved a $60 million open space and parks program strongly backed by Mr. Gaffney that includes $20 million for additional purchases of farm development rights.
Yet as second-home developments continue to overtake farm fields, particularly in Southampton, and as other farmlands lie fallow while their developer-owners pursue building plans, Mr. McDonald and other conservationists see limitations in an agricultural industry that is "getting more and more profit out of less and less land."
Mr. McDonald said farmers must now also come to grips with "the emerging issue of how the pesticide monitoring reports begs the question of how to have Long Island-wide public support for farm preservation."
"We are at a critical juncture," Mr. McDonald said. "We're going to have to get a lot smarter about farming practices, and it's going to require extraordinary creativity and statesmanship among folks in the agricultural industry, public health officials and others. It can't just degenerate into a big finger-pointing exercise."
Mr. McDonald said one problem was a reluctance he found on the part of farms to discuss their use of farm chemicals.
Some farmers say they are too busy to discuss anything. "Look, I've got a lot of work to do, O.K.?" said Todd Wells, a farmer in Riverhead who declined the other day to stop and talk.
Then Mr. Wells drove his tractor into a potato field to spray potato plants within view of a new golf course on a neighbor's land that used to be a farm.
