HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Obstructions to New Rental Projects Are on the Rise

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
ON Sept. 14, a referendum will be held in New Canaan. If it succeeds, the voters will have blocked a $5 million appropriation meant to cover the cost of moving the town's public works garage to a landfill area, thus scuttling plans for a fully approved 104-unit apartment complex by Avalon Bay Communities of Alexandria, Va., that is to be constructed on the garage site.
In New Canaan and three other southwestern Connecticut towns -- Darien, Wilton and Orange -- grass-roots opposition to Avalon's luxury rental communities seems to reinforce recent decisions by state courts. 
 Elsewhere in Connecticut, in the towns of Glastonbury, Newtown and Bridgewater, state courts have upheld local planning and zoning commissions' decisions to deny various developers' applications that conformed to Connecticut's affordable-housing law. The applications were rejected primarily because of a shortage of sewers and of potable water.
The law is intended to provide housing for people of moderate means in towns where zoning regulations and land costs preclude almost all housing for lower-income families. On average, well under 3 percent of the housing in Fairfield County's affluent towns qualifies as "affordable housing," a proportion that falls far short of the 10 percent goal that the state has set for all 169 towns statewide.
Under the 1989 law, developers are allowed to build more densely if one-quarter of their projects are priced below market rates, leading many critics of development to believe that developers use the law to benefit themselves, building large, out-of-scale projects.
Such critics contend that densities ranging from 100 to more than 300 units per complex can overwhelm services in towns with small populations accustomed to single-family homes on one-acre lots. But density is the key to making a project economically feasible.
Antipathy toward rental housing -- the only housing that Avalon builds -- and the word "affordable" persists. To many critics, "affordable housing" is an invitation to undesirable transients with no vested interest in the town. The law requires that affordable units remain so for 30 years.
Nonetheless, Avalon has been notably successful at winning court cases and building formulaic but elegant apartment compounds, with swimming pools, gymnasiums, clubhouses and other amenities residents can use without charge.
One of the largest developers of rental apartments in the state, Avalon has built four market-rate complexes in Stamford and two in Danbury, cities in which the amount of low-cost housing exceeds 10 percent of the total. Under the affordable-housing law, Avalon has built one complex each in the upscale towns of Wilton and Trumbull.
Nationwide it has built or owns 137 apartment communities containing 39,739 units in 16 states.
Samuel B. Fuller, regional vice president in the company's Wilton office, said that residents of other states have tended to accept affordable housing without the protracted legal battles that the company has encountered in Connecticut. "Connecticut is by far the worst," he said. "People are much more afraid of any kind of new development."
The dispute between New Canaan and Avalon began more than five years ago, when Avalon's application to build housing and some retail stores on a three-acre downtown parcel next to the railroad station was rejected, revised and rejected again. Avalon sued New Canaan under the affordable-housing law, saying the town had failed to provide compelling reasons for the denials.
Avalon won that case and prevailed on appeal, but after the town approved the project, a citizen-led referendum to condemn the site for use as a commuter parking lot was passed. Rather than fight an injunction obtained by Avalon to halt condemnation, a land swap was negotiated.
Avalon and the town agreed to exchange the Mill Pond public works site for the downtown parcel in 1997. New Canaan got the commuter parking space it wanted downtown, and Avalon got a suitable construction site as well as a 99-year lease-back on a small portion of the downtown site. It expects to build a 15,000-square-foot building there for its Connecticut headquarters and other offices. The town agreed to bear the $5 million cost of moving the public works buildings to the landfill area.
John M. Potts, a Democratic candidate for First Selectman in the coming election and an opponent of development on either site, calls the swap "giving away the store."
IN an agreement made outside the provisions of the affordable-housing law, Avalon agreed to set aside 21 apartments at Mill Pond for town employees, using a state formula in which the area's median income of $94,300 is the basis for computing eligible incomes and rents. The lower rents, deemed "affordable" by the town, would be $1,508 to $2,800 a month for one- to three-bedroom apartments. Market-price rents would range from $1,700 to $3,100 a month.
Save Mill Pond Park, the name of a citizens' group spearheading opposition to the development, "is a misnomer," said John Cannavino of the Stamford law firm of Cummings & Lockwood. He has represented the town during the years of litigation. "The pond and park areas will not be lost," he said, noting that Avalon's plan will not disturb them. The existing garage, salt storage building, unpaved parking area and dump site for construction debris will be replaced by apartments, landscaping and a public nature trail around the pond, he said.
Richard P. Bond, the Republican First Selectman, who is up for re-election in November, said he supported the Avalon project.
"My position is that we should go ahead with the exchange of property," he said. "It is the most beneficial solution for the town. We are not in the hands of the courts to make a decision on condemnation or to establish the price." The cost of moving the garage, he said, would be half that of condemnation.
Avalon cannot set a date to break ground on the property until it changes hands. Mr. Fuller said that if the referendum passed, the swap would be canceled and Avalon would proceed with its original plan to develop the downtown site.
Mr. Potts and many other town residents opposed the town's adoption of a new zoning category, large-lot apartment development, which was suggested by Avalon for the Mill Pond site. The new designation allows the developer to build higher-density apartments. The critics believe that other developers working under the affordable-housing law will apply the designation to any 5-acre lot with 100-foot frontage on a state road where sewers and public water were available.
"Untrue," said Hiram Peck, New Canaan's Town Planner. "The standards limit where the zone can be located -- on a very small portion of state roads that run through town. There are few potential parcels for which it is applicable." His office is revising New Canaan's long-range plan and zoning regulations, including limiting the expansion of sewer and water districts into residential areas to discourage housing developments.
In Darien, a citizens' movement supported by the Board of Selectmen is focused on condemning a site where Avalon plans to build 189 apartments, some affordable, on 32 acres near the railroad station. Avalon obtained an injunction to halt the action until briefs are filed in State Superior Court in Stamford next month.
Darien's lawyer, John Wayne Fox, recently obtained permission from Superior Court to make test borings on Avalon's property for environmental reasons, despite the fact that the town's environmental protection agency had already approved the project.
Jay Sandak, a lawyer for Avalon, objected, saying the town had no right to enter the property until it had determined a public purpose for it, had had it appraised, and had formally stated its intention to condemn. A decision is expected within the next few weeks.
In the town of Orange, voters recently approved a referendum to condemn a 30-acre parcel under contract to Avalon, where 168 units, including 25 percent at affordable rents, had been proposed. An injunction prevents any action until a Superior Court judge in Middletown makes a decision. The court is also considering Orange's rejection of Avalon's application for residential zoning approval at the site. The area is zoned for light industrial and residential development, said Timothy Hollister, another lawyer for Avalon.
Late last month a public hearing at Wilton High School broke into guffaws and catcalls when Avalon officials presented a proposal to build 119 housing units, some at affordable rents. Speakers objected to the location off Route 7, where traffic is heavy, and to the density -- more tightly packed than anything else in town. The hearing is to continue on Sept. 13.
John Scott of Scott Kinney Partners in Westport, a market research and real estate planning firm, spoke at the hearing on behalf of the developer. "After doing this for 25 years, I've concluded that the public doesn't like change in any form," Mr. Scott said in a telephone interview later. "There is a groundswell of anxiety today, which relates to overcrowded schools and stressed services. I find that hearings have become more belligerent. We are seeing elected commissioners who have always been able to put down an unruly audience but now tend to reflect the popular attitude of 'no growth.' "
Undaunted, Avalon continues to expand its presence in Connecticut. In Stamford, the 195-apartment Avalon Corners opened this month, and Greyrock Towers, with 306 units, is scheduled to open in 18 months. A schedule for 306 apartment units to be built on the site of the former Burdick School in Stamford has not yet been determined. In addition, Avalon has applied for permission to build 306 apartments in Newtown.

HEADLINE: Albany Still Digs in Taxpayer Pockets, Spano Says

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
"DON'T be fooled by the state's budget," County Executive Andrew J. Spano is advising Westchester taxpayers, now that Albany has passed its long-awaited spending package for 1999-2000.
Although local school districts and other parts of the economy are seeing windfalls in the budget -- and property owners can expect some reductions in their taxes as a result -- residents must also factor in $40 million in lost state aid to the county government for social services over two years. 
 "Let's face it, what the state did was take the money out of one pocket and put it in another," said Kathleen M. Tooher-Carrano, Westchester's Budget Director. "Eventually, though, it all comes from the same taxpayers."
If not directly in raised taxes then in a reduction of services, Westchester residents will be asked to make up for the lost dollars, county officials said last week.
"Like a wolf in sheep's clothing, this budget is not to be trusted on its surface," said Thomas J. Abinanti, a member of the Board of Legislators' Budget and Appropriations Committee. Mr. Abinanti criticized the state for cloaking what he said was the real intent of the budget: to mandate but not pay for services like welfare and food stamps.
Not everyone, however, was buying the state budget doom scenario for Westchester. "I don't think it's time to say the sky is falling," State Senator Nicholas A. Spano said. With $32 million in aid for Westchester school districts, Mr. Spano, who is not related to the County Executive, called Albany's spending plan, "generally speaking, a very good budget for the taxpayers of Westchester."
Meanwhile, the County Executive ordered department heads immediately to freeze nonessential hiring and spending. Having campaigned in 1997 on a no-tax-increase platform, County Executive Spano said that other types of cutbacks would also have to be enacted in the coming months. He has pledged to reduce the county's property tax levy by 15 percent, or $52 million, over four years.
"All new initiatives are now at risk," he said.
The county has three main sources of revenue, with about 30 percent of its budget coming from state and Federal aid, about 36 percent from parks fees, sales taxes and hotel occupancy taxes and about 34 percent from property taxes.
"The latter," Ms. Tooher-Carrano said, referring to property taxes, "is the last place we like to go."
The state's $73.3 billion spending package for the current fiscal year reduces state aid to all counties and forces them to absorb the entire cost of cutbacks in social welfare programs.
The reductions come seven months into Westchester's 1999 fiscal year, and while they will not directly create deficits in the county's $1 billion budget, they will significantly erode its $17.8 million surplus at year's end. On Wednesday Ms. Tooher-Carrano said the county will use about $14 million of the surplus to "backfill state aid losses." The surplus ordinarily is applied to subsequent budgets.
"This is especially frustrating when the state is sitting on its highest budget surplus in years," Larry S. Schwartz, Mr. Spano's chief adviser, said.
The state's surplus is now nearly $3 billion. Gov. George E. Pataki achieved one of his major goals for the year, an agreement not to spend the $1.8 billion surplus accumulated in the last fiscal year, which will be saved to help the state pay for tax cuts to take effect next year. But Mr. Abinanti said the Governor will be doing that at the expense of Westchester's residents.
This year, state cutbacks to Westchester could force reductions in hiring and spending. Next year, it might mean higher sales taxes, increased fees and decreased hours at county parks, reduced funds for neighborhood health centers and cutbacks in money for the arts, among other things, county officials said.
"Every program will have to be looked at," Mr. Schwartz said. "It's either cutting services or raising taxes."
By contrast, most school districts in the county reveled in the happy news that they would receive more state aid than ever, with the Board of Education in Ossining, for example, announcing that an increase of about $600,000 -- to $5.8 million in the new budget from $5.2 million last year -- will spell 1.5 percent in relief for property owners.
Yonkers also learned that it would be a beneficiary of the state's apparent largesse, with New York's fourth-largest city receiving a record $72 million -- or 31 percent more -- from the state. Last year the city received $54.5 million. Yonkers officials said they have lobbied hard in recent years to even out what they termed past inequities in state aid. The city will be able to continue to phase out at least two taxes on residents (an income tax surcharge and a real estate tax) and to hire 30 new police officers.
By contrast, here on the ninth floor of the County Office Building, where Mr. Spano's office is situated and the Board of Legislators meets, the words "devastating," "shocking" and "unfair" have echoed through the halls since news of the 120-day-late budget accord was delivered on Aug. 4.
To close Westchester budget gaps, Mr. Spano announced, among other things, his intention to jettison his earlier proposal to set aside 25 percent in tobacco settlement funds for antismoking programs. The money is part of a $206 billion settlement between tobacco companies and 46 states that sued to recoup Medicaid costs related to smoking. Over 25 years the county will receive $481 million in tobacco settlement money, the County Budget Director said.
For the 2000 budget, the County Executive said he had hoped to lighten the tax burden for Westchester property owners with an estimated $12 million from the county's share of the settlement of the lawsuits against the tobacco industry. In June, he pledged to use the remaining $4 million from the first year's tobacco payment for antismoking and public health programs. Now, that money may have to go toward paying for mandated programs.
Although the state has indicated that the county should use the tobacco money to offset the cuts, the County Executive disagreed. He has argued that the funds are Westchester's, and it is therefore the county's decision to determine how to use the money. Also, the intent of the settlement was not to backfill state aid cuts, Mrs. Tooher-Carrano said.
There are other budget restrictions being considered, and Ms. Tooher-Carrano predicted that Albany's reductions would have "a long-lasting impact" on Westchester.
In addition to limiting all new hiring, except in public health and public safety, Mr. Spano has ordered freezes on all nonessential travel, equipment orders and contracts of less than $20,000. Moreover, he said no overtime can be allowed without first being approved by the budget office. As of Sept. 1, the need for hourly employees will be reviewed. About 200 hourly workers who could be affected in September, Ms. Tooher-Carrano said. .
In part, the county will lose nearly $1.8 million in Federal aid because of the state's failure to enact in January new regulations for the Adoption and Safe Families Act, a program meant to move children out of foster care more quickly.
The county will also have to pay an additional $2.3 million in Medicaid expenses because the State Legislature failed to continue a cost-containment measure by June 30.
Westchester will also lose about $500,000 in state reimbursements this year to house some state inmates at the County Jail in Valhalla.
In addition, the county estimates that this year alone it will lose $4.2 million because the state refused to absorb a 3 percent reduction in Federal funds for food stamps, another $1 million because of the elimination of funds for a state-mandated program to move welfare recipients to managed care and an estimated $3.1 million from a shortfall in statewide money for welfare programs.
With more of the same projected for the full 12 months of next year, the county predicts a loss of $25 million in revenue. The county's fiscal year coincides with the calendar year, while the state's budget year runs from April to April.
At least one state legislator questioned why Westchester was acting so surprised and shocked over the cutbacks and said elected officials had "failed to see the handwriting on the wall." Assemblyman Michael J. Spano, Republican of Yonkers, said that although he was sympathetic to the county's plight, he had warned Westchester officials in June that "we're going to lose a ton of money." He said they did not heed his warnings.
The Assemblyman faulted the county's Democrats for failing to work hard enough in Albany on behalf of their interests. "They lobbied with one arm behind their back out of respect for the Democratic Speaker of the Assembly and they ended up getting shafted," he said. "They had to see this was coming." Mr. Schwartz disagreed, saying that county officials paid many visits to Albany. "All of us were up there often," he said. "We were in their face constantly."
He also said that not only did county officials visit Albany but that they also sent letters and made calls.
But Sandra R. Galef, a Democratic Assemblywoman from Ossining agreed that the presence in Albany of Westchester and other counties was not as significant as it should have been.
Overall, the state slashed aid to counties by $300 million.
Referring to a strongly worded letter sent by the County Executive to the State Legislature the day before the budget was passed, Ms. Galef said, "Westchester did not present its case until the very last hour."
Ms. Galef also suggested that the Albany-based New York State Association of Counties, a lobbying group, should have worked harder on the counties' behalf.

HEADLINE: WORKING;
Sharing a Staff With a Ghost

BYLINE: By MICHELLE COTTLE; Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer.

 BODY:
You were recently brought in to replace the head of a department who was let go because of conflict with upper management. Despite your predecessor's rocky relations with her supervisors, she was popular with her staff. Now you're faced with trying to motivate a group of workers demoralized by the loss of their leader, one or two of whom, you suspect, regard you as the enemy. Do you address the problem or ignore it and hope everyone eventually adjusts?
Many people don't deal well with change under the best circumstances. And the firing of a popular supervisor can leave employees with a sense of loss as well as one of fear. The new leader should address both.
"When people work closely with someone, they bond," said Laurie Kalman, president of Performance First, a human resources consulting firm in Branford, Conn. "That's a relationship that needs to be acknowledged. You need to give the staff permission to go through a bit of a mourning process." 
 Cynthia Guy, a partner with Crystal Clear Concepts, a management consulting firm in St. Clair Shores, Mich., said that this process can benefit both the employees and the new manager. "Your job is to maintain high empathy," Ms. Guy said. "Listen. Try to understand their feelings. Find out, if you can, what their fears are. Find out what you need to do in their eyes to build trust."
Ms. Guy said that staffers might be asking themselves: " 'Am I going to get it? Is the new manager going to come in with a new broom?' "
Such concerns are far from groundless, said Joe Buys, another partner with Crystal Clear Concepts. "In terms of any management change, people frequently say, 'We're not going to make any changes,' then they come in and clean house," Mr. Buys said. "So people always have that trepidation."
Be careful not to make any promises, about job security or other conditions, that you may not be able to keep, Ms. Guy warned. "You can't go in there and promise roses and sunshine, because you may decide down the road that you need to make some staffing changes based on performance," she said. Your focus should be to reduce the fear that just because you're a new manager you're going to make changes.
Let the employees know where you stand on things and what you expect of them, Mr. Buys suggested. Lay out your philosophy, your goals for the group, how you like to receive information, some of the things you plan to do.
You should also solicit employees' suggestions. "Find out as much as you can in terms of what their feelings are, what their goals are, what they feel their accomplishments have been, what their ideas are for making improvements or moving ahead," Mr. Buys said. Too often, new managers feel compelled to put their mark on a department immediately, "when really what they need to do is a lot more listening," he added.
Although it's important to talk with employees about their concerns, you don't want them to wallow in what has transpired, Ms. Guy said. Acknowledge the past, but then try to get them to focus on the future.
 
Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she responds to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT;
Bayonne, Long Maligned, Torn Over Trash Plant

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY

DATELINE: BAYONNE

 BODY:
Since state and Federal environmental regulators shut down the Frank family network of marine-transport companies in 1993, the family's former headquarters here along the Kill van Kull has generated little more than weeds.
Even when it was in business, city officials say, the family did not contribute its fair share. In October, the city foreclosed on the bankrupt Standard Tank Cleaning Corporation property -- not only contaminated but marred by a charred and collapsed fuel tank, decaying docks and rotting offices -- to recoup $2.9 million in unpaid property taxes dating to the 1980's. 
 Now, a proposal has come along to clean up the site and provide millions of dollars in annual revenue to the city by building a plant to transfer New York City garbage from barges to trains, and ship it to Pennsylvania and the Midwest.
On Dec. 16, the City Council approved a 50-year lease estimated to be worth more than $150 million. The Bayonne Planning Board needs only to formally pass on the plan on Aug. 24. The company proposing the facility, American Marine Rail L.L.C. of Englewood, also needs the approval of the state Department of Environmental Protection, the Army Corps of Engineers and Hudson County.
But the trash train is not being welcomed by everyone. It would pass within feet of the homes on Isabel Avenue, and residents have mobilized in opposition, with support from City Councilman Anthony Chiappone and former Mayor Leonard P. Kiczek.
"Initially, I embraced the idea as a way to give tax relief," said Mr. Chiappone. But he said he was converted by his constituents' outrage.
In front of the houses on Isabel Avenue are hand-scrawled signs that read: "Help Keep New York Garbage out of Bayonne," "Hey, Joe, the Garbage must go," and "Joe Doria for Mayor" crossed out with red ink.
Last month a group was formed calling itself the Bayonne RATS -- for Residents Against Transfer Station -- referring to the rodents members say will be attracted.
One member, Bill Meehan, 49, recorded a protest song, "The Garbage Train." But it is not so much the train that is feared. Members are more worried they will smell it, and feel it, in the form of falling property values.
In the largest of several emergency cleanups of the Bayonne property, in 1994 the Federal Environmental Protection Agency supervised removal of 840,000 gallons of water and waste oil from a huge black tank that still looms over the site.
Proponents of the complex say it is the only realistic proposal so far for the property. The RATS are not sure how the site should be used, only that it should not attract garbage.
Supporters of the transfer station say the concerns of its opponents are unfounded. Moreover, they say politics is a possible motive, since Mr. Kiczek is a rival of Mayor Doria, a Democratic State Assemblyman who is also the Assembly minority leader.
The transfer station was proposed by Ronald A. Klempner of Teaneck, a former project manager for Browning-Ferris Industries, the Houston-based trash hauler known as BFI. The law firm representing Mr. Klempner is that of Edward T. O'Connor, a Democratic State Senator who represents Bayonne, though the firm says Mr. O'Conner is not working on the project.
Mr. O'Connor said last week that although he worked on the American Marine application, he was not the lead counsel. In addition, he rejected the assertion that he has a conflict of interest by representing a project oppsed by some constituents.
"I don't really see my duties as a legislator conflicted by my law firm's representation of a client that has a project that is now opposed by Isabel Avenue residents."
Mr. Klempner said he and his partners, who include Christopher J. Daggett, a former New Jersey environmental commissioner, will spend $10 million to clean up the Frank site and $40 million to build what he called a state-of-the-art transfer station. "We are a new type of waste facility," he said. "Our trash never touches the ground."
Nor does it stink, he said. Under the plan, up to eight barges a day carrying a total of 5,000 tons of garbage would be floated down New York Harbor and up the Kill van Kull to the site. Mr. Klempner said the trash would be covered with the same type of heavy tarpaulin used to keep smells out of grain transported on Mississippi River barges.
In addition to the approval from the various governmental agencies, Mr. Klempner also needs New York City to agree to the deal. A spokeswoman for the New York City Department of Sanitation said American Marine's proposal is being reviewed, but could not say when the department would award a contract or to whom.
At the Bayonne site, hangar-like doors would swing open, letting the barges into the station. The doors would close, the cover would come off, and with air scrubbers working to cleanse the odor, the trash would be loaded from the barge into sealable containers. Once a day, the sealed containers would transferred to the garbage train.
"Rodents are basically attracted by the smell of the waste, and if they can't smell it, like everybody else, they don't know it's there," Mr. Klempner said.
Mayor Doria has promised homeowners a significant property tax saving. Terms of the lease include annual payments that would start at $420,000 and be pegged to inflation after three years, plus a $1.51 tax, called a tipping fee, for each ton of trash transferred. American Marine would pay real estate taxes on the property, even though the company would not own it.
But Joe Hojnacki, 57, a retired Bayonne police captain who is a member of RATS, said the $170 he would save each year would barely make a dent in his $7,000 annual property tax bill.
RATS also insists that the garbage train will have another cost that not be calculated in dollars and cents. Members say that Bayonne has struggled to overcome ridicule as a dumping ground, an effort now embodied in plans to build Hudson County's first golf course on a capped municipal landfill.
"Bayonne has been the butt of jokes since the days of Abbott and Costello," Mr. Hojnacki said. "What I see is the rebirth of Weehawken, Hoboken, all these waterfront towns. What we get is garbage."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
A Pause to Gape At Celestial Fireworks

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
OUT of gas, out of money and 200 miles from home, Roland Pahland had good reasons to regret his passion for seeing a solar eclipse.
He had battled traffic jams for nine hours driving south from Hanover to Stuttgart to get directly in the eclipse's path on Wednesday. When he got there, rain clouds blocked his view and that of hundreds of thousands of others. Now, having failed to calculate how much gas he would burn sitting in traffic, Mr. Pahland, an unemployed truck driver, was drumming up donations by singing country-and-western songs at a highway rest stop. 
 Yet for all that, he spoke with wide-eyed wonder about watching the sky turn dark and then light again. "This was a once-in-a-lifetime experience," he said. "We didn't get to see the corona of the eclipse, but we did see the sky become totally dark and then suddenly turn light two minutes later. I will never forget it."
Eclipses do that to people. Millions of Europeans drove for hours, just for the chance to put on paper glasses with blackened lenses and gape at an event that lasted two-and-a-half minutes.
There was something wondrous about the wonder itself. Between horrible weather and ghastly traffic in much of Europe, it was as if the Grinch had tried to steal the eclipse.
German autobahns were clogged all day with more than 200 miles of traffic jams. Yet there were few signs of bitterness or frustration. Even though they woke up to warnings of both bad weather and bad traffic, thousands of people decided they simply had to take a chance to witness the event, which won't repeat itself in the area until 2081.
In Paris, which was almost directly in the path of the eclipse, traffic stopped almost entirely and office workers poured into the streets. Trading came to a near halt at stock exchanges in Frankfurt, Paris and other cities. In Rome, Pope John Paul II shortened his weekly general audience in order to watch the eclipse.
Many Germans drove as close as they could to the eclipse's path, then parked along shoulders of the autobahn or at gas stations and rest areas. Parking areas became picnic spots. Astronomy buffs compared notes on their solar-shielded cameras and telescopes. Strangers shared their spectacles, which had become all but impossible to buy by Tuesday.
And as the moon slowly crept in front of the sun, novices and experts alike grew quieter and more reverent.
"You had the feeling that people had put everything behind them for the two minutes when it was happening," said Marcel Wenderoth, 23, a hotel receptionist who decided on Tuesday night to drive with his wife and 2-year-old son several hours from Dortmund. "It was euphoric."

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
Good Deeds Do Go Rewarded

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN

 BODY:
IT is easy to wonder if there are any young professionals today who care about something larger than themselves. Two who do are New York lawyers in their 30's who have devoted themselves to employment issues. They were among the 11 New Yorkers -- out of 32 winners in all -- recently selected for grants by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation.
Sara Horowitz, 36, won $275,000 as founder and executive director of Working Today, a group that promotes the interests of people in flexible employment arrangments. Jennifer L. Gordon, 34, won $260,000 as founder of the Workplace Project, which fights employment abuse and discrimination against immigrant workers. 
 Ms. Gordon, who left the Workplace Project last year, said she was especially grateful for the MacArthur grant right now. "It gives me freedom to decide what I'm going to do," she said. "It gives me a huge sense of relief and potential."
Ms. Horowitz said the grant would help her continue the work she struggled to finance four years ago. "It's not like you get all this money and you decide to go live on some island somewhere doing nothing all day," she said. "I'm going to be doing what I'm doing, but this makes it easier."
Michele Lord, program director of the Norman Foundation, which has supported both groups, said: "These are the kind of people we look for all the time, people who are pushing the envelope, groups that promote systemic change. They've built up their constituencies, they've tested their strategies, they're very patient and they're not afraid to lose."
Both groups help people advance and protect their own interests. At the Workplace Project, which Ms. Gordon started nearly seven years ago, immigrants are encouraged to enroll in a night course, taught in Spanish, on labor law, history and organizing techniques. Graduates -- more than 500 so far -- then become members of the organization and its staff and board.
Ms. Gordon began her advocacy career working on political asylum cases for Salvadoran and Guatemalan refugees in Boston after her sophomore year at Harvard University. She stayed with the organization, Centro Presente, for four years, traveling around Boston's dying industrial ring, to coffin factories, chicken-plucking plants, informing employers about their right to bar inspectors from the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
Visiting the shop floor, Ms. Gordon would stand on a box and explain in Spanish what workers should do to protect their rights if immigration officials carried out a raid.
In 1989, she decided to go to law school. "If I wanted to do something unconventional, I needed to have that stamp of approval of a professional degree," she said.
Ms. Gordon grew up in Storrs, Conn., where her father was a sociology professor and her mother taught special education. "I wouldn't say my parents are political activists, but they care a lot about fairness and justice and made sure we knew growing up that everybody's lives weren't like ours," she said.
State Assemblywoman Catherine T. Nolan of Queens, who worked with Ms. Gordon to make nonpayment of wages a felony, said she was impressed with how she mobilized people and then got out of the way. "I see grassroots groups where there is a strong leader who basically bosses people around," Ms. Nolan said. "She empowered people and they became the leaders."
Ms. Gordon is currently writing a book on law and organizing and teaching a course at Yale University called "Workers, the Law and the Changing Economy." Along with her partner, Linda Steinman, the director of litigation for Random House, she is raising a baby daughter, Sophie Rose,
Ms. Horowitz said she saw a void in the new, more decentralized, less unionized professional landscape in which health benefits and pensions were no longer guaranteed. She founded Working Today for independent workers -- freelancers, part-timers, independent contractors -- who lack corporate support systems.
"There is this tremendous disconnect between the way people are working and the laws that are protecting them," she said. "We needed some way to represent workers who are not connected to the workplace."
Joan D. Firestone, director of economic development for City Comptroller Allan G. Hevesi, said she was impressed with Ms. Horowitz's efforts. "The economy has changed enough so there are a lot of people who are not protected because they are not in full-time jobs," she said. "She has enabled them to have a sense of security."
And Margie McHugh, executive director of the New York Immigration Coalition, said Ms. Horowitz has a strong practical sense. "She first tries to help people address the real-life problems they face as contingent workers," Ms. McHugh said, "and then tries to engage them on the politics."
Unions are in Ms. Horowitz's blood. Her grandfather Israel Horowitz was a vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. Her father, Milton, was a labor lawyer. Her mother, Bernice, a retired schoolteacher, was a union activist.
"It wasn't just about being political, but having a sense of a higher mission," she said. "To have the courage to not go along with the prevailing thought of the day."
Ms. Horowitz started working for unions at age 18 as an intern for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. After graduating from Cornell University, she attended law school at the State University of New York at Buffalo and earned a master's degree in public policy from the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. She also married labor: her husband, Peter Dechiara, is a lawyer for unions.
Ms. Horowitz said the MacArthur award legitimized her unorthodox life choices. "It's nice to feel like you went a different way," she said, "and others think that turned out to be a smart decision."

HEADLINE: THE RIGHT THING;
As Layoffs Loom, Loyalties Are Divided

BYLINE: By JEFFREY L. SEGLIN; Jeffrey L. Seglin teaches at Emerson College in Boston. His column on business ethics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to: righthng@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AN employee asks your advice about whether to buy a house. You know that the company is planning layoffs, and that he is likely to lose his job.
Do you keep quiet? Stall? Drop a hint? Or come right out and warn him? 
 The quandary is likely to keep coming up: even with unemployment at 30-year lows, layoffs are occuring at a record pace, a result of mergers and takeovers.
It's a problem that could test even the best managers. On the one hand, the person sitting across the desk is about to make a move that could turn into a colossal nightmare. Certainly, your compassionate side is drawn to his plight. How could you not tell him? Besides, can a company, a faceless institution, be harmed by one tiny indiscretion?
But hold on. What about your responsibility to the company? Spilling the news may seem insignificant, but it carries risks. The employee might spread the word, making other workers nervous or even setting off an exodus. Furthermore, if the company is public or is merging with a public company, letting an employee know beforehand might run afoul of securities regulations.
If those evils do not outweigh the potential harm of leaving an employee in the dark, where do you draw the line? Would it be O.K. to tell an employee who is low on cash about a pending merger, so she could buy stock at the right time and get out of debt? Insider trading laws make the answer a clear no. But when the issue is ethical, rather than legal, judgment calls can be difficult.
The urge to stop a colleague from stepping off a financial cliff is natural, said Rushworth M. Kidder, founder of the Institute for Global Ethics in Camden, Me. "Here is a real live, breathing person whose whole life is tied up in this thing." But, he added, "you can't sacrifice the good of a great number of other people simply because you want to tell someone a little bit ahead of time."
Heather J. Stone, the president of the Murdock Group, a career training company in Salt Lake City, faced such a decision earlier this year when she had to lay off half of her 52 employees, including two who were house-hunting. She told one of them in advance, but the other "did not have much career maturity," Ms. Stone said, and "would have a hard time" controlling the impulse to talk to other people.
"So I opted not to tell this person," Ms. Stone added -- even though she knew the employee had just made an offer on a house. "No matter how much I want to share with the employee," she reasoned, "if the risk to the company is too high, I'm not going to do it." Because Ms. Stone owns her company, she has more latitude than most managers in making decisions.
Another solution may be to tiptoe between the conflicting principles of compassion and confidentiality, helping the employee make the better choice even when full disclosure is impossible. When my wife's former employer was planning layoffs, for example, she and many of her colleagues began searching for new jobs. When she landed one and went to give notice, her manager stopped her, saying, "If you've gotten a new job, don't tell me." My wife took the hint. She was laid off a week later and received a severance package that wouldn't have been available had she resigned.
"You have to come to terms with how to approach issues like this where you can't divulge all of the information, but to do it without lying," Mr. Kidder said. He recalled a woman who once told him, " 'I really find that I don't ever have to lie; I have too big a vocabulary.' "
Dropping hints may help abide by the letter of one's duty of confidentiality, but it's hardly fair to limit disclosure to employees whose personal situation you know. A better approach might be to immunize the whole company against unpleasant surprises by persuading top management to share information more widely. In fact, a growing number of companies practice a more open style of management, teaching employees how the company makes money by sharing financial statements with them. Employees at such companies "can see there are troubles and know enough about the business to understand when costs need to be cut," said John Case, author of "Open-Book Management" (Harper Business, 1995).
If everyone knew about looming layoffs, as they did at my wife's company, rather than asking for advice about buying a house, an employee could probably discern for himself whether the timing was right.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 1; Style Desk

LENGTH: 2291 words

HEADLINE: So Hard to Find Good Employers These Days

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI

 BODY:
AT a recent dinner party in Southampton, N.Y., in a big white house with a picket fence, the help couldn't keep up with the orders thrown at them. The food was exquisite, lobster salad followed by lamb; the house was picture perfect, decorated only a year before. But the hostess, in a beige silk Bill Blass suit and simple Harry Winston diamond earrings, had two faces. To her high-powered guests -- Wall Street men and media moguls, and women in linen and soft cotton -- she showed a radiant smile. "It's so nice to see you," she said to one dark-haired man as he arrived. "Let's get Lee Ann to get you a drink."
But to the young serving woman in a black skirt and white apron, she barked, "Hurry it up." Minutes later, when the server was drawn into conversation by a guest, the hostess bee-lined over and scolded, "I said, 'Hurry it up.' " Pulling on her arm, she said, "You're not to talk to the guests." 
At the seated dinner, the hostess loudly upbraided another server, one of the full-time staff of three, "There aren't enough water glasses on this table!" As the woman retreated wordessly to the kitchen, the dozen guests looked away so as not to deepen her embarrassment and theirs. The hostess, turning to the man on her right, said, "She's not very bright."
As the economic good times roll on and on, never before have so many been able to employ so many others as servants. But a boom market in domestic help is coinciding with a boom in boorish and disrespectful behavior toward domestics, say maids and drivers on Fifth and Park Avenues, nannies in Central Park, servers at parties in the Hamptons, household employment agencies and chroniclers of the social scene.
"The bad behavior is epidemic," said David Patrick Columbia, the editor in chief of Avenue, the magazine of Upper East Side life, who circulates widely among the beau monde. "There's a huge amount of emotional and verbal abuse going on towards the staff."
Mr. Columbia is careful to keep an ear cocked to the servants who otherwise go unnoticed in the city apartments and country homes of some of the richest New Yorkers. He calls today's generation of ladies and gentlemen of the house "screamers."
"I've seen the hostess get up from dinner because the so-called right fork isn't there, and they get into the kitchen and start screaming at the staff," he said. "Mind you, these are people who didn't know what the right fork was until they married a person who could afford the right fork."
On benches around the Central Park Boathouse, Upper East Side nannies gather daily to trade stories about their employers. A widely heard complaint is that children imitate the raised voices and disrespect shown by their parents.
A West Indian woman who works as a live-in nanny five days a week on the Upper East Side said the family's young teen-age son kicked her in the shins when she wouldn't make sandwiches for him and his friends after school. She complained to the parents, but they did nothing to the boy. "His parents made believe they cared, but they didn't," the woman said. "They didn't punish him."
Complaints by these workers -- who are almost always women, and foreign born -- is wide ranging, and includes illegal abuses like payment below minimum wage for six- and seven-day workweeks, failure to pay taxes, and sexual harassment. Domestic workers deprived of their legal rights have been championed in recent years by a number of groups across the country, including the Workplace Project in Hempstead, N.Y., which helps immigrant maids sue employers in small-claims court for back pay.
Beyond such clear-cut abuses, however, there is a vast category of mistreatment that is not illegal, but simply boorish -- rude and demeaning. While it is rarely discussed by the dinner or house guests at elegant Fifth Avenue apartments or in the Hamptons, it is perhaps inevitable as more people who did not grow up with domestic help are able to afford it but remain unclear on where to draw the boundaries.
"People who come into money late in life or quickly, especially women, don't know how to behave with subordinates and don't respect them," said Nelson W. Aldrich Jr., the author of a 1988 memoir, "Old Money: The Mythology of America's Upper Class" (Alfred A. Knopf), and a member of the extended Rockefeller family.
Mr. Columbia agreed, citing employers who think any household chore, even rinsing a dish, is beneath them. "They go out of their way to leave everything," he said. "They let the food get stiff on the plate. With a lot of these girls it's a measure of success to leave the plates there overnight. The behavior is nouveau. Trophy wives are always the worst -- girls who married wealthy men and never had help before."
But this rudeness is hardly limited to women, or to those new to wealth.
Mr. Columbia noted: "We live in an age that people in general that work in stressful jobs in New York seriously lack the ability to control themselves. People rage a lot."
Scolding in front of guests is one of the most common complaints. It humiliates the employee, and many employers seem to think it adds power to their image. In fact, it often embarrasses their guests.
R. Couri Hay, a society columnist for Hamptons magazine, recalled a seated dinner for 36 at an estate in Westchester County when the hostess stopped the entire party because she thought the table was not being cleared properly. She stood and, in front of the table, chided her Hispanic maid for not knowing that she should "serve left, clear right." The maid started shaking and dropped a plate, a flowered antique, which caused the hostess to yell even louder. The maid burst into tears and left the room. The hostess apologized to her guests, rang her bell and had another maid come out to clear.
In their defense, a number of men and women described by guests as having made such outbursts said that competent household help is scarce and that good people can demand huge salaries -- up to $2,000 a week -- and are quick to leave for a better offer.
"Why is this anyone's business how we treat our help?" said one hostess in New York and Southampton known for frequently raising her voice and who spoke only on condition of anonymity because she pays off the books. "We pay them, and if they don't like it they can work somewhere else."
Carol Mack, a decorator known for her dinner parties in Southampton, New York and Palm Beach, Fla. -- but not known for mistreating staff -- offered an explanation for why some hostesses are prone to raise voices and dress down employees publicly.
"How often do you go to a party and they serve the lamb, and the rice and vegetables comes a half an hour after?" she said. "The reality is, people don't listen. You think they understood what you told them, and they go off and do what they want rather than what you want."
Ms. Mack employes a cook, housekeeper, laundress and house manager (for washing the car, changing light bulbs and stocking the refrigerator). "You're not dealing with a level of professionalism that I think once existed," she said. "People don't view domestic help as a profession. Half of them do it as a summer job."
Clifford Greenhouse, a co-owner of the Pavillion Agency, which has placed nannies and other domestics in the homes of wealthy New Yorkers for 38 years, said the disrespect shown the help is worse today than ever. Well-paid domestics -- who earn at least $500 after taxes for a five-day week while living in, or $400 while living out -- used to remain two to three years with a family. Now, many are leaving after two months, citing poor treatment, he said.
He described, but would not name, a "very high profile" couple who do not allow their help to eat the household food. "They insist that their leftovers be thrown in the garbage," he said. "They do not want their help to eat their leftovers. Few people last more than a few months with them."
Nannies, he added, increasingly find rudeness, and worse, in children. "There are lots of incidents of biting and kicking and verbal abuse," Mr. Greenhouse said. "The older the children are, the more drastic their tempers can be. I'm always hearing stories involving children, teen-agers robbing money and jewelry from the nanny, threats of physical violence."
A live-in nanny in her 30's from Hong Kong said the lady of the house calls her stupid in front of the children. "I'm taking care of their children and I'm not treated like a human," she said. "The children won't listen to their parents. They won't listen to me. The parents maltreat us, the children follow."
Coco Myers, a co-author with Susan Carlton of "The Nanny Book: The Smart Parent's Guide to Hiring, Firing and Every Sticky Situation in Between" (St. Martin's Griffin, 1999), said that in hundreds of interviews with nannies, the No. 1 complaint was lack of respect.
"That's the thing we found made nannies leave more than anything else -- not the money, not the hours, but the respect and the lack of respect," she said. "Employers don't think that they have a life outside the family they are working for. We found that once they feel the lack of respect, it's dispiriting. They disengage."
Another day, at Carl Schurz Park, next to Gracie Mansion, Mina Zayas, 29, sat with four friends, all domestics in some of the wealthiest homes in the city.
Ms. Zayas said that when she first came to New York from Paraguay in 1994, speaking no English and without a resident foreigner's green card, she was hired as a live-in nanny by Muriel Brandolini, a decorator who lives in a brownstone in the East 80's with her banker husband. Ms. Brandolini asked Ms. Zayas for her passport. "She wanted to make a copy," Ms. Zayas said. But her employer held on to it.
Ms. Zayas said she was promised $300 for a five-day week, but when it came to collect her pay, Ms. Brandolini only gave $200, complaining that she didn't speak English. "But she knew that in the interview," Ms. Zayas said. The nanny job turned into housekeeping as well, totaling seven days a week with no time off for the same $200.
Ms. Zayas said that Ms. Brandolini, whose interior designs have appeared in Elle Decor magazine and whose fashion designs have been featured in The New York Times and are sold at Barneys New York, would take her to her Hamptons house on weekends, and she was expected to work there full-time, too. When she said she wanted to leave, she said Ms. Brandolini, still in possession of her passport, would threaten to call immigration authorities. Finally, Ms. Zayas had a friend intervene and she was able to quit, she said.
Ms. Brandolini, reached on a sailboat in the Greek islands last week, said she did not remember Ms. Zayas, though she acknowledged she has had many household workers in the last six years. Currently she employs a housekeeper, a weekday nanny and a man who watches the children on weekends. Two domestics who work for one of Ms. Brandolini's relatives confirmed that Ms. Zayas had worked for her in 1994.
Asked about Ms. Zayas's specific charges of sub-minimum pay, withholding a passport and threatening to call immigration agents, she said, "It's completely nonsense." She added: "I take the passport to make a photocopy, for security. I take their green card and their Con Edison bill and take a Xerox and give it back. You never know if these people live where they say they live."
"You know, at the end they get bitter," she said. "They've done something wrong and they ask for a raise. They break 10 dishes, you get mad and they talk."
"Nowadays if someone offers $50 more a week, they run," she continued. "There's no fidelity. It's rare to find that type of people in help. They come to America to make money. It's hard to find good help."
 
Doing Unto Others
NOT used to having domestic help? Think you're asserting authority or impressing your guests by yelling at the maid? Think again. Remember the old social rule of thumb, as expressed by Letitia Baldrige, the etiquette expert: "The real sign of class in a person is the way he or she treats the staff." Here are some hints, compiled from interviews with etiquette mavens, longtime hosts, nannies, cooks and wait staff on how to treat the help.
* Never correct a servant in front of other people.
* Address your employees by name, look them in the eye, and don't mimic accents.
* Teach children to treat the staff with respect. Have them say, "Good morning" and "Good night." "A 10-year-old should not have airs that some people are beneath him," one mother with a nanny said.
* Provide quality food for the help. Don't eat filet mignon and lobster every night and give the employees TV dinners.
* If you must leave dirty dishes in the sink, at least rinse them off. Similarly, don't leave dirty laundry thrown across the floor.
* Time off doesn't mean taking the nanny to the beach house to watch the children.
* Be clear from the start about what the job entails. If a nanny is hired to watch the children and do light housekeeping, do not change the job to watching the children and cleaning out the basement.
* Don't confuse employees with family members. They have families and lives of their own, deserve time off and must get the minimum wage. Employers must withhold state and Federal taxes.
* To attract better help, pay above the going rate. Give bonuses and paid vacations.
 Employers who ignore these guidelines may think they are eliciting disciplined behavior from a staff that fears them. But they are just as likely to have employees who, behind their backs, sabotage the household, committing petty thefts or ruining a meal. As Ms. Baldrige said, "I see waiter rage instead of road rage all the time."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Allies Shift and Numbers Tease As Greenspan Charts a Course

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AFTER George Bush lost the Presidency to Bill Clinton in 1992, some Republicans blamed one of their own: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
Mr. Greenspan had first become involved in Republican politics during Richard M. Nixon's 1968 campaign, and he had been a fixture among the party's economic policy makers ever since. 
 He had been appointed Fed chairman by Ronald Reagan and reappointed by Mr. Bush. But in the eyes of Mr. Bush's supporters, Mr. Greenspan had committed an unforgivable sin: failing to bring the economy back to full strength quickly enough after the 1990-91 recession.
Mr. Clinton exploited the lingering economic angst masterfully in 1992, and ever since he has ridden an upturn that in hindsight was well under way by Election Day.
All of this is to suggest that Mr. Greenspan is by no means unfamiliar with the rough and tumble of election year politics, or with the many ways in which the Fed can become an issue. And it is already clear, nearly 15 months before Election Day, that Mr. Greenspan will figure into this political cycle.
The first salvos against him have again come not from Democrats but from Republicans. In Iowa, where the Republicans battling to stay in the race against Governor George W. Bush of Texas for the party's Presidential nomination have become increasingly desperate for attention, both Steve Forbes and Dan Quayle have attacked the Fed and Mr. Greenspan for raising interest rates when crop prices are plunging and farmers are hurting.
"Interest rates are too high, and while Alan Greenspan and the Federal Reserve raise rates, commodity prices have plummeted," Mr. Forbes says in a 60-second radio spot being run in Iowa. Mr. Forbes goes on to blame monetary policy together with "bad economic advice from the Clinton-Gore Administration" for the troubles plaguing agriculture.
Populist rage from the farm belt at tight-money bankers is hardly new; what is a bit confounding is that the present attacks are coming from the conservative wing of the Republican Party, Mr. Greenspan's ideological home.
Then again, Mr. Greenspan is an easy target for politicians of all stripes because he never hits back, at least not publicly. Perhaps more to the point in this case, some Republicans view Mr. Greenspan as having sold out and become all but a member of the Clinton Administration.
They have watched with some unease over the past six and a half years as Mr. Greenspan became chummy first with former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and now with his successor, Lawrence H. Summers, as well as with Mr. Clinton himself. And the party's more ardent tax cutters were dismayed, if not aghast, when Mr. Greenspan told Congress last month that the nation would be better off using projected Federal budget surpluses for debt reduction than for reducing taxes.
Since Mr. Clinton has framed the fiscal policy choice just that way -- his prudent debt reduction plan versus irresponsible Republican tax cuts -- Mr. Greenspan was seen as siding with the Democrats. No one paid much attention to the Fed chairman's stated preference for tax cuts over additional Government spending, which in the eyes of most Republicans in Washington is the real choice before the country.
If Congress and the White House fail to work out a deal in the next few months on splitting up the surplus, leaving the issue to be fought out on the campaign trail, Mr. Greenspan's name will no doubt be invoked repeatedly by both parties to bolster their positions.
WHILE fiscal policy can make for powerful politics, it is just a sideline for Mr. Greenspan. The far more compelling issue for him could be how high to push interest rates over the next 6 or 12 months if the economy continues to roar along, setting off inflation alarm bells.
Politically, it will be a tough call; Mr. Greenspan would no doubt prefer to avoid raising rates during a Presidential campaign.
Economically, it could prove even trickier, since Mr. Greenspan is still wrestling with the degree to which this technology-driven, financial-market-centric, globally oriented economy can hold off inflation.
Besides a dozen years' experience on the job and a tough skin, the Fed chairman has something else going for him. If there were a Bush family grudge against him, it has been put aside, and Governor Bush has sent clear signals that he would support Mr. Greenspan's reappointment next year to a fourth four-year term. Vice President Al Gore has been equally supportive.
With that bipartisan support, Mr. Greenspan has considerable leeway in formulating policy, as well as an opportunity to push ahead with his slow but steady efforts to make the Fed more open in the way it considers and communicates its interest-rate decisions.
In the end, demystifying the institution and making clear that the rapidly changing economy is sometimes as difficult to read from within the Fed as from without could prove the best insulation against political attacks.

HEADLINE: Making World Trade Work

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Global Food Fights: The Worst Are Yet to Come" (Economic View, July 25), on the widespread criticism of the World Trade Organization:
While there is undoubtedly room for improvement in the workings of the W.T.O., the organization has proved to be an effective and objective forum for resolving trade disputes and fundamentally better than past efforts at achieving fair, free global commerce. 
 In the United States, 12 million people owe their jobs to exports; two million of those jobs were created from 1993 to 1997. And those jobs tend to be better paid, with better security, than most. The W.T.O., by making trading simpler, cuts companies' costs and increases their confidence in the future. That, in turn, means more jobs and better goods and services for consumers.
The organization is also bringing more and more nations into a prosperous, rules-based world economy and is speeding technological progress that can benefit health, the environment, commerce, artistic creation, scientific research and political debate. And it is advancing the universal values of fairness, open government and the rule of law.
In December, at the World Trade Organization's third Ministerial Conference, which will be held in Seattle, global negotiations will begin that will help shape world trade as we move to the next century. President Clinton has called for this to be an accelerated negotiating round aimed at opening markets, regularly achieving speedy results of disputes and reforming the W.T.O. itself to make it more transparent, accessible and responsive to citizens.
The negotiations represent an extraordinary opportunity. If the system's efficacy is not improved, we are very likely to see public skepticism rise, opportunities for further improvements in growth and the quality of life be lost, and the strength of the system erode.
 
WILLARD A. WORKMAN
Washington, July 30
 
The writer is vice president for international affairs at the United States Chamber of Commerce.

HEADLINE: PRELUDES;
A Generation of Freelancers

BYLINE: By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
FORGET about that X, and all of its slacker implications. We are now in the midst of Generation 1099 -- the once pitied but now envied group of self-employed workers whose income is reported to the Internal Revenue Service not on a W-2 form, but on Form 1099.
Prime evidence of the new era is the emergence of two companies that are making the life of a full-time freelancer even more attractive, offering a lot of the perks that most permanent employees enjoy. Freeagent.com and Aquent ( Latin for not a follower), both opened shop in the last two months, and act as virtual employers that offer group benefits. "The goal is to give the freelancer the same security earned by traditional W-2 employees," said John Chuang, Aquent's chief executive. 
 As of February 1997, there were 8.5 million independent contractors -- a k a free agents, freelancers or consultants -- according to the Government, 1.5 million of them between the ages 24 and 35. Not to be confused with temps, who are employed by one agency, 1099ers have many clients and set their own hours.
The life of the self-employed is not all leisurely lunches and afternoons at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Members of Generation 1099 spend an inordinate amount of time hustling, invoicing and politely harassing accounts payable. And unlike full-time employees, who have taxes withheld, 1099ers are responsible for paying their own state, Federal and Social Security taxes, and shelling out huge amounts for health insurance -- if they have it at all.
"I've never been sick in my life, and I said I'd wait until I'm 30 to get insurance," said Kris Tobiassen, 29, a graphic designer in New York who has been a full-time freelancer for five years. "My birthday's coming up in a few short months, but I'm thinking about waiting -- it's so expensive."
Health insurance, stock options and retirement plans pull many people toward full-time, permanent employment. "The accessibility of benefits can serve as a glue to an existing job," said Jeffrey L. Bradach, an associate professor at Harvard Business School. Then there's the camaraderie and the relief of more structure.
Still, those boons are not enough to lure some people. "It would have to be a helluva lot of money for me to go back to an office," said Michael Bassett, 35, a computer consultant in Manhattan. "Big fat six-figure sums. I like the freedom too much."
But freedom's often just another word for nothing left to deposit -- especially when the landlord comes knocking, the electric bill lands in your mailbox, it's midnight on April 14th, your tooth cracked on a piece of toffee and your latest client can't cough up the cash. That's usually when 1099ers flip through the help wanted ads, looking for permanent employment.
Until now, professional groups like the National Writers Union have offered freelance writers some benefits. Freeagent.com and Aquent aim to offer more benefits -- group-rate health, dental, life, property, casualty, professional and disability insurance; 401(k) retirement plans and pensions -- to freelancers in all fields. Freeagent.com even offers stock options in its privately held parent company, Opus360, for those who want to bet on its future. As a 31-year old in Manhattan, I could join an Oxford Health Plans managed-care plan for $224 a month through Freeagent.com, compared with $270 on my own.
Job seekers can display their resumes on these sites. The companies also have billing and collection services, although they collect only from established corporations. You invoice Freeagent.com or Aquent and they pay the money owed you, less 3 to 5 percent. The companies collect fees or earn commissions from the other benefits.
Mr. Chuang says he wants Aquent to be the "Rosetta stone which translates the W-2-based world of financial services to the world of independent professionals."
Mr. Bradach of Harvard says that the new services will encourage people to try new careers or take more risks. They will also give freelancers more leverage.
With all the possibilities, there seems to be only one reason to get a full-time job: the company Christmas party. Then again, that might be a reason not to.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
How to Play the Treasury Bond Buyback

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
AMERICANS on occasion have suffered various shortages -- of gasoline, for example, or pennies or sensibly priced Internet stocks. Never in memory, however, have they even imagined a shortage of Government debt.
Now, with the first budget surpluses in a generation emerging, the Government is moving to make its obligations a little bit scarce. That is, if anything amounting to $3.6 trillion can be thought of as "scarce." 
 The plan, announced earlier this month and still lacking details, is to buy back some outstanding Treasury bonds and to sell fewer new ones. The Government will eliminate one of three auctions a year it holds for bonds with the longest maturity, 30 years.
This prospect, many analysts believe, not only offers the chance of a modest profit to some bond holders, but also suggests that some rethinking may be in order on the part of those supercautious investors who put their faith in Washington's promises.
A shrunken supply of Treasuries implies higher prices and lower returns, thereby making competing high-quality bonds, especially the $1.1 trillion issued by Federal agencies and Government-sponsored organizations, like the Federal National Mortgage Association, more attractive.
Here's how William H. Gross, managing director of Pacific Investment Manage ment and a prominent figure in the world of bonds, recommends playing the buyback, which isn't slated to occur until next year.
"Start to buy what the Government is going to buy" several months from now, he suggested. "Individuals can actually front-run the Government."
However, transaction costs are significant relative to the potential profits, in the view of William C. Dudley, a vice president at Goldman Sachs. You may need to make a six-figure commitment to benefit enough to compensate for broker fees and other costs.
But other things being equal, the buyback program provides a cushion if rates rise, because the Government is acting as a support for bond prices. If they fall, it can only give your portfolio some extra juice.
You might suppose the Government would target its most expensive debt, such as its 14 percent bonds due in 2011 or its 15 3/4's of 2001, for buybacks, which will be conducted through dealers. But specialists say you would probably be wrong.
This is because such bonds now sell at prices way above their face, or maturity, value. The Government is required to treat any amount it pays above face value as an extra budgetary expense rather than a run-of-the-mill refinancing. That is something Washington presumably wants to minimize. And so, analysts say, the more likely issues to be repurchased are those due from 2015 to 2025 with coupons of between 7 and 9 percent. Today, these trade at far smaller premiums to their face value.
Still, Gary Gensler, Undersecretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, cautioned that budgetary concerns would not necessarily bar the buyback of double-digit coupons since other factors, including market conditions, would also affect the choice.
In addition to saving interest costs, the Government is hoping to improve the liquidity of benchmark issues -- such as the 30-year bond auctioned last week -- by trimming the number of older, competing "off the run" issues, such as the bonds sold last August and now due in 29 years. Off-the-runs now yield about one-quarter of a percentage point more than their newly minted cousins.
"They're taking inactive ones out and issuing more on-the-run," said William Quan, senior economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a specialist in Government securities. That will save the Government interest payments in the short term and insures more demand in future auctions.
With one of the goals being to shorten the average maturity of outstanding debt, another focus will likely be on issues with 15 to 25 years left until maturity, most of these with coupons in the high single digits. And it's almost certain that the Treasury won't be bidding for any bonds with call features under which it can force redemption, many of these, not surprisingly, carrying the highest coupons.
But instead of trying to guess which Treasuries the Government will seek to retire, investors may well decide to shop more profitably elsewhere.
"This is bound to encourage a widening of interest-rate differentials" between Treasuries and the debt of Federal agencies and corporations, said Henry Kaufman, proprietor of a New York advisory firm bearing his name. "That's where the opportunities lie."
Agency debt includes bonds of the Federal Home Loan Bank as well as those of the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation -- the latter two actually private companies chartered by the Government. Their debt already yields between one-half and three-quarters of a point more than Treasuries of similar maturity. That differential will probably be wider in the future due to the lower rates offered by increasingly scarce Treasuries.
If you insist on a Federal stamp of approval, don't forget one obvious alternative: certificates of deposits available at your local bank. The six-month variety is yielding nearly a percentage point more than a comparable Treasury bill -- though, of course, you'll pay both state and Federal taxes.
