LENGTH: 2470 words

HEADLINE: Confessions Of a Frugal Spendthrift

BYLINE: By RICK MARIN

 BODY:
FRUGALITY has never been my problem. I've always made enough to cover my rent or mortgage. I pay my bills on time. I've never been in serious debt. And yet, compared with my parents, I'm a spendthrift.
I leave lights on in my Manhattan apartment. I'm a sucker for the service economy: trainers, housekeepers, tennis pros. And every time I buy an absurdly expensive suit, pay too much for dinner or spring for an unnecessarily fancy hotel, I feel guilty. Not guilty enough not to blow $2,000 on a cool 60's-modern credenza, but guilty enough to resolve to be more cost conscious in the future. So I take the subway instead of a cab and think I'm a hero -- until the next bout of buyer's remorse. 
 Clearly, a deeper kind of fiscal self-examination is called for. So I got in touch with the authors of "Invest in Yourself: Six Secrets to a Rich Life" (John Wiley & Sons, 1998) and offered to subject myself to the ultimate humiliation: a frugality audit.
Written by Marc Eisenson, Gerri Detweiler and Nancy Castleman, the book's 328 pages blend self-help of the simple-abundance school with hard-core financial belt-tightening tips and complicated charts. Reading it you become convinced you could become a millionaire by paying an extra $50 a month on your mortgage or by buying used cars.
Who better to cast a cold eye on my platinum card bill? A frightening idea. There are things on those statements I don't even want to admit to myself, much less expose to complete strangers.
We traded E-mails. Mr. Eisenson and Ms. Castleman, a happily unmarried couple for 19 years, live together on a farm in Red Hook, N.Y., and publish a quarterly newsletter called the Pocket Change Investor, which they describe as a guide to "living better on less." They wanted me to visit their bucolic paradise of organic vegetables. But I felt that to be appropriately appalled by my decadence, they needed to spring for train fare to Manhattan.
In the meantime, they made a series of requests. Information about my monthly mortgage payment, which was recently doubled by the purchase of a summer house, and my 401(k) situation. Phone and utilities bills. Checkbook. A 1998 tax return. Ms. Detweiler, for many years the director of a consumer group called Bankcard Holders of America, asked me to keep a "spending diary," accounting for every penny I shelled out over a week. Ms. Castleman and Mr. Eisenson wanted me to think not just about money but about quality of life issues.
"We're not financial planners," Ms. Detweiler E-mailed me. "We're more 'life style' planners, geared toward helping you create more of the life you want on any income (not just when your portfolio reaches a certain level and you can 'retire')." She added, "Where are you investing your time and energy well, and where do you seem to fall short? What kinds of changes have you been putting off because of money?"
Hey, I thought but didn't write back, if I had a lot of extra time, I'd be using it. Changes? I'd buy a grotesquely huge house in the Hamptons and spend my days by the pool ordering gimlets from my houseboy!
DEFENSIVE? Of course. Anything to avoid thinking too hard about such things.
But the "Invest in Yourself" trio continued bombarding me with subliminal frugality messages.
From Ms. Castleman, re lunch: "Are you by any chance allergic to sunflower seeds?! (I usually use them in my pesto because they're a lot cheaper than pine nuts, and we can't tell the difference.)"
How's anyone supposed to enjoy an overpriced bowl of pasta under this kind pressure?
The lunch date rolled around and the three of them showed up at my apartment with a bowl of sunflower pesto in hand. Mr. Eisenson has a long gray beard and the look of someone who checked out of the rat race -- in his case, an electrical contracting business -- a long time ago. Remember Mr. Natural, R. Crumb's aging cartoon hippie? That's Mr. Eisenson, only, it turns out, with a sense of humor and a savant's skill at crunching numbers in his head. Ms. Castleman is wearing the same sandals she wore to Woodstock in 1969. Literally. Ms. Detweiler, who is about 20 years younger than her co-authors, lives outside Washington, D.C., wore a suit and evinced a little less of the converts' zeal than her collaborators.
As we sat down to salad from Ms. Castleman and Mr. Eisenson's Red Hook herb garden -- served in a bowl purchased for $1 in 1970 -- I asked how long it took to grow the tomato we were eating.
"About 1,000 hours of labor," Mr. Eisenson said. "That's a $50 tomato."
Which was why I mentioned it. If your time is worth X dollars an hour, is it worth spending the time for less than that amount of money in savings? Mr. Eisenson offered a sort of zen reply: "There are times when our time should be worth nothing."
I wasn't going to win that argument, so I told them I needed a car. I've never minded not having one, but with the new house, it seemed to be a necessity. There comes a time in every man's life -- like at age 37 -- when he should stop having to borrow his girlfriend's parents' Land Rover.
They scoffed at the notion of leasing. "Like buying your grandfather a rented tuxedo and burying it," Ms. Detweiler said. Mr. Eisenson contended that "most millionaires drive used cars."
Then they started with the scare tactics, presumably based on a careful scrub of my financials. "If you bought a car, you could be really tight," Ms. Detweiler said. "It wouldn't take much to upset the apple cart," Ms. Castleman added darkly.
O.K., forget the car. I wanted to get back to the stuff I misspend money on right now, not hypothetical future squanderings. First, I demanded a kitchen inspection. My bottle of Pellegrino was the first subject of ridicule -- something wrong with New York City tap water? -- then a box of funghi porcini in the cupboard. "I can go out into the woods and pick these," Mr. Eisenson said.
Ms. Castleman moved on to my air conditioner, set at a refreshing 65 degrees. "It's nice out!" she scolded.
After our meeting, I was inundated with E-mails from Red Hook alerting me to the 23 percent savings I could enjoy on my electric bill if I turned the air-conditioning up to 72 degrees, 44 percent if I went up to 78 degrees. Sure. I could probably make money on the deal if I pushed the thing up to 85 degrees, but I might die of heat prostration.
After hearing that I pay bills the day they arrive, take the subway to work, eat in more than out, they looked disappointed.
"You're much too frugal," Mr. Eisenson said.
I knew better. I've always spent too much money on clothes. When I was in high school, my mother used to mock my vast collection of shirts. So I compared notes with Mr. Eisenson on our polo shirts: my neo-retro rayon J. Crew that has to be dry-cleaned, $65; his secondhand Gap, five cents.
"You paid $65, but really it cost you $100," he pointed out.
Calculating the "real" cost in earned income is one of the book's simplest and most useful suggestions. Always factor in what taxes take out -- in my case, around 30 percent. At this rate, to pay for a $14,000 car you have to make $20,000. Now figure out how long it takes you to make that $20,000. Sobering.
What makes the authors nuts, on the tax front, is the idea that you should spend money to get a deduction. "Every dollar you spend in the hope of saving 30 cents is costing you 70 cents," Mr. Eisenson said.
Still desperate to prove my profligacy, I handed over my latest Visa statement. They studied it as if it were some ancient parchment, full of cryptic words and incomprehensible numerals.
"What's Mikimoto?" Ms. Castleman asked, her eyes widening at the accompanying charge.
It's a jewelry store, I mumbled tentatively. Anniversary earrings.
Mr. Eisenson offered an alternative "gifting" philosophy: "Take over a chore your mate hates and let that be the present."
That was when I realized we were living in different worlds: theirs and the real world of my girlfriend, who requires baubles that can be either shown off or exchanged.
I bid my guests farewell with promises to send them more complete financial documentation of my paycheck-to-paycheck existence and to keep a spending diary for Ms. Detweiler to review.
I started the week of June 28:
Monday: Forget completely.
Tuesday: Subway ($1.50), oatmeal from company cafeteria (85 cents), cafeteria lunch ($6.60), "American Pie" (free press screening), wine for a friend's sendoff ($12.98). Total: $21.93.
Wednesday: More of the same, with some cabs, drugstore products and $27.85 worth of developed pictures thrown in. Total: $77.80.
Thursday: Host Canada Day party ($79.87 for beer and bacon and maple syrup), my housekeeper ($60), plus a bunch of other stuff, like two pairs of Adidas running shoes ($119). Total: $295.22.
Friday: Housekeeper again, for post-party cleanup ($20), stamps at Mailboxes Etc. ($6.90), CD holder from The Wiz ($8.62), gas (20.09), and -- the clincher -- returned stuff to Bed, Bath and Beyond (-$37.87). Total: $38.99.
The lesson of Ms. Detweiler's exercise, which even she agrees is incredibly tedious, is to show you what you think you spend money on versus what you actually spend money on. I think you're supposed to be surprised at where it all goes. I had the opposite reaction. I was amazed at how little I spend and resolved to live a little better from now on. That 85 cents for oatmeal seemed sadly Dickensian.
A few weeks later, I got an E-mail from Mr. Eisenson and Ms. Castleman breaking down some savings options. Dump the health club, to which I hardly ever go (saving $1,000 a year). Mow my own lawn ($2,340 a year). Buy cheaper and fewer clothes ($600). Raise the temperature (Con Ed wouldn't give them figures on that one). Buy cheaper wine ($520). Each dollar amount was accompanied by a "what you'd have to earn" amount: $1,538 for the health club, $3,600 for the lawn guy. How they arrived at some of these numbers I'm not entirely sure, but I got the point.
I could be more frugal.
It made me think about my late father, who considered my mother a reckless spender, even though she was known as the thrifty one among her friends. They both came from comfortable upper middle-class backgrounds. But she had lived through the Depression, in Canada, and he through the Spanish Civil War. Both had seen that it was possible to have everything taken away in a trice and I always figured that was why they saved all those bits of old string. He would do things like measure the amount of water in the kettle before boiling it.
My mother still mails me back uncanceled American stamps from Canada, so that I can re-use them. They litter my apartment, like tiny rebukes to my wasteful ways, until I finally get around to soaking them off the old envelope paper and gluing them on a new one.
A couple of weekends ago I went to my first warehouse club, a hangar-sized temple to frugality called B.J.'s on Long Island. On the way in I silently disdained all the people rolling giant flatbed carts piled high with toilet paper and frozen swedish meatballs toward the 800-items-or-less cash register. On the way out, I had filled two of those carts myself. Grand total: $531.47. But the important thing was how much I saved.
 
Six Steps to Monetary and Spiritual Rewards
ART -- hard-nosed advice about personal finance, part touchy-feely self-help, "Invest in Yourself: Six Secrets to a Rich Life" argues that for readers who can learn to shave a few cents here, a few dollars there, monetary and spiritual riches await. For anyone too frugal to buy the book, here, in summary form, are the authors' "secrets":
MAKE YOUR OWN LIFE-STYLE DECISIONS -- Besides return on investment, consider time, energy -- even fantasies -- as equally manageable assets in your portfolio. That might mean downsizing from a two-income household to a one-income one or moving to the country.
PUT YOUR FAMILY FIRST -- Your love for your family isn't judged by how much you can buy them. The book quotes Paul Tsongas, the late Massachusetts Senator: "Nobody on his deathbed ever said, 'I wish I'd spent more time at the office.' "
BE IN BUSINESS FOR YOURSELF -- Jobs are no longer secure. Think of yourself as a consultant, not an employee. Freelance on the side.
MAKE THE MOST OF YOUR TAKE-HOME PAY -- To paraphrase Ben Franklin: A dollar saved is $1.40 you'll never have to earn, assuming a 28 percent tax bracket. Wealth is having slightly more than you need; poverty is having slightly less -- so adjust accordingly. When you are about to buy something, ask: If I didn't need it yesterday, why do it need it today?
TURN YOUR DEBTS INTO INVESTMENTS -- A typical $100,000 mortgage costs $250,000 over 30 years. Prepay $25 more a month and you'll save more than $20,000 in interest. Paying down credit card debt returns the equivalent of as much as 20 percent on a taxable investment, which beats the Street.
MAP OUT YOUR OWN FINANCIAL FUTURE -- Don't adopt financial habits just because they're popular. For example, college is not a parental tithe; think of it as the six-figure investment it is. Likewise, determine how much you really need for retirement, not what planners want you to invest. Consider a working retirement. Touch the nest egg; you don't have to end up with a big estate. RICK MARIN
 
Lose the Pignoli, Gain Five Grand
By substituting sunflower seeds for pine nuts, Nancy Castleman's pesto recipe may offend culinary purists. But for the frugal gourmet, it is one more way to save.
Ms. Castleman and her co-author and companion, Marc Eisenson, figure they consume a pint of sunflower pesto weekly, and thus 6.8 pounds of sunflower seeds a year. At the health-food store where they shop in Rhinebeck, N.Y., the seeds cost 99 cents a pound, versus $10 a pound for pine nuts. So their annual saving, on a nut-for-nut basis, is $61.27 a year.
By Ms. Castleman's calculations, the pine nut premium would cost an extra $94.25 in pretax dollars. But opting for sunflower seeds and investing the savings for 25 years at an average 8 percent return would yield $4,855.78 -- an impressive harvest.
 
NANCY'S PESTO
From www.investinyourself.com
Time: 10-15 minutes
 
20-25 cloves (5 heaping tablespoons) chopped garlic
1/2 cup sunflower seeds
2 tablespoons vegetable oil
1 tablespoon honey (optional)
1 cup water
6 cups well-packed basil leaves (more or less).
1. Traditional recipes have you use a mortar to pound, or pestare, the ingredients -- thus the name of the dish. It goes a lot faster with a food processor or blender.
2. Either way, combine the garlic and sunflower seeds with the oil and honey, and a little of the water. Gradually add the rest of the water.
3. Add the basil, 2 cups at a time. Process until everything is well blended.
Yield: 4 cups of pesto.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1199 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Great Expectations;
The Retirement Mentality vs. Reality

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
THE United States is far from alone when it comes to worrying about how to sustain a long-term Social Security system in an era of aging populations -- or how to insure that there will be enough new talent to fill the work place as fewer babies are born and more people retire. Around the world, but particularly in Europe and richer Asian nations, the situation is even more alarming, and so are the choices governments may soon have to make.
Persuading people to retire later may seem like the easiest alternative, but planners worldwide are finding that cultural and social attitudes toward leisure, family, old age and status have a great effect on policymaking. Along with economic globalization and urbanization, the idea of a hard-earned, dignified and pleasurable retirement is catching on in many countries. 
 "Within the space of about 100 years, people have not only accepted, but grown to believe that retirement is a right somehow, a human right almost," said Dalmer Hoskins, secretary general of the International Social Security Association in Geneva. "Working with these 150 countries that have pensions system, I'm struck more by the commonalities among them than the differences."
No one knows exactly what a decent level of retirement living is, he said, "but it's written into the constitutions of country after country."
The question, as Mr. Hoskins frames it, is whether more retirement is really what most economies really need, particularly in industrialized Europe, where populations are shrinking and aging, and most people are retiring before the age of 60 and living another 20 years or more. He suggests that in Europe and the United States, national interests and those of private enterprise may be dangerously out of sync.
"The private sector is retiring people at consistently earlier ages," he said, adding that forcing people to retire in the name of downsizing and reorganization has gone hand in hand with the shirking of responsibility for pension plans.
Big, even cosmic, ideas float around the subject of retirement. Peter G. Peterson, an investment banker and chairman of the Institute for International Economics, argued in "Gray Dawn: How the Coming Age Wave Will Transform America -- and the World" (Times Books, 1999) that, "We are confronting demographic changes so substantive that they could redefine economic and political systems in the developed countries over the next generation." Early retirement, he asserted, is already undermining the survival of developed nations.
Unless people can be persuaded to work longer into old age, say Mr. Peterson and others, like Joseph Chamie, director of the United Nations Population Division, developed countries will have to accept a loss of productivity, creativity and even general economic health.
Or they will be forced to accept waves of immigration from poorer nations, a policy Germany, other European countries and Japan would like to avoid for social and cultural reasons.
In the United States, one serious hurdle is ageism, Mr. Peterson says, reflecting on the youth culture that pervades many American companies. "Overcoming ageism will requiring ongoing education and commitment, much as overcoming racism in American work places has over the past few years," he writes. "An entire stereotype will have to be reversed, along with all the institutional rules and habits of thought that perpetuate it."
DON'T bother, a lot of retirees seem to be saying, as they settle into country club retirement communities or book another cruise.
In Singapore, where the proportion of people 60 or older will rise to 26 percent from the current 10 percent in the next 30 years, the Government hopes to push the retirement age from 62 to 67. But Singaporeans, who must contribute to a national savings plan, can take their accumulated retirement package at age 55, and a fair number do, said Dr. Kanwal Jit Soin, a former independent member of Parliament.
"People think they deserve retirement by the age of 55 or 60," she said in an interview, adding that this is particularly true of older people with few or no professional qualifications or skills, born before Singapore's economy took off. "And we are also a society with strong filial ideals," said Dr. Soin, an orthopedic surgeon. "Children take care of their parents and grandparents look after their grandchildren."
With Singapore's standard of living now rivaling southern Europe's, retirees also go on cruises and vacations that they could never have afforded in earlier decades.
Singapore -- with a dominant Chinese population but a mix of people of Indian, Malay and European ancestry -- is almost alone among Asian nations in changing its immigration policy to allow more foreigners with skills to settle in the small country, really an island city-state. It also allows unskilled workers, most from poorer Asian nations, to work for limited periods, filling manual jobs that Singapore's 3.5 million people have largely outgrown through education and training for a technological future.
Japan takes a different approach, rejecting increased immigration. It tries to keep people working longer through incentives to their employers, said Linda G. Martin, president of the Population Council in New York.
"The Japanese Government has a fairly aggressive policy to encourage employers to retain older workers," she said. "It provides some financial incentives to companies that maintain a certain percentage of older employees, and sometimes older workers retire and are rehired by the same company, often with a lesser title or lower stature.
"The Japanese," she added, "are a bit ahead of the United States in how to make productive use of older people."
In the third world, where most people keep on working to survive, the formal retirement situation is very mixed, and sometimes more complicated. A survey of retirement ages by the United Nations Population Division shows the lowest ages in the poorest countries, mostly African, but also several in South Asia. Yet these are also often places where there are no pensions or other benefits, no social security systems and no subsidized health plans. A low national retirement age -- the lowest is 40 in the Solomon Islands -- often reflects short life expectancy, the pressure of younger working-age populations, or both.
In India, the employed are squeezed from both ends of the age scale, with millions of young people joining the work force every year, while older people are living longer than ever before and are beginning to demand retirement programs. Since independence in 1947, India has raised life expectancy to 63 from 39. But until very recently it retained a 58-year-old mandatory retirement age for Government employees, opening places for younger people but forcing even experienced ambassadors and key civil servants to search for work. The age has now been raised to 60.
"In countries like India and China, people can't or don't want to be reliant on their children now," said Mr. Hoskins of the International Social Security Association. But they remain in retirement limbo, waiting for governments and the private sector to act.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2263 words

HEADLINE: Dogfight Over a Must-Win Contract

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

DATELINE: PALMDALE, Calif.

 BODY:
HERE in the Mojave Desert, in huge hangers guarded by armed sentries and high fences, the Government and its two biggest defense contractors are engaged in a high-stakes, high-risk experiment aimed at building a fighter aircraft that will dominate the skies and protect the nation's security for decades to come.
The project is still in its early stages, with the competing airplanes given the code names X-32 and X-35 and workers admonished not to utter a word. 
 But at the end of what the Pentagon promises will be a "winner-take-all" contest, either the Boeing Corporation or the Lockheed Martin Corporation will land what should be the biggest military contract ever. For both companies, this is a must-win competition: The winner will collect nearly a third of a trillion dollars -- and the loser could be out of the military aircraft business altogether.
For now, the companies' competing teams of engineers, test pilots, computer experts and factory workers are at work here, where the scrub soil gives way to an outpost of chain motels and fast-food restaurants, preparing for a flyoff early next year.
After that, and another year of testing and analysis, the Pentagon will make its pick. The winner will build a Joint Strike Fighter in three versions: one able to fly off carriers for the Navy, another to land on ground for the Air Force and a third that can hover into hot spots for the Marines. Nearly 5,000 of these planes are expected to be made, to replace nearly all the fighter planes flying today.
"This plane is the future," said Richard Aboulafia, director of aviation for the Teal Group, a Fairfax, Va. consulting firm. "It will be the fighter plane for all the services. It will be the fighter plane for all the world."
More than an airplane, the Joint Strike Fighter is an unprecedented test of cutting-edge technology, of how the Pentagon does business, of how wars will be fought. And it has profound implications for both the domestic military-industrial base and the nation's security well into the 21st century.
Faced with an increasingly skeptical Congress -- just last month, the House voted to delete funding for the Air Force's new F-22 fighter from next year's defense spending bill -- and a history of eye-popping cost overruns, the Pentagon decided it needed a fresh approach to procurement. And it is starting with the largest contract it has.
The order is a tall one: Design a single-engine, single pilot fighter that can be used by all three services and sold to overseas allies. It must fly faster than the speed of sound, be invisible to enemy radar -- and be produced for the bargain-basement price, by fighter aircraft standards, of around $30 million an airplane.
In building this plane, the Pentagon for the first time is making cost as important as performance. Boeing and Lockheed are being told not to build the best plane they can, but the best the Government can afford -- both in terms of its initial price tag and in maintenance costs over time. Rather than being the Cadillac of the air, the Joint Strike Fighter is designed more as a Chevrolet -- but with a Saturn-style attention to innovation and cost control.
"This program is about building an affordable fighter plane," said General Michael A. Hough, the Pentagon's director of the Joint Strike Fighter program. "It's the real deal. The country is going broke trying to pay for the latest airplane. We want to build it like your car -- just put gas in it and go."
The program is an attempt to break one of Augustine's Laws, a not entirely satirical calculation developed by Norman R. Augustine, the former Lockheed chief executive, that says the price of military aircraft is growing so fast that by the year 2054, the nation will be able to afford only one airplane.
THE Joint Strike Fighter will replace a generation of planes, some of which are 30 years old: Lockheed's workhorse F-16 and Northrop-Grumman's A-10 attack planes for the Air Force; the Marines' Harrier short take-off and vertical landing planes, built by Boeing and British Aerospace; and the Navy's carrier-based F-14 from Northrop and F/A-18 from Boeing. It is designed to work in tandem with the F-22, a far more expensive ($80 million) and sophisticated two-engine plane designed to eliminate enemy aircraft in initial air-to-air combat. The Joint Strike Fighter is designed to follow as part of a "hunter-killer" team, dropping bombs once the F-22 clears the skies.
"We needed to replace older and outmoded aircraft for all three services, and we could not afford to develop three different planes," said Darleen Druyun, the Air Force's top acquisition executive. "So it made sense to make a family of vehicles -- three planes with the same motor, the same avionics and 60 to 80 percent common parts, but with variations for all three services."
The comparison with earlier aircraft development programs is stark.
"In the past, I threw the requirements over the fence and a plane came back, and we didn't think about costs," said George K. Muellner, a retired Air Force general who once headed several acquistion programs, including the Joint Strike Fighter program, and is now a Boeing employee.
Still, for all the Pentagon's sentiments, questions remain.
* Can a plane that is three variations on a theme -- 80 percent the same for all, and otherwise modified to meet each service's special needs -- actually work? Or will it be a compromise that satisfies no one -- like the F-111, a Vietnam-era plane for all three services that was both costly and wildly unpopular.
* Will the Pentagon really stick to it's "winner-take-all" strategy, an approach that some analysts say would most likely leave the Defense Department with only one tactical aircraft supplier? Or will the military -- or Congress -- feel that the work must be split to keep two military aircraft makers in business, even if this increases program costs and reduces efficiency gains?
Everyone involved is mindful of the fate of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, which was cut from the Joint Strike Fighter program and, as a result, forced to merge with Boeing in 1997 -- in spite of rosy statements at the time from Harry Stonecipher, then McDonnell's chief executive and now Boeing's president, that "this does not mean we are out of the military aircraft business."
* Can the Pentagon really shed its old, expensive ways? It says it wants an aircraft designed and produced using the best commercial practices to simplify the plane and lower costs over its operating life. But will the military begin to tinker and increase the price tag?
For instance, if the F-22 program is canceled or drastically reduced from the 339 planes now on order, would the Joint Strike Fighter's capabilities be upgraded in ways that could make it more expensive? Just this month, Michael Ryan, the Air Force chief of staff, warned that cancelling the F-22 could lead to a costly redesign of the Joint Strike Fighter.
* Are Boeing and Lockheed up to the task? Boeing has already been forced to drastically redesign its plane to provide better control on carrier landings, trading a swept-wing design for a more conventional one. Lockheed, meanwhile, has had few design changes, but has faced cost overruns in the $100 million range and been forced to scramble its plans for next year's demonstration tests to stay within budget.
* Will the plane sell? Plans call for the Air Force to buy 1,783 planes, the Marines 609 and the Navy 408, along with 150 for Britain's Royal Navy, which has invested $200 million in the program.
The Pentagon estimates that other countries will buy an additional 2,000 planes. But European countries might decide instead to support European offerings -- the French Rafale, the Swedish Gripen or the British Eurofighter -- even with their higher price tags and lower performance capabilities. And Congress, in another round of budget-cutting, could cut back on Joint Strike Fighter purchases, raising the price for each plane.
"In theory, the Joint Strike Fighter is a good idea," said Eugene Carroll, a retired two-star admiral, who is deputy director of the Center for Defense Information, a Washington nonprofit organization that has been critical of military spending. "So far, it's retained an air of common sense that we are looking for in an era when we are not facing a high-tech major power."
But Mr. Carroll sounded a note of caution: "If we can build this meat-and-potatoes airplane, let's press on. But let's not do the same thing to it that we've done in the past and get the requirements jazzed up so much its goals can't be met."
IN a setting that seems lifted from the "X-Files," the two companies are building competing "concept demonstration models" to show the Government early next year. Spy planes and space shuttles are designed in utmost secrecy here, but it's hard to hide the Joint Strike Fighter program. On the highway coming into town from Los Angeles, there's a huge billboard of a fighter zooming over the motto: "Boeing, the Best. JSF." Leaving town, you come upon Lockheed's billboard -- its fighter with the single word "Imminent."
Inside two huge hangers -- one at Lockheed's Skunk Works, the other at Boeing's Phantom Works -- each company is making a pair of airplanes, one of which will be reconfigured during the Pentagon's flyoff to demonstrate the requirements for different services. Right now, they are only carcasses of titanium and composite, electronics and wires. But by year-end, they will become airplanes -- at a cost of about $500 million for each pair. The Government's total tab for the development process is about $2.2 billion, including $832 million to Pratt & Whitney for the engines for all the planes.
The real question here is just how serious the Pentagon is about "winner-take-all." Can the Pentagon come to the desert, hand one company a golden prize and leave the other empty-handed?
The Pentagon says yes. "I've been ordered to pick a winner," said General Hough. "I don't know how you can have two winners."
Officially, both companies take the Pentagon at its word, though observers argue that the nation cannot afford to be reduced to a single supplier of tactical military aircraft. Or, they say, political pressures will be such that both companies will get some business. That, though, could sharply escalate the costs of the aircraft.
"If you split it down the middle, you lose economies of scale," said Loren Thompson, a military industry analyst at the Lexington Institute, an Arlington, Va., research group. "But if you get a tactical aircraft monopoly, the presumption is you would get less innovation, higher prices and lower performance."
Yet the Air Force's Ms. Druyun says a winner can be picked without harming the nation. "We're always concerned about the industrial base," she said. "But when I look out and see what will be there in 2010 and 2015, it is still apparent that there will be a viable industrial base in the fighter aircraft business."
Lawrence Korb, a military analyst with the Council on Foreign Relations, said the project was so large that no matter which company won, the other would get plenty of subcontracting work. "It's not a winner-take-all, but a winner-will-do-better program," said Mr. Korb.
There is, however, a critical difference between being a prime contractor and being a subcontractor. The prime has control over the project. It gets the most money. And, since it is where all the engineering, design, computer and high-end action is, it is where all the creative and talented people want to work.
"The guy who gets the money is the guy who makes the decisions," said Harry Blot, Lockheed's deputy program manager for the fighter. "If you lose, you may make as many parts as you want, but you won't have the design authority. It's interesting work that keeps engineering teams together."
Mr. Meullner of Boeing, the former Air Force acquisitions head, questioned whether the Government "has the guts" to pick just one producer.
"I'm hoping it will be winner-take-all," he said. "Our defense budget cannot sustain two production lines."
So far, Wall Street has not focused on the contest. The final payoff is at least a decade away -- an eternity for Wall Street. And the market's conventional wisdom is the program will be split: Lockheed will build the Air Force version and Boeing the Navy and Marine planes.
"There is no clear indication as to which way the program is going," said Paul Nisbet, an analyst with J.S.A. Research in Newport, R.I. "So there's nothing of this program reflected in either company's stock."
For the military, the focus is much clearer. Driving the program is the Marine Corps, which wants its own new plane not dependent on Navy carriers for takeoffs and landings. The Navy, happy with the F-18, and the Air Force, going all out for the F-22, were more reluctant converts. The key in getting them on board, according to Mr. Muellner, was to minimize "scar penalty" -- the price that one service pays for the requirements of another.
So, with careful planning, the Air Force and Navy got what they wanted -- a stealthier plane with more range than existing fighters. And in Congress, where both the Air Force and the Navy have taken their share of hits of late, the leathernecks command great respect.
"The Marines have impressive powers of outlasting their doubters in getting the things they want," said Wolfgang Demisch, a managing director at Wasserstein Perella and Company. "And they really want this plane."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Hunting for That Elusive Surplus

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Speaker of the House, J. Dennis Hastert, went to a nuts and bolts factory outside Chicago last week and waved four $1 bills in the air. The money was supposed to represent a trillion dollars.
"This is the surplus," he said, and then promised to give three of the dollars back to Americans in the form of a whopping tax cut. 
 But the surplus right now is as real as a $3 bill. This year was supposed to bring the first surplus in three decades. But when Congress comes back from vacation in September, a ritual dance around this pot of money will resume. And when the dance is done, the pot will be empty. Its fate does not augur well for the 21st-century surpluses that are supposed to underwrite the Republican tax cut.
The tussle over the public treasure is shaping up as a war. Representative Tom DeLay, the House majority whip and conservative major domo, said in an interview last week that draining the surplus was a deliberate strategy designed to force President Clinton to submit to the Republicans' political will.
He said the President had three choices. One: get down "on his knees" and sign the spending bills the Republicans are writing, which cut or kill many of Mr. Clinton's favorite programs. Two: raid another pot of money, the sacrosanct Social Security surplus, to restore those cuts. Three: shut down the Government.
Mr. Clinton responded: "I can think of nothing more cynical or irresponsible."
As Congress and the White House play chicken, and Republicans and Democrats vie for advantage in next year's elections, this will be one of the only serious political games in town next month. "Both sides are just maneuvering, and we throw an occasional stone at each other," said Jim Dyer, staff director of the House Appropriations Committee, where the spending bills originate. "Frankly, it's just a terrible way to do business."
With the future of the American economy, control of the Congress and the next Presidency at stake, each side is accusing the other of bad faith.
First President Clinton submitted a budget balanced with theoretical money, like $10 billion in proposed new cigarette taxes. The Republicans, who would sooner publicly convert to paganism than pass such a tax, wrote their own version of a budget balanced with more theoretical money, mainly cuts in domestic programs so deep that Congress would never approve them.
In theory, the only rule that both sides are supposed to play by in this game is the 1997 law that imposed spending limits, or caps, on Congress.
In practice, the game now is how to evade the caps. Congress has dug deep into a bag of tricks that Stan Collender, the managing director of the Federal Budget Consulting Group at Fleishman-Hillard, a public relations firm, called "the biggest collection of budget gimmicks ever put together in one year."
F IRST, they're calling anything that moves an emergency," said Mr. Collender, whose job is explaining Government spending to corporate clients. This allows Congress to dip into the projected $14 billion surplus. So far, the emergencies include $4.5 billion for the 2000 census and $7.4 billion in farm subsidies. The Republicans also set aside $4.5 billion to finance the first year of their tax cut. Do the math: no more surplus.
"Then you have directed score keeping," Mr. Collender said, "which is essentially lying about the numbers, playing with accounting." This maneuver, by some lights, created the $14 billion surplus in the first place.
"Then there's forward funding," he said, "maybe $12 billion this year, which is borrowing from a future year." This is the Government's equivalent of Popeye's pal Wimpy saying he will gladly pay you Tuesday for a hamburger today.
Add it all up, Mr. Collender said, and the Republicans will spend "about $30 billion more than they're saying they will spend," while claiming they are keeping the caps on tight.
"They can't live with the caps," the White House budget director, Jacob J. Lew, said in an interview. "They're having to do ridiculous kinds of things to keep the process moving along. We're clearly headed toward some difficult days."
Congress left town with 11 of this year's 13 spending bills incomplete. President Clinton has threatened to veto 7 of them over Republican cuts. After Labor Day, 16 working days remain for Congress before the fiscal year ends on Sept. 30.
If there is no budget by then, the Republicans and the President are going to have to cut a deal.
"We will negotiate with the President, after he vetoes the bills, on his knees," Mr. DeLay said, daring him to raid Social Security funds or risk a Government shutdown. This could prove either a brilliant ploy or a paralyzing blunder.
Either way, "It's kind of cynical," said Mr. Lew. "They're going to have to decide whether they want to create a sense of mounting crisis."
That decision seems to have been made. If there is no deal by Oct. 1, Mr. DeLay said, Congress can pass a "continuing resolution" that essentially finances the Government at this year's levels. President Clinton can give up and sign it. Or he can unleash a political nuclear weapon and veto it.
Then the Government shuts down -- or, as Mr. DeLay put it, "the President will have shut down the Government." The last time that happened, in 1995, the Republicans took the blame, and lost Congressional seats all over the country in the next election.
"I don't look forward to this," said Mr. Dyer. "It's really hard to figure how this plays out in September."

HEADLINE: Angst in the Great American Middle

 BODY:
"The American Middle, Just Getting By" (Economic View, Aug. 1), by Louis Uchitelle, discussed the feeling of many middle-class families that they are not sharing in the national bounty as earlier generations did. The column drew many responses.
 
To the Editor:
Mr. Uchitelle showed what average Americans know intuitively: that middle-income families do not feel middle-income, let alone middle-class. Two breadwinners today cannot do what one used to. 
 The first reason is falling wages. For men in nonsupervisory positions, especially, real wages have fallen sharply, dropping 15 percent between 1979 and 1997, according to Lawrence Mishel, Jared Bernstein and John Schmitt in "The State of Working America" (Cornell University Press, 1999). High-paying manufacturing jobs have been replaced with low-paid service jobs.
At the same time, the tax burden has been transferred from the economic elite to the middle. At the end of World War II, the average American paid little tax because the Government (both Republicans and Democrats) wanted a huge middle class.
In their book "America: Who Really Pays the Taxes?" (Touchstone, 1994), Donald L. Barlett and James B. Steele showed that a Philadelphia family earning the median income of $38,000 in 1993 had to pay $8,000 more, in 1993 dollars, in taxes of all kinds than its counterpart earning the median income in 1953 would have.
 
LOUIS COHEN
Manhattan, Aug. 5

SECTION: Section 3; Page 14; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 239 words

HEADLINE: Angst in the Great American Middle

 BODY:
"The American Middle, Just Getting By" (Economic View, Aug. 1), by Louis Uchitelle, discussed the feeling of many middle-class families that they are not sharing in the national bounty as earlier generations did. The column drew many responses.
 
To the Editor:
Astonishingly, your article omitted the largest component of the modern family budget: taxes. 
 In 1997, the last year for which data are available, the combination of federal, state and local taxes took 37.6 percent of income of a median two-income family, according to the Tax Foundation -- more than food, clothing, housing and transportation combined. Compare that with 1957, when the tax bite on the median two-income family was 27.8 percent.
These figures mean that an average family with the $49,000 income of the Brandyberrys, who were profiled in the article, had $18,424 of its income pocketed by governments before its breadwinners even saw their paychecks. Nothing else costs the family so much.
The article was right to suggest that many middle-income families live paycheck to paycheck, unable to save and invest. It was wrong to omit any discussion of one of the principal causes: too much money is being taken by government. It's time Washington politicians and bureaucrats, especially, learned to tighten their belts as other people do.
 
JIM NICHOLSON
Washington, Aug. 4
 
The writer is chairman of the Republican National Committee.

 People have real financial needs. But most of us can get what we want while keeping thrift in mind, without feeling deprived.

HEADLINE: Ex-Wife Is Suing Cuba Over a Spy's Deception

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 14

 BODY:
To Ana Margarita Martinez, an avowed anti-Communist Cuban-American, the dashing young jet pilot seemed to have dropped from heaven.
Juan Pablo Roque, a disenchanted officer in the Cuban air force, escaped the Communist-controlled island by swimming to the United States Navy base at Guantanamo Bay in February 1992. He denounced President Fidel Castro of Cuba and quickly became a vocal militant in the Cuban exiles's pro-democracy movement in Miami. 
 He even flew planes for Brothers to the Rescue, a group of Cuban-American pilots who cruised the Florida Straits searching for refugees fleeing Cuba on rafts. He met Ms. Martinez his first year in Miami, in church, and they fell in love. They were married in 1995, as he established himself as one of the city's more visible anti-Communists. He wrote a book called "The Deserter."
It was all a lie. Mr. Roque, in reality a spy for the Cuban Government sent to infiltrate exile groups like Brothers to the Rescue, vanished from Miami on Feb. 23, 1996 and returned to Cuba, four years after his swim to Guantanamo.
The next day, Cuban jets shot down two of the small planes flown by Brothers to the Rescue, just outside Cuban air space in international waters. Law-enforcement authorities in Miami and Cuban exiles blamed Mr. Roque for the deaths of the four fliers.
Cuban exiles who had trusted Mr. Roque felt violated.
To Ms. Martinez, the betrayal was rape. She never would have married him, never would have shared a bed with him, Ms. Martinez said, if she had known the man she thought was an anti-Communist was actually an agent of the Castro Government.
Now, saying that her consent to have sex with the man over the 11 months of their marriage was based on a lie, she is suing the Cuban Government for sexual battery -- rape.
"They used me," Ms. Martinez said.
In a complaint filed earlier this month in Miami-Dade Circuit Court, Ms. Martinez contended that Mr. Roque used her as part of his cover, and that his decision to court and ultimately marry her was done only to establish himself within the exile community.
"She is the fifth victim of the downing" of the two planes, said Jose J. Basulta, president of Brothers to the Rescue. "We were all victimized but perhaps she was the person with whom there was the most cruelty."
When she filed the court papers, Ms. Martinez described the lawsuit as her only way of fighting back. She has since had the marriage annulled -- Mr. Roque, now in Havana, did not contest -- and has not heard from her former husband since he left the country in 1996.
In fact, in an appearance on Cuban television soon after returning, Mr. Roque told an interviewer that the thing he missed most about living in Miami was his sport utility vehicle, said lawyers for Ms. Martinez.
That man was not the one Ms. Martinez thought she had married.
"He was very attentive," she said. "He made me feel protected and secure. He was the kind of man who went to work and came home.
"He wanted a family," she said, and helped her raise two children from a previous marriage. Now she knows it was just part of his disguise.
"She would not have given her consent, had she known" who Mr. Roque really was, said one of her lawyers, Scott W. Leeds of Miami.
"Her 'husband,' " Mr. Leeds said, using the word derisively, "was a spy in the employment of the Cuban Government. She was victimized and was powerless to do anything."
Mr. Roque, who also served as a paid informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and supplied information about Brothers to the Rescue, has been named in a Federal indictment that accuses him and 13 others with spying and trying to sabotage the efforts of Miami's Cuban exiles. He is also charged with conspiracy to commit murder in connection with the attack on the Brothers to the Rescue planes.
One week before the two planes were shot down over the Straits two members of the alleged spy ring were warned not to fly in any Brothers to the Rescue planes near the island between Feb. 24 and Feb. 27, according to the Federal indictment. The warning apparently came from an agent of the Cuban Government.
Two days later, Mr. Roque appeared on CNN from Havana. That was how Ms. Martinez learned where her husband had gone.
"He just disappeared," said Ms. Martinez, an executive secretary in Coral Gables, Fla. "He told me he was going on a business trip, and the next thing I knew he was in Cuba."
Ms. Martinez is hoping for a moral victory and any financial reward is secondary, her lawyers said. Getting money from the Cuban Government has proved difficult in the past.
The families of the four fliers who were killed also sued the Cuban Government and were awarded almost $188 million by the Federal District Court in Miami, money they hoped to recoup from frozen Cuban assets.
But on Wednesday, the Circuit Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, denied the families access to what had seemed the most likely source of damages, $6.2 million in payments from American telephone companies to the Cuban telecommunications company, Empresa de Telecomunicaciones de Cuba.
That case, a complicated legal tangle, has been in the headlines in Miami for years.
Ms. Martinez's case, at least on the surface, seems simpler.
In the complaint, her lawyers point out that sex cannot be consensual if it is derived by "fraud and concealment."
According to the complaint, Mr. Roque was under orders from Cuba's Ministry of the Interior to become a member of the Cuban exile community, and -- while leading "a normal life" -- to infiltrate Cuban-American organizations.
As part of his cover, he was told to become active in church, where he met Ms. Martinez. His marriage to her was part of his directive, the complaint said. Meanwhile, he doubled as an informer for the F.B.I, also part of his directive from Cuba, the complaint said.
While the lawsuit does not contend that Mr. Roque was under orders to marry Ms. Martinez "specifically," he used her as part of his disguise, said Mr. Leeds, the lawyer.
Cuban-Americans here either defend the lawsuit or shake their heads at its seeming strangeness.
"I think it's a legitimate way of defending herself," Mr. Basulta said.
Legal experts have said the case will be difficult, since Cuban officials are unlikely to cooperate.
Meanwhile, Cuban exiles have one bit of satisfaction. Wherever Mr. Roque is, knowing the economic straits and shortage of good automobiles on the island, he is probably not driving a quality vehicle.

LENGTH: 709 words

HEADLINE: E.P.A. Wants Water Quality As New Gauge For Cleanup

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency will propose next week that states regulate water pollution by focusing on bodies of water, instead of individual discharges.
Once the state determined the extent to which pollution must be reduced in a body of water, the polluters would receive a quota and could then clean up their emissions or buy the right to discharge into the water from someone else whose cleanup had exceeded a quota. 
 The change, which was announced this morning by President Clinton in his weekly radio address, is based on a mostly unused provision of the 1972 Clean Water Act that requires pollution regulators to assess water conditions and issue discharge restrictions accordingly. Federal and state agencies have generally enforced discharge limits on factories and municipal water treatment plants without measuring the quality of the bodies of water involved.
Environmental regulators have sometimes set limits on pollution by analyzing the body of water, mostly when forced to by lawsuits brought by environmentalists; E.P.A. officials said the new rule would be the first that required the states to act.
Mr. Clinton said that under the new rule, states would have to establish schedules for cleanup or the Federal Government would step in and do it for them.
The proposed rule, which will be open for public comment for 60 days, is available at http://www.epa .gov/OWOW/tmdl/index.html. The agency is also publishing what it says is the first comprehensive state-by-state listing of "impaired" bodies of water, which shows the location and nature of each pollutant.
Carol M. Browner, the E.P.A. administrator, said that the new rule would be "the last chapter in how we get to fishable, swimmable waters." Great progress has been made since Congress passed the Clean Water Act in 1972, she said, but five million acres of lakes and 30,000 miles of rivers and shorelines are not fit for fishing or swimming. That comes to 20,000 lakes, wetlands or stretches of river or coast.
Developing the plans could cost the states $1 million to $2 million each, Ms. Browner said. She did not estimate the costs to actually reduce pollution.
Environmentalists hailed the rule but said the trick was not only to assess the water, but to actually force a cleanup. One problem is that much of the pollution comes from unregulated parties, like small farms, as opposed to factories, power plants and sewage treatment plants.
At the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources, Susan L. Sylvester, the administrator for water division, said that under existing regulations, "we've done a lot with 'point' sources," discharge pipes from factories and sewage treatment plants. But she said that many bodies of water were still polluted by contamination from "non-point sources," like runoff from farms or parking lots, which are not regulated. Farms are sources of pathogens from animal manure, insecticides and crops. Farms are also sources of nutrients, which can promote algae and plant growth in water that kills fish.
Under the E.P.A. proposal, Ms. Sylvester said, states could encourage farmers to relocate manure piles or route storm water around them, and take similar steps to cut runoff. States might even use grant money to finance farm improvements. Or, she said, under a trading arrangement, a municipal sewage plant emitting phosphorous, a nutrient, might pay a farm to reduce its releases of phosphorous, at a lower cost per ton. A plant might even pay a farmer to quit raising animals or quit farming, to the economic advantage of each, she said.
But the success of environmental orders based on bodies of water rather than discharges will depend on the willingness of regulators to follow through, said Mark A. Izeman, a lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council in New York. Mr. Izeman said that such rules had prevailed from 1948 until the Clean Water Act was passed in 1972, but had not been enforced, and that even under the Clean Water Act, regulations had been issued in 1979, 1985 and 1992 to allow such enforcement.
"The rules have resulted in beginnings of programs in some states, including listing of impaired water bodies," Mr. Izeman said. "But the program has largely not been implemented."

HEADLINE: Latest Construction Bottleneck: Shortage of Skilled Workers

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
John Carroll is among the most wanted men in New York.
A lean, red-haired electrician at a building project on 42d Street, Mr. Carroll and thousands of skilled construction workers like him are suddenly in short supply as the real estate boom finally ends what many in the industry describe as a brutal seven-year depression. 
 There are no unemployed workers at Mr. Carroll's union, the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 3, where a short time ago many electricians were out of work for six months out of the year. Many are now working what they call "six 10's," or six days a week for 10 hours a day.
"Right now, there are no men on the bench," Mr. Carroll said. "Everybody's at full employment. You can more or less pick your job. I worked just about every day in July. I've been working for 11 years and I've never been able to do that."
Everything seems to be on a fast track as contractors advertise for workers and scour the union halls for journeymen. There may be fewer skyscrapers under construction today than a decade ago, but there are many residential and commercial buildings being built, as well as billions of dollars's worth of public works and lots of rehabilitation work.
These projects range from an $87 million face lift for the Hilton Hotel on the Avenue of the Americas in midtown to the $237 million renovation of the 1.5 million-square-foot office building at 2 Broadway in lower Manhattan.
And contractors want the work done now, especially in Times Square, where everything from a new 50-story hotel at Broadway and 47th Street to the World Wrestling Federation's theme restaurant at 43d Street are rushing to open by the millennium.
Electrical contractors estimate that there is an immediate need for 1,000 to 2,500 electricians in New York today, and that does not take into account projects starting in the coming year or two. "Things have turned around," said Howard Hirsch, president of Forest Electric, which employs 1,200 electricians and is the city's biggest electrical contractor. "We could use a couple hundred electricians right now, easy."
The labor shortage is most keenly felt among electricians, but builders say it is also hard to find enough sheet metal workers and tin knockers who install the duct work and put together the heating and air-conditioning systems.
"We are facing serious shortages," said Ray McGuire, general counsel for the Contractors Association of Greater New York, a trade association. "There's a shortage of elevator construction mechanics, steamfitters, sheet metal workers and electricians. In the short term, the industry is dealing with it by working a lot of overtime. But that is not a long-term solution, because we see, if anything, increased construction activity in the next two years."
It does not help that the situation is no better in other Northeast cities or elsewhere in the United States. John Kirberg, president of Kirberg Roofing in St. Louis, cannot find enough experienced roofers to expand his family business. Some builders are offering bounties for operating engineers in Boston, car mechanics in Buffalo and electricians in New Orleans, Chicago and Fairfield, Conn. Construction companies in New York are luring badly needed project managers and superintendents from rivals with $20,000 bonuses, while others are starting incentive programs to keep their executives.
"It's been slower to hit the Northeast," said John Grau, chief executive of the National Electrical Contractors Association in Washington. "The rest of the country's been feeling it for two or three years. It's part of the stuff every industry is facing. There are more jobs and fewer people to accept the jobs."
And with the economy now booming in places like Ireland and Poland, skilled workers are no longer immigrating to New York in search of work they cannot find at home. Indeed, some Irish carpenters and electricians have already moved back to Ireland.
With the construction industry still largely unionized in New York, contractors have pushed Local 3 in particular to allow union members from the South and other areas to work here, much as they did in the 1980's. But Thomas Van Arsdale, the longtime leader of the electricians' local, has so far resisted, fearing that the labor shortage is a short-term phenomenon.
"Some locals had a tough time getting rid of out-of-towners in the early 1990's and putting their own people back on the job," said Edward Malloy, president of the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York. "That's why there's a reluctance to really open up this time. But they'll adjust to the concerns of the contractors."
The recession in the early 1990's, corporate layoffs and an abundance of vacant office buildings and empty apartments choked the life out of the last construction boom.
In 1988 and 1989, there were 15 office towers totaling 10.5 million square feet under construction and 50 residential buildings with 5,800 apartments, according to Yale Robbins Inc., a real estate publishing company. Construction cranes punctured the skyline from one end of Manhattan to the other and employment climbed to 120,800 in 1989, the highest level since 1964.
But by 1993, 35,000 jobs in the construction industry had disappeared. At Local 3, the electricians' union instituted a shared-work program in which members worked for 26 weeks and then stepped aside for unemployed co-workers.
It took years to fill the empty office space. Even as the New York economy recovered in 1996 and 1997, the cost of new construction proved prohibitive. Contractors went out of business, project managers found other lines of work and skilled workers retired, relocated or found unrelated jobs.
"We lost a generation of kids who wanted to be architects, engineers and tradesmen as a result of the recession in the early 1990's," said Louis Coletti, chairman of the Building Trades Employers' Association, a trade group for 1,100 construction companies and 22 associations. "There's no question that human resources are probably the biggest problem confronting the construction industry over the next 10 years."
The turnaround came suddenly.
Workers are finishing the first new office tower in the city since 1992, the Conde Nast tower in Times Square. There are hotels under construction at 47th Street and Broadway and on 44th Street. The steel is being erected for the Reuters Building in Times Square and work should begin soon on the Morgan Stanley tower on Seventh Avenue at 50th Street; the Bertelsmann building on Broadway at 55th Street; the Bear, Stearns tower on Madison at 46th Street, and the Ernst & Young building at 42d Street and Seventh Avenue. According to the Real Estate Board, there is an additional $1.4 billion in major renovation work at 14 buildings, including the Chrysler Building, Radio City Music Hall and the Woolworth Building.
There are building programs at Columbia and New York Universities and a $1 billion terminal project at Kennedy International Airport. Francis X. McArdle, managing director of the General Contractors Association of New York, estimates that there is a further $5 billion to $7 billion in public works projects in the works.
Although the number of construction workers in New York City jumped by more than 6,000 in the last two years, according to the State Department of Labor, there are still 14,800 fewer people employed today than in 1989.
Contractors say the shortage of electricians, who make $34 an hour, became acute in May and June. "There is such a strong market that many employers are really stretching to get the number of skilled craftsman they need," Mr. Coletti said. "The unions are, if not at 100 percent employment, as close as they've ever been in 20 years."
The demand for labor has been aggravated by changes in the construction industry as well. The corporations and retailers building new homes now demand accelerated schedules. They want a job that used to take, say, 20 weeks done in 10 or 12 weeks. New buildings, as well as renovation projects, also require more electrical work than a decade ago, with computer cables, fiber optic lines and redundant power systems.
"Everything in this city is done in a hurry," said Barry Katzen, president of Katco Electrical, which employs 100 journeymen and apprentices. "Fast track has taken over the business."
That means more workers and lots of overtime, which pleases many workers eager to pay off mortgages, boats and debts accumulated during the lean years. But it is also wearing.
At a hotel project in Times Square, Ed Garvey, a veteran electrician, has been working six eight-hour days a week and expects his workweek to grow to 60 hours in the final push to open before New Year's Eve.
"Instead of 30 guys working for six months, they now load up with 100 guys for two months," Mr. Garvey said. "It's chaos. Chaos means cash, but it also leads to accidents. They're looking to push the jobs a little too much."
To combat the shortage and expand the union share of the labor market, Local 3 and the sheet metal workers' union have organized nonunion contractors, while the Mason Tenders union has recruited immigrant workers. The steamfitters have doubled the size of their apprenticeship programs, but that is a long-term investment because it takes three to five years to attain journeyman status.
Joseph D'Angelo, president of the New York Electrical Contractors Association, said that the group had abandoned efforts to recruit Canadian electricians because immigration laws proved cumbersome and expensive.
Local 3 has taken in unemployed electricians from Long Island as well as 300 temporary college helpers, but it has been reluctant to open up to travelers, electricians with union cards from out-of-town locals. Union leaders say that the problem arose this summer, in part, because so many workers were on vacation. But the local may soon have a no choice but to recruit workers from other areas.
"We've requested that the unions bring in travelers, or out-of-towners, to make up the shortfall," said Ken Colao, chief executive of York Hunter, a construction management company. "So far, there hasn't been any agreement."
Meanwhile, builders have had to make do. Milo E. Riverso, president of the School Construction Authority, said that sheet metal delivered to some job sites lies unused for days because there are not enough skilled workers to go around.
Some contractors have turned down jobs. Only two of eight electrical contractors responded to requests for bids from one hotel developer, according to Raymond Quartararo, president of Quartararo & Associates, a construction manager on the Ernst & Young building and a project at 770 Broadway.
Ed Cettina, first vice president at Tishman Construction, which is building the Conde Nast, Reuters and Morgan Stanley buildings, said his company had resorted to dividing the electrical contract for each project among several subcontractors rather than relying on a single company.
"You don't want to get into a situation where you have a ton of overtime at the end of a job," he said. "It wears people out and you don't have the ability to bring in a fresh crew. They don't exist."

HEADLINE: Ex-Enemies, Ecuador and Peru Shore Up a Strategic Friendship

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 14

 BODY:
As recently as one year ago, Peru and Ecuador were preparing to go to war -- something they have done with unfortunate regularity ever since the Peruvian Navy blockaded Ecuador's principal port in 1860.
But in a sign that the squabbling neighbors are finally learning to live together, President Jamil Mahuad of Ecuador finished a three-day visit through Peru on Friday -- complete with banquets, honorary university degrees, tropical river fishing and a triumphal tour through downtown Lima arm-in-arm with President Alberto K. Fujimori. 
 Troubled by a failing economy and increasing protests at home, Mr. Mahuad came to Peru to consolidate the gains won in October when the two countries signed a peace treaty brokered by the United States, Brazil, Argentina and Chile to settle a longstanding border dispute over a 50-mile swath of the Condor Mountains.
The two Presidents were jeered at on Friday as they drove through the city of Iquitos in the Peruvian Amazon by hundreds of protesters who say the treaty gives Ecuador too many commercial rights in their region. But most experts called the visit a success that augurs well for future relations.
Mr. Fujimori and Mr. Mahuad dressed in matching red sport shirts and donned Indian headdresses to pose for photographers in a dugout canoe on an Amazon tributary. And they met with residents of the jungle town of Sarameriza to announce the construction of a port project.
"Patriotism searches for development," Mr. Fujimori said as Mr. Mahuad smiled widely. Then Mr. Fujimori called for a show of hands of those opposed to opening river commerce to Ecuadoreans. No one voted against the Peruvian President, Mr. Fujimori noted, "not even Mahuad."
It was a backhanded slap at political leaders of the area who oppose the thaw with Ecuador.
"Our friend President Mahuad is Arab, and I am half Japanese," Mr. Fujimori said, "but we speak the same language."
The two Presidents announced an assortment of joint projects, including the extension of parks, construction of river port installations, bridges, roads, forestry projects, schools and clinics that will total up to $3 billion over several years. They also signed a free-trade agreement that will remove tariffs from 585 agricultural, consumer and industrial goods.
The October treaty sets a permanent border along the Cordillera del Condor mountain range, as Peru always demanded. Ecuador gained access to a piece of territory on the Peruvian side to commemorate its war dead at a memorial site in Tiwinza, as well as navigation and trade rights in the Peruvian river ports of Sarameriza and Pijuayal.
The last time the two countries went to war -- in 1995 -- 100 people were killed in four weeks of conflict. The fighting led to an expensive arms buildup in both Peru and Ecuador. Experts say peace will allow them to reduce the size of their militaries, which will help their economies and strengthen civilian rule.

HEADLINE: High-Rise Answer to Brooklyn's Courtroom Problem

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
After seeking for 15 years to escape cramped and outmoded quarters in Brooklyn, state and city court officials say they have finally found the answer: a 32-story, $350 million courthouse that would rise in the commercially reviving heart of Downtown Brooklyn.
Financial, commercial and educational interests near the proposed site, including Chase Manhattan Bank, have strongly opposed the plan, but these normally influential interests now have indicated that they are resigned to it. They say they will no longer fight the proposal, which the Giuliani administration supports. Court officials and the building's private developer will seek the required approvals from the City Planning Commission and the City Council. 
 The critics had contended that the high-rise courthouse, at 330 Jay Street, which would be Brooklyn's second-tallest building and an extension of the thriving Metrotech Center office complex, would bring traffic and security problems and dilute the area's image as a business center.
They said that Metrotech, a 10-block complex that includes seven buildings built during the last decade, was meant to attract corporate office tenants to Downtown Brooklyn, and that leasing one of its remaining prime sites to the government for a courthouse would betray that concept.
Commercial office space would occupy six stories near the top of the brick-and-stone building, whose height of 473 feet (taller than a normal 32-story building because courtrooms are higher than offices) would make it second in Brooklyn to the Williamsburgh Savings Bank Building, which is 512 feet tall.
Court officials responded that the security concerns were unwarranted and that the plans included steps to reduce the effects of added traffic. They said they would support more ideas to minimize traffic, and emphasized that the proposed courthouse would add more than 70 desperately needed courtrooms. The new building would house the criminal part of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn and the entire Kings County Family Court.
"This is the linchpin of our Brooklyn plan," Ronald Younkins, director of court facilities management for the New York State Office of Court Administration.
The criminal section of Supreme Court, in which felony cases from serious assaults to murders are prosecuted, is now split inefficiently between two court buildings in Downtown Brooklyn that court officials say badly need upgrading. The Family Court, whose docket includes cases of child abuse, domestic violence and crimes committed by juveniles, is in a dingy, crowded old courthouse that judges say hardly engenders respect for the court system among troubled families.
Most of the space to be freed up when felony and Family Court cases are moved to the new courthouse will be renovated and used for civil cases now scattered among cramped and often makeshift courtrooms in three downtown Brooklyn office buildings. Those courtrooms are part of the city's Civil Court and Housing Court and the civil branch of State Supreme Court, and they were carved out in the office buildings as the courts expanded beyond the space that was available in regular courthouses.
"What were created as temporary have taken on a permanence we never intended," said Michael L. Pesce, an administrative judge of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. "In the effort to build a new facility, we were shunted from site to site over 15 years."
Justice Pesce said the latest site is at least the sixth to be considered for a new Brooklyn courthouse. Efforts at the other sites have failed for reasons like community opposition, difficulty in acquiring property and inadequate size. The plot at 330 Jay Street now has a seven-story building, used by the City Human Resources Administration, that would be razed.
Justice Pesce said the proposed courthouse was not out of keeping with its surroundings, noting that the existing Family Court, at Adams Street and Tech Place, abuts the site of the planned new courthouse and that the existing Supreme Court Building is just across Adams Street from the Family Court. The courthouses "have been there for decades," he said, and Metrotech and other developments were built near them.
A spokeswoman for the developer of Metrotech and of the proposed courthouse, Forest City Ratner Companies, similarly defended the courthouse proposal as suitable for its surroundings.
"Forest City Ratner has a billion dollars invested in Metrotech and would not do anything to endanger it," the spokeswoman, Michele de Milly, told a reporter during a meeting last week at which Community Board 2 in Brooklyn approved the courthouse proposal on the condition that its "significant adverse traffic impacts" be fully addressed and that steps to combat them be submitted for community approval.
Ms. de Milly said that task forces representing public agencies and civic groups that sought a location for a new courthouse "landed on this as the best site," and Forest City Ratner, a major developer in Downtown Brooklyn, agreed to go along, leading to the proposed court building, designed by Perkins Eastman Architects.
But various occupants of existing Metrotech buildings vigorously disagreed with the choice, as did Polytechnic University, which is across Jay Street from the courthouse site and was a leading force in originating the concept of Metrotech Center. Also objecting was Joshua L. Muss, the developer of Renaissance Plaza, a separate complex comprising an office tower and a Marriott hotel that opened last year next to the proposed court site.
The objecting Metrotech occupants included Chase Manhattan, which employs more than 5,000 people in back office and technology operations at Metrotech; the Securities Industry Automation Corporation, which processes trades for the financial markets, and Keyspan Energy, which has its headquarters at Metrotech.
"We do not look favorably upon the plans to build the new courthouse," said Charlotte Gilbert-Biro, a spokeswoman for Chase Manhattan. "But we don't intend to vocally oppose it," she said, though "we expect the developer to live up to his obligations in safeguarding the quality" of the area for businesses.
Spokesmen for the Securities Industry Automation Corporation and Keyspan said that their companies still believed that another area of Downtown Brooklyn was better suited for a new courthouse but that the companies did not plan to testify against the proposal before the Planning Commission and City Council.
David C. Chang, president of Polytechnic University, said he would express his concerns if those bodies "solicited our opinion." Among those concerns, he said, were the possible worries of prospective students and their parents about "a major criminal court across the street."
Mr. Muss originally thought the site "would be a great stimulus for the area as an office building," said his spokesman, Howard J. Rubenstein. But about a month ago, he said, after "a great many discussions with the elected officials involved," Mr. Muss came to accept that "the government wanted it there and that there was a need to balance the need for court expansion with the desire for developers to build other commercial ventures."
Court officials and Forest City Ratner hope to gain the required approvals by the end of this year and to complete construction in 2002. Forest City Ratner would finance the construction and the city would lease the space for the courts.
The site is two blocks from the Federal Court in Brooklyn, where a long-planned expansion calls for construction of a 14-story addition. It has been delayed by financing problems.
