SECTION: Section 5; Page 10; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2549 words

HEADLINE: Touring the Happy Side of Hell

BYLINE: By MARGUERITE McGLINN; MARGUERITE McGLINN is a teacher who travels frequently to Europe.

 BODY:
I STOOD behind Selfoss Waterfall with my daughter, Heather, watching the glacial runoff make gothic arches splintered with rainbows as it hurtled down to become the headwater of a river. The sunny morning made Selfoss a rainbow machine; later, it placed a perfect multicolored wishbone around us as we stood near its sandy base.
We had just come from Hveragerdi, a town built on an active geothermal zone about 25 miles east of Reykjavik, the capital, where huge hothouses grow tomatoes and bananas close to the Arctic Circle and residents sell bread that bakes in the ground overnight. We were in Iceland traveling the Ring Road, Route 1, on a seven-day bus tour last August that included people from Britain, the Netherlands and the United States. We were all ages and had come for different reasons -- geological phenomena, sparse and wild beauty, pristine air, Nordic culture. Some had already been everywhere else. Heather and I were seeking a mother-daughter adventure before she began graduate school, and Iceland seemed exotic and isolated enough to qualify. 
 Our destination the first evening was Vik, the southernmost village in the nation but described in our guidebook as having the lowest summer temperatures in Iceland. Not knowing what to expect for food or lodging outside the capital, Reykjavik, I was nonetheless amazed when we pulled up to an Esso station cum convenience store -- the perfect set for a film noir -- to learn that we were having dinner there. My daughter and I looked at each other wide eyed, gathered our jackets and followed the crowd.
We walked past the cashier's post to a door that opened onto a large dining room with views of the ocean and the sea cliffs of Dyrholaey. We had already visited the nature preserve around Dyrholaey to see the stone arch that spans the wild Atlantic waves, which created it. Birds wheel over the sea cliffs and the stacks of rock in the sea. We recovered from our surprise in time to enjoy our meal of seafood terrine, roast lamb and apple pie.
With one exception we had good meals everywhere we went in Iceland. Although the guidebook and Icelandic films frightened us with descriptions of putrefied shark meat that had been buried in the earth for months, and sheep heads eaten with eyes and tongue -- the brain is considered a separate treat -- we usually dined on roast lamb or salmon. Esso or Mobil convenience stores were frequently the only place to eat lunch in remote regions, and I quickly learned that if you judged a restaurant by esthetics, you would starve.
We did have a memorable meal on the fourth day of the tour at a family-owned restaurant in the highland desert near Lake Myvatn, where NASA astronauts trained for moon walks. Blasting winds and scouring sand forced us to duck in our parkas and walk in a disorienting, hunchbacked manner. As I ate several helpings of a tasty creamed vegetable soup thick with potatoes and broccoli, I looked around to see people eating on every surface -- counters, tables and windowsills -- all seeking sanctuary from the wicked weather in bowls of comfort food.
"A surprise storm blew in from the North Atlantic," Adda Helgadottir, our guide, told us. "I believe there is better weather ahead." Adda taught philosophy and sociology in Reykjavik when not working as a summer tour guide. Throughout the trip, she was optimistic, resourceful, occasionally ironic. She and Stefan Thorvardarson, the bus driver, worked together to provide hospitality and to explain Icelandic culture, history, wildlife, economics and geology.
Adda's family was from the north and had owned farmland in the Lake Myvatn region, which lies on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge and was geologically one of the most interesting areas we visited. A submarine mountain range that surfaces in Iceland, the ridge grows by several centimeters a year by pushing apart the tectonic plates that meet there with magma from the earth's mantle rock. We stayed at the new Hotel Myvatn, which overlooks the southern shore of the lake, and in spite of its larger size and the addition of minibars, it offered the same blend of spartan accommodations and competent, friendly service we had encountered at other Icelandic hotels.
In touring the area, we first saw pseudocraters, formed when volcanic material flows into water. Resembling minivolcanoes, they dot Lake Myvatn, making it look like a great bowl of broth with triangular dumplings. Then we turned off the road, and in a short distance ran into a fenced area. Adda got out and released a gate; we drove through and picked her up on the other side.
"This is part of the land my grandfather owned," she said. "It is all right for us to visit here. My grandfather sold it because he was always having to stop his work to rescue some tourists who had gotten into trouble here."
In this smoking -- in spots, seething -- stretch of land, it would be easy to fall into boiling mud or get too close to a fumarole belching superheated smoke and gas. We walked to a cave that enclosed a hot spring in which Adda bathed as a child.
"There is a woman side and a man side," she said. "I will show you the woman's side first. It is steeper, a difficult path. Everything is always more difficult for the woman."
We climbed down and put our arms into the water, which was bathing temperature, more than 100 degrees. We walked down the men's side and from there, could see that the two sides joined to make one pool.
We drove on to Krafla, a northern mountain that erupted in 1984. We walked past a sign that warned in Icelandic and in English: "The ground is extremely hot and therefore dangerous to cross. Only walk on the light brown clay, not on the dark clay, the lighter gray or yellowish spots. Never go over the fences around the most dangerous areas."
As I was ticking off the color codes in my head, we began a brisk walk past smoking lava caves, around fissures and over crumbly surfaces -- images from Milton's portrait of hell. Below the boiling zone, we took photos of each other straddling the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, and moved on to see an area with gurgling mud and fumaroles. A sulfur-scented wind accompanied us on our two-hour hike as we viewed the strange color scheme of the soil: creamy and pale like the skin of an Icelandic beauty queen, contrasted with patches of Crayola hues.
The Mid-Atlantic Ridge crosses Iceland in a diagonal running southwest to northeast. Earlier, along the south coast, we saw volcanic mountains that had been honed and scissored by the ice fields, which are now below the summits. A volcanic eruption can melt a glacier and send huge blocks of ice and water to the lowlands. Such an event occurred in 1996, and another eruption was expected in Iceland before the millennium (indeed, last December, a volcanic eruption took place under Vatnajokull, the largest glacier in Europe).
Early in the trip, we toured the southern coast, ending the second day at Jokulsarlon Lagoon, famous for icebergs that break off into the water. Wearing life jackets, we sailed through the lagoon for half an hour, staring at towering ice cliffs; some carried a sooty layer of glacial soil, others had striations of peacock blue and arctic white.
We took a pristine chunk of latticed ice to our evening's lodgings, the Vatnajokull Hotel, named for the glacier, or jokull, that dominated the landscape and provided the ice that chilled our cocktails. After a very good salmon dinner in the hotel dining room, Adda made arrangements for a a jeep ride to the glacier. Because of Iceland's latitude, daylight is interrupted by only a brief twilight in midsummer, so 9:30 P.M. was as good a time as any to begin an excursion.
We happily mounted low ridges, dove down steep planes and splashed through a broad river. While the ride was still in its mundane, early stage, a Dutch man sitting next to the hotel owner, who was our guide, asked how he would rate Icelandic drivers. Just then, we hurtled down a hill as the guide bleated, "They are maniacs."
We stopped at a ridge overlooking the small lagoon formed from the summer melt and saw the heavily creased basalt holding an endless basin of ice. As we found everywhere in Iceland, alpine flowers clung to the rocks. In the shadow of Vatnajokull, we saw arctic river beauty: deep blue, horn-shaped flowers on grasslike stems; elsewhere, we had seen the cottony tufts of artic wool, bluebells and the delicate yellow of alpine cinquefoil.
When the guided tour ended, Heather and I followed Adda's advice and visited the Blue Lagoon, a 40-minute ride from Reykjavik. The romantic name belies the reality of the lagoon, created by runoff from a geothermal power plant. It now uses superheated seawater pumped directly from as much as 6,000 feet underground, which is cooled to about to 98 to 100 degrees. The azure color, which gives the swimming hole its name, comes from blue-green algae and silica mud.
We arrived during a period of light rain and mist, a signature of Reykjavik weather during our stay. The tanks and hangers of the power station loomed over the unrelieved volcanic landscape, a setting made odder by the combination of morning drizzle and mist rising from the lagoon. After following the instructions in the shower room (which are posted at all swimming areas in Iceland) to wash before putting on one's bathing suit and to include all areas marked in a graphic chart, we stumbled, wet and chilled, onto the lava bed that underlies the lagoon.
At some point, Heather and I started laughing. Very quickly, we submerged ourselves in the welcome heat and drifted through the industrial waterscape. We became separated in the mist, and I decided to get as close as possible to the plant to gauge the heat of the water there. I felt buoyant both inside and out, and wondered if this psychedelic experience could get any stranger. I looked around to see if there were lifeguards and spotted a Nordic giant in a snowmobile suit patrolling the perimeter. Tourists dressed in jackets and hats instead of bathing suits walked along the wooden planking taking photographs.
I spotted my daughter and began laughing again. We did a synchronized swim to the dock and steeled ourselves for the cold walk back to our traveling clothes.
 
Sure, it gets cold, but the water's fine
We booked the Iceland Complete Tour through Icelandair, (800) 223-5500, www.icelandair.com. It included air fare, transportation to and from the airport, two nights at the Loftleidir Hotel in Reykjavik and a seven-day, six-night escorted bus tour. A cold buffet breakfast of cereal, bread, meat, cheese, fruit, vegetables and skyr, a dairy product that resembles yogurt, was provided every day. A three-course dinner was part of the package during the bus trip. The Iceland Complete excursion costs $2,371 a person, double occupancy June through August; $1,752 in May, and $1,865 in September.
The Icelandic Tourist Board, part of the Scandinavian Tourist Board, has an office at 655 Third Avenue (42d Street), New York, N.Y 10017, (212) 885-9700, fax (212) 885-9710; www.goiceland.org. It provides information on sightseeing, recreational activities and accommodations. The bureau's tourist information office in Reykjavik is at 2 Bankastraeti, (354) 562-3045, fax (354) 562-3057.
 
Getting There
Icelandair is the only commercial airline traveling to Iceland from the United States. Flights leave New York (J.F.K.), Boston, Baltimore, Orlando and Minneapolis and arrive in Keflavik, 30 miles from Reykjavik, the capital. Passengers going to Europe on Icelandair can stay up to three nights in Iceland with no additional air fare. Current round-trip fares start at $448, for September departures.
The Flybus provides transportation from the airport to major hotels and central destinations in Reykjavik for about $10 one way, at the rate of 73 krona to the dollar. Flights arrive around 6:30 A.M. and hotels in Reykjavik try to have rooms available in the morning.
 
Where to Stay
Many hotels outside of Reykjavik and Akureyri, a city in northern Iceland, are open only May through September. We stayed in boarding schools converted for summer guests, and in hotels belonging to the Key and the Foss hotel chains. The rooms were modest and clean, and all had private baths. Service was usually competent and friendly.
The year-old Key Hotel Myvatn, on Lake Myvatn at Myvatnssveit, (354) 464-4455, was the most upscale hotel on our tour, with spacious rooms with streamlined Scandanavian decor and minibars. It has 37 rooms, with doubles costing $163, including breakfast. The restaurant has views of the lake. The hotel closes Sept. 1. Reservations: (354) 511-6030, fax (354) 511-6031.
The Fosshotel Vatnajokull, on Route 1 between Skaftafell Park and Hofn, (354) 478-2555, sits on the edge of a water meadow, which borders the ocean beach. Mountains and the Vatnajokull glacier are across the road. The hotel's 26 rooms were small, clean and simply furnished. Doubles are $149, including breakfast. It is open till early October. Reservations: (354) 562-4000, fax (354) 562-4001.
Hotel Vik i Myrdal, Route 1, Vik, (354) 487-1480, fax (354) 487-1302, offers 21 small, clean rooms in a building that hugs a mountain base. Doubles cost $102; breakfast is $9.50. It is fully staffed June through August, and will open at other times for groups.
 
Where to Eat
In the countryside, food service is limited to convenience stores, the dining rooms in hotels and small family cafes. Most villages offer both a hotel and either a convenience store or cafe. Summer hotels will provide meals for those who are not hotel guests, but a drop-in customer would have a limited selection.
Coffee, bottled water, juice, soda, packaged pastries, hot dogs, sandwiches, snack foods and creamed soup were lunch staples. Soup, bread and coffee, the lunch we ate most frequently, cost about $10.
Although we did not pay directly for dinners outside Reykjavik, I estimated that a three-course meal averaged $35 a person, including tax. Tipping is not customary in Iceland, but neither is a tip refused. Alcoholic beverages would be additional.
In Vik, we ate at the Esso station convenience store on Route 1, (354) 487-1230, and other evenings, in the hotel dining room. At the Esso, a three-course dinner of smoked puffin, fried redfish and rice, and cheesecake cost about $25, with tax. A glass of wine is about $6.
 
Things to Do
The Blue Lagoon, near Grindavik, can be reached from Reykjavik by a 40-minute ride on a public bus, which costs about $15. Admission to the Blue Lagoon, open daily 9 A.M. to 10 P.M., is $8.20 for three hours of bathing; $11 for six hours. Towels and bathing suits can be rented at the new spa, which opened just last month, for about $3.50 each. Day tours that include the Blue Lagoon and other sites of interest will take passengers to the airport or back to Reykjavik. They cost about $50 and can be booked at many hotels; (354) 426-8800, fax (354) 426-8888, www.
bluelagoon.is.
Reservations can be made for boat trips on the Jokulsarlon glacial lagoon from Fjolnir Torfason, (354) 852-0631. The cost is $20.50 for a 40-minute ride. The lagoon is off Route 1, east of the Skaftafell Park. MARGUERITE McGLINN

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
An Entertainer, Unapologetically

BYLINE: By BARRY SINGER; Barry Singer's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about Joe's Pub, a club at the Joseph Papp Public Theater.

 BODY:
CLAIBORNE CARY has nothing to apologize for. In an age of cabaret performance often practiced as some rarefied art form, she is unabashedly an entertainer, one who likes to raise a ruckus.
Rude jokes and raw schtick are in no way beneath her, and as a singer Ms. Cary, now in her 60's, flat out likes to swing. All of which leaves her on the contrarian fringe of today's cabaret universe, where the notion of entertainment seems to get shunned somehow as lacking in serious purpose. 
 "It can get lonely," said Ms. Cary, who is in the midst of a monthlong return engagement at the somewhat less than mainstream Danny's Skylight Room on West 46th Street in Manhattan. "There aren't many people who aspire to be fun anymore. Not in a serious way."
A two-time winner of New York cabaret scene's top honor, the MAC Award, Ms. Cary is still a favorite within the industry but a name popularly recognized only by a few. Since arriving in New York from Lone Tree, Iowa in the 1950's as an aspiring dancer, she says has most definitely "been around": singing and dancing on Broadway and off and working the great cafes -- and also the not so great -- of the city.
Barely more than five-feet tall, she nursed little hope initially of making it as a Broadway chorus girl. Yet the choreographer Bob Fosse cast Ms. Carey in 1957 for his new show "New Girl in Town" over the vehement objections of that production's director, George Abbot.
"They were running up and down the aisle of the 46th Street Theater, screaming at each other," Ms. Cary recalled recently over lunch at a restaurant on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. "Abbot wanted another long-legged lady, but Bobby wanted me."
With characteristic capriciousness, however, Ms. Carey quit dancing for good immediately after "New Girl in Town" closed. "I just didn't want to be in the chorus anymore," she said. "I started doing parts and singing; I'd always listened to singers, especially Peggy Lee. Also Lee Wiley. And Anita O'Day."
At first there were gigs at tony Manhattan nightspots like the Blue Angel and Julius Monk's Upstairs at the Downstairs. Then came rock-and-roll and the near-death of cabaret in the 60's, followed by voice-over work, commercials and television, as well as two marriages and a son. Finally, some 10 years ago, Ms. Cary abandoned the city for Los Angeles. "A nasty little town," is all she will say about her experience there. Her long-planned, permanent return to New York is now imminent.
Onstage, she remains an extraordinary amalgam of musicianship and standup comedy: her pitch sure, her sense of time, both musically and comedically, effortless. Though her voice possesses the razorblade tone and ironic attack of an Elaine Stritch, her singing can be surprisingly expansive, even lyrical.
She shapes her sets into melodramatic narratives with well-chosen song juxtapositions: Irving Berlin's "Say It Isn't So" opposite John Wallowitch's "I Live Alone Again"; Cy Coleman and Joe McCarthy's "Why Try to Change Me Now" sung against Harold Arlen and Ted Koehler's "As Long as I Live." The potential effect could be bathetic but rarely is; Ms. Cary's wit and sense of survival bend the songs to her will.
"I cut right to the bone," she said. "I've learned that I'm better being funny between songs, rather than just doing funny songs; funny songs quickly get not so funny. Maybe that's another reason I'm nowhere, though, professionally. I'm trying to swing and be funny. Who else ever managed that?"
On her latest CD, "Claiborne Cary Live," she leads off tackling George and Ira Gershwin's "The Man I Love" at a ferocious clip. The result is not just exhilarating but revelatory. "I used to sing all of these songs much more slowly," Ms. Cary tells her audiences. "But I had more time then."
"How do I exist?" she asks. "Or, at least, subsist? I play a lot of private parties. And I don't work much. That helps."'
Her point is well taken. With few club owners these days paying performers anything at all beyond a small percentage of the door, the hard costs of cabaret -- salaries for musicians, up-front expenditures for arrangements and advertising -- largely come out of the singers' own pockets.
"You've got to save up for these gigs," Ms. Cary said wearily. "Let's face it, if I was looking to make a decent living, I'd have gone into computers by now."
Cabaret's persistent inability to provide her with financial security would surprise at least one person, Ms. Cary maintains.
"My mother viewed show business as a sure guarantee of economic freedom for her three daughters, both from the Depression and from men. (One of Ms. Cary's sisters is the actress Cloris Leachman.)
" 'Maybe you'll have your own money someday,' Mother would constantly say," Ms. Cary recalled. " 'Maybe you won't have to get married; maybe you'll just read and travel.' She'd call us in to watch her scrub the floor. 'Girls, come here and look,' she'd say. 'Don't ever do this.' "
"And," Ms. Cary added with the impeccable timing of a lifelong entertainer, "I never have."

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
The Wonder of It: The West Just So

BYLINE: By RICHARD B. WOODWARD; Richard B. Woodward is photography editor-at-large for DoubleTake magazine.

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
CARLETON WATKINS would rank among the great enigmas of late 19th-century American art even if his life weren't so mysterious and sad. The pictures he made of scenic glories in the West during the 1860's and 70's have been the sublime standard for generations of landscape photographers. Ansel Adams, for one, worked in his long shadow.
A fine Watkins photograph is about as fine as a photograph gets. There is nothing hit or miss about where he chose to aim his camera. His so-called mammoth prints, developed from 18-by-22-inch glass plates, often combine an eerie clarity with a bold massing of shapes that verges on analytic geometry. As the rigor of his compositions is startling for the time, so are his later studies of domesticated trees and fruits. A romantic's sense of wonder was matched by a classicist's restraint. Contrary to the practice of many painters in the West, then and since, Watkins surveyed nature without trumpery. By printing the facts he didn't need to elaborate myths. 
 The exhibition of his work at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (through Sept. 7, then moving to the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Oct. 12) offers pristine examples of Watkins the magnificent. His prints of Yosemite Valley are front and center. The power of persuasion in these images was such that Congress preserved the valley as a sanctuary in 1864; and for a while print sales to the public gave Watkins a comfortable living.
But the show's curator, Douglas R. Nickel, also highlights many lesser-known pictures in order to ask questions about the puzzling maturity of the work. Nothing in the Watkins biography -- what little we know of it, anyway -- explains how a former carpenter and bookstore clerk, born in 1829 in Oneonta, N.Y., came to possess such expressive gifts. How did a bumpkin who spent his adult life in the northern California backwater produce some of the most forward-looking pictures of the 19th century?
In looking for clues, Mr. Nickel examines the innovative ways of seeing pioneered by the Victorians, specifically the invention of stereography. An early form of 3-D that became a craze in the 1850's, it was, in Mr. Nickel's judgment, the most important and pervasive visual technology the 19th century produced, excepting photography itself. A series of booths at the end of the show lets viewers experience -- with the aid of computer software coupled to wireless goggles, both courtesy of StereoGraphics -- what the thrill was all about. The show and catalogue (which has been published by Abrams)are rightfully subtitled "The Art of Perception."
Like most field photographers of his time, Watkins also made stereographs for the home market, some 6,500. Mass marketed as cards that fit into a binocular hand viewer, they heightened the drama of perception. A street scene could become a stage in a stereograph, with sharp divisions between foregrounds and backgrounds, and figures cut out from both like silhouettes.
Watkins exploited the stereograph's displacing qualities with glee. In a shot of San Francisco, the streetcars look like toys in a child's pop-up book. In another, of a ferry and its passengers, he has arranged the people in layers, like ducks in a shooting gallery. An 1878 image of lily pads on water reflecting a grid of windows in the background offers the viewer no clear way to resolve a pictorial riddle. Both the subject and its reflection seem to exist in the same plane. As a study in flattened perspective, it rivals a Degas.
Watkins was clearly involved with the theatrics of space. He put together multipanel photographs of cities, or of mountaintops, that look down and across from high cliffs. Not only do these cinematic panoramas convey the appropriate awe at the width of the horizon; they can also bring on a dose of vertigo. Even the mesmerizing detail in some of Watkins's enormous plates, as Mr. Nickel says, force the viewer's eyes to spiral around the print and study it, rather than take it in at a glance.
At the same time, Watkins was also making careful documents of his time. His pictures of the Columbia River in 1867 show how the Northwest was really won -- not on any battlefield, but in mining camps and lumber mills, where the day-to-day harvesting of minerals and timber produced the raw materials for exportable wealth. However much he may have manipulated space with his triptychs and wide-angle lenses, Watkins stayed grounded in the economic reality of his employers, primarily mine owners and the railroads. A respect for the material world can be found throughout his work. All his life he photographed trees as if he knew they were essential for both life and culture. It is possible to examine a dozen Watkins prints and, except for the train tracks and rare steam engine, find little or no metal parts. The houses in a panorama of Portland, Ore., appear to be entirely built of wood, with stumps of felled trees prominent in the foreground. Even the dams at this time were hewed out of timber.
People hardly figure in Watkins's work, except as puny yardsticks for measuring the loftier stature of nature. The five men standing shoulder-to-shoulder in front of Grizzly Giant, the wizened sequoia in Yosemite's Mariposa Grove, are barely visible beside the massive base of its trunk. Almost no one in his pictures exhibits traits of personality other than endurance in the face of vaster forces.
The less grandiose trees he photographed in the 1870's may be his most intimate work. They are like character studies. The buckeye tree in a California front yard shades a cabin like a floppy hat. His 1878 view of a house in a larch grove is as plain and mournful as a Willa Cather novel.
Seven detached figures stand in the shadows. The subject of the picture appears to be neither the people nor the trees, but the uneasy struggle to establish a home. A photograph of a box of peaches on its side from 1887-88 is shocking in its simplicity. In arranging the fruits so that their cleavage is unmistakable, Watkins even seems to be telling a harmless dirty joke.
That Watkins produced this majestic and diverse body of work with little or no formal esthetic training is still hard to fathom, as is his rapid and tragic decline in popularity. The Yosemite pictures made him famous and employable. He was praised by Emerson and Oliver Wendell Holmes. By 1871 his studio in San Francisco was the grandest in the West.
But in the late 1870's his fortunes reversed like a train rolling backward down a mountain, and he never really found the brake. He was a wretched businessman. In 1874 he lost a studio he had opened in Yosemite, as well as the copyright on his plates of the park, to bankruptcy. At 50 he married a woman 28 years younger, only to find that he could barely support her. The market for stereographs dried up through saturation. Watkins's meticulous skills were less and less in demand. He suffered from arthritis and blindness.
In 1895-96 he lived with his family in a boxcar -- they couldn't afford a house -- until his childhood friend, the railroad baron Collis Huntington, deeded him a ranch. As a final blow, the 1906 San Francisco earthquake and fire destroyed the glass-plate negatives in Watkins's main studio and, in effect, wiped out a life's work. In 1910 he was committed to the Napa Hospital for the Insane, where, six years later, he died. He is buried on the grounds in an unmarked grave.
The strangest puzzle may be how late recognition for Watkins has been in coming. Beaumont Newhall's standard history of photography didn't include a Watkins photograph in its first four editions. Finally, in 1982, Watkins made the grade. Only in the last 25 years, thanks in part to the advocacy of scholars like Peter Palmquist, has Watkins been considered the finest American photographer of the 19th century.
His contemporaries didn't regard him as anything special, either. They never saw him as unusually modern in his picture making but rather as an exceptional craftsman. That also seems to be how Watkins saw himself.
One of the few remarks we have from him is second-hand -- he left no diary or articles, and gave no interviews -- from the photographer John Hillers, who had brought him prints to review. "I have little advice to offer," said Watkins. "You are a clean worker in which lies the great secret of photography."
Although scholars have found that there is a great more to it -- and to him -- than that, the bedrock of Watkins's remarkable artistry, even after as excellent a show and catalogue as this, can still seem more submerged than exposed.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 3; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2242 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Quirk After Quirk in Side-by-Side Festivals

BYLINE: By JESSE MCKINLEY

 BODY:
IN the fractious world of Off Off Broadway, it was bound to happen. The Fringe has developed a fringe.
Beginning Wednesday, the downtown theater scene will be witness to the opening of two simultaneous festivals, each based on the Lower East Side and each purporting to represent the rich variety among the city's littlest and least-known theater troupes. 
 This year's newcomer is the Pure Pop Theater Festival, which will kick off just hours after the first show of the New York International Fringe Festival, now in its third summer.
Pure Pop's organizers promise to match the Fringe quirk for quirk, with programming that includes a rarely seen temperance play ("Ten Nights in a Barroom" by William Pratt), an 18th-century Japanese epic ("The Battles of Coxinga" by Chikamatsu Monzaemon) and several shows with titles not suitable for a family newspaper. All in all, Pure Pop promises to stage nearly 60 productions over seven weeks (through Oct. 3), at sites ranging from the Queens Theater in the Park to Theater 4S, a 15-seater in an East Village apartment.
For its part, the Fringe will present some 150 productions in 12 days, through Aug. 29, an ambitious schedule that includes theater, dance and performance art. Here, too, some of the titles suggest a deep immersion in the odd: "Urinetown," an original musical, and "Jinkies," a series of Scooby Doo episodes based on the television cartoon. There is also a revival of the Robert Wilson-Tom Waits-William S. Burroughs rock opera "The Black Rider," which was staged at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1995.
Does downtown really need all this? Aaron Beall, the founder of Pure Pop, answers: "Nobody's saying to Lincoln Center, 'Hey, too many festivals, guys! Too much creativity! You've got to stop it! Why do you need the Mozart? You just did Schubert! Enough with the Mendelssohn!' "
Pure Pop and the Fringe have a shared history. Mr. Beall (pronounced Bell) was a founder of the Fringe, but earlier this year he had a falling out with a co-founder, John Clancy, and left to start Pure Pop. (Mr. Beall is also the founder of Todo Con Nada, a storefront theater on Ludlow Street, and Mr. Clancy is also the artistic director of the downtown theater group Present Company).
Mr. Beall's departure led to rumors -- and news reports -- of a vitriolic crisis in the heart of the city's Off Off Broadway community. But Mr. Clancy and Mr. Beall, who are both 35, say there is little animus between them. They ascribe the fight to personality differences and some grumbling over dividing box office receipts. Each man's company lost money on the two previous Fringe festivals.
"When times are tight, a little bit of money gets to be very important," Mr. Clancy said at the Theatorium, the Fringe's headquarters and mainstage on Stanton Street. "But Aaron and I are getting along."
What the two men can also agree on is that their festivals represent only a part of what is going on Off Off Broadway, which many on the scene say is in the midst of a period of remarkable popularity, economic growth and structural change.
"I think there's an influx of extraordinary people working in the scene right now," said the playwright Mac Wellman, a stalwart of downtown theater. "And a lot of them don't want to make it in the traditional way."
Indeed, many in the new generation of theater artists and downtown producers have begun to exhibit the professional trappings of larger institutions: press agents, marketing plans and six-figure annual budgets. The Fringe and Pure Pop are no exception: the Fringe has a budget of $180,000; Pure Pop about a third of that. Mr. Beall, in particular, is something of a media hound, talking up his festival with the showy optimism of a circus barker. "It's the beginning of festival season," he said recently, smiling over a plate of sushi near Todo Con Nada. "You got to make the scene."
While Mr. Beall was with the Fringe, he aggressively promoted the festival in radio and television interviews; with Pure Pop, he has taken to dyeing his hair -- blue, most recently -- for effect. He is also pushing Pure Pop in interviews and on the Internet as the first season in a "99-year plan" to save Off Off Broadway from what he complains is invasive real estate development.
Mr. Beall's fears aside, much of downtown theater is blooming. Critical praise has begun to follow young companies like Elevator Repair Service and playwrights like Richard Maxwell, the author of "House." That play toured Europe this summer after good reviews in New York; Elevator Repair Service's "Total Fictional Lie" will tour five American cities this fall and winter.
At home, Target Margin's acclaimed 1998 production of "Mamba's Daughters" was the headliner at the Spoleto Festival in Charleston, S.C., in May. The chamber musical "Running Man," a March production at HERE in SoHo, was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize, while the winner, "Wit," had its New York premiere at the 99-seat MCC Theater on West 28th Street.
Commercial success stories have been more hit and miss. Downtown shows like "Shakespeare's R&J," which began at the tiny Expanded Arts theater on Ludlow Street, had a long commercial run Off Broadway, as did "Gross Indecency: The Three Trials of Oscar Wilde," which began on Off Off Broadway. On the other hand, last season's commercial transfers of the Adobe Theater Company's "Duet!" and Premium Bob's "Manhunt" were not successful in larger auditoriums.
Downtown theater isn't even always downtown anymore. "Three Virgins," developed by the experimental company Collapsable Giraffe, reclaimed Show World, a former sex superstore on Eighth Avenue near 42d Street, as a theatrical space.
Such activity has jumped the rivers, too, spreading to hot neighborhoods like Dumbo in Brooklyn, where the experimental troupe Gale Gates et al. has its own 40,000-square-foot performance space. An additional large performance space and gallery, Smack Mellon, has opened in an old spice factory.
While the technical definition of Off Off Broadway is any theater with less than 100 seats, the term is also emblematic of the artistic standards of a movement that was born in the early 1960's. Those criteria -- being noncommercial, experimental and, in the words of the director Richard Caliban, "off the radar" -- are still embraced by a majority of downtown theater artists. But the term has also had its less flattering associations.
"To me, when I started, it seemed Off Off Broadway was synonymous with bad," said Jeremy Dobrish, the artistic director of the Adobe Theater. "It was like, 'I'm going to go, it's going to be hot, it's going to be cramped, the people won't know what they're doing, it will be pretentious and alienating, and I'm not going to have a good time." But, he said, downtown theater in New York is "different now," more like "the independent film scene."
Conversations with some 20 downtown theater artists supported the notion that changes were afoot, though some said the reasons might be more personal than professional.
"I think we were all just sick of playing for our friends," said Jim Findlay, the co-artistic director of Collapsable Giraffe. "I'd rather have an audience of 25 people I don't know than 40 friends."
Another factor that has had an effect is dwindling Government support. "This generation of artists came up not expecting to get a grant," said Mark Russell, the executive director of Performance Space 122 in the East Village. "All these guys came of age after the N.E.A. Four and the Karen Finley episode. You say Karen Finley, and they have a blank look on their faces. It's like Kennedy getting shot. They don't remember it." (In 1990, Ms. Finley and three other performance artists had their Federal grants revoked by the National Endowment for the Arts after conservative Congressmen objected to using government money for what was deemed by some to be obscene art. )
The new climate, Mr. Clancy said, has made Off Off Broadway more self-sufficient: "The 1990's are really a time when people started thinking in a businesslike fashion -- if you're going to keep your doors open, you're going to have to earn money. And part of that is understanding that you're in the service industry. and that that goes not only for the art but also the conditions." In short, cramped basements and creaky folding chairs are out; air-conditioning and comfortable seating are in.
But does all this spit and polish mean that downtown theater has lost its edge? One elder statesman said he had found indications of trouble. "I haven't seen anyone walking out angrily like they did from my work," said Richard Foreman, the experimental director. "That's a bad sign."
Young downtown types scoff at the thought that they have gone soft. And, to be sure, gratuitous nudity, violence and simulated kinky sex can still be found in a number of shows. Some say, though, that the content of downtown theater work has become more populist -- more easily accessible and less cynical. But part of that, said David Latham of the Premium Bob troupe, has to do with "shock fatigue."
"Who hasn't seen someone urinate onstage?" asked Mr. Latham.
Even without a Finley-style controversy, directors agree that Government grants for small companies have diminished during the 1990's, while private support has improved and corporate support has dwindled.
David Herskovits, the artistic director of Target Margin, said the losses in corporate support have been "particularly disgraceful," considering the money being made in the 1990's.
But what of the boom? Has there been a trickle down?
Off Off Broadway producers are divided. Some say that New York's economic resurgence has caused nothing but headaches, raising rents and production costs. Dixon Place, a performance space on the Bowery, recently announced it would have to move because its rent had been increased; other theater spaces and companies are still operating hand-to-mouth.
"What Off Off Broadway means," said Jeff Sugg, a lighting designer, "is you still ask if you're getting paid."
Others say the boom has made downtown fashionable and safe again, a comfortable place for monied audiences and producers to seek out new work.
Then there are the peripheral benefits. "There are literally 175 new condos being built next door to us and they were expensive," said Michelle Stern, a co-founder of Gale Gates. "So we have an audience literally right next door that walks by every day."
The influx of young people into the city is also being felt. "Broadway is always talking about trying to get a young audience, but I go to see one of these shows at HERE, or the Ontological, or the Flea, and I feel like I'm clubbing," said Stephen Nunns, a director and an editor for American Theater magazine. "It's the most beautiful audience I've ever seen."
The roster of popular downtown theater spaces has expanded in the last few years. Newer ones like Access Theater in TriBeCa and the Present Company's Theatorium on the Lower East Side are home to a steady stream of work of their own as well as that of renters. The same is true of theaters like HERE, the SoHo Rep and the Workhouse Theater (now known as the Flea Theater). Of the older performance spaces, P.S. 122 on First Avenue and Ninth Street, the Ontological at St. Mark's Church and Second Avenue, the Ohio Theater and the Performing Garage, both on Wooster Street in SoHo, are still vibrant breeding grounds for young artists.
And look at them come. "More and more training schools churn out more and more actors who arrive in New York City," said Mr. Beall of the Pure Pop Festival. "And it becomes harder and harder for younger theater artists to carve out a spot."
Which is where, ironically, the Fringe Festival comes in. The Fringe's role is to "provide access and opportunity to talent without reputation and without resources and without cash and without experience," said Mr. Clancy. But some larger companies, he added, have also begun to look at the Fringe as a place to present work in its early stages.
At the same time, Mr. Clancy acknowledged, most of the better-established companies have little motivation to perform at his festival, where several companies share the same theater and where turnaround time between different shows can be as little as 15 minutes. "For a company like Elevator Repair Service," he said, "is this going to serve them? I don't know."
John Collins, the artistic director of Elevator Repair Service, said: "All these festivals are working at the very basic level, and though I probably shouldn't say this, some of it can be really awful stuff. But that's a great kind of evidence that companies are still generating raw material, and the festivals keep trying to give the work a chance."
For their part, those involved in downtown theater seem to respect the Fringe. "I asked someone about the Fringe and they said, 'It's cheap, and we get a venue for our play,' " Mr. Herskovits said. "And I said, "Fantastic. That's all you need.' "
Not, of course, that they don't have a few suggestions: more international programming for one, and oh, yes, more good stuff. Mr. Clancy said he's working on it.
New York International Fringe Festival tickets are $11. Information and tickets: (212) 420-8877. Also: www.FringeNYC.org. Most Pure Pop Theater Festival tickets are $9. Information and reservations: (877) 932-4222. Also: www.purepop.org.

PUB-DATE: August 15, 1999

SECTION: Section 2; Page 9; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1963 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
When the Spice of Choice Was Sin

BYLINE: By J. HOBERMAN; J. Hoberman is senior film critic for The Village Voice.

 BODY:
"I WISH to join the Legion of Decency, which condemns vile and unwholesome moving pictures. I unite with all who protest against them as a grave menace to youth, to home life, to country and to religion." So began a pledge written in the spring of 1934 by the Archbishop of Cincinnati, John T. McNicholas. Distributed in Roman Catholic churches across America, the petition garnered some four million signatures within a month.
Racy and insolent, populated by dynamic, street-smart criminals and glamorous "fallen women" in scanty lingerie, set in Art Deco penthouses and skid row dives, predicated on breezy wisecracks and slangy double-entendres that confounded censors and offended less cosmopolitan audiences, the Hollywood movies of the early 1930's were a different world. Or were they? "I condemn absolutely those salacious motion pictures which, with other degrading agencies, are corrupting public morals and promoting sex mania in our land," the Legion of Decency pledge continued. 
 Adopted four years before the Legion began its crusade, the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America Production Code had proscribed undue exposure, indecent dancing, lustful kissing, obscenity and explicit adultery, seduction or rape, not to mention "sex perversion," "white slavery" and "miscegenation." But the Code was not truly in force, having gone into effect just as the movie industry was stunned by two surprise developments, one technological, the other economic. Movies became "talkies" even as hard times battered a business previously imagined depression-proof.
Two years after the stock market crash, Warner Brothers and Fox were suffering heavy losses. Universal had discharged hundreds of its employees. RKO was already in receivership. Paramount, which would declare bankruptcy the following year, was selling off its theaters. Weekly movie attendance was 60 percent of what it had been before the Depression began. By the summer of 1932, a third of American moviehouses had gone dark, and exhibitors were experimenting with exploitation angles ranging from double bills to dish giveaways to bingo games. Producers were desperate and, as demonstrated by "The Joy of Pre-Code: Sex, Booze and Red Hot Jazz, 1930-33," a 44-film series starting on Friday at Film Forum 2, they pushed the weakly enforced Code to its limits and beyond.
For anyone brought up on the movies of the 1940's and 1950's, those of the early 30's can be a revelation. Sinners escape punishment and virtue is not necessarily rewarded. Crime sometimes pays and marriage vows are frequently flouted. Self-interest is a near-universal principle. Fast-talking, tough-acting James Cagney became Warner Brothers' top star by hustling his way up from the streets, but he was scarcely the only tiger in the urban jungle. The now-forgotten Warren William ("Skyscraper Souls," "Employees Entrance"), oiliest of alpha males and caddish personification of ruthless capitalism, abused the men and seduced the women lucky enough to be working but unfortunate enough to be working for him.
Women acted out as well. If the former factory worker Joan Crawford was kept by the Park Avenue lawyer Clark Gable in MGM's enormously successful "Possessed" (1931), the more proactive Jean Harlow wrecked her boss's home, then married and betrayed him in the 1932 comedy "Red-Headed Woman." In "Female" (1933), Warner Brothers' biggest female star, Ruth Chatterton, ran an automobile plant and satisfied her sex drive with a succession of handsome young employees. Marlene Dietrich sold her body to support her sick husband in "Blonde Venus" (1932). That movie lost money for Paramount, but the studio struck gold with Mae West -- even if Will Hays, the mostly ineffectual head of the producers' and directors' Code, did manage to keep them from titling her second vehicle "It Ain't No Sin."
"Baby Face" (1933), which opens the series on a bill with the luridly expressionist Edward G. Robinson vehicle "Two Seconds" (1932), is a crude, still-powerful morality play in which Barbara Stanwyck systematically sleeps her way to the pinnacle of economic power. Dreamed up by the Warner production boss Darryl Zanuck in the wake of MGM's "Red-Headed Woman," the movie single-mindedly tracks Stanwyck's climb from a gritty Pennsylvania steel town, where she is pimped by her father in his speakeasy, to control of a New York bank. Each new conquest celebrated by a honkytonk chorus from "St. Louis Blues," Stanwyck is a femme fatal as inexorable as the Depression itself: her discarded men lose their jobs, their fortunes and, in two cases, their lives.
Bruce Goldstein, the director of repertory programming at Film Forum 2, calls "Baby Face" the quintessential pre-Code movie, although he singles out the moment in the 1932 "Call Her Savage" when an amorous Great Dane jumps Clara Bow as "the most astonishing pre-Code shot." Mr. Goldstein organized his first pre-Code series 11 years ago. "I don't think anyone had ever done one before," he says. "The period was completely overlooked. They never showed these films on television when I was growing up. Not one of them is a 'classic' and that's why it was a discovery for most people." Film Forum's "Hollywood Before the Code" not only clicked at the box office but also won national publicity.
Within the year, Mr. Goldstein said, revival houses in Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco ran similar programs, while MGM Home Video issued a collection of pre-Code movies. The forthcoming series is Film Forum's fourth, and interest in the period continues to grow. Two books are scheduled for publication this fall, Thomas Doherty's scholarly history, "Pre-Code Hollywood: Sex, Immorality and Insurrection in American Cinema, 1930-34" and Mark A. Vieira's lavish coffee-table volume, "Sin in Soft Focus."
Initially, the pre-Code movies were attacked for their amoral violence. The 1931-32 gangster cycle drew most of the heat -- even Al Capone professed to disapprove, telling reporters that movies like "Public Enemy" and "Little Caesar" were "doing nothing but harm to the younger element of the country." By 1932, the studios were cranking out "bad girl" movies. Variety, which attributed their popularity to the female audience, would estimate that 80 percent of the 440 pictures released during the 1932-33 season had some sort of "sex slant." Nevertheless, some movies were more scarlet than others, and "Red-Headed Woman" in particular sent studios stampeding down the primrose path.
AN Irving Thalberg project, written by Anita Loos to relaunch Harlow at her new studio, "Red-Headed Woman" was as much throwback as innovation. The irresistible vamp who haunted the American screen 15 years earlier in the exotic form of Theda Bara was resurrected as a gum-chewing stenographer. Sound brought silent movies down to earth, and Harlow embodied the triumph of the vulgar, seducing her married prey on his living room sofa with his photograph pinned to her garter. As comic as she is steamy, Harlow's two-timing golddigger maintains audience sympathy even when she petulantly shoots her estranged husband. Nor does the movie see fit to punish her. The bad girl winds up in Paris, mistress to a marquis, with a handsome chauffeur in tow.
"Red-Headed Woman" inspired Warner Brothers to make "Baby Face" and Fox to adapt Tiffany Thayer's risque "Call Her Savage" as the comeback vehicle for the erstwhile "It Girl," Clara Bow, after sound and scandal short-circuited her career. (Plodding as cinema and racist in its implications, this sordid saga of a half American Indian vixen is best known today for its often anthologized scene of two men dressed as French maids entertaining the patrons of a Greenwich Village speakeasy.) Paramount adapted William Faulkner's sensational "Sanctuary" in 1933 for the "The Story of Temple Drake" (thrill-seeking Southern belle slips into degradation after she is raped by a gangster and dumped in a New Orleans brothel), while embarking on a protracted struggle to bring Broadway's bawdy sensation, Mae West, to Hollywood. Hays managed to delay West's screen debut but failed to prevent it. Released in early 1933, "She Done Him Wrong" grossed $2 million in less than two months, returning 10 times its production costs in North America alone.
In many cases, pre-Code advertising promised more sex than the movies themselves delivered. (For "Baby Face" -- "She Had IT and Made IT Pay.") The strategy ultimately backfired. It was a movie billboard that so offended Denis Cardinal Dougherty of Philadelphia that he called for a boycott of all movies. The first selective boycotts had been organized by the Detroit diocese during the summer of 1933. With the Legion of Decency pledge promoted from the pulpit and Mae West pilloried in the Hearst press, the crusade gathered momentum over the next 10 months. "Hollywood is in the most serious crisis of its history," The Los Angeles Times reported in June 1934. With the creation of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's National Recovery Administration, which sought to regulate film exhibition practices, the studios were worried that the Federal Government might then try to police movie content as well. Once the Bank of America's chairman, A. H. Giannini, threatened to link continued financing to Production Code Administration approval, the industry buckled.
That summer, Hays had appointed the hard-nosed and well-connected Catholic journalist Joseph Breen to enforce the Code. (As Mr. Doherty points out, pre-Code is a misnomer; the correct term should be pre-Breen.) From then on, as the screenwriter Herman Mankiewicz paraphrased the Code for his peers, the hero and heroine have to be virgins, while the villain can have sex with anybody he wants, "cheating and stealing, getting rich and whipping the servants." He added, "But you have to shoot him in the end." By 1935, Hollywood had passed from inspired disorder into the golden age of regulation.
Did the Code improve American movies as well as morals? Mr. Doherty concludes his detailed and fascinating study by stating the "inconvenient truth" that Hollywood's "most vivid and compelling motion pictures" were produced "under the most severe and narrow-minded censorship." And yet the early, free-wheeling 30's churned up a remarkable number of enduring celluloid archetypes, ranging from gangsters and gold diggers through Dracula and King Kong, to such pop icons as W. C. Fields, Mae West, the Marx Brothers, Betty Boop and even Mickey Mouse. Moreover, individual filmmakers as distinguished as Ernst Lubitsch, Josef von Sternberg and Busby Berkeley produced their finest work during the pre-Code period.
There is something to be said for crisis as a stimulus to popular art. Similarly, the transformation of movies to talkies served to break existing rules for narrative filmmaking, even as the Depression pushed producers towards wild experimentation. Taken as a whole, the movies of the early 30's constitute a distinctive American idiom. The strongest pre-Code movies are as rowdy, pungent and oddball as the Sunday funnies or the country blues. Tawdry gems like the electric-chair flashback "Two Seconds," the declasse daisy-chain "Blood Money" -- a madam loves a bail bondsman who loves a masochistic debutante who loves a bank robber -- or the tropical, "No Exit"-like nightmare "Safe in Hell" are hard-boiled beyond belief and almost kabuki in their economy of means.
Indeed, thanks to their Depression-induced frugality and the exigencies of the double feature, pre-Code movies are admirably terse. Perhaps even more wondrous than their convoluted, down-and-dirty narratives is the seemingly lost art of squeezing such shenanigans into a highly satisfying 70 minutes.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 3220 words

HEADLINE: Perfect Together, New Jersey and Kitsch;
From the Diners to the Rest Stops, There She Goes Again, Miss America

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
WELCOME to New Jersey, the kitsch capital of the world, from Lucy the Elephant to the Joyce Kilmer rest area.
Salt water taffies and Silver Stream-like diners. 
 Trenton makes the world takes.
From Sinatra's Hoboken to Steel Pier's diving horse.
From Miss America to Elsie the Cow.
A traipse through the trivia, from Lindbergh to the Hindenburg and from Hoffa to the mafia.
It's enough to make Jimmy sit up, claw his way out of end zone at Giants Stadium and growl, "Cheez, can't a guy get any rest here?"
So you get in the family minivan, pop in a Bruce Springsteen tape, and don't stop until you climb your way into the Berkshires -- an area with its own cachet born of places like Tanglewood, Jacob's Pillow and Alice's Restaurant -- and there it is dominating a shop window in Great Barrington, Mass.: a huge poster of the late, lamented Palisades Amusement Park.
Arghh.
The beautifully framed reprint of a 1909 poster shows the small figures of people in silly-looking turn-of-the-century-garb taking trolleys to the summit to spend a day on the rides.
"I have sold more of that poster than of any single poster we have in here," said Margaret Wheeler, an owner of the shop. "It's been remarkable."
Not bad, considering that it sells for $165 framed and $32 unframed. But the amusement park is just one part of Jersey lore that has spawned an entire industry of Jerseyana -- books that rhapsodize about Jersey diners and the New Jersey Turnpike, beer mugs and magnets that display lighthouses and recordings like Dave Van Ronk's whimsical "Garden State Stomp" whose only lyrics are New Jersey's eclectic place names ("Allamuchy, Hacklebarney, Rockaway, Piscataway . . .")
New Jersey downright abounds in tchotchkes, whether they're found in concession stands down the shore or gift shops along the turnpike and the Garden State Parkway or even in bookstores.
Maybe only Florida and California -- and the operative word is maybe -- have cultures that mass-produce as much kitsch. But many of the people there have migrated from New Jersey. You don't believe that? The next time you're in a Chinese restaurant or a delicatessen in Boca Raton, stand up and ask how many people remember Syd's in Newark.
The outpouring of books alone about everything from the archetypal to the arcane in New Jersey has boomed enough in recent years to have set back several forests in the Pacific Northwest well into the next millennium. There are, for example, "Palisades Amusement Park: A Century of Fond Memories," "Jersey Diners," "Roadside New Jersey," "New Jersey Trivia," "New Jersey Firsts: The Famous, Infamous and Quirky of the Garden State" and "Murdered in New Jersey."
In some Barnes & Noble stores -- like the palace on Route 17 South in Paramus -- the display of books and magazines devoted to New Jersey is lavish. But even in the smallest shops the browser can find a healthy selection on history and geography, day-tripping, gardening, golfing, canoeing, hiking trails and motor routes, and shopping and weekend visits.
What is it about the state that has set off an unquenchable interest in things Jersey and created this huge cache of kitsch?
Cultural anthropologists -- from vaunted institutions of higher learning to neighborhood bars -- say New Jersey has been drawing a lot of attention of late for a variety of reasons. They include the resurrection of a popular marketing slogan, "New Jersey and You, Perfect Together," from the days of Gov. Tom Kean; a prosperous economy; the Presidential aspirant in basketball shoes, Bill Bradley; the latest concert tour of the quintessential Jersey spokesmen, Boss Springsteen and the E Street Band, and "The Sopranos," the highly rated television show about mob life in which New Jersey locations give a gritty but not unappealing view of life in the land of the exit ramps and jug handles.
But one answer right from the get-go -- ironic for a state accused of having an identity crisis -- is personality.
Yes, personality, says the gourmand Michael Stern, who traverses the countryside with his wife Jane. Together, they report on what they eat for Gourmet Magazine and "The Splendid Table" on National Public Radio. Mr. Stern says New Jersey -- unlike many states -- including his home state of Connecticut, has a strong personality.
"There's kitsch from the Jersey Shore," he says. "There's diner kitsch. There's Jersey Turnpike kitsch. Then there's the whole horsy part of New Jersey, which has its own kitsch.
"I admire New Jersey the way the class wallflower admires the person who has a million friends and has a colorful personality," he says. "New Jersey has a colorful personality, and that explains why it has so much, from the tackiest kind of kitsch to the very cultural type of New Jersey artifacts."
But not so fast. Mr. Stern acknowledges that this can work against the state, too.
"It's a mixed blessing because New Jersey is the butt of a lot of jokes," he says. "But it's only the butt of jokes because it has a personality. Nobody makes a joke about New Hampshire because there's no popular cultural identity there."
Year after year, punch line after after punch line, New Jersey kitsch absorbs the negatives and almost revels in the things that people used to ridicule, like the turnpike and such famous murders as the slaying of Charles Lindbergh's young son, the case of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, or most recently the murder of little Megan Kanka, which spawned Megan's Law requiring sex offenders to notify the authorities when they move into a neighborhood.
"I'm from New Jersey/I don't expect too much/If the world ended today/I would adjust," is the refrain from the song by John Gorka, "I'm From New Jersey," that in confronting some of the negative images of the state head-on becomes a paean to the malleability of its people.
Dave Van Ronk's "Garden State Stomp," although nothing more than a quirky compendium of Jersey place names, taken all together becomes something more, something almost celebratory of their uniqueness.
The magazine "Weird N.J.: Your Travel Guide To New Jersey's Local Legends and Best Kept Secrets" gleefully reports the offbeat and nutty, leaving the more salutary to a proliferation of other magazines, "New Jersey Monthly," "NJ The Magazine, for New Jersey," "New Jersey Life, Town & Country Living at Its Best," "New Jersey Country Roads" and "Outdoor New Jersey."
"I think we in New Jersey looked around one day and discovered the New Jersey joke is still alive but it's in hibernation," says Michael Aaron Rockland, head of American Studies at Rutgers University in New Brunswick who has written books and several articles about New Jersey, including why New Jersey is so often the butt of jokes.
"What I think I've seen in recent years is a growth in Jersey pride, kind of in a sense a New Jersey renaissance," Mr. Rockland says. "You used to apologize about coming from New Jersey, Now you brag about it, although we don't go as far as the people from Texas."
Once, Mr. Rockland says, T-shirts like, "New Jersey: Only the Tough Survive," were everywhere. That was in the 1970's, when, according to Cliff Zukin, director of the Star Ledger-Eagleton Poll at Rutgers, New Jerseyans had a low opinion of their own state compared with how people in other states felt about theirs.
"Years ago we used to see things like that," says Tommie Sanders, vice president for operations at Host Marriot Services operations in New Jersey and New York City, which manages the rest stops along the turnpike and the parkway.
"But we don't sell stuff like that anymore," Mr. Sanders says. "We sell a lot of 'You and New Jersey, Perfect Together' type of shirts."
Got a problem with that? Just walk into the gift shop in the Cheesequake service area of the Parkway (milepost 125), the busiest of all, and there is a shirt on display that waxes almost Biblical about the state: "His orchestration by the Sea -- A mesmerizing symphony. Jersey Shore."
It's almost enough to make a guy from Perth Amboy hunger for a veggie burger. Well, maybe not.
A display case nearby features the usual hats and shirts -- but also an adult nightshirt and a teddy bear in a T-shirt, all emblazoned with "New Jersey." And on a wall of shelves beyond that is more colorful apparel praising the state, including a T-shirt that reads: "Someone who loves me very much went to the Jersey shore and brought me back this shirt."
The shore -- down the shore, to be precise -- all 127 miles. Atlantic City and Cape May inns are prominent motifs: shot glasses and beer mugs and a coffee mug with a display of Jersey lighthouses called "Beacons of Light at the Jersey Shore;" key chains with an ace of spades to lament or fondly recall a trip to the tables, and enough refrigerator magnets modeled after Cape May's Victorian houses to make the Earth implode at the poles.
A far cry, you might say, from the classic postcard that showed a mosquito and the words: "New Jersey State Bird."
"I'm from Florida," said Mr. Sanders, "and when I first came up here, nobody wanted to buy anything from New Jersey. They wanted souvenirs of New York and Pennsylvania."
Now, he says, "We sell replicas of New Jersey lighthouses, when we're not running out of them."
David Ryan, general services manager for the New Jersey Highway Authority, who oversees the service areas, estimates that in the last five years the amount of New Jersey merchandise sold in the souvenir shops has doubled and maybe even tripled.
"People are traveling more and, as they travel more, they get to understand what New Jersey has to offer and appreciate it more than they used to," Mr. Ryan says.
But long before there was rebirth in New Jersey, there was an older, industrial New Jersey captured in Americana in the form of Nipper the dog and the Campbell soup can immortalized on canvas by Andy Warhol.
Nipper originally sat in a tower atop the Camden building that was home to the Radio Corporation of America and its predecessor, the Victor Talking Machine Company, leaning toward a gramophone and listening to "his master's voice." It was a beacon displaying a well-known commercial logo and a symbol of industrial Camden.
As for Warhol, according to a brother, the artist's love affair with Campbell's had its roots in their Pittsburgh childhood, when it was the family's favorite soup. Nonetheless, the Campbell Soup Company was always a bit leery about having him involved with the brand.
So when did New Age New Jersey become respectable -- or at least popular, like the bad boy in the T-shirt and jeans all the girls would like to spend a weekend with down the shore? Mr. Zukin of the Eagleton Poll says New Jersey began to get a better sense of itself and cast a different national image with the creation of the Meadowlands Sports Complex and and the advent of gambling in Atlantic City.
And that good feeling continues today with a prosperous economy, the creation of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark and the growth of minor league baseball in parks throughout the state.
"These are sort of little icons popping up," Mr. Zukin says.
But as strong as the kitsch industry is in New Jersey, Mr. Stern insists it is not the leader, despite the turnpike, Jersey mosquitoes, Jersey diners, Stewart's Root Beer stands and the jokes about Jimmy Hoffa being buried under a goal post in the Meadowlands.
"If I had to identify the kitsch capital of America it would not be New Jersey," he says. "It would be Florida, and it has been that way for decades. I think California has slipped as far as having that aura that produces the postcards and tacky souvenirs to hang on the wall."
Helping to enhance New Jersey's image is the wide range of books extolling everything from its geology to, as one book title puts it, "funky adventures."
Not surprisingly, Rutgers University Press is the largest publisher of books about New Jersey, with about 80 new titles a year, said its director, Marlie Wasserman.
Of those, said Ms. Wasserman, 70 percent are scholarly and 30 percent are regional books that "celebrate the state."
Twenty years ago, she said, regional books made up only 5 percent of the publisher's total output. "It's a jump in so-called coffee table books, but it's because we decided to make it happen," Ms. Wasserman says. "We made it a major goal."
Okay, but why? "Our main purpose is to disseminate knowledge," she explained. "Notice the use of the word 'knowledge' rather than 'scholarship.' Knowledge includes scholarship -- knowledge of trails and roads and butterflies and the general history of the state as well as the academic."
Two of the publisher's most popular books that have sold well nationally are "Jersey Diners" by Peter Genovese, a reporter for The Star-Ledger of Newark and "Palisades Amusement Park, N.J.: A Century of Fond Memories," by Vince Gargiulo, a graphic artist. "Diners" has sold 9,000 copies since it was published in 1996, and "Palisades Park" 11,000 since it came out in 1995.
That is a significant number says Christopher Kerr, a freelance sales representative for Parson Weems, a company that represents university presses, considering the average press run of a book is from 3,500 to 5,000. The sales figures also give some indication of the increased interest in things New Jersey.
Things New Jersey and diners -- they're almost synonymous terms. And though the diner was not born here, Mr. Genovese writes, New Jersey has far more than any other state -- 570 by his last count -- in part because three of the nation's four diner manufacturers are situated in the state.
"I also like to think there is something innately New Jersey about a diner," he writes. "Diners are colorful and kitschy, and in New Jersey, which Rutgers University professor Michael Aaron Rockland calls the roadside pop architecture capital of the world, they have found a home."
What's more, in addition to the 570 diners serving ham and eggs and meatloaf and malteds, the older ones are finding new homes in Europe, thereby spreading New Jersey kitsch abroad. The former Beach Haven Diner is now open for business in Barcelona; the Excellent Diner, formerly of Westfield, is now serving cups of joe in Aalen, Germany.
Mr. Genovese is no stranger to New Jersey kitsch. In 1994 he came out with "Roadside New Jersey," also published by Rutgers Press, which deals with roadside pop architecture including Lucy, the three-story metal and wood elephant in Margate that was born in the last century as an inn and is now a museum.
Former Governor Kean could well have coined the phrase, "New Jersey and Kitsch, perfect together." Ask Mr. Gargiulo, who says that since the publication of his book "Palisades Amusement Park, N.J.: A Century of Fond Memories," he has been inundated with letters and E-mail from all over the country.
"If I had to attribute it to anything, it's probably two factors," says Mr. Gargiulo, who is founder and director of the Palisades Amusement Park Historial Society. "One is the craze for nostalgia and remembering happier times, and the other is a love and devotion for the state."
Margaret Wheeler, who with Holly Hamer operates Mill River Studio in Great Barrington, said that most of the people who buy the Palisades Park poster are from New York and New Jersey. "Everyone who comes in to buy it has a story to tell about how they went there as children or had a first date there or met a husband or wife," says Ms. Wheeler, who used to live in Summit.
The New Jerseyfication of America is not just a matter of perception. Don Linkey, president of the Public Affairs Research Institute of New Jersey of Princeton, an independent, nonprofit organization that provides information on trends and issues affecting New Jersey, says there appears to be a growing interest in the state.
Mr. Linkey says he bases this on the sales of "The New Jersey Almanac," which the institute publishes. Since the almanac's publication in 19xx, it has sold out it first press run of 430 copies, and 600 copies of expanded second edition went on sale in the spring.
The book is crammed with facts and statistics about things like New Jersey taxes but also touches on such Garden State esoterica as the icon that spawned a hockey team, the Jersey Devil, and tons of books, mugs and sweat shirts. "There seems to be a strong interest in memorabilia," Mr. Linkey says.
Don't want a mug, a book, a sweatshirt, some decals, a lighthouse keychain? No interest in a collection of diner photos, pictures of boardwalks, jetties, fishing boats or garish gamblers? Then how about a CD called "Sounds for the Soul" that came out earlier this year with songs about New Jersey or by New Jersey artists, including "My Hometown" by Bruce Springsteen, "Jersey Girl," by Tom Waits, Mr. Gorca's, "I'm From New Jersey," Mr. Van Ronk's " Garden State Stomp" and "I Like Jersey Best!" sung by John Pizzarelli Jr.
Despite a spotty distribution network, including Barnes & Noble and the Internet, the CD quickly sold out 1,000 copies and is now in a second life with another 1,000.
The driving force behind the CD was Jane Roberti, a social worker from Edgewater who assembled a group of volunteers and managed to get permission to use the songs free of charge with the proceeds going to five New Jersey charities.
"People who live here are proud of the record and the state," Ms. says Roberti. "The interesting reaction was that people said they wanted to hear more and said, 'Let me tell you what other songs there are and maybe you can do it again.' "
As when a generation ago, Simon and Garfinkel were "counting the cars on the New Jersey Turnpike" while trying to unscramble the mysteries of 1960's America.
Despite the songs by such heavyweights as Bruce Springsteen and Tom Waits, the most popular cut turned out to be a commercial for the Palisades Amusement Park by Gladys Shelley that was broadcast incessantly on the radio, urging everyone to "come on over."
But when it comes to this latter-day love affair with New Jersey, there is more than just nostalgia at work. Consider the HBO hit "The Sopranos," a prime-time series about an organized crime boss who is undergoing psychoanalysis when he is not seeing to the family business.
David Chase, its creator, writer and sometime director, has insisted that all exteriors be shot in New Jersey. The result has been that New Jersey, in all its grittiness and beauty, has become as important a character as the actors on the screen.
Mr. Rockland, who co-wrote "Looking for America on the New Jersey Turnpike," said New Jersey has long had the same gritty down-to-earth image as the turnpike, which has always fascinated artists who are alternately repelled by and attracted to it.
No one captures this dichotomy better than Bruce Springsteen.
"I think Bruce Springsteen is a major figure in the New Jersey renaissance," says Mr. Rockland, "He didn't sing silly songs about wonderful and perfect New Jersey. Quite the contrary, he took those raunchy aspects -- which 'Saturday Night Live' and Woody Allen put down -- and made them attractive. Turnpike riding on a wet night beneath the refineries' glow out where great black rivers flow -- images of hell, but it's also one that's exciting. He said it's so bad, it's good."
