HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Shares Up for3d Consecutive Session, and Dow Gains 70.29

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks rose for a third consecutive session yesterday, led by Citigroup and other financial-sector issues which gained because of optimism that inflation is not picking up.
Investors still expect the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates a quarter of a percentage point when policy makers meet next Tuesday. But a report yesterday that the Consumer Price Index rose a seasonally adjusted three-tenths of 1 percent in July showed no unexpected increase in inflation. 
 "The trend is now back up" in the stock market, said Robert Bloom, chief investment officer for Friends, Ivory & Sime, which manages $4.3 billion in assets. "There's still no sign of troubling inflation numbers out there," suggesting that the Fed will not have to raise interest rates more than that quarter-point this year.
The Fed last changed the overnight lending rate on loans between banks June 30, raising it a quarter-point, to 5 percent.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 70.29 points, to 11,117.08. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 13.39 points, to 1,344.16. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 25.94, to 2,671.22. Three stocks rose for every two that fell on the New York Stock Exchange.
Major stock indexes are down from their July 16 closing highs because of investor concern that the Fed will raise rates several times in the coming months to stem inflation. Such increases could raise business costs and reduce earnings, thus making stocks less attractive investments.
With rate fears abating, though, yesterday's rally lifted the Dow to within 93 points of its high.
"Today's number wasn't a positive surprise; it was right in line" with forecasts, said Robert LaFleur, chief investment strategist for the Northern Trust Company of Chicago, which oversees $230 billion. Investors, he said, would not bid stocks higher until they knew how much interest rates would increase.
Trading was comparatively light. Roughly 691.5 million shares traded on the Big Board, less than the three-month daily average of 727 million.
Citigroup rose 1 5/16 a share, to 47 5/8; American Express gained 4 3/8, to 140 1/4, and Bank of America climbed 2 1/8, to 64 5/8. The prices of some financial stocks already reflect expected declines in earnings, Judah Kraushaar, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said.
He said that Citigroup, Mellon Bank and Wells Fargo were among his top picks. Mellon gained 7/8 a share, to 34 1/8, and Wells Fargo rallied 1 3/8, to 41 3/8.
Shares of Hewlett-Packard fell 5 3/4, to 104 1/2, after the company, the No. 2 computer maker, reported a profit that was a penny more than the analyst consensus of 80 cents a share but short of the most optimistic forecasts.
Several retailers' stocks fell, despite earnings reports that were better than expected. Home Depot Inc. lost 15/16 a share, to 63 1/16, after posting a profit of 44 cents a share, up from 31 cents a year earlier and surpassing the consensus estimate of 42 cents.
Limited Inc. fell 7/16 a share, to 44 3/8. The apparel retailer said it earned 26 cents a share before extraordinary items, double the profit in the quarter a year earlier and matching analyst estimates.
With the retailers' reports today, 475 of the companies in the S.& P. 500 have posted second-quarter results. Operating profit for the companies in the index grew 14.6 percent from a year earlier, the fastest pace since the first quarter of 1997, according to First Call/Thomson Financial, which tracks corporate earnings.

HEADLINE: Hoping for Repeat Success, Auto Makers Build a Hybrid

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Pickup trucks are popular and auto makers cannot build sport utility vehicles fast enough, so three auto makers have separately come to the same conclusion: it is time to start building sport utility pickups.
At an annual convention here to show dealers the offerings for the new model year, the Ford Motor Company introduced the Explorer Sport Trac, to go on sale in January. Like similar vehicles planned for next year by the General Motors Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company, the Sport Trac has the passenger compartment of a four-door sport utility vehicle but also has a short, open truck bed in back. 
 New classes of automobiles come along rarely, and it is a particularly unusual example of parallel automotive evolution for three companies to try to create the same new market at the same time. The coming proliferation of sport utility pickups is a sign that the light truck market is starting to resemble the car market, in which auto makers are forced to bear the cost of designing dozens of vehicles of various shapes and sizes to compete in ever-smaller market niches.
Joseph C. Collins Jr., Ford's brand manager for sport utility vehicles and minivans, said that 21 new sport utility vehicle models would be reaching the market in the next year and a half, so Ford had to come up with new designs like the Sport Trac to distinguish itself. "We're going to have a plethora of S.U.V.'s in the marketplace, and that's a problem and a challenge," he said.
Ford dealers here were enthusiastic about the new vehicle, saying it would appeal to people who perceived pickup trucks as too plain but still wanted to be able to carry big objects like chairs or camping equipment. "I can name 10 customers off the top of my head who are willing to buy this truck," said Laura Martin, a Ford dealer from Bremen, Ind., who attended the convention.
But auto analysts say that sport utility pickups are not different enough from sport utility vehicles and pickups to prompt Americans to flock to dealerships. "It isn't going to expand the market the way the Explorer did" when Ford introduced it in 1990, said James Hall, the president of industry analysis at Auto Pacific Inc., a market research firm based in Santa Ana, Calif. "It'll parasite sales from compact pickups and sport utilities."
Sport utility vehicles have become the lifeblood of the auto industry in recent years, with profits of $5,000 to $15,000 each, because they can be built cheaply like pickups but are in such demand that they can be sold with big markups. As more models crowd the market, these margins are starting to fall but remain far higher than for any other types of automobiles. The auto industry hopes that it can charge the same markups on sport utility pickups as on sport utility vehicles, in which case profit margins would actually improve for customers who switch to the new vehicles from pickups.
Sport utility pickups, like normal pickups and sport utility vehicles, will be regulated as light trucks, so they will be subject to more lenient fuel economy, pollution, safety and tax rules than cars. As is the case for many sport utility vehicles, Ford decided to produce the vehicle in 1996, before criticism of sport utility vehicles over safety and pollution concerns began to emerge.
Because most sport utility vehicles are essentially pickup trucks with fancy interiors and more sporty exteriors, the new sport utility pickups are not as expensive to design as new vehicles would be. The Sport Trac, for example, combines two Ford vehicles that already share a common underbody: the Explorer sport utility vehicle and the Ranger pickup.
The Sport Trac has more rear seat room than a Ranger, but only a four and a half foot bed, not the Ranger's six-foot bed.
The Sport Trac will be the first high-volume sport utility pickup on the market. Nissan has been working on a similarly sized sport utility pickup that will combine two of its vehicles that also have a common underbody, the Xterra sport utility vehicle and the Frontier pickup. According to industry consultants, G.M.'s Chevrolet, GMC and Cadillac units are working on combinations of a Suburban sport utility vehicle and a Silverado pickup. G.M. refuses to discuss the vehicles yet for competitive reasons.
The first sport utility pickup to reach the market will be yet another Ford Motor product, the Lincoln Blackwood, a combination of a Lincoln Navigator sport utility vehicle and an F-150 pickup. The Blackwood, which will come with a wood-lined bed and is expected to sell for $40,000 or more, is scheduled to go on sale later this autumn but is purely a niche vehicle, with Ford only planning to build a few thousand each year.
By contrast, the Sport Trac is likely to cost closer to $23,000, although no price has been set yet. Ford will market the Sport Trac to men and women in their 30's with outdoor life styles, said Jan Klug, Ford's marketing and advertising manager for Ford brand cars and light trucks, people who, "want to be able to throw all the stinky stuff in the back and have the people in the front."

 BODY:

ASIA
 
INDIA: NUCLEAR DOCTRINE -- India should adhere to its nuclear arms policy of "retaliation only" while building "credible minimum deterrence" with the ability to fire its weapons from the land, air or sea, according to a recommendation by the National Security Advisory Board. The 27-member panel was asked by the Government to suggest a "doctrine," or set of strategic goals, to guide a nuclear buildup. Barry Bearak (NYT)

Mr. Suharto, left, who is 78, was in power for 32 years until pressed to step down last year. Britain responded that it had no grounds for action against Li Hongzhi, who is based in New York, and that any visa application would be judged against normal British immigration laws. (Reuters)
 
SOUTH KOREA: DOG ON THE AGENDA -- A group of lawmakers introduced a bill to legalize sales of dog meat, arguing that this would allow the Government to oversee slaughtering methods and hygiene. Dog meat was banned during the 1988 Olympics in Seoul out of concern for the country's image, but enforcement has been lax. Samuel Len (NYT)
 
SOUTH KOREA: NORTHERN MISSILE THREAT -- Foreign Minister Hong Soon Young plans to visit Japan on Sunday to discuss joint measures to deal with North Korea's apparent preparations to launch a long-range ballistic missile. North Korea fired a missile a year ago that flew over Japan and into the Pacific, and fears have mounted that it is planning to test-fire another one. Samuel Len (NYT)
 
AFGHANISTAN: U.N. CRITICISM -- Secretary General Kofi Annan strongly condemned the forced displacement of civilians in Afghanistan as a result of the latest offensive by the Taliban militia. The United Nations refugee agency in Geneva said almost 20,000 civilians had fled the fighting and had poured into the capital in recent days, raising the number displaced by the two-week-old offensive to 100,000. (Reuters)

His comments came as Northern Ireland Secretary Mo Mowlam met with officials of the I.R.A.'s political wing, Sinn Fein, before her ruling on whether I.R.A. actions warrant expelling Sinn Fein from the peace effort. (Agence France-Presse)

Unicef said it doubted these were goods it had distributed in Iraq, but an Iraqi official told The Associated Press that they were donations being returned because they were of poor quality. HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Are thecash levels of emerging-market mutual funds telling a cautionary tale?

BYLINE: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. 

 BODY:
CURRENCY problems and a bank scandal in Indonesia. A political and economic mess in Russia. Military tensions in China. Dwindling interest in Latin American stocks.
The world's emerging markets are showing some small signs of stress. After soaring a collective 40 percent in the first half of the year, their stock markets have fallen 7 percent more recently, leaving investors to wonder whether the rally is over. 
 One other gauge also gives pause.
Mutual funds that invest in emerging markets now have the lowest levels of cash on hand in the three years that records for these funds have been kept. At the end of June -- the most recent reading -- the funds had cash equal to just 3.9 percent of their assets, or less than $700 million, according to the Investment Company Institute, the fund trade group.
Cash was probably further depleted as investors pulled about 2 percent of assets out of emerging markets funds in the four weeks ended last Wednesday, according to AMG Data Services, a fund tracking company in Arcata, Calif.
The redemptions suggest that fund managers have little money left to invest in stocks and to fuel a rally in emerging markets, and that they may even have felt pressure in recent weeks to sell stocks to meet investor redemptions.
The lack of cash "by itself is disturbing to me," said Henry Kaufman, the former Salomon Brothers chief economist who is now president of Henry Kaufman & Company, an economic forecaster in New York.
For many years mutual fund cash levels were considered an important contrary indicator of market performance, playing off the historic inability of portfolio managers to time the market. When cash levels were low -- meaning fund managers had put all their investors' money into stocks -- poor market performance often followed. Conversely, high levels of cash often signaled a market turnaround.
But many fund managers today are loath to go heavily into cash, no matter their instincts. Even acclaimed managers like the former Fidelity Magellan skipper Jeffrey N. Vinik and Foster S. Friess of the Brandywine Fund were harshly criticized for moving their funds into cash and missing out on strong gains in the stock market.
So, although cash levels remain important to managers, they have become less useful as market indicators. The United States stock market has risen even as cash has remained low at stock funds for three years running. The Investment Company Institute says cash levels at the average equity fund have ranged from 3.9 percent to 12.9 percent the last 30 years and now stand at about 5 percent.
But cash levels in emerging-markets funds have swung wildly while their domestic counterparts have held steady. Lately, those sharp moves have tended to move inversely with the performance of the Morgan Stanley Capital International emerging-markets index.
In September 1997, for example, cash in emerging-markets funds plunged to 5 percent, and the Morgan Stanley index subsequently fell by 25 percent in four months. In January 1998, cash increased to 11.5 percent, and the index rose by 15 percent. A few months later, in April, the index turned down again, though this time cash was at about 8 percent. But cash peaked at 14.3 percent of assets at the end of last August, right at the beginning of a major rally in the emerging stock markets.
Cash levels of funds within certain categories, like emerging-markets or small-cap funds, are still a valuable contrary indicator, Mr. Kaufman said, even if overall industry measures have proved less useful.
Moreover, he sees reasons other than plunging amounts of cash to be concerned about emerging markets. Given indications of improvement in the economies of Japan and other developed nations, these countries may begin to "reassert their demand for credit at a time when United States monetary policy may be tightening," Mr. Kaufman said, referring to concerns that the Federal Reserve will again raise interest rates later this month.
"That does not bode well for emerging countries," he said.
But the cash situation does not bother Arjun Divecha, who manages $1.3 billion in three Grantham Mayo Van Otterloo & Company emerging-markets funds, including two of the best performers in the category for the last year. "Those kinds of things are important in the short term, perhaps, but they have no bearing looking out five years," Mr. Divecha said. He added that emerging markets had been driven higher this year because of investments by locals -- not Americans.
Long term, Mr. Divecha said, emerging markets, particularly in Asia, should do well as the national economies improve and as more companies revamp and adopt shareholder-friendly policies. In the near future, however, the emerging markets will more likely track the domestic stock market. "If the U.S. market continues to pull back," he said, "they will be affected."

HEADLINE: Campaigning For Top Job At Unesco

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 17

 BODY:
An iconoclastic Egyptian working at the World Bank has begun a public campaign for the top job at Unesco, in defiance of the secrecy that now surrounds the choice.
The candidate, Ismail Serageldin, has a Harvard Ph.D. and has written books on topics as diverse as Shakespeare and biotechnology. He is being supported by a lengthening list of Middle Eastern intellectuals and some American scholars who would like to see Unesco get more international recognition. 
 Mr. Serageldin, an architect by training and now a vice president of the World Bank, has proved that he can give a higher profile to global scientific issues. In other words, he is good at publicity, a rare talent in the United Nations.
Americans will have no influence in the election of a new director general because the United States left the organization under President Reagan and has never rejoined.
Unesco -- officially the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization -- is based in Paris and has 2,500 employees there. It chooses a director general in a secret ritual worthy of Byzantium: officials will not release the names of candidates, thought to be 11. Mr. Serageldin is one of those but has the disadvantage of not being put forward by his home country, Egypt.
The cutoff date for nominations is Sept. 6, and in later weeks Unesco's board will meet to pick a nominee to send to the general membership for approval, also in secret.
In the informal system of geographic rotation that prevails, Asia -- a term that in this case encompasses countries from the Middle East to the Pacific -- is claiming the job, a six-year appointment. The two regional countries most actively promoting their candidates are Japan and Saudi Arabia.
The Japanese are as open as Mr. Serageldin about their nominee, Koichiro Matsuura, the Japanese Ambassador in Paris and a former director general of Tokyo's Economic Cooperation Bureau, which handles development issues worldwide. Something of an insider, he is chairman of Unesco's World Heritage Committee, which selects and tries to preserve important natural sites, architectural treasures and monuments.
The Saudis, by contrast, have been busy behind the scenes on behalf of their nominee, a diplomat and poet, Ghazi Al-Gosaibi, who is now Ambassador in London. To the distress of Mr. Serageldin and his backers, the Saudis have lined up most of the Arab world, including Egypt, behind Mr. Al-Gosaibi.
Mr. Serageldin openly called on Middle Eastern intellectuals to protest. "The writers, authors, intellectuals should be heard," he said in an interview. "I tell them, write to your leaders." His backers say that Saudi Arabia, with its cultural restrictions and lack of a free press, is hardly qualified to lead in the world of ideas.
Clovis Maksoud, a former Arab League envoy who now directs the Center for the Global South at American University in Washington, said he supports Mr. Serageldin because the independent Egyptian has a wide intellectual range. He is also well known in Washington.
"Whoever gets elected has to bring back the United States, because that is a major, major resource and also because it is a bridge between the global North and South in education, culture and so on -- the most revolutionary country in technology, communications and science," he said.
In 1984, Unesco -- at that time mismanaged, corrupt and toying with a New International Information Order that would have hobbled journalists -- was jolted by the withdrawal of the United States, Britain and Singapore. By 1987, it found a reforming director general in Federico Mayor of Spain. He improved management, even some of the sharpest critics say. Two years ago, Britain returned to the organization, which now has 185 members.
The Clinton Administration also decided to return, but President Clinton backed away after Unesco drew hostile criticism from Republicans, some outraged that an organization of foreigners had dared to designate American landmarks as World Heritage Sites or natural regions as important biospheres without consulting Congress.
"This was another case of the Clinton Administration not wanting to have a fight," said John Bolton, executive vice president of the American Enterprise Institute in Washington and a former Assistant Secretary of State for International Organizations in the Bush Administration.
Mr. Bolton opposes rejoining Unesco, saying it has not reformed enough. In any case, he said, the rest of the world has given up on American participation and no one is interested in Washington's views.

HEADLINE: Lender That Helps Immigrant Cabdrivers to Be Acquired by Larger Company

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Freshstart Venture Capital Corporation, one of the last remnants of the Nixon Administration's black capitalism program, agreed yesterday to be acquired by the Medallion Financial Corporation, the largest lender to taxi medallion owners in the city.
As a Specialized Small Business Investment Company, Freshstart is licensed to make most of its loans to economically disadvantaged borrowers. In return, investors who bought Freshstart shares using gains from the sale of other securities could defer capital gains taxes as long as they retained their Freshstart stock. 
 Although Federal officials had expected that these specialized lenders would help African-Americans, Freshstart made most of its loans to immigrant cabdrivers.
Since its founding in 1982 the company has made several thousand loans to immigrant cabdrivers, said Zindel Zelmanovitch, Freshstart's president.
But rising interest rates were squeezing the company, which borrows money and then lends it to cabdrivers at higher rates.
"Freshstart just never took off," said Neil Greenbaum, one of the largest brokers of taxi insurance in the city and a major shareholder in Freshstart.
Most cabdrivers rent a medallion, sometimes for as much as $115 per day. But those who bought their own medallions have benefited from the city's policy of tightly limiting the number, since the price rose to $232,000 in 1997 from $28,000 in 1970, according to the Taxi and Limousine Commission.
Since 1997, however, the prices have fallen slightly, and the current price is $215,000 to $220,000, Mr. Zelmanovitch said.
Medallion prices have been depressed by rising insurance costs as well as a police policy of increased attention to cabdrivers, who face more fines for motor vehicle violations. Their liability insurance, for example, now must cover $300,000 per accident, up from $15,000.
Medallion has been somewhat insulated from the recent rise in short-term interest rates because it has the financial strength to issue its own notes to investors, said Andrew Murstein, the company's president and a third-generation medallion financier.
In the last three years, Medallion has acquired 11 other small finance companies that specialized in loans to cabdrivers, minority radio station owners and other niche commercial lending markets.
Mr. Murstein said he has been diversifying Medallion Financial's commercial loan base. Freshstart "adds different elements to our portfolio because we are more of a wholesale lender to taxi fleets and they have a good book of loans to individual taxi owners."
Freshstart shares closed yesterday at $4.50, up 62 1/2 cents, while Medallion Financial closed at $18.785, down 25 cents.

HEADLINE: Data Show Inflation Is Still in Check, Easing Worries About Rates

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
The United States economy may be rocking and rolling, but inflation remains remarkably well behaved.
That was the main message from a fresh batch of Government data on consumer prices, industrial activity and home building released yesterday. The new evidence further soothed investors who have been worrying that the Federal Reserve might raise short-term interest rates more than a quarter-point next week to slow the economy. Bond and stock prices rallied. 
 The Consumer Price Index -- a broad measure of inflation that reflects the prices of imports and services as well as those of domestically produced goods -- rose just three-tenths of a percent last month after registering no increase at all in May and June, in line with forecasts. Better still, most of the increase reflected another big rise in cigarette prices and higher energy costs, which were widely expected and raised everything from gasoline prices to airline fares.
Best of all, the so-called core rate of inflation, which excludes volatile food and energy, was up only two-tenths of a percent in July, despite the jump in transportation and tobacco prices. That core rate has been creeping up more slowly than at the same point last year, 1.7 percent compared with 2.4 percent.
"We knew energy was going to be up," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at Standard & Poor's DRI in Lexington, Mass. "There's nothing here that looks alarming."
At the same time, two highly cyclical sectors of the economy, manufacturing and housing, continued to expand briskly last month. Industrial production, which had been merely inching up earlier in the summer, surged seven-tenths of a percent in July. While the nationwide heat wave accounted for heavy energy use and a bumper crop of air-conditioners and fans, overall manufacturing output rose robustly, by six-tenths of a percent, despite a drop in car production. And construction of single-family homes and apartments, which cooled in June as mortgage rates climbed higher, rebounded sharply last month.
"What that's telling you is that even the interest-sensitive sectors aren't cooling off with higher rates," said Roseanne Cahn, chief equities economist at Credit Suisse First Boston. "The pickup in manufacturing is plenty strong, too."
Yesterday's reports bolstered investor sentiment that the Fed would not raise the overnight bank lending rate, known as the Federal funds target rate, more than a quarter of a percentage point. In the wake of a strong jobs report earlier this month, there had been speculation on Wall Street that the Fed might raise the rate by as much as a half-point. But a report on Friday showing a modest increase in prices at the wholesale level in July combined with yesterday's figures eased those concerns. Even a quarter-point increase is no longer regarded as a sure thing.
"It's 50-50 whether there will be a tightening this month," Ms. Latta said. "If I had to put money on it, I guess I'd put my money on an October tightening. But it's such a close call."
At the moment, the inflation picture is one of crosscurrents. On one hand, a number of the forces that clearly helped hold inflation down in the past are fading. The slump in Japan and Europe, which drove down world prices for energy and other raw materials, seems to be over. The strong dollar, which made imports a bargain for Americans, has lately been weakening. The wholesale shift by employers to health maintenance organizations, which drastically slowed the rise in health care costs, is almost complete. At the same time, as Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has emphasized again and again, the United States labor market remains extraordinarily tight, with unemployment at a 30-year low and job growth strong.
Rapid productivity gains are, however, holding down production costs and there is very little indication that strong demand is giving corporations much leeway to pass cost increases on to consumers in the form of higher prices. While an earlier report by the National Association of Purchasing Management showed that most manufacturers say they are paying higher prices, few report that they are receiving higher prices.
One exception, of course, is energy, which posted the biggest increase in July since April, 2.1 percent. As a result, transportation costs also leaped. Gasoline prices jumped 4.3 percent in July, and air fares surged 6.5 percent. Another exception was tobacco prices, which surged 3.3 percent. The price of imports -- about one-fifth of everything American consumers buy -- are also going up.
But the prices of other goods are falling or rising more slowly than in recent months. Food was up just two-tenths of a percent in July. Housing costs, which account for nearly 40 percent of consumer outlays, rose just one-tenth of a percent in July, half the June rate. Medical care costs rose three-tenths of a percent, a bit slower than in June. And, despite the dominance of imports, clothing prices continued to fall in July, dropping a hefty nine-tenths of a percent.
The lack of pricing power is not preventing businesses from producing more. The July gain in industrial production was the biggest monthly advance since March. Excluding cars, manufacturing output was up nearly a percentage point. American factories are pumping out lots of big-ticket items for American homes, including appliances, home computers and, of course, air-conditioners. But they are also churning out a lot more business equipment, especially computers, which are up 15.2 percent from a year ago, but also heavy industrial gear.
"The slump in manufacturing that we saw early in the year is over," Ms. Latta said. "Exports have been deteriorating, so this indicates very strong domestic demand."
The biggest surprise in yesterday's numbers, given that mortgage rates recently climbed to 8.15 percent, was the jump in new housing. After dipping in June, housing starts rose 5.7 percent in July, to a seasonally adjusted rate of 1.661 million units, soaring in the West and posting solid gains in the South and Northeast. The rebound was particularly surprising given that contractors nationwide have been reporting shortages of both labor and building materials. And even more so because mortgage rates have lately climbed over 8 percent to their highest level in two years.
Ms. Latta pointed out that many buyers were rushing to lock in deals because they expected rates to move even higher while others were switching to adjustable-rate mortgages.
"That means that the rise in rates doesn't have as big an impact as you might think," she said.

HEADLINE: AT&T's Planned Mediaone Deal Poses Testfor U.S. Cable Policy

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
As two Federal agencies review the AT&T Corporation's $58 billion bid to buy Mediaone Group, they face the central question of whether the combination is, in essence, too large to block.
AT&T executives say the acquisition is needed to establish a cable network so vast and powerful that it will provide high-speed Internet service, cable TV and telephone service that can compete with the regional Bell companies. Those companies have so far kept newcomers from challenging them in their local phone markets. 
 But three consumer groups said today that the cost of opening the local markets was not worth the price and urged the Government to kill the deal because it would permit AT&T to dominate both the cable television industry and the market for high-speed Internet service.
In papers filed at the Federal Communications Commission and the Justice Department, the groups asserted that the proposed acquisition would violate a raft of antitrust and telecommunications rules intended to limit concentration of ownership in the cable and other industries.
"Regulators should never accept a massive concentration in one market as a condition for increasing local competition in another," Mark N. Cooper, research director for the Consumer Federation of America, said. "This merger breaks all the rules."
AT&T's deal for Mediaone, the fourth-largest cable operator, is quickly becoming an important new test case of antitrust policy. It has also prompted a re-examination of the current cable ownership rules, rules that have been suspended for seven years because of litigation between regulators and the industry.
While AT&T has recently set out to have some of those rules rewritten, consumer groups maintain that the deal would enable AT&T to dominate two markets. "This merger will result in inflated cable and broadband Internet service prices for consumers and thwart the development of vibrant competition in these markets," the three groups -- Consumers Union, the Consumer Federation of America and the Media Access Project -- wrote in a letter to the Justice Department today.
In response, AT&T executives reasserted the central argument they made in May when the deal was announced: By growing so quickly, the company will benefit millions of telephone customers nationwide by using the newly acquired cable lines to break into local telephone markets that have been dominated by a handful of Bell companies fiercely resistant to competition.
"It's an extreme stretch to suggest that there's any antitrust issue here," said James W. Cicconi, general counsel and head of government relations at AT&T. "There is no competitor to the services we are offering that is being taken out here. Far from it: the whole purpose is to provide local competition."
"We will be providing competition where it doesn't now exist," he said.
Federal communications guidelines prohibit a single company from holding a 5 percent active interest or 10 percent passive interest in companies whose wires come close to 30 percent or more of the nation's homes.
But seven years ago, a Federal judge threw out some of those rules in a case in which AT&T is not involved, and the F.C.C. voluntarily stayed the enforcement of those guidelines. That case is now on appeal, and agency officials say they are reviewing cable-ownership rules, a review they hope to complete before deciding about the AT&T deal.
Consumer groups have contended that after the merger with Mediaone, AT&T's cable market penetration would reach 57 percent of the nation's households. Executives at AT&T, which completed its acquisition of Tele-Communications Inc., the No. 2 cable operator, earlier this year, have said they think the market penetration would not be anywhere near that level. But they have also told analysts they think it would be more than the 30 percent permitted under the rules that have been suspended.
The company has asked the F.C.C. both to raise the 30 percent threshold and to change its ownership attribution rules so that a small ownership interest in a cable company would count less than it now does.
At the Justice Department, Federal antitrust rules written during the Reagan and Bush Administrations generally make any proposed merger suspect if it increases an economic index used by the Government by 50 to 100 points.
But an analysis by the three consumer groups says that the AT&T-Mediaone deal would raise the index, the Hirschman Herfindahl Index, in many markets by 700 to 3,000 points, even including proposed spinoffs that AT&T has already announced.
"AT&T's proposed acquisition is a blatant blatant violation of our nation's antitrust laws and our nation's competition laws," said Gene Kimmelman, co-director of the Washington office of Consumers Union.
Mr. Cicconi of AT&T disputed the consumer groups' figures. He also said they had distorted the true size of the market and failed to recognize that AT&T competes with other high-speed Internet services offered by the regional Bells and with satellite broadcasting companies.
To block a merger on antitrust grounds, "one has to show that market power is being used to constrain competitors, which clearly is not the case here," Mr. Cicconi said.

HEADLINE: Study Warns Against Grand Transit Plans

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
With huge investments in new subway lines under consideration by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, an analysis released yesterday by New York City fiscal experts finds that such improvements may not be within the transit agency's financial reach because of looming budget deficits.
The analysis, by the city's Independent Budget Office, a nonpartisan research group that advises the City Council and other elected officials, challenges a widespread assumption by transit advocates and some public officials who say a strong city economy, booming tourism and robust growth in ridership have paved the way for large new infusions of cash into the subway system. 
 Whatever fiscal basis now exists for that optimism, the report says, will be squashed if the city economy sours. Because increased ridership on the subways and buses has been fostered, in part, by fare discounts, it says the amount of money raised from customer fares has declined.
The system's economic health is being propped up by borrowing and the economic windfall of a burst in tax revenue, resulting from the strong economy, that flows to the M.T.A. from such sources as property transfer fees and real estate taxes. But if the economy worsens, lower tax collections could reverse the transit system's fortunes, leading to deficits, service cuts or fare increases, the city's economic analysts said yesterday.
"People might have the impression that it should be easy to add service and expand the subways," said Douglas Criscitello, director of the Independent Budget Office, which was created as a fiscal watchdog as part of the revisions to the New York City Charter in 1996.
"However, potentially large operating deficits over the next few years mean that additional revenues or operating budget savings would be needed to enhance the system," he said.
The report says such operating deficits will not occur immediately -- it forecasts that New York City Transit, the arm of the M.T.A. responsible for buses and subways, will continue to benefit from its tax windfall and end 1999 with a surplus of $49 million to $91 million.
But from 2000 through 2003, the report predicts, the tax receipts dedicated to pay for bus and subway operations will fall off, leading to a deficit that could reach $890 million in 2003, even without major investments in new subway lines.
Tom Kelly, a spokesman for the M.T.A., declined yesterday to respond to the details of the study, other than to say that its forecasts "may be exaggerated" in both their optimism for a 1999 surplus and their pessimism over deficits in the future.
"Nobody here has been expecting that we would run a surplus ad infinitum," he said, adding that uncertainty over the economy and tax revenue was being taken into account by the M.T.A.'s planners.
Although the report is not the first to cast doubt on the financial prospects of the transportation authority -- similar warnings have been made for a year by Wall Street analysts -- it comes at a critical time for the M.T.A. By October, the agency is expected to unveil a five-year spending plan, which many transit groups and riders are hoping will provide for the first large-scale subway construction program in decades.
Among the proposals under study by the M.T.A. are a new Second Avenue subway, costing $3 billion or more. Another project, paid for through a combination of funds from the M.T.A. and Federal subsidies, would extend Long Island Rail Road service through a new Manhattan tunnel to Grand Central Station. Other projects on the list include an expansion of subway lines in Queens to La Guardia Airport, and extension of the No. 7 Line from Times Square to the far west side of Manhattan.
Although the study may dampen enthusiasm that the M.T.A. can afford all, or any, of the proposals, some experts said it merely underscored the need for greater commitments of financial support to mass transit from the city and state.
Even as the amount of money raised through customer fares on the city's subways and buses has declined, the report says riders continue to pay for a greater share of their service than people using mass transit systems in other big cities.
It says subway and bus fares cover 66 percent of the New York City Transit budget. That contrasts with the mass transit systems in Washington, where fares account for 50 percent of the budget; in Chicago, where they cover 46 percent; and in Boston, where they cover 29 percent.
The study was requested by Councilman A. Gifford Miller, who represents the Upper East Side and has been an advocate of several proposals for subway expansion, particularly a new Second Avenue line.
Although the conclusions reached in the study seem to shed doubt on how the such projects can be financed, he said it underscored the need for government support. "The bottom line is that we are not going to meet the needs of an expanding economy and mass transit system unless the city pitches in, and challenges the state and Federal government to do so as well," he said.

HEADLINE: Robbery String Linked to Man By an Odd Scar

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
An upper Manhattan man was arrested yesterday in connection with 23 armed robberies in the Bronx, upper Manhattan and Harlem after what officials described as "good, old-fashioned detective work."
The man, Anthony Stevenson, 38, was arrested on robbery and gun charges stemming from five Bronx robberies after several victims picked him out of lineups, said Capt. Geryl McCarthy, the head of the major crimes section of the Bronx Detective Bureau. 
 The lead that eventually cracked the case came after the most recent robbery, on Thursday, when a witness spotted several numbers of the license plate of the getaway car, Captain McCarthy said. Detectives looked up the motor vehicle records for more than 100 cars with the same few numbers that were registered at addresses near the robberies.
As they narrowed the list down to drivers with dark-colored sedans, they checked whether any of the registered owners matched the description of the robber, the police said. Then they checked whether any of those people had arrest records.
They came up with Mr. Stevenson, whose mug shot was on file because he was charged with fare-beating in Harlem in April, Captain McCarthy said. The photo strongly resembled a police sketch of the robbery suspect that had been drawn with the help of victims, she said. Both showed a half-moon-shaped scar under the suspect's eye, she said.
When the police went to Mr. Stevenson's apartment in upper Manhattan on Monday night, she said, they found a .380-caliber handgun whose serial number had been defaced. They then brought him in for questioning, and he was arrested today after being placed in several lineups.
An investigator said Mr. Stevenson told detectives that he had been unemployed since 1990 and had begun his armed robberies after he lost his welfare benefits. He told them he needed to support a child, who does not live with him.
Captain McCarthy said that the police estimate that Mr. Stevenson stole a total of $3,000 in the robberies. Most of his targets were Chinese restaurants, she said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stress in Emerging Markets Trims the Year's Big Gains
The world's emerging markets are showing some signs of stress, from currency problems and a bank scandal in Indonesia to a political and economic mess in Russia, military tensions in China and dwindling interest in Latin American stocks. 
 After soaring a collective 40 percent in the first half of the year, their stock markets have fallen 7 percent more recently, and the mutual funds that invest in them have little cash on hand. Market Place. Page C8.
 
Black Analyst Sues Morgan Stanley
A black financial analyst on extended leave from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter has sued the firm, accusing it of racial discrimination and adding to its legal burden. Morgan Stanley did not comment on the suit. C7.
 
A New Design: Sport Utility Pickups
Ford, General Motors and Nissan are capitalizing on the profitability and popularity of pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles by building sport utility pickups. C2.
 
Boeing to Cooperate in U.S. Case
Boeing agreed to cooperate with a Labor Department investigation into charges of racial discrimination at several of its plants. A17.
 
Inflation Tame, Stocks Advance
Led by Citigroup and other financial-sector issues that gained on optimism that inflation is not growing, stocks climbed for the third straight day. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 70.29 points, to 11,117.08, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index 13.39 points, to 1,344.16, and the Nasdaq composite index 25.94 points, to 2,671.22. C8.
 
Bonds rallied sharply as traders concluded that the Federal Reserve would raise rates only slightly. The yield on the 30-year issue fell to 6.01 percent from 6.08 percent. C8.

Half the catch of North Pacific white fish comes from 11 Russian supertrawlers, but the business is threatened by the Russian Government's decision to void a contract with a joint Russian-United States venture. C4.

HEADLINE: Wildlife Agency Objects To Cranberry Bog Plan

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Aug. 17

 BODY:
New Jersey cranberry growers and Federal environmental regulators have reached agreement for the first time on a plan to expand the state's cranberry bogs into sensitive wetlands. But today, officials of another Federal agency said the proposal, released without much fanfare last month, was objectionable to them.
The draft agreement between Federal environmental regulators and the growers seeks to end nearly five years of feuding among regulators, environmental groups and farmers over attempts to set guidelines for an increase of up to 300 acres in cranberry growing areas statewide. 
 Twice in that time the Federal Government has rejected other proposed expansion plans, buoying environmentalists but sinking the growers' efforts to maintain New Jersey's status as the third-largest cranberry growing state, after Massachusetts and Wisconsin.
But the United States Fish and Wildlife Service says the expansion guidelines "are by far the most environmentally damaging" proposals that have been offered in those five years. And the agency is calling for a more detailed study of their impact on water quality, wildlife and rare and endangered species.
Ed Henry, a spokesman for the wildlife agency, said the proposed agreement contradicted the Environmental Protection Agency's statutory goals of no net loss in wetlands, its mandate to avoid all wetlands impacts whenever possible and the requirement that there be mitigation and replacement when such avoidance is not possible.
If it receives final approval, the draft agreement will take effect on Jan. 1. The agency's objection sets the stage for a battle pitting it against growers, New Jersey officials who have long supported the compact, a 3,500-acre industry that pumps $25 million a year into the economy, and officials of the Federal environmental agency.
The wildlife agency also contends that, according to a recent aerial survey, the very group of growers with whom Federal regulators had been negotiating terms for expansion had illegally expanded their bogs even as the talks were going on.
Federal and state environmental officials said they were still reviewing the charges of illegal expansion, and acknowledged that there was a significant difference of opinion between themselves and the wildlife agency over the conditions under which expansion should be allowed. But, one Federal official said, the environmental regulators would hold firm on the new conditions for expansion. Mario Paula, an environmental scientist in the agency's New York regional office, said the agreement satisfied requirements that expansion have "minimal adverse impact."
Joseph Darlington, a cranberry grower in Browns Mills, applauded the draft agreement, saying: "What they came out with was probably the best that cranberry growers could hope for. I think we will all accept this because it looks at the bigger picture and balances out the economic, human and environmental factors."
Under the plan, growers would be allowed to expand 300 acres at a rate of 60 acres per year so that any environmental problems that resulted could be detected and dealt with quickly. The growers had originally sought a quicker pace of expansion, starting with 100 acres in the first year.
The agreement would also place stricter requirements on clearing forested wetlands and even stricter barriers on forested wetlands where the rare Atlantic white cedar predominates. Even then, the growers would have to mitigate that loss by replacing those wetlands and forested growth on an acre-for-acre basis elsewhere in the state.
The E.P.A.-endorsed agreement, however, lets stand the Fish and Wildlife Service's nearly absolute veto power of any expansion that can be proved to adversely affect anything covered by the Endangered Species Act. While several species of plants, frogs and turtles included on the list of federally protected life forms thrive in the wetlands of New Jersey, exactly how and whether they will be affected by the expansion of cranberry bogs is not yet known.
But Mr. Darlington noted that this veto power might prolong the impasse on any expansion by shifting the battlefield from the E.P.A. to the Fish and Wildlife Service.
"In one way, I understand E.P.A. deferring to them on endangered species, but our experience with Fish and Wildlife is that they have made a crusade of opposing expansion and are unwilling to listen," he said. "The chance of getting a permit to expand is about zero when an endangered species is involved."
As for the claim by the Fish and Wildlife Service that some farmers have illegally expanded their growing area, State Department of Environmental Protection officials noted that one of the parcels had received approval for the expansion after a nine-year process in which the wildlife agency had been involved. The other major parcel is the subject of a state enforcement action.

HEADLINE: Legal Pioneers Seek to Raise Lowly Status of Animals

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
More than a generation after civil rights and environmental lawyers took their battles to the courts, there are now lawyers who say they are following in those footsteps on behalf of clients with names like Freckles and Muffin and Rainbow.
Fighting for creatures like performing orangutans and dogs used in experimentation, the lawyers are creating a new field of animal law with far more ambitious goals than traditionally weak anti-cruelty laws. They are filing novel lawsuits and producing new legal scholarship to try to chip away at a fundamental principle of American law that animals are property and have no rights. 
 These lawyers are more than brief-writing counterparts of animal activists who throw paint on fur wearers.
And they are influenced by developing scientific and ethical scholarship showing animals to have far higher levels of cognition and social development than previously believed.
This summer, the fledgling field of animal law took an important step toward legitimacy when two of the country's most prestigious law schools, Harvard and Georgetown, announced that they would offer courses in animal law for the first time.
The animal lawyers have also gained a handful of court victories in recent years, the most important of which was a Federal appeals court decision last year that gave a human zoo visitor the right to sue to get companionship for chimpanzees. And since 1994, legislatures across the country have given these lawyers a potent new tool by sharply upgrading animal cruelty crimes to felonies from misdemeanors.
"We have created a field of law," said Joyce Tischler, executive director of the Animal Legal Defense Fund, an organization based in Petaluma, Calif., with an annual budget of $3 million. "We've learned our trade, and now we are focusing on the next steps."
Critics ridicule animal law as the latest example of absurdity in the legal system. They see it as an attack on the economic system's reliance on animal products that could wreak havoc in the courts.
"Would even bacteria have rights?" asked Richard A. Epstein, a professor at the University of Chicago Law School. "There would be nothing left of human society if we treated animals not as property but as independent holders of rights."
The animal lawyers say the idea that animals are mere property evolved centuries before modern notions of some animals as sentient beings with perceptions and even emotions. The lawyers have been moving on many different fronts to establish precedents that they say could provide a foundation for direct attacks on the property status of animals.
In civil cases involving veterinary malpractice or pet deaths, some lawyers have won verdicts and settlements of $15,000 or more. Lawyers have also had success in battling what they call execution orders, the sort of routine euthanasia that occurs when dogs bite people.
In Washington, D.C., two lawyers who had worked in Ralph Nader organizations started a firm specializing in animal law six years ago. The firm, Meyer & Glitzenstein, now with five lawyers, handles complex cases involving animal issues, like filings with Federal agencies concerning standards for the treatment of circus elephants.
Yesterday, the firm's lawyers announced an important victory in a legal battle that had gone to the Pennsylvania Supreme Court. The organizers of an annual pigeon shoot in Hegins, Pa., canceled the event. The animal lawyers were seeking an injunction to stop the shoot, which has taken place for 65 years, on grounds of animal cruelty.
Last year, a groundbreaking ruling was issued in a case that involved an apparently lonely chimpanzee named Barney. In its decision, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit gave a zoo visitor the legal standing to sue the Government to try to force it to issue regulations assuring chimpanzees group living arrangements and appropriate amenities.
The suit involving Barney (and a female monkey named Samantha who was alone in a cage near Barney's at the Long Island Game Farm Park and Zoo) was filed under amendments to the Federal Animal Welfare Act that had received little judicial interpretation. The amendments, passed in 1985, said conditions of confinement must assure "the psychological well being of primates."
Valerie J. Stanley, a lawyer who worked on the case, said the law "does not mean you throw them a toy and you give them an orange once a month." The decision has been widely viewed as giving people new powers to challenge the living conditions of animals that are publicly displayed.
The suit is still being fought in Federal court, but Barney was shot to death by a zoo employee in 1996 after he escaped from his cage, bit someone and uprooted a sign, which he threw at a merry-go-round.
Some lawyers say they are in the field to advance their ideology, but some note that it is an area of legal practice that could be profitable. The lawyers in private practice charge fees to human clients, like pet owners. Some groups, like the Animal Legal Defense Fund, pay salaries to staff lawyers. And lawyers for industry groups that battle the animal lawyers say millions of dollars are available from animal welfare groups to pay for work that advances their goals.
Critics of the animal law movement, including livestock groups and representatives of pharmaceutical companies that rely on animal experimentation, say such rulings are an alarming foot in the courthouse door for advocates of animal rights.
"If the goal is to use the courts to put us out of business," said Steve L. Kopperud, president of the Animal Industry Foundation, a livestock and poultry group, "they've got a pretty effective tool. I look at this as an abuse of the system."
Lawyers concerned with animal issues say civil rights and environmental lawyers faced ridicule, too. In interviews, several of them noted parallels with those who began the fights for integration and clean air.
The new legal field, for example, has a single scholarly journal, Animal Law, which has been published for five years by the same law school that published the first environmental law journal 30 years ago: Northwestern School of Law of Lewis & Clark College in Portland, Ore.
Animal Law serves as a manifesto for lawyers in the field. Steven M. Wise, a Boston lawyer who is to teach the course this spring at Harvard Law School, has argued in articles in the journal that rights to bodily integrity and liberty should be given first to chimpanzees and bonobos because they are so similar to people. Mr. Wise, who once listed a captive dolphin named Rainbow as the plaintiff in a suit against an aquarium, is one of a group of perhaps 30 lawyers across the country who spend most of their time on animal issues. Hundreds more, including lawyers at some of the country's largest law firms, handle animal cases on a volunteer basis.
Mr. Wise, who taught animal law this summer at John Marshall Law School in Chicago, said the legal work now being done on behalf of animals was paving the way for change.
"It is a long-term strategy," he said, "to show that animals are not just things for our use."
One example, he said, is a case he is handling in a Massachusetts appeals court on behalf of the owners of seven pet sheep who were killed by two dogs owned by a neighbor.
Because animals are property under American law, damages are generally limited to their market value. But in some cases lawyers have persuaded courts to award added damages for loss of companionship or for the emotional distress of the owner when a pet is killed.
The case of the dead sheep, Mr. Wise said, could help establish that market value is not adequate compensation. The sheep owners, a childless taxidermist and his wife, Mr. Wise said, were attached to the animals. "I am talking about people who let the sheep in the house and baked them muffins," Mr. Wise said.
The strategy of lawyers practicing animal law has included a campaign to increase the criminal penalties for animal cruelty. In 1994, all but six states regarded such violations as misdemeanors, punishable by small fines and short jail terms. Now 27 states make violations felonies, with fines up to $100,000 and prison terms up to 10 years.
Lawyers often provide prosecutors with legal assistance to make such prosecutions stick. In one case, involving cruelty to turtles, lawyers provided a veterinarian as an expert witness. The veterinarian testified that elevated heart and respiration rates showed that turtles do suffer.
Anti-cruelty laws typically declare that people cannot be prosecuted for standard farming practices, like beef slaughtering. But there have been some felony prosecutions involving malicious mistreatment or torture of farm animals.
Last month in northeastern North Carolina, a district attorney, Frank R. Parrish, announced the state's first felony animal cruelty indictment. The case, which involved workers at a hog farm, was taken to a grand jury after an animal welfare group, People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, gave Mr. Parrish videotape that it had secretly recorded.
Members of the group and their lawyers said the tape clearly showed hogs being beaten and skinned alive.
The farm workers, who face sentences of up to 15 months in prison if convicted, have not yet entered pleas. But the manager of the farm, Fred Cunningham, issued a statement saying that the farm was committed to humane practices and that scenes on the tape "seem certain to be staged."
Neither the farm nor Dr. Cunningham, a veterinarian, face charges.
Some lawyers say cases like the one involving the hog farm are legal milestones. But even among animal lawyers there are sharp disagreements over strategy.
Prof. Gary L. Francione, who teaches animal law at Rutgers University, said in an interview that animal lawyers should be much more aggressive than they are.
Professor Francione, once a law clerk to Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court, said they should, for example, file suit on behalf of gorillas, asserting that "they should be declared to be 'persons' under the Constitution," with constitutional rights.
For the moment, most animal lawyers are adopting a more incremental approach. The Animal Legal Defense Fund, for example, has a staff lawyer who spends her time studying precedents that could be used on behalf of animals, including the legal steps taken in the emancipation of slaves.
Although there are similarities to other legal movements, the animal law movement has differences, too, some animal lawyers say. For example, several lawyers, like Ms. Tischler of the defense fund, said they no longer ate animal products.
"My commitment," she said, "is I don't eat my clients."

HEADLINE: The Fairness of Women

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Alejandro Gertz Manero, Mexico City's chief of police, explains his decision to turn the city's notoriously corrupt traffic enforcement over to female officers by saying simply, "I trust them more" (Week in Review, Aug. 15). 
 Mr. Gertz need not rely solely on vague intuitions or anecdotal evidence to rationalize his policy. A growing body of work in the social sciences is finding that women are more likely than men to exhibit "helping" behavior, vote based on social issues, score more highly on "integrity tests," take stronger stances on ethical behavior and behave more generously when faced with economic decisions.
While it is unclear whether the relative honesty of women is biological or environmental, it certainly appears that women really are the fairer sex!
 
RAYMOND FISMAN
New York, Aug. 16, 1999
 
The writer is an assistant professor of finance and economics at Columbia University School of Business.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
New Jersey Jobless Rate

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The New Jersey unemployment rate dipped to 4.8 percent last month, State Labor Department officials said yesterday in Trenton. It is the first drop in the state jobless rate since February. Employers in the state created about 5,500 jobs during July.
"All the indicators, in both the state and nation, show the economy's strong," State Labor Commissioner Mel Gelade said. "Inflation fears have calmed, all sectors seem to be adding jobs, and more people are coming into the job market. It's a healthy, strong economy." 
 The 4.8 percent unemployment rate was slightly below the 4.9 percent recorded in June. The rate had steadily risen since it reached 4.1 percent in February, the only month during Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's time in office that the state rate has been lower than the national rate.

A New Accent on Business

BYLINE: By ABBY ELLIN 

 BODY:
The State University of New York at Stony Brook has created a new position typically reserved for corporations: vice president for economic development. The job entails fostering relationships between the university and local businesses, said Shirley Strum Kenny, Stony Brook's president.
Yakov Shamash, dean of the College of Engineering and Applied Sciences, will assume those duties as well as oversee two on-campus sites, one focused on software and one on anything from technology to lyme disease vaccines. The sites are incubators for 36 startup companies at which undergraduate and graduate students will work as interns or employees. 
 "We have many projects that we collaborate with the business community," Dr. Kenny said, "and economic development is giving a real push to this endeavor and making it one of our top campus missions, right up there with education and research. To be a great university we must be a great local university. It's really all about getting new industries on Long Island." ABBY ELLIN
