SECTION: Section A;Page 1;Column 2;National Desk

LENGTH: 2744 words

HEADLINE: ON THE RECORD: Governor Bush on Crime;
Bush's Law and Order Adds Up to Tough and Popular

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
Law and order has always been part of George W. Bush's politics.
Just as his father, George Bush, benefited from televised images of the furloughed murderer-rapist Willie Horton to attack Michael S. Dukakis in the 1988 race for President, Mr. Bush ran for governor of Texas in 1994 with a series of grainy black-and-white commercials depicting a man abducting a woman at gun point in a parking garage and, a moment later, a police officer draping a blanket over the woman's body. 
 Asserting that his Democratic opponent, Gov. Ann Richards, was soft on crime, Mr. Bush promised to get tougher with criminals. That stand helped him win, and an examination of his record over the five years he has been Governor shows he has been consistent in pressing a law-and-order agenda. Mr. Bush has presided over the nation's largest prison-building program and a record number of executions. At the same time, breaking ranks with many law-enforcement officials, Mr. Bush has signed laws expanding the right of Texans to carry guns and has opposed gun-control legislation.
"For Governor Bush, gun control is not yet part of crime control," said Bruce Elfant, the Travis County constable, one of the officials who have come to see gun control as important as fighting drugs and gangs in the battle against crime.
In a conservative state where being "Texas tough" is high praise, Mr. Bush's positions have been popular.
"The reason Ann Richards was ousted was her opposition to the right to carry handguns and being soft on crime," said State Representative Suzanna Gratia Hupp, a Republican from Lampasas, expressing a view shared by Republicans and Democrats alike. "George W. Bush is a real Texan, someone who is very down to earth and tough on crime."
How Governor Bush's record on criminal justice, particularly gun control, will appeal to voters in other regions remains to be tested as he campaigns for the Republican nomination for President. In Texas, experts on criminal justice are studying another question: whether his policies are responsible for the state's drop in crime.
Mr. Bush declined several requests for an interview on criminal-justice issues. But his spokeswoman, Karen Hughes, said his initiatives, especially those toughening punishment for juvenile offenders and making convicts serve longer terms, had produced a 20 percent drop in the Texas crime rate. "Governor Bush believes in tough laws and long sentences to keep criminals off the streets," Ms. Hughes said.
But according to the Texas Department of Criminal Justice, crime had already fallen 25 percent under Governor Richards, from 1991 to 1994, as she began the state's multibillion-dollar prison-building program.
"I always thought it was utter nonsense for Bush to attack Richards for being soft on crime, when she presided over this huge prison buildup," said Steve Martin, a consultant on prisons for Federal courts and a former chief counsel for the Department of Criminal Justice.
Since Mr. Bush took office in 1995, crime rates have also fallen as much, or more, in most other states as they have in Texas. This has led governors and mayors across the country to take credit, even as many experts point out that the widespread decline in crime rates makes it less likely that any one policy can be credited. Longer prison sentences are one factor in the overall decrease, experts say, but so are an improved economy, a decline in the use of crack, new police strategies and changing attitudes among young people.
Even many of Mr. Bush's Democratic opponents acknowledge that Texas is a strong law-and-order state, where politicians must appeal to a conservative electorate. But they question the Governor's assertion that he is a "compassionate conservative" when it comes to criminal justice.
"In order to hold statewide office here, you have to appeal to a very conservative electorate," said State Senator Rodney Ellis, Democrat of Houston. But Mr. Ellis went on to say, "There is no compassion on the Governor's part when it comes to law and order."
 
On Guns
Battling Crime, Not Firearms
By nature, friends here say, Mr. Bush prefers to avoid taking stands on difficult issues. He is neither an ideologue nor confrontational, they say. But perhaps more than on any other issue, events in Texas have pushed him into defining his position on guns.
The first step came in his race against Governor Richards, when he pledged to support the concealed-weapons bill. When, as Governor, he signed the bill into law in 1995, he declared, "This is a bill to make Texas a safer place."
The bill had been championed by the National Rifle Association, but was opposed by the police chiefs of Texas's largest cities, who were concerned that the law would lead to more violent confrontations between individuals armed with guns and a greater risk to police officers.
Texas is one of 31 states that allow people to carry concealed weapons, though lately public opinion in other states has been shifting against the policy. In Missouri last April, in the only referendum ever taken on the issue, voters rejected a proposal to allow concealed weapons. After the shooting rampage by two students at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., on April 20, lawmakers in both Colorado and Michigan abandoned bills to allow concealed weapons.
Opponents of the Texas bill had predicted it would lead to a rash of shootings. Supporters said it would sharply cut crime. Neither seems to have happened.
A study by the Violence Policy Center, a gun-control advocacy group, found that since the Texas law took effect, 15 people with concealed gun permits had been charged with murder or attempted murder and 103 with assault or aggravated assault with a deadly weapon. But that is a tiny proportion of homicides and other violent crimes in Texas. Similarly, there is little evidence that people with concealed guns have prevented many crimes.
"In Texas, people have carried guns for a century," Tony Fabelo, the director of the Texas Criminal Justice Policy Council and Governor Bush's top criminal justice adviser, said in seeking to explain the law's limited impact. "Now they just carry guns with a license."
This spring Mr. Bush was pushed into further defining his position on guns when the National Rifle Association, in response to the filing of lawsuits against the gun industry by a number cities and counties, began urging state legislatures to pass laws barring such suits. No Texas city suggested it was considering such a lawsuit, but the Legislature passed a law barring cities in the state from suing the gun industry and Mr. Bush signed it.
Mr. Bush's spokeswoman, Ms. Hughes, said the Governor signed the bill because "he does not believe that manufacturers of a legal product should be held liable for criminal misuse of the product."
Fourteen states, mostly in the South and West, have adopted such legislation. After the Littleton shootings, lawmakers in Colorado, Florida and Michigan withdrew similar bills, and Gov. Jane Dee Hull of Arizona, a Republican, vetoed one.
Mr. Bush went against the police chiefs of the state's seven largest cities this spring by opposing a bill to require background checks on all prospective firearms buyers at gun shows. According to the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, gun shows are the leading source of guns for criminals and juveniles in Texas.
The bill requiring background checks died in committee on April 20, a few hours after the killings in Littleton, which were carried out with guns bought at gun shows.
Under Federal law, only licensed dealers at gun shows are required to conduct background checks on buyers. Other people can sell guns at the shows without even asking for identification. Mr. Bush's spokeswoman, Ms. Hughes, said the Governor thinks that there should be background checks on buyers at gun shows but that the loophole should be closed at the Federal level. Congress has debated the issue this year without result.
Some states have acted to tighten gun-show sales: California has a system for checking the background of buyers at the shows, and last year Florida voters approved an initiative authorizing its cities to require background checks on buyers at the shows.
Despite his policies on gun control, the amiable Mr. Bush has remained popular with the police. "I know the Governor," said Police Chief Ben Click of Dallas. "We run together. He is a very nice, sincere person and I like him a lot."
But in states where voters favor gun control, Mr. Bush can expect challenges on the issue. Last month in New Jersey, a small group of gun-control advocates demonstrated outside a hotel where Mr. Bush was speaking at a fund-raising event. Afterward, Mr. Bush defended his record supporting gun owners' rights and predicted it would not hurt him. "That's what elections are for," he said. "But I'm proud of my record."
 
On Prisons
More Inmates For Longer Terms
Under Mr. Bush, Texas has the largest criminal justice system in the country, with 545,000 people in prison or jail or on probation or parole, a point of pride to many Texans, said Mr. Fabelo, the Governor's top criminal justice adviser. The state's prisons hold 724 inmates for every 100,000 residents, second only to Louisiana's 736. By contrast, Minnesota, with the lowest incarceration rate, has 117 inmates per 100,000 people.
The enormous buildup of the Texas prison system had actually begun by the time Governor Richards took office in 1991.
In 1989, the state's prisons had 41,000 beds, and the buildup was far advanced when Mr. Bush became Governor. When the buildup is completed next year, the prison system will have 150,000 beds.
The Bush Administration says the total cost will approach $3 billion while some of the state's leading Democrats put the figure at $10 billion.
In any event, Mr. Bush has enthusiastically supported the growth of prisons, unlike California, where politicians have begun to question the state's prison-building program. Republicans there worry about higher taxes to pay for new prisons, and Democrats say the program has taken money away from the state college and university system.
In Texas, the money spent to build prisons is cutting into spending for public education, one of Mr. Bush's priorities, said Eva DeLuna Castro, a budget analyst with the Center for Public Policy Priorities, a nonpartisan research organization in Austin.
"There has been a definite trade-off," Ms. Castro said. State spending for public schools was 36.4 percent of the budget in 1999, compared with 41.3 percent in 1989, while spending for prisons was 7.8 percent, up from 5.2 percent, she said.
Mr. Bush's spokeswoman, Ms. Hughes, said that to cope with the growing number of inmates who will be released from prison, the Governor is counting on programs like a voluntary Christian boot camp pioneered by Charles Colson, once the special counsel to President Richard M. Nixon, and who served a Federal prison term on Watergate-related charges. The program includes Bible study as well as courses on personal responsibility, parenting and financial management.
"I'm absolutely convinced this program will work," Mr. Bush said after visiting a pilot project near Houston. "The best recidivism program is a changed heart."
One of Mr. Bush's major planks in his race against Ms. Richards was a promise to tighten the juvenile justice system in the face of skyrocketing teen-age crime, and as Governor, Mr. Bush has transformed the juvenile justice code. One result: a tripling of the number of young inmates in the Texas Youth Commission's juvenile prisons, to 6,000.
"If George W. Bush can do for the United States what he has done for Texas, no one can lick his boots," said Hal Gaither, a Bush adviser and a Dallas Juvenile Court judge, who describes himself as "the most conservative man in Texas."
The major change under Mr. Bush, Judge Gaither said, was switching the main purpose of the juvenile system from protecting the best interests of the child, its historical role, to more of a prison system in which punishment is emphasized. Among the changes was lowering the age at which juveniles can be sent to adult court for serious crimes to 14, increasing the maximum sentence for a juvenile to 40 years and requiring a one-year minimum sentence for anyone sentenced to the juvenile prisons.
The new code does provide flexibility, Judge Gaither said. Juveniles given long sentences can either be sent to an adult prison when they turn 16, or they can have their sentence reduced if their behavior has improved. Many of these changes have been enacted in other states.

On Death Penalty
Leaving Appeals To Higher Power
Mr. Bush has also been a strong supporter of the death penalty. He has presided over a record 98 executions as Governor, according to the Texas Department of Criminal Justice.
Among those executed was Karla Faye Tucker, a born-again Christian whose death-row conversion led to calls for clemency from the Rev. Pat Robertson and other religious leaders. The appeal from the Christian Right gave Mr. Bush "maneuverability" to commute Ms. Tucker's sentence without offending conservative supporters, said Jim Harrington, director of the Texas Civil Rights Project, which opposes the death penalty.
But in one of his most publicized moments as Governor, Mr. Bush chose not to intervene, saying: "In every death penalty that comes to my desk, I ask this question: Innocent or guilty? And I will tell you of all the death penalties we have had in our state, I am confident that those that have been put to death have been guilty."
Addressing appeals for clemency based on Ms. Tucker's religious conversion, Mr. Bush said, "I have concluded judgments about the heart and soul of an individual on death row are best left to a higher authority."
This month the Tucker execution again became an issue because of a profile in Talk magazine that quoted him as mocking Ms. Tucker's plea for her life. Campaign officials have denied the profile's characterization of the Governor, saying his comments were misread.
Mr. Bush did halt the execution of Henry Lee Lucas, who had received several life sentences in a series of killings, but who, evidence showed, had been nowhere near the scene of the crime for which Texas was about to execute him. Mr. Bush commuted the sentence to life in prison.
Americans support the death penalty by a large majority, with 71 percent in favor and only 21 percent opposed, according to a Harris Poll released in July.
Given the frequency of executions, some Texas legislators introduced a bill this spring to bar the execution of the mentally retarded. Five such inmates have been executed in Texas since the death penalty was reinstated in 1976, according to the Death Penalty Information Center.
After the bill passed the State Senate, Mr. Bush announced his opposition, saying, "I like the law the way it is right now," with juries having the right to make the decision. The bill died in the House.
In another measure to deal with the number of executions and the growing number of inmates, the Texas Senate and House unanimously passed a bill this spring to create a state public defender system, guaranteeing that indigent defendants be assigned a lawyer within 20 days of arrest. Defense lawyers are now appointed by elected local judges, often from among their campaign contributors, leading to charges of cronyism, delays and incompetence.
Mr. Bush vetoed the bill. "While well-intentioned," he said in a statement, the bill proposed "drastic changes" that would have lowered the quality of representation and posed a public danger by requiring the release of defendants who were not assigned a lawyer within 20 days.
The Houston Chronicle, in an editorial, said Mr. Bush should have signed the bill, since virtually alone among the states "Texas has no system at all" for public defenders. When lawyers appointed by judges are competent, the paper said, they have an ethical conflict, since the judges who pay them want a speedy trial, not an aggressive defense.
Senator Ellis, who sponsored the bill, said Governor Bush had given in to lobbying by judges who did not want to lose their patronage system. "One can be a proponent of the death penalty, as I am," said Senator Ellis, "but also sane enough to realize we need a real public defender system."

SECTION: Section E; Page 2; Column 3; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1102 words

HEADLINE: ARTS ABROAD;
Two Worlds (Well, at Least One) Still Spin at Spoleto

BYLINE: By Anne Midgette 

DATELINE: SPOLETO, Italy

 BODY:
At 8:30 the piazza in front of the cathedral here is empty. Late sun strikes gold from the high bell tower, but the square is steeped in silvery shadow, and the air is so unseasonably cool that the musicians playing on the steps of the Teatro Caio Melisso are comfortable, rather than sweltering, in their formal tails.
Only a few people are sitting in the chairs in front of them. Across the square a couple of cocktail drinkers watch from the handful of tables huddled in front of the restaurant Tric Trac. The musicians finish, to a scattering of applause, and the Teatro Caio Melisso prepares for a performance of "Les Porteurs d'Eau" by the Theatre Talipot from Madagascar that only a few dozen people will attend. 
 "The first week of the festival is always slow," says the sculptor Robin Heidi Kennedy, a local resident, red velvet glowing from the empty seats around her.
In a town like Salzburg or Bayreuth, using the words "slow" and "festival" in the same sentence might imply the kiss of death. But in Italy one expects invited guests to come a little late. And the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, while it has moved far from the kind of informal happening it was when the Italian composer Giancarlo Menotti founded it in 1958, still offers something of the casual intimacy that characterized it when Jerome Robbins and Luchino Visconti were fixtures, and young musicians named Yo-Yo Ma and Jacqueline Du Pre or luminaries like Sviatoslav Richter made impromptu appearances in the noontime concerts.
Established though it be, Spoleto, which ran this year from mid-June to mid-July, still relies on a personal touch, announcing noontime programs at the last minute, or loading audiences for the series Music in Secret Umbria into buses and driving them out for a picnic and concert in Romanesque churches nestled in the hills, like a good host showing the area to out-of-town guests. Mr. Menotti, creator of "Amahl and the Night Visitors," holds the unofficial title of most-performed living composer. Still, the German newspaper Rheinischer Merkur is not alone in assessing him as "cleverer as a festival founder than as a composer."
Today the mainstream classical-music world looks askance at his operas, condemning them as popular and facile (even as American opera companies seek out new narrative, tonal works to lure the audiences that used to flock to Mr. Menotti's pieces). His festival, on the other hand, is an acknowledged institution, unusual in Europe for its equal emphasis on music and theater, film, art and dance.
The 1999 program included a new monologue by the Nobel Prize winner Dario Fo, a theater piece by the French film director Eric Rohmer, a concert by the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet (who played here at earlier stages of his career) and Mr. Menotti's staging of Prokofiev's seldom-performed opera "War and Peace."
"Spoleto was started to prove that the arts could turn the economy around in a small, depressed town," Mr. Menotti said over lunch recently. A village that used to boast but a single hotel now has a full complement of pensione and ristoranti for the annual influx of guests; and more and more well-heeled foreigners are buying and restoring houses in the area.
Mr. Menotti has changed his economic outlook as well. Now 88, the man who once said he wanted to live out his old age in a cottage by the sea resides during the year in a full-blown castle in Scotland, with his adopted son, Francis, his son's wife and their two sons, Claudio, 12, and Cosimo, 8.
The Italian press has called Mr. Menotti the Sun King of Spoleto: a benevolent but all-powerful ruler with a whim of iron. But the second of his "two worlds," the United States, countered monarchy with democracy in the best American tradition at Spoleto's American colony in Charleston, S.C., founded in 1977. When Mr. Menotti tried to designate Francis as his heir, the board of Spoleto U.S.A. rebelled, and the elder Mr. Menotti finally cleared the field in 1993 and retreated to Umbria, severing ties with the Charleston festival altogether.
Italy has no problem with dynasties: Francis Menotti has served as the festival's president since 1993, and this year he officially took over as artistic director. Born Francis Phelan in Pennsylvania, a former professional ice skater and actor who used to appear in Menotti works (like the play "The Leper," which was written for him), he was adopted in 1974, at age 36. He proclaims himself dedicated to continuing the festival in his father's spirit while solidifying an organizational structure that has been dependent on Giancarlo Menotti's whim.
Testimony to the weather vane changes of his decrees are the short tenures of some of the festival's artistic and music directors. Thomas Schippers, who served a long tenure as artistic and then music director until 1975, was followed by a string of short-termers: Massimo Bogianckino, Romolo Valli, Rafaello de Banfield. "Four or five years," Mr. Menotti has said, "then I think that we should get some new view in here." This year was the first for the newest director, the British conductor Richard Hickox.
In conversation Mr. Menotti bubbled with charm and anecdote, opinions about the evils of modern stage direction, and concern about how to fit the huge cast and chorus of "War and Peace" onto the diminutive stage of the Teatro Nuovo. Still, he would hardly have undertaken the Herculean task of staging the work had the scheduled director not pulled out at the last minute. In any event, the co-director, Roman Hurko, did most of the heavy lifting, with Mr. Menotti presiding over an occasional rehearsal.
The staging hardly won raves: reviews described it as naive, rudimentary and even "in an antiquated Bolshoi style." Yet the ensemble was roundly praised, and Mr. Hickox, who had devoted considerable time to auditioning the students who play in the Spoleto Festival Orchestra, was hailed for creating "a vibrating cosmos of tender lyricism." The event made a good case for revivals of an opera that the expert on Russian music Richard Taruskin calls "Prokofiev's masterpiece." Opening night of "War and Peace" was sold out.
Festival regulars often wax nostalgic about Spoleto's glory days; and there is no question that the festival, like its founder, has lost some of its energy. Yet the Festival of Two Worlds prevails.
"That the festival has hardly lost its freshness is demonstrated by the program of this 42d edition," said the German daily Suddeutsche Zeitung. "Where else in Europe can you find such a constellation" of different shows and events?

HEADLINE: The Sound and the Fury: Beating Back the Beep

BYLINE: By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

 BODY:
THE computer first beeped almost 50 years ago. It hasn't stopped since. And now it's not alone.
Pagers beep. Answering machines beep. A.T.M.'s beep. Elevators beep. Phones beep. We have warning beeps, ready beeps and attention beeps. There have been private and public beeps and beeps heard around the world. The beep has even entered the vernacular, courtesy of the answering machine ("Leave your message after the beep . . ."). American society has been inundated by peppy beeps. 
 The beep originally served as an alert. And for a long time, only high-tech things beeped, like satellites and computers. But today the most mundane things -- from children's toys to pens -- do so.
"There are moments of my day where I think: If hear another beep, I think I am going to shoot the device," said Cindy Mason, a computer scientist at the University of California at Berkeley, who added that sometimes she hears more than 100 beeps in an hour.
With its democratization over the last 40 years, the beep has moved from cutting-edge chic to downright tacky. And it may be headed for the scrap heap if sound designers have their way. "The time has come for the beep to die an honorable death," said B. J. Fogg, a researcher at Stanford University.
A small army of researchers, engineers and programmers has declared war on the beep, which, they say, has overstayed its welcome.
"Beeps have become like the little boy who cried wolf," said Bruce Tognazzini, a human-computer interaction designer for the Healtheon Corporation. "They are often ignored even when they might have been useful. Having a computer that constantly emits the identical sound whether it is just happy to see you or is on fire and about to explode is akin to having a housemate that is similarly afflicted."
But the beep continues to hold its ground. "The downfall of the beep is only in fiction," said Bill Buxton, chief scientist for Alias/Wavefront, a software subsidiary of Silicon Graphics, and a foe of the beep. "In the real world, the beep is still thriving."
The sheer irritation caused by the beep is one reason for its longevity. Research has shown that humans are bothered by sounds that are sudden, high-pitched and short.
"If you wanted to design an annoying sound, you can't do much better than a beep," said Bill Gavin, a researcher at the Royal College of Art in England. Dr. Fogg described a beep as "a poke in the ribs, a simple but annoying method for gaining attention or compliance."
Computer historians say that modern computer beeps evolved from typewriter carriage return bells. Piercing beeps were substituted as alert signals for the familiar ring of the bell. Today the program code to make a computer beep is still called the bell character.
Why a beep, as opposed to a buzz or even a ding? The answer is dictated by economics. "Beeping is cheap," Dr. Gavin said.
A beep requires only two mechanical parts: an energy source and something to vibrate. Beep sound waves are produced by the rapid oscillation of on and off electrical pulses, in either a square form or a sine wave form. In contrast, more complicated electronic sounds require many more components.
The 1957 launch of the Russian Sputnik satellite ushered in a new era of celebrity for the beep. At the height of the cold war, American television and radio stations continually broadcast the satellite's taunting signal as it blazed over United States soil every 96 minutes.
"The sound was something very remote, very powerful and very frightening" said James Katz, a Rutgers University professor who was 9 years old at the time. "After all, it was a man-made entity in space over the United States. The beep made it much more real."
In the 1960's, beeps became most strongly associated with high-powered mainframe computers, and for engineers and technicians, they were a comforting and familiar sound. But when computers breached mainstream workplaces, the beep began to lose its luster.
"Bankers are very sensitive about not making mistakes, so the beep gave the users an incredible psychological stress," said Giordano Beretta, who worked as a bank computer support technician in the 1970's. "If you use a beep to signal a problem, people hate it because they feel socially responsible for making a mistake." Mr. Beretta said he was regularly asked to disable beep features on the computers.
When bar code scanners were first introduced, many library and supermarket employees often felt that beeps represented management's measuring of their efficiency.
Even appliances not designed to beep will chime in the chorus given the right electrical impulses. In 1987 a utility company in Dallas conducted an experiment using electrical transmission lines to carry digital signals. As a result, all the electronic appliances around the house of John Feagins began emitting a series of soft beeps every few seconds.
"I'd hear it out of the TV speakers," recalled Mr. Feagins, who was a physics student at the University of Texas at the time. "I'd hear it out of the radio speakers. I'd hear it out of the stove. It was everywhere in the house."
Despite his complaints to the utility, the beeping continued on and off for about a year. "I got aggravated enough to unplug everything, because otherwise I couldn't sleep," Mr. Feagins said.
Some have argued that the proliferation of the beep has a cultural basis.
"For some reason, Americans believe that the device needs to shout at you -- hence the loud beep," said Richard Giordano, a computer science lecturer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "The French, on the other hand, believe that the user should not be distracted from solving the problem, that the device should indicate the problem to the user in a calm manner and not get in the way of solving the problem."
That is why French nuclear power stations are much quieter than American ones, Dr. Giordano said.
Getting rid of the beep is not simply a matter of eradicating it; the beep has to be replaced with something else. Specialists who work in "human factors" laboratories are looking to create sounds that are less sharp and richer in timbre.
"It's a pity people don't use chimes and bells more often," lamented John Murray, a human factors specialist at Exponent Failure Analysis, a consulting firm in Menlo Park, Calif.
There are three main approaches to the design of information tones. One is the earcon, an audio equivalent of an icon, which uses different rhythms, pitches, timbres and melodies to communicate different messages. Increasing a sound's tempo, for example, makes it seem more urgent. A paralinguistic approach gives computers a library of nonspeech tones used in human spoken communication (like "uh-oh"). Finally, audio icons use caricatures or simulations of naturally occurring sounds -- like a burp -- that carry specific associations.
The current trend is for high-tech companies to have their own trademark sound -- a logo for the ears, like America Online's "You've got mail" and the ICQ instant messenger's peppy "Uh-oh!"
Apple's Macintosh computer was the first serious desktop assault on the computer beep. Instead of using the simple grating tones, users could choose from a host of alerts ranging from a quack to the sound of a droplet. One Macintosh sound, called sosumi ("so sue me"), was a pointed taunt at the Beatles' Apple Corps company, which threatened legal action to prevent Apple Computer from releasing music under the Apple name.
The Windows platform also comes with a standard litany of sounds to choose from. Screen savers and other programs let users substitute sounds, from Homer Simpson's "D'oh!" to the "Star Wars" theme song.
Despite the enmity it faces, the beep is still healthy, thanks especially to answering machines and to personal pagers, which made beeps mobile (much to the dismay of many churches and theaters).
But pagers also contributed to the beeper backlash. Pagers were originally the domain of an elite few who had to be reached immediately, like doctors. "A loud ring on such a device let certain louts know, who might otherwise have remained unaware, that the pagee was someone of money and distinction," noted Mr. Tognazzini, of Healtheon.
When pagers became commonplace, their beeps became scorned rather than respected. As a response to customer complaints, companies introduced vibrating pagers, dealing the beep a major blow.
"Vibration was huge," said Karen Holmes, a marketing manager at Motorola. "Consumers just loved it."
Audrey Glassman, author of a book on techno-etiquette, says that pagers should always be kept on vibrator mode while in public. She adds that the only reason pagers still have a beep mode is "so that we don't have to call them vibrators."
The pager beep was displaced not only for reasons of etiquette but also for practical reasons. Mono-frequency beeps are unnatural to the ear, and psycho-acoustic research has shown that human ears have great difficulty determining the direction the sound is coming from, which is why it often seems difficult to find a misplaced pager or cell phone in a room or to identify whose phone or pager is sounding.
To Dr. Buxton, of Alias/Wavefront, this is evidence that the beep's days are numbered. "When people start designing devices that demonstrate subtle, well-designed sounds are less intrusive and more effective than the beep, the beep will be shamed out of existence," he said.
But it's not going quietly. Even without a sound card, today's desktop PC's can still belt out a primitive trill, which Eric Isaacson, a technical writer at Schweitzer Engineering Laboratories in Pullman, Wash., discovered much to his dismay.
After Mr. Isaacson installed Windows NT on his office computer, the machine suddenly began beeping loudly enough for officemates 10 feet away to hear. For four weeks, the support technicians at his company could not figure out how to make it stop.
"At first I just got a little irritated when it beeped at me," Mr. Isaacson said.But the situation soon escalated. "Later," he said, "I started making it beep on purpose, after it beeped at me first -- kind of the 'I'll show you' attitude. This progressed to the point of my stabbing at the keys to make it beep, taking out my frustrations on the poor keyboard."
Finally, through an on-line news group, he found a way to silence the beep. "Now my beep lets out not a peep," he said.
 
Et Tu, Captain?
Where No Beep Had Gone Before
 LIKE an aging movie star, the beep has seen its glory days in Hollywood fade over the last 30 years, paralleling its fall in the public sphere. The 1960's television series "Star Trek" and its later offshoots provide a case study of how the beep has fallen from high-tech symbol to low-tech annoyance.
In the original series, which ran from 1966 to 1969, the beep was a star. Machines on the bridge of the starship Enterprise emitted a constant backdrop of beeping and booping to accompany the plot line. During the height of the 1960's space race, beeping was considered cutting-edge chic.
In recent "Star Trek" incarnations, however, the beep makes only cameo appearances. Gurgling, swishing and speaking have taken its place. The banishment of the beep was a conscious decision by the producers of the pilot of "Star Trek: the Next Generation" in 1986.
"We pulled up the sound of the bridge from the original series," said Peter Lauritson, who has worked as a producer on "Star Trek: The Next Generation," as well as the later series "Deep Space Nine" and "Star Trek Voyager." "It was a loud, constant, harsh environment. In contrast to that, we tried to make things softer and calmer."
Like the electronic interface designers of today, the "Star Trek" producers tried to serve the esthetic thresholds of humans. The "Star Trek" characters live aboard the ships for years on end, Mr. Lauritson said. "The reality is they wouldn't be able to take it," he noted.
"We tried to keep the sounds fairly gentle and minimal until something needed to be said with the sound. We were hoping it would convey sophistication, that things had advanced."
In "Star Trek: The Next Generation," the sound designers aimed for a so-called pastel range of electronic sounds that were muted and subtle. But then they realized even the harsh beeps and boops had a necessary role. As a result, the background sounds in "Deep Space Nine" and "Star Trek Voyager" aimed for a more "primary" sound palette, with harsher electronic noises.
"We originally went overboard in making things so sophisticated that it was boring," said Mr. Lauritson. "We had to start backing off of that a little bit to get a little more life into the scene."
The beep's prestige has diminished as it has become more mundane. "I think that the beeps and the boops sounds in the earlier days were kind of a futuristic signature," Mr. Lauritson said, "whereas now, they're kind of everywhere."

HEADLINE: Too Many Phones, Too Little Service

BYLINE: By CATHERINE GREENMAN 

 BODY:
IN case you haven't noticed, this country's 300 or so wireless telecommunications companies are eager for phone users to cut the cord on their wired phones and go completely mobile.
Leading wireless carriers like AT&T Wireless, Sprint PCS, Bell Atlantic Mobile and BellSouth are encouraging "bucket plans," in which subscribers pay flat monthly rates for as much as 1,500 minutes of cell phone time. 
 According to the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association, a trade group based in Washington, the pricing plans, which in many cases are better than long distance rates for wired phones, are working. The group estimates the number of cellular phone users in this country to be near 77 million, with more than 37,500 people signing up for wireless phone service each day. And these users are talking more than ever before.
But for every college-bound student who has just purchased 1,000 minutes a month of talk time, there is a cell phone user out there like Stephanie Rudolph Soderberg, a New York City resident who signed on to AT&T's Digital One Rate plan more than a year ago. When asked if she was satisfied with her cell phone service, she replied: "What service? I have no service."
Mrs. Rudolph Soderberg said that every time she tries to call her husband, Bob Soderberg, an electrical engineer who works mostly outdoors in the city, she hears a fast busy signal, indicating that the call cannot be completed because there is too much traffic on the phone network.
"I take it very personally," she said. "I'm starting to think it's me, maybe something about my body that obstructs calls."
While no one knows the precise number of calls that are not completed, fade in and out or get cut off midconversation, such incidents are increasingly common complaints among wireless users. And they raise an important question: As successful as wireless companies have been in attracting subscribers, what are they doing to keep them happy?
In cities like New York, Los Angeles and Seattle, where cell phone use is among the highest in the country, incomplete or disconnected calls often occur because there are too many conversations for the limited number of channels within a wireless carrier's network. Buildings also greatly interfere with the transmission of cell phone signals. In less populated suburban and rural areas, transmission failures occur because the wireless networks have yet to be fully built, leaving holes in coverage areas.
The simple solution to these problems is to increase the number of cell sites -- the antennas and base station equipment that send and receive cellular signals. And wireless carriers, responding to the complaints of cell phone users, have, in fact, escalated the construction of cell sites. The Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association estimates that as of December 1998, there were more than 65,000 cell sites in the United States, a 28 percent increase over the previous year.
Jane O'Donaghue, a spokeswoman for AT&T, whose digital wireless network had difficulty sustaining the initial demand brought on by the carrier's Digital One Rate calling plan, said the company would spend more than $2 billion on its wireless infrastructure in 1999. At Sprint PCS, which has 11,000 sites in 280 markets, Tom Murphy, a spokesman, said the company would spend more than $1.5 billion on coverage and capacity this year.
"The big fix is for the carriers to go out and spend the money on building cell sites" said Matt Hoffman, an analyst with Dataquest, a research company in San Jose, Calif. "But they also have to factor in how much that will improve coverage. They can try and cover you in an elevator, but you could also wait until you get downstairs. How much adding a cell site will increase customer satisfaction is tough for the carriers to grasp."
Even with huge expenditures on infrastructure, wireless companies face an uphill battle to achieve better service coverage. There are a number of obstacles to overcome. The low signal strengths inherent in the newer digital wireless networks, for example, are the source of a slew of coverage problems.
A wireless phone works by transmitting and receiving radio signals to and from the nearest cell site. As the user travels from one cell to the next, the system hands off the signal so that service is uninterrupted. Every wireless carrier has a designated chunk of the radio spectrum, which it divides into cells. A typical cell in an urban area will handle about 100 channels, depending on the wireless technology being used.
Even though channels can handle more than one call simultaneously, if there are too many subscribers in a given cell at one time, the result can be a fast busy signal. If a subscriber already on the phone travels into a cell that is at capacity, the result can be a disconnected call.
Most cell sites cover transmissions in an area from 2 to 10 miles in diameter, depending on the terrain and other factors. Because the signals are transmitted at relatively low power (as low as 0.6 watts in digital wireless phones), channels can be reused in other cells without concern that there will be interference. A carrier with a limited number of channels can theoretically take on more subscribers by building more cells and reusing the channels.
Because the zeros and ones of a digital signal take up less space on a channel than do analog signals, digital wireless represents a boon to a channel-hungry wireless carrier. A digital cell can handle up to 10 calls per channel, several more calls per channel than an analog cell.
But some digital signals transmit at higher frequencies than analog signals and are more susceptible to energy loss as they travel between points. As a result, it takes more towers to carry the signals. That is a likely explanation for why digital wireless subscribers experience the most dropped calls while they're driving. The digital signal becomes weakened as the driver moves out of one cell, and it is not strong enough to be picked up immediately by the neighboring cell site.
Sometimes, however, it is not signal strength that is the problem, but the lack of digital cell sites. Although the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association estimates that 70 percent to 75 percent of the land area of the United States has wireless coverage, there is greater coverage for analog systems than for digital. Many wireless operators use the analog network as a fallback for digital customers.
But even when there is an analog cell in the area to default to, it's generally easier to hand off calls between digital cells than it is to hand off calls between digital and analog cells. A digital-analog handoff involves moving to a separate system as the signal is transmitted at the carrier's switching network. And if the analog transmission fails, the signal cannot be transferred back into digital mode.
In addition, wireless providers use different digital technologies that don't always hand off seamlessly between cells, particularly when a call is being relayed out of a cell in a subscriber's home coverage area and into the cell of another carrier, during a process known as roaming.
"We'd be so much better off if we had a couple of nationwide networks handing calls off to each other," said Nancy Gohring, wireless networks editor at Telephony, an industry trade magazine.
Radio frequency engineers at companies that manufacture base station equipment, like Lucent Technologies and Motorola, are constantly working on software upgrades to ease compatibility. Industry experts say the next generation of digital wireless will have a standard interface to improve the way different systems hand off calls to one another.
Kent Olson, an analyst at the Strategis Group, a telecommunications information services company based in Washington, estimates that it costs between $140,000 and $180,000 to build a cell site. In any urban area, there is usually a high density of sites to accommodate a large number of users.
Wireless providers are looking for more economical ways to build their networks. One alternative to building a cell is to extend the signal by stringing a series of devices known as repeaters in areas between cells. Repeaters can amplify and extend a signal up to 10 or 20 miles. More and more, wireless carriers are also installing micro cells, which have lower power and fewer channels, in areas that are difficult to penetrate, like buildings and tunnels.
Repeaters and micro cells are cheaper, but they will not solve all coverage problems.
"Some structures will still be almost impossible to penetrate, given the high frequency and low power of the digital signals," said Richard Wong, a network engineer for Telus Mobility, a cellular provider in western Canada.
Another economical alternative to building more cell sites is to lease channels on another company's existing cell site, something that wireless carriers are becoming much more flexible about. Such consolidation is also a response to community zoning regulations, which often prohibit the construction of new towers.
Over the last couple of years, many carriers have sold their cell sites to companies including the Crown Castle Corporation, based in Houston, and Pinnacle Holdings, based in Sarasota, Fla. These companies then lease the space to the carrier that used to own it, and to one or two others.
"With only two players in the market, there weren't the current issues with real estate and zoning," said Mr. Olson, of Strategis. "Now, with five or six players in each market, the carriers are much more likely to share tower space."
With the new generation of digital phones allowing limited Web access and E-mail already here and expanded wireless data services on the horizon, mobile phone use will only increase. Will a time come when the digital wireless network fills up entirely?
"The potential for that exists, but it's not any kind of a reality at this point," said Mark Desautels, managing director of the Wireless Data Forum, a Washington-based trade organization. The Federal Communications Commission, he said, "has the ability to shift spectrum and allot additional bandwidth should that become necessary."
And despite the current coverage problems, experts believe that the carriers will be able to build themselves out of it.
"The good news is that this, too, shall pass," said Tom Wheeler, president and chief executive of the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association. "It took 75 years before wire line phone service had the same kind of coverage that the wireless carriers have achieved in a much shorter period. It's not where it should be, but it's moving at lightning speed and improving every day."
 
Too Much Static?
Staying Loud and Clear
Here are some steps you can take to improve your wireless service:
* Study and compare various carriers' coverage areas, which are viewable on maps in cell phone stores and on carriers' Web sites. Or talk to wireless phone users who use the different services available in your area. "For most people, usage tends to be fairly predictable, so it's possible to do a little research and to subscribe to a carrier with the strongest signals in your area," said Sam Simon, chairman of the Telecommunications Research and Action Center, a Washington-based consumer group. Sign up with a carrier that offers a 30-day trial period so you can switch carriers if you have service problems.
* If your phone has an extendable antenna, pull it out. Like the antenna on a transistor radio, it will improve the reception. If you experience coverage problems indoors, move close to a window or, if possible, go outside to improve the signal.
* Consider buying a car antenna if you make a lot of calls while driving. They
are available for under $100 at electronics stores and at Internet-based wireless phone dealers like those at www.point
.com and www.cellwest.com. Because they are mounted to the exterior of your car, the antennas can prevent the signal interference sometimes caused when making calls from inside. Most car antennas connect to your phone by a cable, which is unplugged when exiting the car.
* Don't forget the analog mode. Most digital wireless phones are capable of being switched to analog by pressing a function key. If you're in an area where your digital service is spotty, you can try switching for better reception. But be aware that you run the risk of being disconnected during the transition.
* Move around. When outdoors, moving just a couple of steps or waving your phone around in the air can improve the signal. Check the signal strength bar on the screen before dialing a phone number. It will help you avoid having to hit the resend button. CATHERINE GREENMAN

HEADLINE: Keeping Up With All the News Back in Anytown, U.S.A.

BYLINE: By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

 BODY:
WHEN Thomas G. Nelson was teaching English in Malaysia last year, he was able to keep up with old friends and family in his hometown in Kansas every week by using his computer to read The Marion County Record, the local weekly newspaper, on line.
He could find out about high-school friends celebrating their anniversaries, check out the wedding announcements of people he remembered as babies and see how the local sports teams were faring. One week, his father was featured in an article on refinishing furniture. 
 He would joke with his family in Burdick, 20 miles northeast of Marion, that he would get the news on line a day or two before they would get it in their mailboxes.
"With the computer, you felt like you weren't missing out," said Mr. Nelson, 46, who is now back in Burdick. "You know everybody in town."
On-line news is not the exclusive territory of major daily newspapers anymore. In the last few years, small community daily papers and weeklies have been setting up Web sites and getting into the on-line news business.
While many just sample the waters by putting up a simple Web page with a few local stories, sports items, classified advertisements and obituaries (the most popular item), others have hired extra staff members, put display advertising on line and set up large community news operations.
Like many of their bigger counterparts, these smaller papers generally are not making profits yet from their on-line ventures. But many editors and publishers interviewed said they believed it was essential that small-town America get its news and advertising on line from them before someone else takes that market out from under them.
"We had to stop viewing ourselves as a newspaper company and view ourselves as an information company," said Mark Hamilton, who publishes the The Iowa Falls Times-Citizen (www.iafalls.com), a twice-weekly publication with a circulation of 4,000, and put the paper on line three years ago. "This is important for small towns."
But the game can be expensive, and many small newspapers that are already operating with tight budgets and small staffs are choosing to go slowly.
"Just like the large papers, small papers' on-line operations run the gamut," said Peter M. Zollman, principal partner in the Advanced Interactive Media Group , a Florida consulting firm. "Some are making money, some are losing their shirts, some aren't doing it because they are afraid they will lose their shirts."
Going slowly and not using much staff time or financial resources seems to be the game plan of most weeklies and dailies with circulations under 30,000.
"Everyone who has any sense is doing only that, because the economics of publishing will not sustain a large investment," said Eric Meyer, assistant professor of journalism at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and managing partner in Newslink Associates, a research and consulting firm for on-line publishers. Mr. Meyer also owns the 3,500-circulation Marion County Record (www.marionrecord.com), with his father, Bill, who is the publisher and editor.
While it is not known exactly how many of America's 1,500 daily papers and 7,200 weeklies are on line, Mr. Meyer estimates that the figure includes more than half of the dailies and at least 1,000 of the weekly papers.
Studies show that Americans still prefer delivery to their doorstep, he said. But competition from large dailies trying to compete for suburban and small-town circulation, and races against other small publications, have pushed many small papers onto the Web in the last four years, Mr. Meyer said.
"They believe that they will be left behind if they don't go on line," he said.
In Aspen, Colo., both daily papers have gone on line. The Aspen Daily News (www.aspendailynews.com), a free, 12,500-circulation daily, set up a Web site three months ago in "an effort to distribute our content without printing more papers," said Darin Miller, general manager of the newspaper. The Aspen Times, which has a circulation of about 15,000 and charges for only the weekend paper, has had a weekly version on line (www.aspentimes.com /weekly.htm) for about three years and a daily one (www.aspentimes.com) for a year, said Andy Stone, the paper's editor.
Some papers that go on line eventually decide to abandon the effort. About 100 newspapers in each of the past three years have made that decision, Mr. Meyer said.
The Griffin Daily News, a 13,000-circulation daily in Georgia, went on line in late 1995 and took the Web site down in the summer of 1997. The paper plans to go back on line this summer with a simpler site that will include less content, said Alan Turner, the publisher.
The Rochester Sentinel (www.rochsent .com), a 4,800-circulation daily in rural Indiana, has gone the route of many small dailies, with a less labor-intensive and expensive Web site. Each day the site includes a new photo, the main local news story, weather, obituaries and classified ads. The paper's publisher, Sarah Overmyer Wilson, said it probably costs about $250 a month for server space and to pay an employee who comes in about one hour a day to update the site.
"It's profitable from a commitment standpoint," Ms. Overmyer Wilson said. "We've made many friends by having it, and friends can be currency, too."
While many small papers look at their Web presence as a public service, said Steve Outing, a consultant, they may be losing advertising revenue by not taking advantage of the potential to be a dominant information and commerce site for their area.
"Its tough for them, because they don't have much in the way of resources and they don't have much staff to throw at this," said Mr. Outing, who runs Content Exchange, an employment service for the on-line publishing industry.
The sites that are successful, he said, are often those that have more than just the newspaper. Sites like Town Online in Massachusetts are handbooks for small towns where users can find the news and also learn where to go to get a dog license or find Web pages on nonprofit community groups.
The Community Newspaper Company, based in Needham, Mass., publishes more than 100 papers, including The Metro West Daily News, as well as weeklies and shoppers. It began its Town Online Web site in the summer of 1996 (www.townonline .com). The site provides newspapers as well as guides to more than 200 towns and communities in eastern Massachusetts.
At Thomson Newspapers, executives decided to build the commerce side of the on-line business before turning to news content. Thomson, which includes about 60 daily newspapers in the United States and Canada, started looking into Internet strategy in 1995, said Jonathan R. Sheer, vice president of electronic products for Thomson and chief executive officer of Thomson Interactive Media. By June 1998, all the papers had an on-line presence, but only about 10 percent carry daily news content.
"The greatest risk to us is advertising migration, not reader migration," Mr. Sheer said. "It's commerce, community and content, in that order."
Mr. Sheer said he wanted to build an advertising base first, then add community information, and add the news content last. Newspapers need to "take people from the real world and direct them to the on-line world," he said.

HEADLINE: Piggy Banks, Then and Now

BYLINE: By Robert J. Shapiro; Robert J. Shapiro is Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Americans continue to spend more than they earn, and this worries a lot of people. The personal saving rate was negative 1 percent in June, according to recent data. In fact, the saving rate has been negative for the last seven months.
While high saving is almost always better than low saving, the current trend should be viewed in light of three facts. First, while Americans are saving less as individuals, as a nation we're saving more. Second, the reason many people save so little is that gains in the market have reduced their need to save. Third, home equity loans and other tax provisions make it easier for families to meet their financial goals without high saving. 
 Our personal saving rate has been falling for about 15 years and turned negative in 1998. Yet during the very years that personal saving has been lowest -- from 1996 on -- the economy has expanded faster, and for longer, than at any time since the 1960's.
In fact, the rate at which people save contributes to economic growth only as part of the nation's total saving rate: how much individuals, government and business save altogether. Here the news has been good. For most of the 1990's, this total figure has been rising, reaching a healthy 17.1 percent in the first quarter of 1999. And healthy national saving has been a boon to business investment, which recently recorded its sixth consecutive year of double-digit increases, a record.
The Government deserves some credit. After a decade of large deficits that were dragging down the measure, budget surpluses now contribute to national saving. This has helped the Federal Reserve maintain moderate interest rates, fueling strong growth and productivity gains. This further bolsters national saving by increasing both business saving (retained earnings) and state and local government surpluses.
Today most people save for specific purposes: to buy a home, send their children to college, weather a bout of unemployment, and eventually retire. With Americans' net worth up by more than half since 1994 and capital gains (realized and unrealized) at their highest levels in history, millions of Americans can achieve their saving targets without putting aside more money.
Changes in tax laws also help. Home equity loans are a ready source of money. The new tax deduction and credit for college costs, as well as tax incentives for 401(k)'s and I.R.A.'s, also reduce pressure to save.
It's helpful to understand what the personal saving rate measures. The Bureau of Economic Analysis first adds up everyone's regular income -- wages and salaries, interest, dividends and rents -- and then subtracts all their spending. This focus on how much people put aside each year is an important measure. But it doesn't cover all forms of saving. It treats all spending equally, from a wager in Atlantic City to a tuition bill, even though education costs and many other large purchases are also investments.
Further, the measure does not include capital gains, because such "income" simply represents changes in the price of existing assets. (Next year, there will be a new measure of household wealth that does include capital gains.)
Still, tens of millions of families today don't own stock and can't afford to save very much. To help them, the President has proposed plans like Universal Savings Accounts, hoping to encourage more personal saving where it's most needed.
To help everyone, we have to maintain a strong national saving rate, which means resisting large tax cuts that would end the budget surpluses that support business investment and growth.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Group Seeks Motor-Scooter Maker

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, Aug. 18

 BODY:
The Vespa, the perky little Italian motor scooter, was immortalized by Audrey Hepburn and Gregory Peck in the 1953 American film classic "Roman Holiday." So there seems to be some poetic justice in the news today that a group of United States investors is close to a deal to spend about $650 million to acquire a controlling interest in Piaggio Veicoli Europei S.p.A., the Italian group that manufactures the Vespa.
The announcement of talks by officials of Piaggio and the Texas Pacific Group, based in Fort Worth, came in response to a report in Corriere della Sera, an Italian daily newspaper. The news ends a period of speculation about the future of Piaggio, which invented the sputtering two-wheelers after World War II. 
 For Italians, the surrender of the Vespa appeared to signal the loss of yet another of the nation's industrial icons.
"Let's hope they keep the same characteristics," said Stefano Malatesta, a 32-year-old Rome musician, who drove his first Vespa at 14 and now owns his seventh, a white 125cc BX model.
The puzzling over Piaggio's prospects began after the death in December 1997 of Giovanni Alberto Agnelli, the company's 33-year-old chief executive, after an eight-month struggle with abdominal cancer. Mr. Agnelli, an offspring of the family that controls the Italian auto maker Fiat, was credited with the strategy that returned Piaggio to profitability last year after several years of losses. The death in April of Mr. Agnelli's mother, Antonella Bechi Piaggio, a major Piaggio stock owner, is said to have encouraged the search for a strong new shareholder to insure direction and capital for the company's future.
Abel G. Halpern, managing director of Texas Pacific Group Europe, would say only that "we are in serious discussions" for Texas Pacific to acquire a controlling share. A Piaggio executive referred to "advanced discussion."
An agreement would result in the second major recent investment in the Italian two-wheeled-vehicle market for the group.
In 1996, Texas Pacific took over Ducati Motor Holding S.p.A., the icon of Italian motorcycle making. Managers hired by Texas Pacific overhauled Ducati's manufacturing plants, rebuilt the bike's image and, on the model of Harley Davidson, or maybe Gucci, opened exclusive Ducati stores, including one on 42d Street in Manhattan. Fresh models were rolled out by a new chief designer, Pierre Terblanche.
In September, Sotheby's Chicago showroom is expected to auction a one-of-a-kind Ducati, the MH900e, designed by Mr. Terblanche, and collectors are expected to bid at least $500,000.
Federico Minoli, Ducati's chief executive, was quoted today as saying that "our company is not involved" in the talks. But a Piaggio executive noted that with a Piaggio deal, Texas Pacific's portfolio would cover virtually the whole range of motorized two-wheelers, from tiny 50cc Vespas to Ducati's monster bikes.
Analysts said the Ducati experience must have influenced Piaggio shareholders.
"Texas Pacific is specialized in buying into a company when it is underperforming its potential," said Michael Millman of Salomon Smith Barney. "They are sure to have a vision when they come to Piaggio."
Neither Texas Pacific nor Piaggio would say how much money would change hands if a deal is struck. But people close to the financing said the price would be roughly $650 million. In a straw vote at a meeting of Piaggio's major shareholders earlier this month, a majority agreed to the sale, which could be formally concluded soon after Italians return from their August holidays.
No immediate management changes are expected at Piaggio, people close to the discussions said.
Piaggio, which is based in Pontedera, near Pisa, made aircraft engines until 1946 when it came up with the Vespa -- Italian for wasp, and so named because of the pinched shape of the vehicle's body and its buzzing noise -- as an economical means of transportation for Italians just emerging from wartime.
By the mid-1990's, a combination of aging products and tough competition by Japanese leaders, including Honda, caused Piaggio to suffer two years of losses. Piaggio's comeback began under Mr. Agnelli. In 1996, he began a new generation of Vespa, with a bulbous retro look evoking the original model, which was introduced 50 years earlier. As sales revived in Europe and beyond, Piaggio reported a profit of $5.4 million in 1998, against losses of $28 million the previous year. Revenues rose 4 percent in 1998, to $1 billion.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Carnival's Cunard cruise line plans to spend $12.5 million to stress a touch of class.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
WHEN the Carnival Corporation and a group of investors paid $500 million for the Cunard cruise ship line a little more than a year ago, some cruise industry executives wondered why. After all, just a few years earlier, when the Walt Disney Company was looking to enter the cruise business, a Disney executive told a British newspaper: "We have no interest in Cunard or the QE2. It is seen in the industry as something of a liability."
While lacking in diplomacy, that assessment was basically correct. Even though Cunard's flagship, Queen Elizabeth 2, was the most famous cruise ship afloat, both the ship and the company had been adrift for several years. The low point occurred during a trans-Atlantic voyage in December 1994, when the newly renovated QE2's pipes exploded, toilets erupted and passengers were on the verge of rioting. That embarrassment cost the ship bookings and cost Cunard $13 million to settle the claims of angry passengers. 
 But Carnival executives were confident that in buying Cunard, whose 158-year-old pedigree and name were unequaled among people who wanted to travel in style and were willing to pay for it, they were buying "a brand equity." Within months they merged Cunard with the company's other upscale brand, Seabourn Cruise Line, and during the next five months, through the end of the fiscal year ended last Nov. 30, Cunard wound up with a modest profit of $35 million. While that was not a bad first step, Carnival, which last year made more than $1 million of profit a day, has larger long-range ambitions for its acquisition.
Cunard plans to spend $12.5 million on a worldwide all-print advertising campaign that will get under way by month's end and run until December 2000. The campaign will appear in 14 newspapers in the United States, from New York to California, including The New York Times, The Los Angeles Times, The Philadelphia Inquirer, The Washington Post, USA Today and The Miami Herald; in nine upscale magazines including The New York Times magazine, Travel & Leisure, Conde Nast Traveler, Gourmet, and Forbes FYI and five travel trade publications. The same campaign will also appear in Australia, Asia and Europe.
Dubbed the "Continuum Campaign," the Cunard ads do not seek to be all things to all cruise line passengers, but to recapture the elegance and mystique of ocean travel -- of the time, as one ad puts it, "when gentlemen on Queen Mary dressed for dinner, and passengers wore T-shirts under their clothing."
Under the motto "Advancing Civilization Since 1840," and with at least several ads headlined, "Those who worship change simply don't understand tradition," the ads speak to "timeless elegance" and a "gracious atmosphere," while turning up their collective nose at "a world of mass production and glitz."
"The campaign's tone is reminiscent of a bygone era -- where civility and manners were traits of ladies and gentlemen, and Cunard was the only way to cross," said Dorn Martell, senior creative vice president of Tinsley Advertising of Miami, which has the account.
The new ads blending Cunard's rich history and past advertising appeals are based on extensive research. To achieve historical authenticity, Tinsley researched the Cunard archives at the University of Liverpool and in the Maritime Museum in Liverpool, Cunard's original home port. "The backgrounds of every ad contain the actual technical drawings of ships like Aquitania, Oregon, Queen Mary and Royal George," Mr. Martell said. "The illustrations are gleaned from sources like the original brochure for Lusitania and photos of classic maritime architecture like the Palladian lounge from Aquitania, all melded with contemporary images from the QE2."
Larry Pimental, the chief executive of Cunard and Seabourn, views this as the perfect time for ads in this style. "While most of the cruise industry is trying to differentiate itself from the formality of classic cruising," he said, "we feel there is a niche for us where people still desire the graciousness and elegance that has always been our tradition."
In addition to the QE2, Cunard's fleet includes the 700-passenger Caronia, which is expected back in service in November after being refurbished, and a new ship that is being billed as the world's biggest ocean liner, planned for introduction in about three years. The Caronia, formerly the Vistafjord, is a single-stack liner and the third Cunard ship to bear the Caronia name.
The overall cruise market reached a record 5.4 million passengers last year and is expected to continue growing as long as the economy remains healthy. The luxury cruise segment, generally thought to be about 15 percent of the market, is also expected to grow, although competition from luxury resorts will be more intense than ever. To counter that threat, Cunard is lowering its rates an average of 20 percent next year, while hoping that its reputation, tradition and new ad campaign will fill more berths as it sails into the new millennium.

HEADLINE: Berkshire Hathaway Bond Holdings Rise

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Berkshire Hathaway Inc. increased its bondholdings in the second quarter, as its chairman, Warren E. Buffett, moved to invest almost $10 billion from a cash hoard that had soared since early last year, according to a regulatory filing.
Berkshire, the Omaha holding company controlled by Mr. Buffett, disclosed that its cash on hand dropped to $4.2 billion on June 30, from $14.2 billion three months earlier. Berkshire said its investments in fixed-income securities rose by about $9.3 billion, to a total of about $30.4 billion, in the same period. 
 Berkshire's quarterly report to the Securities and Exchange Commission did not say what kinds of fixed-income investments were purchased, leaving questions about whether the company bought short-term debt to squeeze extra interest income from its excess cash or whether Mr. Buffett was buying bonds in a bid to repeat a successful 1997 bet on the future direction of interest rates.
Berkshire's filing to the S.E.C. said investments in securities with fixed maturities soared to $30.4 billion as of June 30, from $21.1 billion on March 31. In the same period, the total value of Berkshire's stock portfolio dropped to less than $39 billion from about $39.7 billion three months earlier.

HEADLINE: Group Seeking 2d Ave. Subway Takes Issue With M.T.A.

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Sending an early salvo in what promises to be an impassioned debate over the proposed Second Avenue subway, a small cadre of elective officials and transportation advocates yesterday denounced a decision by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to consider an abbreviated version of the project.
The group, including Mark Green, the New York City Public Advocate, and Eliot L. Engel, the Bronx Congressman, called a news conference to criticize what it called a short-sighted approach to the Second Avenue project, one of several large subway construction proposals under review. 
 "The M.T.A. has proposed mere tokens," said Mr. Green, referring to an environmental impact statement released on Monday in which the agency said its most ambitious option for the Second Avenue project would be to build a new subway line under the avenue from 125th Street to 63d Street, combined with a street-level trolley that would extend south to lower Manhattan.
That option, costing an estimated $3.6 billion, falls far short of what many people on the East Side of Manhattan and in the Bronx had been hoping the M.T.A. would promote -- a new subway running from Co-op City in the Bronx to lower Manhattan.
"We expect the M.T.A. to offer bold solutions to big problems," the group said in a letter to E. Virgil Conway, the chairman of the M.T.A. and a close adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki. Without building what it called a "full-length line," the group said, the M.T.A. would undermine the city economy "because we are plagued by an inadequate transportation system."
The group's protest was orchestrated before a phalanx of television cameras in front of the M.T.A.'s Madison Avenue headquarters, and came against a backdrop of widespread calls by community groups, Congresswoman Carolyn B. Maloney, the Manhattan Borough President, C. Virginia Fields, and others to include, or at least consider, the ambitious vision of a "Bronx to Battery" subway line as part of a five-year capital spending program. The M.T.A. must submit that plan to the State Legislature before the end of the year.
But the M.T.A., whose senior executives have repeatedly warned of the huge expense and engineering hurdles confronting such a project, surprised few when its environmental analysis, prepared for Federal regulators, outlined smaller options.
Besides building the new line from 125th Street to 63d Street, the options included building nothing at all, but speeding up the trains on the Lexington Avenue line in Manhattan. Other alternatives included new bus priority lanes on the Upper East Side and new bus routes on the Lower East Side to ease subway congestion.
The M.T.A.'s decisions are complicated by several other large projects that are being proposed as part of its five-year spending plan. These include construction of a new Manhattan tunnel that would connect the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal, a project backed vigorously by Governor Pataki.
Advocates of the Second Avenue subway contend that the proposed Grand Central connection will only heighten the need for new subway service on the East Side of Manhattan, because thousands of Long Island Rail Road commuters could be expected to use the already overburdened Lexington Avenue subway line.
The M.T.A., in recent years controlled largely by the Governor, will face its most difficult puzzle in choosing which projects it can pay for. Despite the strong economy, which has funneled more tax revenue than expected into the M.T.A.'s budget, a report on Tuesday by New York City's Independent Budget Office cast doubt on whether the agency could afford any of the current proposals without raising fares or obtaining new government subsidies.
Despite such financial questions, though, the group criticizing the M.T.A. yesterday said the agency was simply giving up on a much needed subway project without fully exploring its options, or seeking new sources of financial support.
"We have the benefit of a strong economy, and we are living in the financial capital of the world, so it's about time we started coming up with some fresh ideas about financing," said A. Gifford Miller, a New York City Councilman who represents the Upper East Side and who joined yesterday's protest.
Among the financial options that might be explored, he said, are reinstating a state tax on people who commute into Manhattan, with the proceeds dedicated for subway construction. In what was widely regarded as a power play to benefit suburban political candidates, a long-standing state commuter tax was thrown out by lawmakers in Albany and Governor Pataki in June.

HEADLINE: Water Costs Enough

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Robert N. Stavins's proposal to encourage people to conserve water by charging them more for usage sounds plausible (Op-Ed, Aug. 14). 
 However, in New York City water rates are already rising because of the increasing costs of watershed protection, filtration and infrastructure needs. Since 1986, water rates in the city have risen more than 200 percent.
Moreover, because of the city's water-metering policy, which measures water use in an entire building rather than in individual apartments, individuals have little incentive to save money by conserving water.
And, as a report by Anthony J. Blackburn, a former Harvard economist, shows, metering is hyper-regressive. Those least able to pay spend eight times more of their income on water than do the most affluent.
 
DAVID FERGUSON
New York, Aug. 17, 1999

HEADLINE: Sale of PEC Shares To Parent Is Urged

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The PEC Israel Economic Corporation, which has holdings from telecommunications satellites to textiles, recommended yesterday that its stockholders sell their shares to the parent company, the IDB Development Corporation, at a sweetened price of $36.50 a share.
Minority investors had objected to the previous offer of $30 a share, saying it was too low. The new price is 22 percent higher than that figure and represents a 24 percent premium over yesterday's closing price of $29.50, which was up 25 cents from Tuesday. PEC Israel announced its recommendation after the close of regular trading in New York. 
 IDB, one of Israel's biggest investment companies, already owns about 81 percent of the stock of PEC Israel, which is based in New York. It would merge the company with its other investment subsidiary, the Discount Investment Corporation, to unify their portfolios and make operations more efficient.
Discount Investment, which has interests in finance, communications, software and electronics, hopes to complete the purchase by year-end. Once that happens, assuming it does, PEC Israel shares are to be delisted from the New York Stock Exchange.
